HEADLINE: For Flint, Mich., Takeover Adds to the List of Woes 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich., July 9 

 BODY:
Even in a city used to hard knocks, this has been a bruising year.
 In March, Mayor Woodrow Stanley was recalled by voters frustrated with the city's deteriorating finances, and racial tensions simmered as the Rev. Al Sharpton came to rally support for the mayor, who is black. 
 In May, unemployment rose to 8.3 percent, far higher than even beleaguered Detroit to the southeast. 
Since then, Flint's municipal debt has climbed to nearly $40 million, alarming state officials, who began a review of the city's finances in the spring. Gov. John Engler, a Republican, said the city had no credible plan to turn itself around. Darnell Earley, the city administrator who became acting mayor when Mr. Stanley was recalled, went so far as cutting public ambulance service to try to bring the city's finances under control.
The denouement came on Monday when the state took control of the city's government, stripping elected officials of much of their power. Flint, a city of 125,000, is the largest municipality that has ever been run by the state. 
"I can't say I'm looking forward to it," said Edward Kurtz, a college president who has been appointed the city's financial manager, adding that his chief concern was the debt burden.
"If you have any money," Mr. Kurtz said with a laugh, "we'll take it."
Mr. Kurtz, 59, built the Flint-based Baker career college system from 200 students to 23,000 over more than three decades, creating the state's largest private college. A lifelong resident of the Flint area, he said he took his new job out of civic duty and would not accept pay.
As Mr. Kurtz gets to work, the City Council is challenging the state's action in court. Scott Kincaid, the Council president, said he did not believe a financial emergency existed.
"We're hoping that the court looks at the true financial condition of the City of Flint and determines that the governor appointed a financial manager not based on the city finances but based on some other reasons," Mr. Kincaid said. "We assume they're political."
But the acting mayor, Mr. Earley, a career administrator who is not running in the August mayoral election, said it was time to stop battling the state and to fix the city. 
"We should work towards eliminating this problem and getting beyond it," he said, adding that he hoped to work with Mr. Kurtz.
The state's action was set in motion by the Michigan Senate, which requested a financial review of Flint in the spring. When the city turned over its financial statements to the state, it was revealed that Flint's debt had doubled from June 2000 to June 2001.
The origin of the financial problems can be summed up in two words: General Motors. In the 1970's, G.M. employed 80,000 people in 15 factories here. Now there are fewer than 20,000 workers in three plants.
Little appears to have improved since the 1989 film "Roger and Me," which depicted Flint as a city ravaged by lost G.M. jobs. 
Though downtown is lively enough, the city's problems can be seen just beyond, where decaying factories create an ominous industrial ghost town in some areas. Abandoned apartment buildings, houses and businesses, along with the occasional prostitute, line the north end of Saginaw Street, a main thoroughfare.
"Everybody was like, what are we going to do now?" said Billye Williams, 38, describing the feeling when G.M. started closing plants in the 1980's. 
Mr. Williams had just gotten off a bus after a morning job search and stood next to an abandoned tooling shop. He said his family moved from Kansas in the 1970's, drawn by auto work. When the plants began closing, he said, "I was like, Mom, we should have just stayed in Topeka."
The jobs disappeared as the Big Three automakers faced withering pressure from foreign competitors. That opened plants in the South, where labor is cheap and local law discourages unions. The trend has led G.M. and the Ford Motor Company to move some work overseas. 
But the city bears much blame for its condition because it did not adjust to its rapidly declining tax base and curb spending, city officials and residents said.
The huge job loss "was a terrible warning sign to the leaders of the community," said Joe Conroy, 67, a retired Democratic state senator who was eating lunch at a food court. "More cuts had to be made." 
The job losses "had a devastating effect on our tax base," Mr. Earley said. "The city should have made tough decisions sooner."
Lawrence A. Roehrig, secretary-treasurer of the Flint chapter of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said the state's takeover would stop "a case of absolute denial by the City Council that they've had anything to do with the problems of the city."
But Mr. Kincaid, the City Council president, said the union's resistance to job cuts and privatizing garbage collection hindered efforts to put the city's finances in order. 
"We are trying to protect as many of jobs we can in the city," he said, "but in the waste collection department they've been over their budget by over a million dollars every year for the past several years." 
The end result, said the state treasurer, Doug Roberts, was that the city had never reckoned with its deteriorating tax base.
"Why do you have to have the state come in and tell you that you have a problem?" Mr. Roberts said. "If we don't act now, when do we act?"

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Raising School Standards And Cutting Budget: Huh?

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com

 BODY:
CONGRESS and the president have demanded that states raise academic standards, and every state has now complied. Yet state leaders have also recognized that disadvantaged students need extra help to achieve these higher standards.
 So several states, with some federal aid, have added summer schools, preschools and early childhood services. They have reduced class sizes and raised salaries to attract better teachers. From 1997 to 2002, school spending rose by 12 percent nationwide, after considering inflation and enrollment growth. Much of the increase was intended to help low-achieving students. 
 But now almost every state has a budget crisis. Programs that were added in recent years are either being cut or likely to be cut soon.
As reductions occur, most state and federal officials have ducked an obvious challenge: if programs like summer school and preschool and class size reduction were needed to reach higher standards, does cutting these programs call the standards into question?
A few policy makers have expressed concern. Thomas D. Watkins, Michigan's superintendent of schools, is one. His state has cut $100 million from its summer school and early childhood budgets, including a math and literacy program for 4-year-olds from low-income families. Mr. Watkins insisted that Michigan would not lower academic standards in response. "We don't lower standards in this state," he said.
But he acknowledged that the cuts would probably "raise the odds of not meeting the standards," with more failures and dropouts in the future.
In California, several districts had promised salary increases to attract more qualified teachers to urban areas. But falling revenues have forced these districts to break the promises or cut other programs. The Legislature's budget proposes eliminating monetary rewards for improved schools, dealing a blow to California's accountability system. In Los Angeles, class sizes are growing and the school board has voted to consider cuts in salaries and benefits as well.
Teri Burns, California's deputy superintendent of public instruction, said that next year the budget crisis would be even worse, making even larger classes likely. Like Mr. Watkins of Michigan, Ms. Burns insisted, "We would not consider lowering our standards." But she admitted: "We may have to reconsider how fast we can get there. If we can't provide the resources for schools to meet our expectations, we can't penalize schools for not reaching them."
Kentucky was a leader of the drive for higher standards, but its revenues have also declined. Class sizes are growing, art and music classes are being dropped, teachers' aides are being eliminated. But schools are still expected to meet Kentucky's learning standards. Now, 142 school systems (80 percent of the state's districts) have banded together to determine how much it would cost to meet the standards. The districts' next step could be a lawsuit against the state for its failure to finance the higher standards it requires.
National leaders, too, have not squarely faced the contradiction of wanting higher standards while states cut the dollars needed to meet them. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, took the lead in getting President Bush's education bill passed last winter. Senator Kennedy believed he had a commitment from the president to support more aid to education in return for higher standards, more testing and more accountability.
But the administration endorsed less new money than the senator expected. Last month the Senate defeated a bill, sponsored by Mr. Kennedy, to provide $150 million in emergency spending for summer school programs. The money was partly intended to offset budget cuts that states are making.
Mr. Kennedy has not yet said that sanctions for failure to raise achievement should be postponed until adequate resources are provided. But this would be logical, because proponents of the new education law often cited summer school as a way that higher standards could be met.
In New York, an appellate court ruled last month that the state Constitution only required Albany to finance an education that gets children to eighth-grade achievement levels. But the court did not say whether, the Constitution aside, it is reasonable for the state to adopt tough new Regents standards while failing to pay for smaller classes, better teachers, summer school and early childhood services. Most educators believe that these programs are needed to achieve higher standards in urban districts where low-income students are concentrated.
Higher standards and adequate finances cannot be separated. State budget crises are testing this relationship and, sooner or later, something will have to give. Without more money or lower standards, student failures are bound to increase.

HEADLINE: Robertson Stephens Will Dismiss Half Its Staff to Prepare for Sale 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 

 BODY:
Robertson Stephens, the investment-banking arm of the FleetBoston Financial Corporation, said today that it planned to lay off half of its staff to reduce costs and allow a sale to employees. 
 A Robertson spokeswoman, Courtney Weber, said the firm, which lost more than $80 million in the last five quarters, would lay off 425 of its 950 employees over the next few months. 
The layoffs will affect all departments of the firm, based in San Francisco. 
 FleetBoston said last week that it expected to lose more than $282 million on the sale. Robertson Stephens management and FleetBoston have been in talks on the sale for weeks. An announcement may come as early as next week, Ms. Weber said. 
The terms being discussed call for management and employees to assume more than $200 million in liabilities and pay no cash for the firm, The Daily Deal reported. FleetBoston announced in April that it was seeking a buyer for Robertson Stephens, which caters to technology companies, after demand for arranging stock sales and mergers for technology companies dried up in the recession. 
Mike McCaffery, who ran Robertson Stephens for seven years before leaving to manage the endowment at Stanford University, will return as a nonexecutive chairman if the management buyout is completed, Mr. Weber said. 
BankBoston purchased Robertson Stephens for $800 million in cash and stock options in 1998 as investments in technology companies soared. BankBoston was acquired by Fleet Financial Group a year later to form FleetBoston.

HEADLINE: 2 Top Officers Quit Elan, Troubled Irish Drug Maker 

BYLINE:  By BRIAN LAVERY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, July 9 

 BODY:
The two top executives of the Elan Corporation, the Irish drug maker, resigned today after six tumultuous months of questions about its accounting practices and a collapse of the company's stock price.
 Donal Geaney, 51, gave up the posts of chairman and chief executive, and Thomas Lynch, 45, resigned as vice chairman. The board named a member, Garo Armen, to take over as chairman, but no new chief executive was named. 
 The absence of Mr. Geaney, one of Ireland's best-known executives, from an hourlong conference call today attracted little comment, because the analysts and investors on the call were much more concerned about Elan's ability to stay solvent. Dr. Armen told them Elan would raise $1 billion over the next nine months by selling nonessential assets and businesses. 
In Dublin, shares of Elan, which have fallen 96 percent this year, closed unchanged at 2.35 euros; its American depository receipts fell 19 percent, to $1.80. As recently as Jan. 17 they were worth $44.60, and at their peak of $65 last June they gave Elan by far the largest market capitalization in Ireland, nearly as great as all other Irish stocks combined.
Elan now has $1.38 billion in cash, just about enough to cover its major bond payments and other commitments over the next 18 months, including a $959 million payment in December 2003. Another $200 million will be needed by the end of the year to complete product acquisitions that have already been initiated. Both Moody's and Standard & Poor's have downgraded Elan's debt to junk status.
"The foremost concern in people's minds, we believe, is a liquidity risk," Dr. Armen said in a telephone interview after the conference call. "The best way for us to remove that concern is to shore up our balance sheet."
Dr. Armen made an impression on analysts by fielding almost every question in the hourlong conference call himself, only rarely deferring to the company's chief financial officer, Shane Cooke. But they were disappointed that Dr. Armen did not offer revised earnings forecasts or explain just how he planned to raise the $1 billion.
"There was no sort of sense of strategy," said Eugene Kiernan, head of asset allocation at Irish Life Investment Managers. "It was more battening down the hatches for cash in the short term. They're going to be a forced seller in a weak market."
Dr. Armen said Elan's credibility in the marketplace would grow in line with its cash reserves, and that the company would publish new forecasts for 2002 within the next few weeks. "At $2 a share, earnings estimates are meaningless," he said.
In February, Elan forecast total revenue for 2002 of just over $2 billion, of which $1.6 billion came from product revenue. Net earnings were forecast to be $1.55 to $1.65 a share, or $570 million and $610 million over all, down from $696.5 million in 2001.
"People were questioning those figures that same afternoon," Mr. Kiernan said.
More recently, investors and analysts have called into question practices that even the company acknowledged were "aggressive accounting." To spread the risks of product development, Elan created 55 different joint ventures and partnerships, and did little to make the consequences clear to investors. Dr. Armen acknowledged today that Elan would have to write down the value of those ventures by $600 million in the second quarter.
Only recently did Elan reveal that it had been selling the rights to future royalties on some of its top products since 2000. It has the right to buy them back now for $550 million, but the terms of the sale call for the price to increase 25 percent a year. And analysts have asked whether the companies that bought the royalties are truly independent of Elan, raising echoes of the Enron debacle.
The company's practice of consolidating the ventures' results in its income statement but leaving them off its balance sheet prompted the Securities and Exchange Commission to begin an investigation into its accounting in February. 
The company's product line has also run into trouble. It had to halt tests of an eagerly awaited drug for Alzheimer's disease in January after some patients developed brain inflammation. Over the last few weeks, the Food and Drug Administration approved three generic competitors for its best-selling pain management drug, Zanaflex.
Elan has not yet determined how the new competition will erode the product's sales and profits, saying only that it "expects a significant decline." In 2001, Zanaflex accounted for $161.7 million in revenues, or 9 percent of Elan's total.
The company is likely to focus its attention on neurology, pain management and autoimmune diseases. Dr. Armen said that research and development in those areas was "untouchable." Its diagnostics, hospital products and drug-delivery technology businesses are more expendable, Ian Hunter, senior equity analyst at Goodbody Stockbrokers in Dublin, said.
A five-person executive committee headed by Dr. Armen will oversee Elan while a new chief executive is sought, the company said. Mr. Geaney and Mr. Lynch remain on the payroll and will advise the committee on how to restructure the company. 
"There was no fight; there was no ugliness," Dr. Armen said of Mr. Geaney's and Mr. Lynch's resignations. "Because of internal and external factors, they were no longer able to operate effectively."
For most of the last decade, Elan was held up as the epitome of the Celtic Tiger economic boom in Ireland, and seemed to have the staying power that had eluded most Irish technology companies. Founded in 1969 as a specialist in drug delivery systems, the company was the first purely Irish company to list its shares in the United States, in 1984.
Mr. Geaney, a former accountant at KPMG, became chief executive in 1995 and chairman in 1997. Under his leadership, the company became a ravenous acquirer, absorbing 15 companies in six years. Last year, reported revenues reached $1.86 billion, though analysts said that because of the partnerships and joint ventures it was not easy to tell quite what that number meant.
"We want to simplify our balance sheet, and we want to be transparent, so that you don't have to go through 55 footnotes in order to be able to interpret what our cash level is, what our warnings are and what our future looks like," Dr. Armen said.
Analysts have said Elan's pipeline of new drugs and its beaten-down stock might make it a takeover candidate, though likely buyers might be scared off by the questions about its accounting. Dr. Armen said the board would entertain any offer of greater value than management thought it could deliver.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: QUEENS; 
Complex Near J.F.K. to Get Building 3

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
With a November completion planned for the first of its two buildings, construction -- accompanied by the intermittent roar of jets taking off from Kennedy International Airport just across Rockaway Boulevard -- is set to begin next week on the third of what will be a four-building cargo and office complex. 
 The new building, with 178,000 square feet, will be the largest in the $100 million 530,000-square-foot project, the first large-scale development in decades within a three-mile radius of the airport. 
 As was the case with the first two buildings, each of them with about 100,000 square feet of space, construction is to begin on the third structure without a tenant in place, according to International Airport Centers of Highland Park, Ill., the developer. 
The project is on 25 formerly city-owned acres that were once part of a municipal landfill. Financing came from the developer's own equity and private sources, and New York City provided property-tax and other incentives that are expected to have a value of $37 million over 25 years. 
Building without a tenant may seem like a big gamble at a time when the economy is less than robust and airports are still reeling from the events of Sept. 11. But Jacob Citrin, managing director at the development company, said that while leasing at the project had been affected by those factors, the long-term trends were in his company's favor. Construction began last August and the first tenant in the initial two buildings signed on in January. 
"With the globalization of businesses and improvements at J.F.K.," Mr. Citrin said, "there will be a continued need for such space." And, he added, while some companies that were prospective tenants no longer exist or are considering half the amount of space they initially contemplated, others are willing to take twice as much. 
Some potential tenants also are repeat customers for his company, which started in 1995 with the idea of building projects near leading international airports and serving tenants that want multiple locations. Beyond the New York project, the company has six others, totaling 4.5 million square feet. The largest are in Los Angeles, with a million square feet of space, and in Detroit, with 900,000. 
In the last year the vacancy rate in the 4.5-million-square-foot Kennedy airport market rose to 6.5 percent from 4 percent, according to Reid Berch, a senior director at the Long Island office of Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services firm. Much of the available space is in 20- to 30-year-old buildings, said Mr. Berch, who is the leasing agent for International Airport Centers.
This project "capitalizes on the unmet need for modern buildings near the airport," he added, noting that the first two buildings are collectively 70 percent leased to three tenants. Each is an international logistics company and rents space in at least one of the developer's other projects 
The buildings have ceilings 24 feet high, compared with 12 to 20 feet in older area buildings. They also have 200-foot-long truck courts that enable a 72-foot-long trailer to turn around with ease.
In the past, Mr. Berch said, tenants have gone to other places, including Nassau and Suffolk Counties in Long Island, to find comparable space. The average rent for warehouse and office space in the area is $12 to $17 a square foot a year, depending on age and location, he said, noting that rents at the new Queens development are at the higher end of that scale.
Getting the project to this point has taken six years. In 1998 the New York City Economic Development Corporation selected International Airport Centers to develop the site over others that had answered a request for proposals two years earlier. The company spent the next four years securing approvals and having the site rezoned.
The 25 acres were once part of Idlewild Park, a 200-acre area zoned for industrial use that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey transferred to the city in the 1950's. Ninety of those acres, including the International Airport Centers site, were formerly a landfill that was closed in the 1960's. 
Two decades later the city and Community Board 13, which guides growth in the area, designated the 25 acres for its current use. To meet the community's desire for open space, 110 acres of the site were rezoned and turned into parkland. 
Mr. Citrin said the buildings had been designed with concrete block and metal panel facades and the grounds would be heavily landscaped, giving the complex the look of a suburban business park. And the structures will also have special features like sound resistant windows to reduce plane noise.

HEADLINE: Wyeth Stock Falls 24% After Report 

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
Shares of Wyeth, the drug company that makes the top-selling drugs for hormone replacement therapies, tumbled more than 24 percent yesterday after news that a large study had found that women taking one of the company's drugs had a higher risk of breast cancer.
 The hormone replacements are Wyeth's biggest-selling products. Sales of Prempro, the subject of the federal study, and the related products, Premarin and Premphase, generated more than $2 billion in sales last year, or nearly 15 percent of Wyeth's revenue. 
 Some Wall Street analysts said they thought Prempro sales would fall sharply as many women stopped taking the drug. But they said investors might have overreacted by pushing the stock price down so low. Shares of Wyeth dropped $11.94, to $37.30.
Viren Mehta of Mehta Partners, a health care investment firm in New York, estimated that the three drugs now accounted for about 20 percent of Wyeth's market value and said he thought most of the sales of Prempro, which is a combination of estrogen and progestin, could be lost. Prempro had sales of about $732 million last year, according to IMS Health, a health care information company.
But Mr. Mehta noted that the researchers had decided to continue the long-term federal study of Premarin, which contains only estrogen. Premarin sales were $1.3 billion last year.
"The market is reacting as if the products are being pulled from the market," said Rita M. Freedman, a health care analyst at PNC Advisors in Philadelphia. "This is not good news, but it is not a disaster."
Wyeth executives tried to calm investors yesterday, saying the hormone therapies still played a crucial role in treating the symptoms of menopause, which is the main reason women begin taking them.
The directors of the federal study, the Women's Health Initiative, sent letters to the 16,000 participants, telling them to stop taking Prempro. The researchers halted the study after finding a higher risk of breast cancer in women who were taking the drugs compared with those who were taking a dummy pill. 
Dr. Victoria Kusiak, vice president for global medical affairs at Wyeth, said that the risk of breast cancer found in the federal study was actually lower than the risk found in other studies and already stated in the drug's label.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
S.& P. 500 Is Dropping Seven Foreign Companies
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is going all-American, and in the process it is producing a little bit of buying power for the struggling market. The S.& P. will drop the seven companies in the index not based in the United States, a move that involved replacing two companies that have been in the index for more than six decades.
 The companies being added are not as large as the ones being removed, and in a world where indexing is a huge investment strategy, that could provide significant buying power for stocks remaining in the index. Floyd Norris: Market Place. Page C11. 

Jackson's Feud With Sony
The pop singer Michael Jackson, left, has depicted Thomas D. Mottola, chief executive of the Sony Music Group, as the devil, waving photographs of the executive scrawled with horns and a pitchfork. He contends that the music business is racist. But it is widely believed in the industry that his new passion for struggling black artists is an attempt to extract concessions from Sony. C2.

United Machinists Reject Pay Cuts
The machinists union at United has rejected a proposal for a 10 percent wage cut, a move that could jeopardize an application the carrier has filed for a federal loan guarantee. C10.

France Starts a Vivendi Inquiry
French regulators have opened an investigation into financial information released by Vivendi Universal, potentially delivering a setback to the company as it scrambles to reach a rescue package with its banks. C11.

Moody's has downgraded the credit rating of Alcatel, the telecommunications equipment maker, citing a sour outlook in the industry. World Business, Section W.

Chief Executive Resigns at Elan
Donal Geaney, the chief executive of the Irish drug maker Elan, has resigned over accounting questions. World Business, Section W.

Argentina Abandons Rescue Plan
Argentina's government has had to abandon its latest plan to persuade savers to exchange their savings for government bonds, dealing a blow to its efforts to end a seven-month-old freeze on bank withdrawals that has paralyzed the economy. World Business, Section W.

Markets Have Another Down Day
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 178.81 points, at 9,096.09. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 24.15 points, to 952.83, and the Nasdaq composite index lost 24.49 points, to 1,381.12. C11.

Wyeth Shares Fall on News of Study
Shares of Wyeth, the drug company that makes hormone replacement therapies, tumbled more than 24 percent after news that a study had found that women taking one of the drugs had a higher risk of breast cancer. Sales of Prempro, the subject of the study, and related products generated more than $2 billion in sales last year. A16.

The announcement that a hormone replacement regimen taken by six million American women did more harm than good was met with puzzlement and disbelief. A1.

New Drink With a Familiar Name
Jack Daniel's Original Hard Cola, which is actually a beer, goes on sale next week, joining a crowded field of so-called malternatives that incorporate the established brand names of distilled spirits. Advertising. C10.

Prominent Lawyer Leaves Firm
Harvey R. Miller, a prominent bankruptcy lawyer, is leaving Weil, Gotshal & Manges and is joining Greenhill & Company, an investment banking and advisory firm. C8.

Lessons in Disaster Planning
Since Sept. 11, landlords of commercial buildings have taken another look at the way their coordinate security and evacuation plans with other landlords and with the fire and police departments. Commercial Real Estate. C8.

HEADLINE: President of the Cleveland Fed to Retire 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9 

 BODY:
The president of the Cleveland Federal Reserve, Jerry Jordan, known for his vocal antipathy to inflation, will retire on Jan. 31, the regional Fed bank said today. 
 The deputy chairman of the Cleveland Fed, Robert Mahoney, will lead a committee to find Mr. Jordan's successor. 
 Mr. Jordan, 60, who took the helm of the Cleveland Fed in March 1992, dissented five times in 1998 when he was on the policy-making Federal Open Market Committee because he wanted to keep monetary policy tighter than other members. 
Mr. Jordan said he was looking forward to spending more time with his family.

HEADLINE: The Corporate Scandals; 
Cleaning Up

 BODY:
Reacting belatedly to the continual reports of malfeasance undermining investor confidence and threatening the economic recovery, President Bush came to Wall Street yesterday to deliver his "clean up your act or else" message to corporate America. He sounded at times like a sheriff, warning of jail time for crooks, and at other times like a preacher admonishing business executives to look deep into their souls before issuing their next quarterly reports. At its core, however, the president's address was disappointingly devoid of tough proposals to remedy underlying problems in accounting, corporate governance and the safety net of federal laws and regulations that is supposed to prevent abuses.
 It was one of those speeches that promise more than they can deliver, which is probably why expectant markets found no reason to rally after Mr. Bush left the lectern. For instance, his call to strengthen enforcement resources at the Securities and Exchange Commission by $100 million sounded good at first blush, but it falls far short of what is needed to revive a critical agency -- one that his administration was merrily weakening until the business scandals hit the headlines. 
 Mr. Bush rightly condemned the glaring conflicts of interest at Wall Street firms whose ostensibly independent research analysts have touted stocks solely because they were investment-banking clients. But it was New York State's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, not the Bush administration, who cracked down on these conflicts.
Mr. Bush missed an ideal opportunity yesterday to vault ahead of the pack and seize command of the reform campaign. He embraced sensible proposals that have already been introduced by others, such as the New York Stock Exchange, and that have already gained traction in response to the accounting scandals at Enron, WorldCom and elsewhere. Mr. Bush's endorsement of the stock exchange's new guidelines calling for independent directors and shareholder approval of stock-option plans allowed him to appear bold while actually remaining on the sidelines in the fight to restore the integrity of financial markets and public trust in them.
The president was right in urging companies to ban outrageous loans to executives -- an easy call. But he should also have pushed for re-examining the more complicated issue of how corporations handle executive stock-option grants and finding ways to reflect them realistically as an expense.
The biggest disappointment was Mr. Bush's failure to insist on a forceful reform of the accounting industry. Auditors are the primary guardians of business integrity, and in the recent boom they lost sight of their mandate to serve the public, not company officers. The House passed a weak reform bill in the spring. But the president at best appeared to be equating it with the more meaningful proposal the Senate is currently considering. The Senate bill, proposed by Paul Sarbanes, would establish an independent oversight board for the industry, and place limits on the consulting work auditors can perform for companies. Mr. Bush would have best served the interests of the tens of millions of Americans who want to continue entrusting their retirement savings to the stock market if he had transcended partisanship on this one issue and directed his party's leadership in the House to adopt the Senate's version of accounting reform. 
Establishing a Justice Department task force on corporate fraud is a fine idea, as is Mr. Bush's effort to make corporate insiders personally liable for their misrepresentations, and to make them return ill-gotten gains. Americans no doubt appreciated the president's tough talk about punishing executives who commit crimes. But what they really wanted to hear from Mr. Bush was how he intended to prevent corporate fraud from occurring in the first place. He had little to offer on that score.

HEADLINE: U.S. Official Is Jeered at AIDS Conference 

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN 

DATELINE: BARCELONA, Spain, July 9 

 BODY:
Jeering protesters today drowned out Tommy G. Thompson, the United States secretary of health and human services, as he addressed the 14th International AIDS Conference here about the Bush administration's global prevention program.
 It was a revival of militancy over issues relating to AIDS seldom seen in the past decade. 
 As Mr. Thompson, the chief of the American delegation here, began his speech this afternoon, about three dozen demonstrators from the audience -- mainly Americans from Act Up, a protest group -- marched onto the stage, blowing whistles and shouting through bullhorns, "Shame! Shame!" Mr. Thompson stopped talking until they retreated. 
Surrounded by security agents, he resumed speaking. But the protesters began jeering again, calling on the United States to support protected sex and needle-exchange programs, to spend more for AIDS drugs and to give billions more each year to a global fund to fight AIDS.
The shouting kept the audience of 17,000 from hearing Mr. Thompson. His prepared text said the United States had doubled financing, to $500 million over the next 18 months, for programs "to prevent the transmission of H.I.V. from mothers to infants and to improve the health care delivery systems in 12 African nations and the Caribbean."
"No administration in any nation has ever made fighting H.I.V.-AIDS as high a priority as the United States under this administration," Mr. Thompson said.
It was a day of protests seldom seen since the early years of the AIDS epidemic, when advocates for AIDS patients chained themselves to doors of drug companies, squirted red liquid at scientists and heckled political leaders. A similar demonstration in 1990 prevented participants at the International AIDS Conference in San Francisco from hearing Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, who was secretary of health and human services in the last Bush administration. Dr. Sullivan was near the front of the room for Mr. Thompson's speech.
At this conference, international AIDS leaders like Dr. Peter Piot, an assistant director general of the United Nations and chief of its AIDS program, have been urging the public to demand greater accountability from their governments in battling the epidemic. On Sunday, Dr. Ronald O. Valdiserri, a senior AIDS official at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, called on Americans "to revive the passion with which the U.S. once faced the H.I.V. epidemic."
But today Dr. Piot was among the leaders who assailed the protesters for not allowing the audience to hear Mr. Thompson.
Dr. Piot, who was a political activist in his youth, said in an interview that he supported the concept of protests, "but only after someone has had a chance to speak, and there's no way one can judge what Mr. Thompson wanted to say."
A spokesman for the protesters, Gregg Gonsalves of the Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York, a social service group, said they represented 12 groups in the United States.
The protesting focused on Mr. Thompson's statement here on Sunday that the Bush administration was committed to reducing the incidence of H.I.V. among American youth by 50 percent by 2010; to redressing racial and ethnic disparities fueling the epidemic in the United States, and to supporting domestic and international programs to reverse the epidemic.
Protesters called those promises hollow, saying in a news release that the administration was "attacking science-based prevention programs that talk frankly about sex and supporting abstinence-only prevention programs."
Mr. Thompson criticized the protesters as "closed-minded." In a telephone interview from his car as he left the conference center, he said he was "sorry that the militants had to rush the stage instead of listening, but that is their prerogative."
Later, Mr. Thompson talked with 10 protesters for about half an hour in a meeting that had been arranged before their demonstrations, said his spokesman, Tony Jewell.
At a news conference shortly after the demonstrations, a leading American economist, Dr. Jeffrey Sachs of Columbia University, called the protests "a reflection of the utter confusion" within the administration about AIDS-related programs.
He said he had gone to the White House several times recently to discuss AIDS with senior staff members, though not with the president. "When I asked for numbers on the costs," he said in an interview later, "I found tremendous confusion, and it results from an absence of a plan."
Dr. Piot, Dr. Sachs and other experts said they expected to present an AIDS plan by October, in time for a board meeting of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Malaria and Tuberculosis, an organization set up at the urging of Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general. 
The White House has budgeted $988 million for worldwide anti-AIDS efforts this year, including $200 million for the global fund. But with Mr. Annan saying the fund needs $10 billion a year, advocates, including American lawmakers, say the United States' fair share is much greater.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Protesters from the group Act Up yesterday at the AIDS conference, with signs referring to the estimated annual cost of a global AIDS fund. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Slouching Towards Populism 

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD; Thomas L. Friedman is on vacation.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
It must be frustrating for the George Bushes.
 They go through all the motions of proclaiming that they're self-made Texas bidnessmen. 
 They become president by acting more red-blooded than blue-blooded.
They whup small, backward countries that brutalize their own people and get dizzying approval ratings. 
And then, after everything they've done, after all the laurels and plaudits, that darn economy gets its knickers in a twist.
And they are hounded by the same old question they have designed their lives to avoid: Can a Bush -- born on third base but thinking he hit a triple -- ever really understand the problems of the guys in the bleachers?
Despite the efforts of W. and Karl Rove to use Poppy's one-term presidency as a reverse playbook, to instead aim for the populist two-term touch of Ronald Reagan, the junior Bush now finds himself combating the same accusations of elitism that cost his father re-election.
By November 1991, with the demise of the blue-collar bard Lee Atwater and the decline of the economy, the rich white guys running the first Bush administration were openly admitting they were in a fog of privilege.
"Bush's idea of solving a domestic problem is to fire the maid and yell at the butler," chortled the Democratic senator Tom Harkin of Iowa.
The Democrats are going to town again on Bush obliviousness. America is repulsed by corporate gluttony and accounting racketeering. And the younger Bush must prove that his connection to the common man goes deeper than a peanut butter and jelly sandwich.
The 180-degree turn from "Kenny Boy" to "Book Kenny" is going to be tricky. 
How can Mr. Bush crack the whip on Big Business when he's a wholly owned subsidiary of it? His dynastic ties to business gave him his career in oil and baseball, provided the record-breaking $100 million that made him president, and spawned his C.E.O. administration. 
How can Mr. Bush lecture companies on setting a moral tone, getting tough on accounting practices and ending "malfee-ance," as he calls it, when there are pesky questions about his own windfall at Harken Energy? (His $848,560 stock cash-in made Hillary, the Cattle Queen of commodities trading, look like a piker for only taking home $100,000.)
The president's speech on Wall Street yesterday was a Karl Rove production, making all the right noises, with the reassuring blue "Corporate Responsibility" backdrop. But TV viewers who looked lower on the screen could see the Dow arrow sliding down steadily, off 178 points for the day.
Mr. Rove pushed W. out to the White House press room on Monday so he would not seem to be evading corporate responsibility for himself while preaching it for others.
But the president was acting petulant. When a reporter asked why he did not attend the N.A.A.C.P. meeting in Houston this week, Mr. Bush impatiently brushed off the question, noting that Colin Powell and Condi Rice work for him. So, once you give the estimable Colin Powell a job, you don't need to reach out to the rest of the black community?
Like his father before him, the president resents being challenged -- on his judgment or on his trustworthiness. He just wants the country to take it on faith that he and Dick Cheney, who got filthy rich at Halliburton, and Army Secretary Thomas White, who got filthy rich at Enron, are "good actors," as he puts it. 
Poppy, at some level, always knew and subtly acknowledged that his Texas up-from-bootstraps story line was a pose. He never gave up the summers in Kennebunkport, the preppy threads, the patrician posture, the upward tilt of his chin.
Junior, with his pseudo-James-Dean-in-"Giant" lectern slouch, believes he's the real thing, coated in Midland dust. He sees himself as self-made and anti-elitist. But given his slacker start, he ended up relying even more on family connections for business and political success than his father did.
He bought a dusty ranch in Crawford to show he's not a New England preppy. But he got the money for the 1,600-acre spread by having the famous name of a New England preppy. 
He talks the populist talk, while walking the elitist walk.

HEADLINE: Senate Approves Nuclear Waste Site in Nevada Mountain 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9 

 BODY:
The Senate gave final Congressional approval today for the establishment of a nuclear waste repository deep inside Nevada's Yucca Mountain, a pivotal moment in the 20-year search for a home for the radioactive byproducts from the nation's nuclear reactors. 
 Opponents of the site, led by Nevada's senators, were dealt a stinging blow when the Senate voted 60 to 39 to consider the issue, a procedural vote that both sides had said would be the critical test. The Senate then approved the repository by voice vote. 
 The Senate action, coming after years of fierce lobbying and a recent blitz of the airwaves by environmentalists and industry, was a victory for President Bush, who endorsed the repository site in February. It cleared the way for the Energy Department to apply to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to license the repository, in the desert 90 miles northwest of Las Vegas. 
The administration's plans call for the repository, 1,000 feet below the peak of Yucca Mountain, to receive high-level radioactive waste shipments of up to 77,000 tons from more than 100 civilian and military nuclear reactors around the country over the next quarter-century, the largest cross-country transfer ever of dangerously radioactive material.
The site is envisioned to open in 2010. But it still faces numerous regulatory and legal hurdles that are likely to delay the opening. Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, a Democrat who is the assistant majority leader, vowed that the battle would continue.
"I don't want to be trite by saying I've just begun to fight," Mr. Reid told reporters, "but I'm still not tired."
Mr. Reid said that he would assist in his state's lawsuit against the designation of the site and noted that he could oppose financing for the repository. "We are going to make sure that all i's are dotted and all t's are crossed, which hasn't been done with the jam job of George W. on this issue," he said.
The vote was a defeat for Mr. Reid and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, who also fiercely opposed the site on safety grounds. The two men worked the phones and at a closed-door party lunch made a last plea to fellow Democrats to stand with them.
But they were unable to keep their colleagues in line. Fifteen Democratic senators joined most Republicans to support action on the waste site; among the Democrats was a possible presidential contender, John Edwards of North Carolina. Only three Republicans -- John Ensign of Nevada, Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island and Ben Nighthorse Campbell of Colorado -- voted to block it from the Senate floor. On Monday, Senators Orrin G. Hatch and Robert F. Bennett, the two Republicans from neighboring Utah who had been holding off on making a decision, declared they would vote for the Nevada site. 
Critics of the plan questioned its safety, asking whether the design would really safeguard water from contamination and protesting that it was unwise to transport waste from sites across the country, particularly when the terrorist threat is high.
"Once people thoughtfully consider the ramifications of moving 77,000 tons of nuclear waste through 39 states, they're going to have a lot of second thoughts about the advisability of doing so," Mr. Daschle said. Supporters of the repository argued that it would be more dangerous to leave waste at temporary sites around the nation. They also called the decision critical for the future of the nuclear power industry, saying the plants were not viable without a permanent disposal site. 
"Nuclear power is a clean, efficient source," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority leader. "It is being supplied in 39 of our 50 states. We need to deal with nuclear waste."
Mr. Lott called antinuclear forces unrealistic, saying: "There are people in America that don't want nuclear power, that don't want hydropower, that don't want oil. How do they propose that we fuel this growing economy in America?"
In defeat, some Democrats tried to use the vote for further accusations that the administration and Republicans were beholden to corporate interests like the energy industry.
"A lot of special interests are behind this," said Senator Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat who protested that the Nevada site risked contaminating her state's drinking water. "Who are we fighting for here?"
Nevada's senators had long acknowledged they faced an uphill fight, particularly because of the issue's regional politics. Lawmakers from states that are heavy users of nuclear power were eager for a permanent storage site far from their own borders. "Nimby," said Mr. Ensign, explaining his difficulty in getting supporters from other Republicans. "Not in my backyard."
The day's Senate vote took place under unusual procedures established in a 1982 act about the site search and subsequent legislation. In highly unusual deference to a state, Congress gave Nevada the power to veto any presidential decision about Yucca Mountain. After President Bush approved the site, Gov. Kenny Guinn, a Republican, exercised that veto in April. Congress had until late July to sustain or override the veto. The House handily overrode the governor earlier in May.
In the Senate, Mr. Daschle resisted bringing the Yucca Mountain site up for debate; usually, the Senate majority leader controls the floor. But under the rules established in 1982, any senator had the right to call for debate on the issue.
Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, the ranking Republican on the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, brought the measure to the floor for a vote, arguing that the nation could no longer afford delay.

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE OVERVIEW; 
Bush, on Wall St., Offers Tough Stance

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
President Bush came to Wall Street yesterday vowing to "end the days of cooking the books, shading the truth and breaking our laws." He advocated legal reforms ranging from longer prison sentences for fraud to a new task force to prosecute corporate malfeasance.
 But critics, including Senate Democrats, said the reforms were not as far-reaching as some of the proposals now gaining steam in Congress. 
 In his first extensive policy speech in months on a subject other than combating terrorism, Mr. Bush tried to quell a growing political storm by asking Congress to provide the Securities and Exchange Commission with $100 million in additional funds to increase enforcement, far less than the increase some in Congress are demanding. He also urged the stock markets to adopt rules assuring that a company's directors are truly independent. Transcript, Page C4. 
"Self-regulation is important, but it's not enough," Mr. Bush said, striking a more aggressive tone than he did in the presidential campaign two years ago, when he regularly urged less government intervention in the economy so that American business would be free to innovate. "In the long run," Mr. Bush told an invited audience of chief executives, investors and city leaders in a hotel ballroom just blocks from the New York Stock Exchange, "there's no capitalism without conscience. There is no wealth without character."
Mr. Bush's speech was striking for the harshness of the criticism he leveled at corporate executives -- a list that clearly includes some of the biggest contributors to his presidential campaign, though he never mentioned a name or a company. But Mr. Bush's 27-minute speech was also notable for the changes he declined to endorse or mention. 
As a result, while chief executives praised the President's speech, saying it would help restore confidence in American business, many professional money managers expressed disappointment that there were not more specific proposals for cleaning up corporate America. Page C1. 
The White House's decision to call for longer prison sentences for anyone convicted of wire fraud or mail fraud appeared to be an effort to defuse a more far-reaching proposal now gaining considerable support in the Senate to create a new category of felony for any "scheme or artifice" knowingly used to defraud shareholders. 
Mr. Bush's aides dodged questions about whether Mr. Bush would support that Senate bill, sponsored by Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat. A senior White House official told reporters that Mr. Bush "shares the goals" of the legislation but was troubled by its specifics. Similarly, Mr. Bush said Monday that he was uncomfortable with another provision the Senate was considering that would set up an independent board to regulate the auditors of public companies. 
Not surprisingly, Democrats leapt on the limited nature of Mr. Bush's proposals to argue that it created only the illusion of reform. The Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, urged Mr. Bush to endorse a series of more drastic changes that the Democrats have now seized on as a crucial issue for the November elections. 
In a measure of how partisan the battle has become, Mr. Bush was not even out of the ballroom yesterday before Eliot L. Spitzer, the attorney general of New York, was providing a critique to a group of reporters on the other side of the room. The speech was "not even sizzle and no steak; there wasn't any sizzle," Mr. Spitzer said.
"It was a lost opportunity," he said.
Republicans countered that Mr. Spitzer, who recently forced Merrill Lynch to pay heavy penalties after he charged that the firm's analysts had misled investors, is encroaching on the S.E.C.'s turf. 
Wall Street's verdict on Mr. Bush's speech was mixed at best. Stocks, which were flat when the president began his speech, began falling after he finished and ended the day sharply lower. 
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index of major companies fell 24.15 points, or 2.5 percent, to 952.83, just above the four-year low it set last week. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 24.49 points, or 1.7 percent, and the Dow Jones industrial average skidded 178.81 points, or 1.9 percent. But it was not clear how much of the declines could fairly be linked to the speech itself.
Politically, Mr. Bush was walking a fine line yesterday. He stood before a pale blue poster that had the words "corporate responsibility" repeatedly imprinted across it, a made-for-TV message. He was accompanied to New York by, among others, Karl Rove, his chief political adviser. Aides say Mr. Rove has taken on the difficult job of seeking to strike the right political tone for Mr. Bush, urging him to get out in front of the issue of corporate reform, while calming business leaders who fear that reforms will open American industry to an endless string of federal investigations and shareholder lawsuits. 
"Karl has warned that this issue has a lot of resonance around the country," one White House official said on Monday. "But he knows that there is a danger in going too far." 
While Mr. Bush sounded determined yesterday, his speech lacked the kind of passion he regularly brings to the subject of routing out terrorism or protecting the United States from further attack. But he was clearly comfortable with his surroundings and his audience, and he lingered for more than 20 minutes after the speech was over, signing autographs, slapping backs and greeting a few people he clearly knew from his past life as a student and then a Texas businessman.
His prescriptions were more detailed and expansive than a 10-point plan he laid out in March. His new measures indicate a greater willingness to use the courts, and the threat of jail time, to rein in chief executives. But the effectiveness of his series of new proposals is difficult to judge, experts say.
Mr. Bush announced, for example, that the new Corporate Fraud Task Force would "function as a financial crimes SWAT team," words that created the image of a financial F.B.I. empowered to swoop down on wrongdoers. But officials at the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Department described the new task force as a coordinating body and a clearinghouse for information, with no direct responsibility for investigations and prosecutions, which would remain under the F.B.I. and the United States attorneys.
To some experts, like Philip B. Heymann, a former deputy attorney general now teaching at Harvard Law School, the creation of the task force makes less sense than a steady, long-term emphasis on a particular kind of fraud.
Similarly, Mr. Bush's call to double the maximum sentence for various kinds of fraud might frighten some executives. But several former prosecutors said that increasing the odds that a guilty executive is actually caught is far more important.
"Someone who's about to lose their livelihood, their reputation, their income and their standing in the community -- it doesn't matter" if the maximum sentence is harsher, said Ira Lee Sorkin, a former prosecutor who currently practices at Carter, Ledyard & Milburn in New York. "It's not an issue of the penalties."
Lawyers also said that modifying the Federal Sentencing Guidelines, which dictate a range of sentences that judges may impose for various crimes, would be more effective than doubling the maximum penalty for specific frauds. The guidelines take into account, for example, how many people were affected by the fraud, how much money was lost, and whether it was part of a complicated scheme, Mr. Sorkin said.
Lawyers who have prosecuted or defended executives charged with fraud said that the proposal to increase the staff and budget of the S.E.C. could prove the most important effect of the president's proposal. 
In a letter to Mr. Bush dated Monday, Harvey L. Pitt, the head of the S.E.C., said that "events have made it clear that we require significant additional resources" in the next fiscal year, and he asked for the $100 million increase that the president endorsed yesterday. If approved, the amount would raise the financing for the agency in the 2003 fiscal year to $567 million, enabling the hiring of 100 new staff members and the revamping of computer systems.
White House officials regard yesterday's speech as important because of the symbolism of the event: a Republican president coming to the heart of Wall Street to call for reform, and using some pretty unvarnished language to do so.
"The business pages of American newspapers should not read like a scandal sheet," Mr. Bush said. "The American economy today is rising, while faith in the fundamental integrity of American business leaders is being undermined. Nearly every week brings better economic news, and a discovery of fraud and scandal."
But he never mentioned Enron, or Worldcom or Arthur Andersen by name, and he certainly made no allusions to his activities as a board member of Harken Energy years ago. Much of a news conference at the White House on Monday had been spent with Mr. Bush parrying questions about his sale of Harken stock in June 1990, not long before the company posted a big loss.
Mr. Bush did seize the moment in his speech yesterday to talk about two groups of professionals that have seen their own approval ratings drop faster than almost any politician's: Wall Street stock analysts and chief executives who cash out before their companies hit the skids.
"Stock analysts should be trusted advisers, not salesmen with a hidden agenda," Mr. Bush said. "We must prevent analysts from touting weak companies because they happen to be clients of their own firm for underwriting or merger advice. This is a flat-out conflict of interest, and we'll aggressively enforce new S.E.C. rules against this practice."
And Mr. Bush, a former chief executive himself, said, "I challenge every C.E.O. in America to describe in the company's annual report -- prominently and in plain English -- details of his or her compensation package." Mr. Bush was more circumspect about his own salary while he was in private business, but now his salary, tax returns and assets are a matter of public record.

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: INVESTORS; 
Those Feeling the Pain Now Await a Remedy

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
As the president wrapped up his speech on corporate responsibility in a Wall Street ballroom yesterday, Arthur Urrows stared into a small television screen at a discount brokerage office near Rockefeller Center and slumped in his seat.
 Maybe he was merely beaten down by the oppressive midday heat outside. But as he spoke he seemed more defeated by what he had just heard. 
 "I'm very skeptical of my president," said Mr. Urrows, 72, a fund-raising consultant for nonprofit groups. "I'm skeptical of whatever he says in most realms, but in this realm, I think he's largely on the side of the corporate executives." 
President Bush had just finished ticking off a litany of proposals meant to restore investors' confidence in the financial system, but Mr. Urrows was unimpressed, saying those measures -- including longer prison sentences and forfeited payouts for executives who commit fraud, more money for enforcement of securities laws, a new corporate-crime task force -- did not go far enough.
Mr. Urrows, who owns a few blue-chip stocks and invests in the market more broadly through a pension fund, said he had lived through many recessions and had been unemployed himself several times. But he said he could not remember a time when he felt so disillusioned about the nation's corporate and financial institutions and so unsure of the government's ability or resolve to clean them up.
"I think we need some harsh measures," he said. "Action is going to be more important than words."
Across the country yesterday, Mr. Bush's speech drew similarly underwhelmed reactions from a wide range of investors, from day traders and white-collar workers in the Northeast, to factory workers and pensioners in the South, to investment club members and venture capitalists on the West Coast. While all said they were glad that the president had finally addressed the rash of corporate misdeeds head-on, many said they remained doubtful that he was proposing sufficient reforms, or that what he was proposing would actually be done.
But others like Carl Hinton, a retired bank vice president from Norcross, Ga., applauded Mr. Bush's speech, saying it showed he was tackling the crisis of confidence in American corporations as aggressively as the war on terrorism. 
"He has really got the jump on this," Mr. Hinton said. "He ended up with saying there's no wealth without integrity. I think he's right. You know, he was talking about the attitude of the corporate executives, how they have to set an example of integrity for their companies. I think it's fortunate we've got a guy like President Bush to convey his integrity to the public."
Mr. Hinton, 70, said he was pleased by Mr. Bush's calls for freezing payments to executives accused of fraud, and for requiring executives to swear to the veracity of their financial reports. 
"If they don't, they'll be suspect," he said. "That's going to turn up some more stuff, get it cleaned up. That really gets to my heart. Another thing I liked is saying that these executives that cause losses, they should lose their compensation. Hell, if you deceive the public in your annual report and you want to leave the company and get paid for the next five years, that's ridiculous. I definitely liked that."
Dolores Fanton, a pharmacist from Victor, N.Y., welcomed Mr. Bush's call to bar dishonest executives from working at publicly held companies. "Prison by itself is not always a deterrent for people who are that slick," she said.
Those who praised Mr. Bush more often than not also found his proposals wanting in some respects, however. In Humble, Tex., Peter W. Hilgarth stayed up to watch the president after returning home from his graveyard shift as an airplane mechanic. He called the speech "a step in the right direction," and said he remained confident in America's economy. But he complained, for example, that the 10-year sentences Mr. Bush had called for -- a doubling of the maximum for people convicted of mail or wire fraud -- were still too lenient. 
"I think he should've went with 15 to 20," said Mr. Hilgarth, 64, who said he had a portfolio with shares of more than 100 companies but did not want his small-town neighbors to know its value. "I want to see these people go to jail, because they're ruining an awful lot of lives."
Frank North, 73, a retired manager for a crane manufacturer in Roswell, Ga., watched Mr. Bush from his family-room couch while nursing a pulled tooth, and sounded as irritated by what he had not heard as by the pain in his mouth. "There was an awful lot of bones but really no meat," Mr. North said. "It was like somebody went around and dusted a little here and dusted there and hoped it would make everybody happy."
"In my opinion they don't need new laws," he said. "They should just enforce the ones they've got. The chairman of the S.E.C., Harvey Pitt -- he boasted about making a friendlier S.E.C. That's not what we need. We need someone who will take it serious and do something about wrongdoers. Harvey Pitt should be replaced."
Most of those investors interviewed said they trusted that Mr. Bush had the best interests of individual investors at heart, if only because investors are becoming synonymous with voters. 
"I would say he's really out to protect the economy and people's confidence in it," said Michael Pullen, 43, a county government employee from Portland, Ore. "I would give him that. But obviously we're heading into an election in about four months where our two houses of Congress are very evenly divided. This is the last thing he needs, when he's already fighting a war, is to have to restore Americans' confidence in the basic financial institutions of the country."
Mr. Pullen added: "It just feels so much like the bubbles have burst. It's not just the dot-com bubble, but a number of things that have made Americans highly confident about their economy and their institutions just a couple of years ago all seem to be bursting. It's really an incredible confluence of events when you combine the biggest domestic terrorist attack in the country's history with the biggest corporate bankruptcy in the country's history and then the Catholic Church's problems. It's a number of institutions that people are losing faith in."
And the pain being felt by investors is quite real. John H. Sullivan, 52, a claims manager from Kansas City, said he had lost more than $100,000 already this year from his investments, 90 percent of which are in stocks. "WorldCom really hit me," he said. "It really hurts, seeing your portfolio go down 25 percent, especially when you have two teenage sons."
Mr. Sullivan doubted that the president's address would have immediate and lasting impact, and called it more of a political exercise than anything else. 
"The Democrats were going to come out and get him for his ties to business. He had to come out and say something. I viewed it as a political necessity."
Still, few investors who were interviewed expressed concern about the renewed attention to Mr. Bush's 1990 sale of shares of Harken Energy, where he was a director. Democrats have raised that trade, and a subsequent investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, as evidence that the president is unsympathetic to smaller, less well-connected investors.
Mr. Hinton, the retired banker in Georgia, called that "ridiculous," especially since Mr. Bush had disclosed his intention to sell his shares beforehand. 
"If he was trying to defraud anyone, he wouldn't have told them in the first place," Mr. Hinton said.
But in the next breath, Mr. Hinton suggested that Mr. Bush's brush with the S.E.C. years ago might give him more credibility as a reformer now. "They always say it takes one to catch one," he said.

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE REACTION; 
A Talk on Corporate Integrity Heard in the Street and the Suite

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Chief executives widely praised President Bush's speech yesterday, saying it would help restore confidence in American business. But many Wall Streeters and those who run large pension funds that own billions of dollars in stocks expressed disappointment Mr. Bush did not offer more specific proposals to clean up corporate wrongdoing.
 The two points of view represent competing visions of the current scandal over corporate behavior: executives who feel their credibility is at stake and investors angered by a cascading series of financial losses and a string of accounting failures. 
 While both sides praised Mr. Bush's focus on the need for integrity and ethical behavior among chief executives, from that point on, opinions diverged. Institutional investors felt more sweeping changes in boardroom rules and accounting oversight were needed while others, mainly business leaders, said they opposed any move toward greater regulation.
"I was hoping for more commitment to regulatory reform and to corporate governance reform in light of what happened," said Felix Rohatyn, the longtime Wall Street financier and former ambassador to France. "There are still too many holes in our regulatory dikes. They must be fixed; otherwise a very important national asset, namely our financial markets, will be badly damaged."
Mr. Rohatyn has advocated, among other changes, putting institutional investors on corporate boards and reporting stock options granted to top executives on income statements, items that were not on the White House's agenda.
By contrast, chief executives were lavish in their praise.
"We needed this speech because people are losing confidence," said George David, chief executive of the United Technologies Corporation, a diversified manufacturer in Hartford. "Some bad things happen and people say the system is broken. It's not. A huge percentage of corporate America is honest and his speech reinforced that."
Robert S. Miller, chief executive of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, amplified on that. "The president struck a nice bipartisan balance. He talked about doubling prison terms and going after the bad apples rather than imposing new burdens on the majority of American businesses."
At the same time, chief executives said that they, too, had little sympathy for unethical behavior within corporations and praised the president's high moral tone. "People who rob banks go to jail; people who rob shareholders should, too," said William Hickey, chief executive of the Sealed Air Corporation, best known for making bubble wrap packaging.
Larry Johnston, chief executive of Albertson's, the supermarket chain based in Boise, Idaho, thought "the president hit the nail on the head."
"He stood up as C.E.O. of this country and said the whole issue of integrity needs to be higher on the scale of awareness," Mr. Johnston added. "I can't argue with that."
Perhaps most disappointed were institutional investors and corporate governance advocates who were hoping Mr. Bush might endorse some proposals they had long advocated. These include greater financial oversight and a requirement that stock options be treated as corporate expenses. They were especially concerned Mr. Bush declined to endorse proposals in a Senate bill introduced by Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat, for overhauling the accounting industry. Instead, Mr. Bush praised a House version of the bill, which they contend is too weak.
"My concern is whether the speech was just more political rhetoric or whether it was truly a call for action," said James E. Burton, chief executive of the California Public Employees Retirement System, the nation's largest public pension fund, with $150 billion in assets. "We think it is time for Congress to act."
Sarah Teslik, executive director of the Council of Institutional Investors, which represents the nation's public pension funds, was also disappointed. "What he did was to do as little as he could possibly do and still give a speech," she said. " 'Putting people behind bars': It sounds good, but he ducked and took the easy way out."
Mr. Bush's failure to back proposals to treat executives' stock options as a normal business expense was seen as a shortcoming by corporate governance activists. "My feeling is sadness," said Robert A. G. Monks, an executive of the Corporate Library, a research group. "He had the perfect opportunity to start with a new morality," Mr. Monks added, "and stop this nonsense of not calling a stock option an expense."
On Wall Street, Mr. Bush's speech got mixed reviews. Peter G. Peterson, chairman of the Blackstone Group and co-chairman of a corporate governance task force at the Conference Board, a business research group, called the speech "too little, too late and too general."
Mr. Peterson added that while "this business of putting people into jail is a laudable idea," the speech lacked specifics on things like executive compensation and the disgorgement of any ill-gotten gains.
Wall Street executives who attended Mr. Bush's presentation came away praising the speech as a much-needed confidence booster. "He lowered the hammer," said Henry M. Paulson Jr., chief executive of Goldman Sachs. "This shows he is serious about driving the abuses out of the system." Still, Mr. Paulson felt that the problems in corporate America were more systemic. 
"You are not going to get me to say it's just a few bad apples," Mr. Paulson said, adding that his firm backed proposals to tighten accounting standards and toughen punishment for financial fraud.
Philip J. Purcell, chief executive of Morgan Stanley, disagreed, saying that corporate wrongdoing was "not systemic at all."
Mr. Purcell praised Mr. Bush's proposal that chief executives sign and certify their companies' financial statements. "We've got to get beyond political parties and address what we think is best for confidence in the markets," he said. "If this is what it takes to restore confidence, let's sign them and move on."
On Wall Street, Mr. Bush earned points for talking forcefully about corporate responsibility. Sanford I. Weill, chief executive of Citigroup, has put out his own proposals for stricter accounting standards and the deduction of some stock options from corporate profits. "The president just being here," he said, "showed that he gets the message."

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: STRATEGY; 
Bush's Dance: Moral Outrage Without Pain To Loyalists

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9 

 BODY:
On Wall Street today President Bush carefully positioned himself, politically and economically, as a leader willing to come down hard on unscrupulous capitalists without alienating the business constituency that remains his party's financial and ideological base.
 Mr. Bush had to be candid enough to acknowledge a crisis of confidence, but not so alarmist as to risk unnerving the financial markets further. He had to promise an aggressive response, but not one so harsh that it would leave him open to accusations of abandoning his deregulatory, free-market principles. 
 Speaking to an audience best known for its focus on the bottom line, Mr. Bush stressed the importance of character and conscience. But he did not mention his own history as a businessman, one that led him at a news conference on Monday to plead that when it comes to accounting, things are not always black and white.
The speech he delivered today was full of the moral tone that suffuses his major public pronouncements, and it ranged across the landscape of complex issues raised by cascading corporate troubles -- from criminal fraud prosecutions, to the independence of auditors, to the need to protect the pensions of workers. While it was light on new proposals, its emphasis on seeking stiffer sentences for executives convicted of fraud and its promise that the Justice Department would step up its prosecutions of criminal cases allowed Mr. Bush to portray himself as determined to root out wrongdoing.
As far as his broader goal of seizing back control of the policy agenda and insulating himself from political damage, it is not clear whether he was successful, at least by two early barometers.
The stock market fell after his remarks, suggesting no immediate surge in confidence that the worst is past for investors. And Democrats in control of the Senate showed no signs of relaxing efforts to push for broader legislation or slackening their criticism that the President is more protective of rich chief executives than of average investors. "I thought the president spoke loudly," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, "but he offered a very, very small stick."
Mr. Bush still has great opportunity to influence whatever legislation on the matter emerges from Congress, and his personal popularity, while eroding somewhat, remains very high. Should the economy and the stock market turn around, much of the pressure on him might dissipate.
But for now, Mr. Bush seems likely to remain on the defensive over corporate ethics.
"Not long ago, on homeland security, he saw an issue getting away from him and he gave a speech in an attempt to put himself back in a leadership position," said Thomas D. Gallagher, a political analyst at International Strategy and Investment, an advisory firm. "He could do that on homeland security pretty easily because he's got so much credibility in the war on terrorism. It's harder to do here. Instead of capturing the issue, he's just contributing to a political process that's still intensifying."
In a sense, Mr. Bush's speech today was an extension of a dance he has been performing since the 2000 campaign, blurring ideological lines to expand his political appeal and give himself maximum room to maneuver as circumstances dictate.
He is often cast as one of the best friends business has had in Washington, and in some respects that reputation is justified. On environmental regulation, taxes and other topics that are red meat to economic conservatives, Mr. Bush has delivered for the corporate constituency, or made a determined effort to do so.
But he has also proved willing to put political considerations first when he and his advisers deem it necessary to his electoral prospects, as when he imposed tariffs on imported steel earlier this year under pressure from steelmakers and their workers in battleground states like Pennsylvania and West Virginia.
In this case, Mr. Bush is trying to have it both ways, using some populist language, but trying to place strict limits on how far new laws and regulations should go. 
He said he would seek longer prison sentences for executives convicted of fraud, but he did not endorse a bill pending in the Senate that would create a broad new definition of corporate fraud to make it easier for prosecutors to bring cases. He criticized the practice of companies paying their top managers huge amounts for pumping up their short-term earnings, but continues to oppose legislation that would make it more expensive for companies to issue stock options to their executives.
"He ran on a platform of compassionate conservatism, and I guess that was amended today to ethical capitalism," said Paul McCulley, chief economist at Pimco, a bond-trading firm. "What he's trying to say is that we live with the tug and pull of democratic capitalism: as capitalists we respect the notion of one dollar, one vote, but in a democracy, it's one person, one vote."
The public is angry now, he added, and "we have to find a more happy union in the state of the union between capitalism and democracy."
