HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL; 
Frustrated, Bud? There Are Ways to Avoid a Repeat

BYLINE:  By Jack Curry

 BODY:
As Commissioner Bud Selig searched for a solution that would help him end the All-Star Game on Tuesday night in any manner but a dreadful tie, he raised his hands above his shoulders in exasperation. He looked like a driver who put his foot on the brakes of a rusted economy car, but was still propelled into his neighbor's new luxury sedan. What should I do now?
 Poor Bud. This game was his party, his chance to beam. Selig is presiding over a sport that could have another work stoppage in weeks, a disturbing reality. But Selig wanted a few hours of bliss in Miller Park, the snazzy stadium he helped bring to his beloved Milwaukee. He got a few hours, but it must have felt like a few seconds. 
 After both managers told Selig they needed to protect their last pitchers, he ended the game with a 7-7 tie in 11 innings and heard thousands of people in his living room vilify his choice with their expansive lungs. It was a terrible finish to a promising night and left everyone debating Selig's actions and what could have been done differently. Some were serious and some were playful.
"I don't know how we could have broken the tie," said Paul Konerko of the Chicago White Sox. "Maybe we could pick the fastest guys and raced. Or flipped a coin. Maybe we could do it like in soccer, those kickoffs. Yeah, those penalty kicks. Do that on the side. You could have tie breaker with the most hits."
Stop. At least Konerko was polite enough to attempt an answer. But there are some changes that could be enacted in the future to prevent another tie and there are some things that should have been done to make Tuesday less irksome. Bud, put the car in park and consider these suggestions.
THREE-INNING STINTS The pitchers who start the All-Star Game should be expected to last at least three innings, and maybe as many as four. Curt Schilling and Derek Lowe pitched two innings each, a breeze. The last time both starters went three was when Roger Clemens and Dwight Gooden did it in 1986. Time to turn back the clock and turn up the pitch count.
THE AMERICAN WAY No one wants to see Freddy Garcia hit, as he did on Tuesday, so the game should always include a designated hitter. Lowe and Schilling were removed so they would not have to bat. I hate the D.H., but it works in this format and will allow pitchers to stay in the game longer.
NOT LITTLE LEAGUE It is time to stiffen the strategies and deal with the fact that some All-Stars, especially some pitchers in storage, might not play. Torre and Brenly are nice guys, so they wanted to play their entire 30-man rosters, a decision that backfired on them. It is their responsibility to save a pitcher so the game could have continued.
USE TAXI SQUAD In case you do run out of players, pick a four-man taxi-squad consisting of two pitchers, a utility player and a catcher. They should be first- or second-year major leaguers who would be thrilled with the assignment. These players would only be in uniform on the day of the game. If they are needed in an emergency, they are used. If not, they got a great seat.
SECOND CHANCES Give the managers the flexibility of using a player or a pitcher again after he has been removed. Other than the rubber-armed David Wells, it is doubtful any pitchers would do this. But the position players would. If Jason Giambi singled and was the potential tying run in the ninth, how cool would it be if Alfonso Soriano (who had left the game in the fourth inning) could pinch-run? 
HONORARY ALL-STARS Pitchers who start on the Sunday before the game can be named as All-Stars, but they do not count on the roster. Torre was worried about picking Oakland's Barry Zito because of this conflict and it haunted him as Zito faced only one batter. Zito is an All-Star, but a rested pitcher could have helped the game advance to the 12th inning.
PUT A RUNNER ON If everyone detests the idea of playing extra innings, let both teams start the 10th with a runner on first. If no one scores, move him to second in the 11th and third in the 12th. This is not ideal and will make purists grimace, but it is an exhibition and anything that produces a winner is better than a tie.
ALWAYS AN M.V.P. Baseball made a savvy move in naming its most valuable player award after the late Ted Williams, but then declined to present it Tuesday night because of concern that fans would boo the presentation. In this instance, baseball needed a little more fortitude. Barry Bonds and Williams have been cited as perhaps the two best left fielders in history, and Bonds should have received the Williams award last night. 
TURN P.A. OFF Never again tell over 41,000 fans in the middle of an inning that the game will be over if a team fails to score in that inning. Major League Baseball should have waited until after the 11th ended and then asked Robin Yount, an icon in Milwaukee, to take the microphone. Yount could have explained why the game was being halted and fewer fans would have booed.
THANK THE FANS In a frustrating situation like Tuesday's, baseball should have been shrewd enough to offer fans something in return for not getting to see a complete game. Autorgaphed items, tickets to another game, something. An official should set aside some memorabilia for this purpose from now on in case there is another bizarre ending.

HEADLINE: Japan Carves Out Major Role in China's Auto Future 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 10 

 BODY:
In what may be the first big step toward China's emergence as a major source of automobiles, Honda Motor of Japan announced today that it would build the first car plant there dedicated to exports.
 The new plant will be able to turn out as many as 50,000 vehicles a year, starting in 2004, the company said. Hiroyuki Yoshino, Honda's president, told reporters that the quality of cars built at the plant would match those made in Japan, but that production costs in China would be 20 percent lower. 
 The announcement comes at a time when all of Japan's five largest automakers have unveiled ambitious plans to expand production in China and serve the rapidly growing domestic market there, augmenting or replacing cars they now ship from Japan. Taking advantage of China's low labor costs -- one-twentieth of those in Japan -- the new Japanese investments could make China a car-exporting power by 2010, analysts said. 
"China today is our No. 1 geographic priority in terms of market development," Carlos Ghosn, president of Nissan Motor, said last month in Beijing, where he was attending the annual motor show. "Over the next 5 to 10 years, China will have the highest growth in all our markets."
And as it happens, the first consignment of Chinese cars exported to the United States is due to arrive in Florida in two weeks. The 252 Xiali sedans, built by the Tianjin Auto Group, are to be re-exported to Mexico, not sold in the United States, but the importer, American Automobile Network Holdings, hopes to win United States safety and emissions certificates for the Xiali so that it can market the model in the United States next year. 
The shipment has not escaped notice in Tokyo, where car executives still remember American complacency 30 years ago in the face of imports with exotic names like Toyota and Honda.
Honda already produces about 60,000 vehicles a year in China for local sale, and officials said at the Beijing auto show that they planned to double that output by next March at the existing plant, a joint venture in Guangzhou that builds a mix of Accord sedans and Odyssey minivans. The new export plant will probably be built in the same area. 
While Honda's Japanese rivals have not yet announced export plans, they, too, are jumping in or stepping up Chinese production ventures. At the show, Katsumi Nakamura, the new head of Nissan's China office, unveiled the Paladin, a sport utility vehicle to be built by a joint venture, Zhengzhou Nissan Automobile, beginning next year. The Xinhua news agency reported today that Nissan is also talking to Dongfeng Motor about jointly producing 150,000 vehicles a year by 2005.
"Everybody wants to get in on the ground floor, they don't want to miss the action later on," Christopher Richter, an auto analyst for HSBC Securities, said in Tokyo. "Eventually, the Japanese will use China as an export platform."
Automakers call Japan's market mature, a euphemism for stagnant, and they have more plant capacity in Japan than they need. In contrast, China's market is immature, shop talk for fast-growing. Forecasters expect car sales there to top one million this year and keep growing at double-digit annual rates for the rest of the decade. "In terms of automakers' investment, nobody is investing in carmaking capacity here," Mr. Richter said of Japan. "They are all either spending their money in the States or in China."
The main foreign player in China now is Volkswagen, whose joint venture has about half the car market. Among the American concerns, General Motors has the biggest presence; its joint venture, Shanghai GM, has built and sold Buick and Chevrolet cars since the late 1990's, and last month G.M. bought a stake in SAIC-Wuling Automotive, a light truck maker. DaimlerChrysler assembles Jeeps in China, while Ford Motor has a stake in Jiangling Motors, a car and truck maker.
Toyota Motor, the leading manufacturer in Japan, has a market share in China of just 1 percent, but it has set an ambitious goal of expanding it tenfold by 2010.
At the Beijing show, along with showing off its Japan-built cars, Toyota unveiled its first model for Chinese production, based on the Vitz compact sedan, which is not marketed in the United States. Some 30,000 of the cars will be built each month by Tianjin, now a subsidiary of First Automotive Works, known as F.A.W. Toyota is negotiating with F.A.W., China's largest domestic car company, over a broader alliance that may include a luxury model as well.
"Toyota is enlarging the Vitz for the China market, adding navigation equipment, so they are coming in with their very best product," said Michael J. Dunne, director of Automotive Resources Asia, a car markets consultancy based in Beijing.
Suzuki Motor and Mitsubishi Motor also have China plans. Suzuki wants to double its output of subcompacts to 100,000 by 2005, while Mitsubishi expects to begin building the Pajero Sport in partnership with Beijing Jeep. 
Rolf Eckrodt, Mitsubishi's new president, told his company's annual shareholder meeting in Tokyo on June 25 that the project, which will turn out 10,000 cars a year to start, "is a great chance to take part in the future growth of this huge market." Neither Mitsubishi nor Suzuki has spoken of building vehicles in China for export.
Some voices in Japan say the carmakers should think twice about building more cars there at all. They say that shipping cars to China from Japan is about to become much easier and cheaper. With China's entry into the World Trade Organization this year, import quotas are to be abolished and tariffs cut in stages, reducing the duty on cars from around 100 percent today to 25 percent by 2006. And, these people say, people who are affluent enough to afford a car are likely to prefer a made-in-Japan label over made-in-China, according to an essay published in June by C. H. Kwan, a senior fellow at the Research Institute of Economy, Trade and Industry, a Japanese government research bureau. 
His view echoed wider Japanese industrial insecurity about China. Japan's economic ministry this year surveyed executives at 102 Japanese companies operating overseas about Chinese technical prowess. Only 17 percent said they thought their Chinese rivals were up to Japanese levels now, but 48 percent thought they would be in five years.
But Japanese manufacturers do not trust the government to deftly handle the increasingly crucial trade relationship with China. Last year, after conservative farming interests succeeded in pushing the government to restrict imports of leeks, mushrooms and tatami mat rushes from China, China responded with high duties on Japanese cars, computers and cellphones.
"The whole vegetable spat sent a signal to them that maybe they could not import cars into China," Mr. Richter said of the manufacturers. Though the trade dispute was defused in December after a nine-month standoff, many manufacturers hesitate to count on ready access to the Chinese market from Japan.
And from the China side, few people think Beijing will allow a flood of imports to swamp its domestic carmakers, any more than have South Korea, Malaysia, Indonesia -- or for that matter, Japan.
"Across Asia, car imports as a share of total sales is less than 5 percent," Mr. Dunne said. "I don't expect the story to be any different in China."
Instead, he predicted that new joint-venture production would make the market intensely competitive, with the number of models exploding from 20 today to 70 in a few years. "Hyundai, Mitsubishi, Fiat -- they will all be here," Mr. Dunne said. "China will go from a seller's market to a buyer's market."
The Suzuki joint venture has already cut the price of its compact sedan twice this year, most recently by 15 percent, in an effort to step up sales volume.
A price war would savage what are now fairly fat profit margins on cars in China, but Japanese manufacturers are expected to hold up well in such a battle. 
Mr. Dunne said he expected the combined share of the market for Japanese manufacturers to rise to about 40 percent over the next five years, from about 25 percent now. "They have dealerships everywhere in China," he said. "People know Toyota, Nissan and Honda. By 2010, they will be making China a major exporter, like Korea, like Japan."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
S.&P.500 and Nasdaq Fall to Levels Last Seen in 1997

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
The worst bear market in a generation deepened yesterday as stocks plunged for the second day, leaving two major indexes at their lowest levels since 1997.
 Corporate accounting scandals, global political instability and questions about the strength of the recovery have combined to produce a smog of fear over the market. Many of the same investors who two years ago viewed Wall Street as a risk-free way to make money now see it as a dangerous place that can destroy fortunes and wreck retirement plans. 
 Just as the boom of the late 1990's pushed shares to irrational highs, the current drop is causing investors to flee even from reasonably priced stocks, said James W. Paulsen, the chief investment officer of Wells Capital Management, which is based in San Francisco and manages $25 billion in stock. The bear market, he said, "has started to take on a life of its own; it builds on itself." 
Yesterday, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, a crucial gauge of the market's performance, fell 32.36 points, or 3.4 percent, to 920.47, its lowest level since November 1997. The S.& P. 500 has fallen 40 percent since its peak in March 2000, compared with a 48 percent decline for the bear market of 1973 and 1974. The index needed eight years to retrace that drop.
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 282.59 points yesterday, or more than 3 percent, closing at 8,813.50. The Nasdaq composite index skidded 35.11 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,346.01, its lowest level since May 1997. In the last two years, the Nasdaq has lost almost three-quarters of its value, the worst performance by a major market index since the Depression. Many technology stocks have fared even worse.
Yet even after wrenching declines, most stocks are still not cheap by historical standards. Depending on who is calculating it and what definition is used, the S.& P. 500 has a price-to-earnings ratio of 16 to 20, slightly above its historical average. Although relatively few companies have warned of weaker-than-expected profits or growth in advance of second-quarter earnings announcements, which begin later this month, investors appear concerned that more warnings are coming.
As a result, the conservative investors who stayed on the sidelines during the bubble and today have cash available are not putting that money into stocks. Instead, they are buying bonds, which rose strongly yesterday.
"The market itself is not statistically cheap," said Scott M. Black, president of Delphi Management in Boston, which oversees $1.5 billion in stocks. "We way overshot it in the 1990's, and now there is a fundamental lack of earning power."
Since Sept. 11, the market has repeatedly tried and failed to rally, adding to discontent. During the 1990's, the prolonged bull market trained investors to "buy on the dips," because stocks seemed to bounce back quickly every time they fell for more than a few days. Now, some professionals seem to be selling into any rallies, disappointing small investors who are hoping to recoup losses they have suffered.
A fall in drug company shares, which have been battered recently, ignited yesterday's decline, and the selling quickly spread. But the panic selling and very heavy trading volume that big investors say can signal the end of a down move was absent.
Instead of that "capitulation," as professional traders call it, stocks ground steadily lower, and the indexes ended just above their lows for the session. The biggest losers included bellwethers like Pfizer, General Electric and Citigroup.
Wall Street's disappointment with President Bush's speech about corporate responsibility on Tuesday contributed to the decline, strategists said. Tobias M. Levkovich, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, said Mr. Bush had lots of harsh words but offered few concrete steps to prevent scandals.
"There's disappointment that there wasn't something meaty to his comments, aside from the fact that people have to play by the rules," Mr. Levkovich said.
Mr. Black said the accounting scandals had caused a crisis in confidence. Especially disturbing is the fact that many corporations facing questions are "old bellwether companies, the bluest of the blue chips," like Xerox and Merck, he said.
Still, Mr. Bush's comments were only part of the reason that the market plunged, Mr. Levkovich, other strategists and investors said. "You've just got this downward momentum that's kind of overwhelming people's thought patterns," Mr. Levkovich said.
Mark Greenberg, the manager of the $1 billion Invesco Leisure Fund, said he thought that American and foreign economies were improving.
"But I don't think investors are focusing on that," he said. "They're upset about corporate wrongdoing and wondering where the other shoe will drop. They obviously don't want to own stocks right now."
The Invesco fund, based in Denver, is among the best-performing mutual funds over the last five years, with an average annual gain of 15.5 percent, compared with the S.& P.'s average annual gain of 2.3 percent. Mr. Greenberg said he thought many stocks in his portfolio had been unfairly damaged over the last month.
For example, Valassis Communications, a coupon-printing company and a longtime favorite of Mr. Greenberg, has fallen 13 percent since the end of May, even as Wall Street estimates of its profit have not changed. Valassis, which has grown steadily, now has a price-earnings ratio of 15, he said.
"There's a lot of companies that I go through in my portfolio that are like that," he said.
Among the biggest losers yesterday were seven Canadian or European companies that will be removed from the S.& P. 500 index, which is supposed to consist of American stocks. Royal Dutch Petroleum, the biggest company to be removed, fell $5.16, or 9.2 percent, to $50.73. On the other hand, the seven companies that will replace them, including Goldman Sachs and eBay, gained an average of 2 percent. --------------------

Treasury Prices Gain
(By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bonds rose yesterday on expectations the Federal Reserve would delay interest rate increases until 2003 and as stock declines bolstered the allure of government debt.
The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note increased 27/32, to 101 30/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 4.62 percent from 4.73 percent on Tuesday. The 30-year bond rose 1 2/32, to 100 16/32, yielding 5.34 percent, compared with 5.41 percent in the previous session.

HEADLINE: Phone Stocks Causing Pain For InvestorsIn Europe, Too 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 10 

 BODY:
As investors and politicians in the United States recoil from the collapse of WorldCom and other telecommunications companies, Europeans are nursing their own feelings of outrage and betrayal.
 Spurred in many cases by their own governments, Europeans in recent years put their money into the stocks of former state-owned telephone monopolies as those companies were spun off as commercial, competitive enterprises with global ambitions. For a period in the late 1990's, those stocks soared and European investors -- often first-time stock players -- had a taste of capitalism at its best. 
 But since the market bubble burst in early 2000, Europe's telecommunications giants have lost half a trillion dollars in market value. Investors here are realizing too late that those big, seemingly solid telephone companies -- household names like British Telecommunications, France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom -- were actually high-risk bets. 
"I had reached the age where you worry that your pension may not be enough," said Monica Wiesler-Frisch, a 54-year-old retired social worker here. She bought about $6,000 worth of shares in Deutsche Telekom, Germany's former government-owned phone company, which issued its first public stock in 1996. "This seemed like a reasonable long-term investment," she said.
She was wrong. Since March 2000, Deutsche Telekom shares have plunged from 104 euros to just over 11 yesterday. Mrs. Wiesler-Frisch, who bought shortly after the peak, has watched the value of her shares drop to about $1,000. Not knowing what else to do, she still holds them. 
While shareholders have felt the pain, they are not the only ones. At Deutsche Telekom, powerful members of the board are battling over whether the chief executive, Ron Sommer, should be allowed to keep his job in light of the company's battered shares and staggering debt. Deutsche Telekom said today that its full board would meet next Tuesday. At that session the future may be decided for Mr. Sommer, who during the boom was the epitome of the new-style, deal-making European telecommunications executive. 
Deutsche Telekom, which accumulated more than $62 billion in debt as Mr. Sommer went on an acquisition spree, has lost $260 billion in its stock market value in a little more than two years -- a plunge of more than 80 percent.
France Telecom's market value is down more than $150 billion, about 90 percent, since April 2000, and its credit rating has slid to one notch above junk bond status.
The BT Group, formerly British Telecommunications, and Royal KPN of the Netherlands became so loaded with debt last year that each had to change its top management, sell off many businesses and desperately try to raise new cash.
All these companies were part of a global wave of telephone privatizations and stock listings that took place from Japan to Brazil and across much of Europe in the last decade. Investors have lost money in many parts of the world. But the losses suffered by investors in European companies seem to be fostering a special resentment, because companies whose businesses had seemed so conservative -- what could be a safer haven, after all, than the telephone company? -- turned out to be almost recklessly aggressive. 
"They were very much into empire-building," said Denis McCauley, director in charge of European telecommunications at Pyramid Research, a research company based in London. "It was, 'Let's buy new businesses, let's buy wireless licenses, let's buy our way into countries that we aren't in right now.' "
The European telephone companies made big acquisitions in Asia, Central Europe and the United States. They spent nearly $125 billion in frenzied auctions for licenses to radio frequencies that are designated for "third generation" wireless networks, which are supposed to be able to transmit video and innovative new services. They are now spending almost as much money on building the actual networks, and analysts like Mr. McCauley do not expect the new systems to generate significant sales until 2005. 
Meantime, the great profit engine in European telecommunications over the last decade -- conventional cellphones -- is running out of fuel. More than 73 percent of all Western Europeans now have cellphones, and the number of subscribers has not only stopped growing, it actually declined slightly in the first quarter of this year. 
"The key problem of the large telecom operators may have its origin in their origin as state-controlled companies," said Rolf Drees, a fund manager at Union Investment, one of Germany's largest investment funds. "They all look to being very large. They are more oriented to size than to profit." 
The collapse of the telecommunications giants will probably have a social and cultural effect, too. In countries like Germany and France, where much of the public had long considered the stock market too risky, millions of people ventured into the market for the first time through telephone stocks. The former monopolies seemed big and safe, and they promoted their public offerings with huge advertising campaigns on television and billboards.
But the companies were being forced by regulators to admit new competitors into their markets, which quickly grabbed big chunks of the lucrative long-distance businesses and drove down prices.
Rather than defend their home turf, the big telephone companies reacted by expanding. 
BT, for example, racked up $30 billion in debt buying stakes in companies across Europe and in Japan and Malaysia. Its plight might have been even worse had it not been for WorldCom, which outbid BT in a takeover battle for MCI Communications, the second-largest long-distance carrier in the United States after AT&T. 
Deutsche Telekom, Europe's biggest traditional telephone company, amassed even more debt. Under Mr. Sommer, it spent more than $24 billion in stock and cash to buy the United States wireless company VoiceStream -- which Deutsche Telekom may now be feeling pressure to sell. Deutsche Telekom also spent more than $14 billion on third-generation wireless telephone licenses in Britain and Germany, an additional $10 billion to buy Britain's smallest existing cellular phone company and hundreds of millions more on major stakes in telephone companies across much of Central Europe. 
Some European institutional investors are running out of patience with Deutsche Telekom. Union Investment put the company on its "name and shame" list this year, citing a lack of openness and lack of responsiveness to investors. 
For his part, Mr. Sommer, Deutsche Telekom's embattled chief executive, who was not available for comment today, has argued that investors have simply failed to understand the strategy. 
"The capital market is scarcely differentiating any more between winners and losers," Mr. Sommer told shareholders at the company's annual meeting in late May. "The events we have observed in the last few weeks are no longer comprehensible and can only be explained with psychological mechanisms." 
Despite Mr. Sommer's struggle to keep his job at Deutsche Telekom, the company in most acute distress at the moment is France Telecom, which went public in October 1997 at a price equal to about $36 a share. The stock, whose value soared as high as $159 a share, closed yesterday at 13.4 euros ($13.25). Analysts estimate that its net debt is $67 billion, at least $15 billion of which comes due within the next year. 
Many analysts say France Telecom must raise as much as $15 billion by selling additional shares in the very near future. The problem is that its stock has fallen so low that the company's total market value is only about $17 billion.
Michel Bon, France Telecom's chief executive, has vowed to block a new stock issue because it would drastically dilute the value of existing shares. In desperation, the French government recently hinted at the possibility of "renationalizing" the company. 
In the aftermath of WorldCom's accounting scandal, analysts have also begun to worry whether accounting issues might eventually embroil Europe's telecommunications companies. Deutsche Telekom is fighting off accusations that it inflated the value of its real estate for years. 
German magazines and newspapers began raising questions about the valuations several years ago, unearthing documents suggesting that the company had overvalued its land by billions of dollars at the time it went public in 1996. 
The company denied doing anything wrong, but then wrote down the value of its land holdings by nearly $2 billion last year. Now the issue has come up again. A German government agency has charged that Deutsche Telekom may have inflated the value of its buildings as well as its land. Company executives say they were following proper valuation procedures, but skeptics abound. 
Many of the European telephone companies have made use of legal but aggressive accounting policies, like booking labor costs associated with network construction as a capital investment. The practice allows them to write down the expense over many years rather than all at once, reducing their current-year costs and increasing their profits, or at least reducing their losses. 
"It is all perfectly legal, but after the WorldCom debacle these practices may come into focus," Frank Wellendorf, a telecommunications analyst at WestLB Research in Dusseldorf, said. "It is not conservative."

HEADLINE: Pacing, and Worrying; 
Hard Times Overtake New York's Harness Tracks

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

DATELINE: MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 10 

 BODY:
At the end of another long afternoon at the track, John Stubits found his assistant trainer sitting stiffly on a bucket in the stable. His back hurt, and so did his wallet.
 "We got nothing today," Carl Wellman announced with characteristic bluntness. Battleshoe Easy, a horse that Mr. Stubits co-owns and trains at Monticello Raceway, finished sixth out of a field of eight. The purse for Battleshoe Easy's race was $2,500 -- paltry compared to the $10,000-or-so purses on harness racing cards at premier tracks like the Meadowlands in New Jersey. 
 The annual handle, the total amount bet at the track, continues to slip year after year at Monticello. Grass grows through cracks in the empty parking lot. Stray cats roam the crumbling barns; one afternoon, Mr. Stubits shooed one away from the track during Battleshoe Easy's race. 
In the 1950's and 60's, racing -- both thoroughbred and harness -- was just about the only form of legal gambling. But as state lotteries and casinos boomed, the tracks suffered and have groped for ways to stay alive. And harness racing -- with its quirky rules, slower pace and without an event as prestigious and as well known as the Kentucky Derby -- has been hurt more than thoroughbred racing.
Now, the latest hope for salvation may be fading, too. 
A casino gambling law passed last year allowed the state's racetracks, Monticello and five others, to install video lottery terminals -- slot machines, essentially -- to make more money. But now the tracks say limitations on their operating hours and, more important, the state's share of the revenue (75 percent) would make installing and operating the machines unprofitable.
New York's law would give track owners and horsemen 12.5 percent each of the proceeds. In Delaware, which introduced the terminals in 1995, the state gets 40 percent; the tracks get 49 percent and the horsemen receive 11 percent.
The lobbyist for New York tracks haggled with legislators to increase their share, but made little headway in Albany this year.
Training and racing horses, especially the trotters and pacers of harness tracks, has never been for the faint of heart or wallet. Most of the 350 horsemen get by from paycheck to paycheck, eking out a living of about $20,000 to $40,000 a year, depending on how well the horses are running.
"There are martini days and no-martini days," said Norman Bradbury, a longtime trainer and driver.
While the harness tracks in New York have been slowly dying, a state subsidy in New Jersey helps keep purses high at the Meadowlands, and revenue from video lottery terminals has revived parks and bolstered the take in Delaware and Canada. At Dover Downs in Delaware, for instance, revenue from the 2,000 machines has pushed average daily purses to $150,000 now (Monticello's daily purse averages $20,000), from $10,000 before the slots, and attendance has jumped to 2.4 million (Monticello counts about 75,000 a year) from 32,000 a year.
The nearly abandoned Monticello grandstand, with its pale orange, blue, yellow and green seats, appears locked in the 60's. The track's summer schedule has racing from Saturday through Wednesday; a typical daytime card includes 10 to 12 races, with seven or eight horses usually entered in each two-minute, mile-long race.
Most of the fans, and a large number of the trainers and drivers, are middle-age or older. With just a smattering of patrons day after day, the running joke in the backstretch is, "There are not enough people to field a basketball team."
Mr. Stubits, 50, has been at Monticello since 1969, which means he has seen it at its best and at its worst. Nowadays is about rock bottom, he said, with some trainers and drivers working second jobs as carpenters and roofers and laborers to get by. Mr. Stubits himself now relies on income from running a supply shop at the track.
"We all used to make a living," he said. "Not that it ever was a great living. But it was a living."
Monticello, a half-mile oval track, opened in 1958. It catered to vacationers at a time when the Catskill Mountains were a popular destination and harness racing was taking off.
The sport traces its roots to nearby Goshen, where in the early 1800's bored farmers would race each other while sitting in buggies to see whose horses were the fastest. Eventually, trotting, as it was called, moved off the farms to tracks.
Nearly all of today's standardbreds, as the horses in harness racing are known, are descendants of a single horse, Hambletonian, born in Sugar Loaf, N.Y., in 1849, the father of 1,331 foals.
The horses are bred to pace or trot with a peculiar straight-legged gait. One quirk of harness racing is that unlike thoroughbreds ridden by jockeys, the standardbreds are disqualified if they break into a run during a race. For that reason, they do not bolt out of starting gate, but build up their pace behind a car with a swinging gate that races off when the horses reach the starting line.
By the 1960's, promoters were calling harness racing the fastest growing sport in the world, and Monticello rode the boom into the 70's.
Thousands filled the stands on a Saturday night and top entertainers, including Barry Manilow and Ike and Tina Turner, performed there.
"We were saturated," recalled John Manzi, Monticello's head of publicity, who has been with the track since 1974. That, of course, was when there were about 400 resorts and hotels in the Catskills; today there are three major ones.
Apart from the economic slide, a wave of race-fixing and horse doping scandals at several tracks helped drive some bettors away, even as track officials here and elsewhere said they took steps to curtail abuses.
At Monticello, the total annual handle dropped to $18.9 million last year from $28.6 million four years ago, even as improvements to its simulcasting signal and changes in racing hours helped keep the track afloat. Statewide, in the same period, the handle at harness tracks dropped to $158 million from $259 million, far from the peak of $870 million in 1974.
General Washington, 63, a veteran trainer, used to work with a dozen horses at various meets, but he is down to five now. "People don't want to buy a horse because they don't see where they are going to get the money," he said.
Costs have risen substantially as purse money has fallen. (The driver and trainer get 5 percent of a horse's winnings per race.) Top purses are now $4,000, compared to about $7,500 going back 25 years ago.
"That was a lot of money back then," Mr. Washington said.
A bag of oats that went for $8 then now costs $18. Shoeing a horse used to cost $25 but is now closer to $70. 
Mr. Washington's son, Cedric, 40, one of the top drivers here, dreams of moving on to more lucrative tracks in other states if prospects do not brighten here. "If it doesn't pan out next year I got to go," he said as he took Gloria Gloria for a walk.
Many other horsemen, however, plan to stay, hoping that the video lottery terminals will eventually come and improve things. 
Horsemen like Mr. Stubits find it hard to leave racing. He grew up around horses on a farm near Monticello and visits to the track, watching the graceful horses pull their drivers along in sulkies, hooked him on the sport. It didn't hurt, either, that on his first bet of $2 he won $100.
He was a driver at first but the care and tending of the horses interested him more, he said. Now he trains six horses, arriving at the barn at 6 a.m. to feed them and often not leaving until 5 p.m. or later, when racing is over.
He understands it may be difficult for outsiders to appreciate the subtle glories of this life. "We do it because we love it -- not because it is financially rewarding," Mr. Stubits said.
His assistant, Mr. Wellman, brushed Ricky's Future -- a new horse for them who recently ran fast enough in a qualifier to enter races down the road -- and then he shoveled a fresh mound of manure. He is in his element, here in the barn. 
"It's like a narcotic," Mr. Wellman said of harness racing. "When you're away from it, you get withdrawal."

SECTION: Section D; Column 5; Sports Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1315 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
One More Misstep For a Battered Sport

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
At a promotional news conference Tuesday morning, Major League Baseball unveiled its selections for the 30 most memorable moments in its history. The All-Star Game played that night will not be No. 31.
 In a worst-case scenario growing out of an evolution of baseball's popular midsummer game between the best players in the American and National Leagues, the 73rd game did not have a winner. The All-Stars played 11 innings and wound up with a 7-7 tie because the teams ran out of pitchers. 
 Perhaps this day had been coming. Once an often fiercely competitive contest, the All-Star Game has evolved into an event that is the hub attraction of an entertainment extravaganza. The managers still want to win the game, but they have made it a priority to attempt to get all 60 players into it. 
That's what Joe Torre of the Yankees and Bob Brenly of the Arizona Diamondbacks did in Milwaukee on Tuesday night, and by succeeding, they left themselves short of pitching when the game went into extra innings.
Commissioner Bud Selig, in whose city the game was played, was left with no other decision than to end the game after 11 innings. Fans at Miller Park lustily booed the announcement that was made with one out in the N.L. half of the 11th and chanted, "Let them play!"
In a telephone interview yesterday, Selig reflected on the outcome. "The more I thought about it, I'd have to make the same decision today that I made last night," he said. "The only option was to have position players pitch in the 12th inning. That would have been a travesty."
Nevertheless, he said: "We've already started discussing it, and we will continue in the off-season to make sure this doesn't happen again. How do you do it with 30 players? Have pitchers and position players play longer."
Instead of letting them play to a decision Tuesday night -- fans obviously want decisions even in exhibition games, which is what the All-Star Game is -- Major League Baseball was left with another questionable development that added to a growing list of problems afflicting it.
The owners and the players are negotiating a new collective bargaining agreement but are seemingly more on course to their ninth work stoppage in 31 years than to labor peace. Allegations of steroid use have called into question the achievements of baseball's most popular sluggers and have created demands for testing of all players.
The owners are trying to eliminate two teams for reasons of economic health and, in fact, would have already jettisoned the Minnesota Twins and the Montreal Expos had legal challenges not stepped in the way. Selig, in an interview in yesterday's Houston Chronicle, said one team might have difficulty meeting its payroll on Monday. And the television ratings aren't encouraging, either, with Tuesday night's game the lowest rated for an All-Star contest, down 14 percent from a year ago.
Even an attempt to honor the memory of one of the game's greatest players went awry, though through no fault of baseball. Ted Williams, who died Friday, was a central part of the pregame ceremony, but the script had to be revised because of the attempt by Williams's son to have his father's body frozen for possible future use.
And the All-Star Game's most valuable player award was renamed for Williams, but it wasn't given Tuesday because no M.V.P. was chosen. Had a player been named most valuable despite the tie and an award made on the field after the game, the scene would most likely have only incited the fans even more.
While standing by the decision to end the game, Selig acknowledged yesterday that the Tuesday night announcement had omitted one very important piece of information.
"We should have done much better," he said, agreeing that the announcement should have included the reason. "We did not communicate as well as we should have."
To understand two significant ways in which the All-Star Game has changed, one need only look at two games and one scene from each.
At Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati in 1970, Pete Rose scored the winning run in the 12th inning by crashing into the American League catcher, Ray Fosse, who was never the same player afterward. 
As the teams changed sides after the first inning Tuesday night, Barry Bonds met Torii Hunter, the A.L. center fielder, near second base and spontaneously picked him up and held him over his shoulder. It was Bonds's good-natured response to the catch Hunter had just made, leaping above the center-field fence and robbing him of a homer.
In the 12-inning 1970 game, the A.L. used seven pitchers and left two unused while the N.L. used five pitchers and left three on the bench.
The other night Torre, who played in the 1970 game, used all nine of his pitchers and Brenly used all 10 of his.
There was also a difference in the makeup of the staffs. All 12 of the 1970 pitchers were starters. Of the 19 pitchers in Milwaukee, 10 were closers and an 11th was also a reliever.
Managers like having closers on their teams now because closers are accustomed to pitching one inning and pitching it effectively. Tuesday's closers plus the 11th reliever, Mike Remlinger, pitched 10 2/3 of the 22 innings. None of the eight starting pitchers worked longer than two innings. In 1970, 4 of the 12 pitchers worked three innings each.
In the last 14 All-Star games only Greg Maddux, in 1994, pitched as many as three innings. The last time a game's two starting pitchers worked three innings each was in 1986, when Roger Clemens and Dwight Gooden did it. Two innings has become the limit for pitchers as managers have become more concerned about their arms and more interested in getting more players into the game, if not all of them.
Steve Rogers pitched in three All-Star Games during the 13 seasons he pitched for Montreal. 
"When I was on the team," Rogers related in a telephone interview yesterday, "at least one or two -- maybe three or four -- guys didn't play because you had to have them in reserve. But the players who didn't play felt they had missed out."
Rogers, who is a special assistant with the players union, said he had no problem with managers' using all the players, but he said, "If the guiding force is to make sure everybody gets in the game, then you really do have to consider that under special circumstances, which we witnessed last night, you might have to consider a tie."
The primary reason the game was ended was that Vicente Padilla of Philadelphia, the N.L.'s last pitcher, was in his second inning, and Brenly said Padilla had experienced trouble getting loose in the bullpen when he was warming up. Brenly said he would not have had him pitch a third inning. Nor did Torre want to use Freddy Garcia of Seattle, his last pitcher, for a third inning.
Larry Bowa, Padilla's manager, said Padilla was not throwing as hard as usual. "That's a red flag right away," Bowa said in a telephone interview.
Bowa said he could see that the managers were trying to use everybody. For that reason, he said, he agreed that the game should have been ended. 
But he added: "As a fan, do I agree with it? No, not at all. If I'm paying $100-125 a ticket, I want to see somebody win. That's what the baseball purist wants. If they're trying to be nice guys, which they both are, it's probably beneficial, because they got everybody in the game. But there's nowhere to go. You paint yourself into a corner."
Bowa and Rogers agreed that the All-Star Game was different from what it used to be. The leagues no longer play to see who is "king of the hill," Rogers said. "That's fine," he added. "There's nothing sacred about that."
The fans, on the other hand, believe there is something sacred about playing a game to a decision. The problem could have been avoided if one team had scored in the 10th or 11th.
Selig said his wife, Sue, left after the ninth inning. "I said, 'Don't worry, someone will hit one out and I'll be home shortly.' Little did I know."

HEADLINE: Uncle Sam Wants You (To Play This Game) 

BYLINE:  By BRIAN KENNEDY 

 BODY:
"BE all you can be"? Ancient history. "An army of one"? Last year's news. The military's newest promotional campaign is not even televised; it is America's Army, a free computer game produced by the military and aimed at winning the hearts and minds of tech-minded teenagers. 
 The game is the brainchild of Lt. Col. Casey Wardynski, director of the Office of Economic and Manpower Analysis at West Point. Although Colonel Wardynski is not a gamer himself, his two sons are, and his oldest, 17-year-old Casey, is a big fan of the action game Delta Force. The colonel said the idea for the game came to him three years ago while he was researching ways to attract computer-adept recruits for an increasingly high-tech military. 
 The Army is looking to hire 79,500 young adults this year -- and, as Colonel Wardynski said, "Gaming tends to be very interesting to young Americans." 
Colonel Wardynski concluded that releasing a free, high-quality game -- and encouraging gamers to copy it and share it with friends -- would be an effective (and relatively inexpensive) way to reach those budding computer whizzes.
America's Army is actually two games. The first, Operations, is a multiplayer first-person shooter inspired by the popular game Counterstrike. Players log on through the Internet, take on the roles of United States soldiers and team up to battle terrorists. 
But Operations is no Rambo-style shoot-'em-up. Although it uses the engine -- or basic structural programming -- from the newest version of the sci-fi game Unreal, the Army has gone to great lengths to make the game as realistic as possible, soliciting input from soldiers at bases nationwide.
The designers, primarily the Modeling, Virtual Environments and Simulation Institute at the Naval Postgraduate School in Monterey, Calif., say they have modeled each weapon accurately. A player's aim will be affected by his stance, breathing and movement. A player who charges an enemy trench, wildly firing his rifle, is unlikely to hit very much.
Everything from the direction and velocity of shell ejection to the way soldiers high crawl when carrying a rifle is based on the way the Army really operates, said Michael Capps, the game's executive director and a professor at the modeling institute. 
Unlike many multiplayer games, Operations features mechanisms to ensure participants' good behavior. Gun down your drill sergeant on the rifle range, for example, and you'll serve hard time in a virtual Fort Leavenworth. 
In another departure from gaming norms, Operations is not very bloody.
"We don't want to use violence as an entertainment vehicle," Colonel Wardynski said. Bullet hits are registered by puffs of blood instead of the sprays of gore typical of some first-person shooters. The game is rated appropriate for teenage players (most graphic first-person shooters are rated for mature players). 
The enemy is designed to look as generic as possible. "We've got blond guys who are bad guys, black guys who are bad guys," Colonel Wardynski said. "Usually, they're not well shaven." 
In the second part of the game, Soldiers, players progress through a virtual career in the Army, serving in a variety of units and improving their ratings in categories like loyalty, honor and personal courage as they go. 
A preliminary version of the Operations game released on July 4 includes two training missions and four combat operations, including an assault on a terrorist camp that Colonel Wardynski said was modeled after a raid conducted in the early days of the Afghanistan campaign. 
Maj. Chris Chambers, the project's deputy director, said that more than 500,000 copies of the game had been downloaded by Wednesday morning -- prompting a frantic rush for additional servers and an accelerated plan to release "community software" allowing groups to play without tapping into a server.
The full version of America's Army is scheduled for release in late August or early September. It will be available free as a two-CD set or by downloading from the Internet at americasarmy.com. 
The Army is hoping the game will help cut down on one of its biggest expenses -- filling its ranks. Doug Smith, a spokesman for the Army Recruiting Command in Fort Knox, Ky., said the Army spends about $15,000 to recruit every soldier. 
Colonel Wardynski said the government will have spent about $7.6 million to develop the game by September; he said he expected the cost of creating new missions and other updates to be about $2.5 million a year and the cost of maintaining the multiplayer infrastructure to be about $1.5 million.
If the game draws 300 to 400 recruits in the next year, he said, it will have been worth the cost -- especially since the game is considered likely to attract people attending or considering college, who tend to be more expensive to recruit. 
He also hopes that by providing more information to prospective soldiers, the game will help cut down on the number of recruits who wash out during the nine weeks of basic training and subsequent specialized training, which can last up to a year. (All told, the Army loses 13.7 percent of recruits during training, according to a spokesman for the Training and Doctrine Command in Fort Monroe, Va.) 
Recruits who signed up but then quickly changed their mind "had an information problem," Colonel Wardynski said. 
"That's $15,000 down the drain," he added. 
Initial reaction among gamers has been positive. The Army's display booth at the Electronics Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles in May was packed -- despite, or perhaps because of, the presence of uniformed soldiers and military vehicles instead of the typical scantily clad women. Army officials said they had received more than 150,000 advance orders for the game before the preliminary version became available for download on July 4. 
"It's a blast," said Amer Ajami, an editor at Gamespot.com who spent last weekend playing the game online. "It's pretty realistic -- you take one or two shots and you go limp, you take one more and you're done." 
From a marketing standpoint, Mr. Ajami said, its prospects are excellent. "You see all these commercials on TV with catchy phrases, but nothing beats going in and seeing what the Army really does," he said. "Without actually having to do it."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Bush is talking tough on corporate ethics, but where is the regulatory bite?

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick, who teaches at Cooper Union, is the editor of Challenge Magazine and of a new journal of social health, Indicators. His new book, "Why Economies Grow," will be published by Basic Books in October. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
AT bottom, President Bush's speech on Tuesday reflects the belief that the current corporate scandals are merely the handiwork of a few bad apples. If we enforce existing laws more strongly, he essentially told us, the mess will be cleaned up. He called for longer prison sentences and a federal SWAT team to combat fraud.
 Is such law enforcement talk what he thinks Americans understand? Any new rules or regulations will be left to self-regulators, like stock exchanges. There is no need for direct government oversight of accounting. 
 But something more systemic than a few clever swindlers is staining America. It is hard to believe that Mr. Bush's economic advisers don't know that. The Enron deceptions alone involved some of the nation's most prestigious accountants, lawyers, Wall Street brokers and commercial bankers, along with some of Enron's own highly respected directors. About 1,000 corporations have had to restate earnings the last five years.
A good economist's first instinct would be to determine whether there are incentives built into the financial system that encourage deception and fraud. A president who wanted to make business trustworthy again and renew the nation's confidence would address these incentives directly.
It's helpful to return, for perspective, to the corporate scandals of the 1980's and 1990's. The best piece of economic analysis on the subject was done by George A. Akerlof, of the University of California at Berkeley -- later a Nobel Prize winner -- and Paul M. Romer, now of the Stanford Business School, in the Brookings Papers on Economic Activity.
The two developed a model that showed fairly convincingly that it was rational for executives to "loot" their companies when accounting standards were lax. Their most compelling examples were the savings and loan bankruptcies of the 1980's.
Accounting rules were changed and existing standards relaxed to aid the S.& L.'s after high interest rates devastated them in the late 1970's. But permissive accounting, coupled with federal guarantees of deposits, ultimately enabled executives to make highly risky investments to inflate short-term profits. They could pay themselves enormous compensation because the accounting methods did not properly reflect the risks or costs until years later. The incentives encouraged them to make investments that, Mr. Akerlof and Mr. Romer wrote, could have had "no reasonable payoff in any future state of the world."
This is sadly familiar. Enron inflated profits through highly devious accounting; it made many bad investments whose long-run risks could be hidden but that could produce rapid if temporary profits. WorldCom and other telecommunications companies made similarly risky investments, building capacity aggressively even when there was no sign of demand. But the executives were still able to enrich themselves.
The widespread granting of stock options created similar incentives with damaging consequences. The prevailing worry, famously raised by Adolf Berle and Gardiner Means in the 1930's, had been that managers would run companies to preserve their jobs rather than to maximize profits. Now, the problem had purportedly been solved. Options allowed them to buy large quantities of their companies' shares at low prices. Managers who received options, it was argued, would act entrepreneurially because they would be compensated as owners would be.
But options, it turned out, encouraged managers to take unduly big risks, as long as they showed handsome short-term profits. They became rich if investments paid off, but they did not lose money if they failed. And they could usually bail out long before the investments went bad.
They also managed earnings to appeal to Wall Street's short-term orientation. Nothing was quite so ludicrous as when investors clobbered a stock because earnings per share were a penny or two below expectations. Now we know that billions of dollars of profits were simply fabricated.
True reform must correct such distorting incentives, and if we are honest, it should involve new regulation. The stakes are high. It is not just a matter of a few executives stealing a hundred million here or there. Perhaps hundreds of billions of dollars of national savings were misallocated to businesses that did not last rather than invested in businesses that might have created long-term profits and permanent jobs. The holdings of pension funds, endowments and individuals have collapsed. 
Here is a start:
*First, every effort must be made to make sure accounting rules are tough and are adhered to. Industry on its own has not been up to this task. Accounting rules have been consistently watered down the last 10 years. Government should be involved in setting the rules. A bill working through the Senate, sponsored by Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, is worth consideration.
*Second, the ultimate authority over the annual audit of accounting practices should be held by special committees of corporate boards, completely separate from chief executives and their staff.
*Third, options should be deducted from current earnings, so shareholders know what they are paying. Now, there is no required deduction. Mr. Bush has said nothing about expensing options, but even the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, supports such a reform.
More jail time for fraud, as the president recommends, may help. But it will hardly be enough. Finding executives guilty, SWAT team or not, will continue to be difficult. Enron and WorldCom executives will cite in their defense the opinions of accountants and lawyers who assured them, usually in writing, that what they were doing was not deceptive or illegal.
Mr. Bush apparently cannot or will not see that these deceptive and greedy executives operated in an environment that not merely tolerated their actions but encouraged them. It is not just the bad apples that need to be expunged; distorting incentives must be changed. Until that is acknowledged, confidence will not be restored.

HEADLINE: Colon Cancer Screening Bill Advances in Senate Panel 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10 

 BODY:
A Senate committee voted today to require all private health insurance plans in the United States to pay for screening tests to detect colon cancer in people who are 50 or older or have a high risk of developing the disease.
 In addition, the committee moved toward approval of a bill that would expand access to low-cost generic versions of prescription drugs. Democrats appeared to have the votes needed to approve the bill, which was also endorsed by Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine. 
 Ms. Collins described the drug bill as a necessary response to abuses by some drug companies, which she said had exploited the existing law "to maximize their profits at the expense of consumers." 
The cancer screening bill was approved by a vote of 16 to 5 in the Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions. Five Republicans and 1 independent joined 10 Democrats in voting for the bill, while 5 Republicans opposed it.
Supporters of the bill said it could save tens of thousands of lives by requiring insurers to provide coverage for colonoscopies and other tests to detect colon cancer. "Overwhelming scientific evidence indicates that with early detection, we can save lives, and millions and millions of dollars," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, who introduced the bill with Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina.
But opponents said the bill would impose a new, potentially costly federal mandate at a time when health costs and insurance premiums were rising rapidly.
"Every time we increase the cost of health insurance, we throw people into the ranks of the uninsured," said Senator Tim Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas.
Mr. Helms is eager to see the bill become law before he retires in January, and supporters of the measure said they had a better-than-even chance of achieving that objective.
More than 56,000 Americans died last year from colorectal cancer, the second leading cause of cancer deaths, after lung cancer. On June 28, the day before he had a colonoscopy at Camp David, President Bush said, "I do recommend and urge that people get these precautionary tests and take a look." But the administration has not taken a public position on the Kennedy-Helms bill.
Manufacturers of brand-name prescription drugs vehemently oppose the other bill, to give consumers swifter access to generic pharmaceuticals. These companies say the bill would reduce patent protections for new drugs, thus reducing the economic incentives for the discovery of cures and treatments.
But the measure has support from most Democrats and some Republicans. It has also been endorsed by a coalition of consumers, businesses, labor unions, insurers and others who pay the bills for prescription drugs.
Senator Kennedy said drug makers had exploited a 1984 law to secure "near-immortality for drug patents," thus delaying the sale of generic drugs that were just as safe and effective as the brand-name products.
In the absence of any abuses, Ms. Collins said, patents on brand-name drugs with annual sales of $20 billion will expire in the next four years. Consumers could save at least 50 percent of that amount by using generic versions, she said.
The Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said, "We will be taking up prescription drug legislation next week." Democrats and Republicans have very different ideas of how to provide drug benefits under Medicare, and Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, said neither party had the 60 votes needed to ensure victory.
But members of both parties say they want to make drugs more affordable, so the debate may focus initially on proposals to increase access to generic medications and drug products imported from Canada.
Senator Jeff Sessions, Republican of Alabama, said he was "inclined to support" the generic drug bill. D. J. O'Brien, a spokesman for Mr. Hutchinson, said the Arkansas senator was leaning the same way. Both senators are up for re-election.
Under current law, a maker of brand-name drugs can get an automatic 30-month delay in federal approval of generic drugs by filing a lawsuit that alleges infringement of its patents.
The bill, drafted by Senators Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and John McCain, Republican of Arizona, would remove barriers to the marketing of generic drugs by eliminating this automatic delay in most cases.

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE PRESIDENT; 
Bush Calls for End to Loans Of a Type He Once Received

BYLINE:  By JEFF GERTH and RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10 

 BODY:
President Bush received two low-interest loans to buy stock from an oil company where he served as a board member in the late 1980's. He then benefited from the company's relaxation of the terms of one loan in 1989 as he was engaged in the most important business deal of his career.
 On Tuesday, Mr. Bush called for a halt to those types of insider transactions, challenging corporate directors to "put an end to all company loans to corporate officers." 
 The loans from Harken Energy allowed Mr. Bush to acquire 105,000 shares in the company -- 80,000 in late 1986 and 25,000 in 1988 -- through a stock option program that was available to top corporate officials. Harken did not require repayment of the principal for eight years and charged 5 percent annual interest. The prime rate in December 1986, when Mr. Bush received the initial loan, was 7.5 percent. 
He ultimately returned the stock he acquired this way, canceling the loans. Such loans were not uncommon among companies seeking to promote long-term shareholding among executives and directors. 
Dan Bartlett, the White House communications director, said Mr. Bush was not being hypocritical in calling for an end to loans of a kind he once got. He said that while such loans had been properly used by many companies to encourage long-term share ownership, they had in some cases recently been abused.
To finance the stock purchase in 1986, Mr. Bush originally had to assume personal liability for repayment. He pledged as collateral not only the 80,000 shares he got through the options program but also other Harken shares he had gotten for selling his struggling energy company to Harken earlier that year.
In 1989, Harken relaxed the terms of the 1986 loan to remove any "personal liability to yourself," the company's lawyer wrote to Mr. Bush on Oct. 5 of that year. The change had the effect of freeing Mr. Bush's original 212,000-share block of Harken stock, which he sold the next year.
That sale, in June 1990, brought him $848,000, which he used to pay off a $500,000 loan he had taken out to help him buy into the Texas Rangers baseball team, a deal that helped secure his own personal fortune and propel him into Texas politics.
Mr. Bartlett said Mr. Bush never profited from the Harken loans because after Harken changed its stock option program, Mr. Bush returned the shares in exchange for new options that he never exercised.
In view of the recent abuses, Mr. Bartlett said, "President Bush looked at these loans, and the president felt the best way to do it was to draw a bright line; the best way to handle these loans going forward is through a bank." 
The June 1990 Harken stock sale led to an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission -- during his father's administration -- of whether Mr. Bush had knowingly sold the stock in advance of worse-than-expected financial results that temporarily drove down Harken's share price.
The S.E.C. took no action against Mr. Bush. But the issue has dogged him politically for almost a decade and has again come up in recent weeks as accounting and insider trading accusations have dominated the headlines. Democrats have seized on it again in an attempt to draw a contrast in the president's business record and his call for more ethical corporate behavior. 
His demand in a speech to Wall Street on Tuesday for companies to stop making loans to insiders has raised the question of how his toughened standards today would have applied to his own corporate experience.
Harken publicly disclosed the $180,000 in loans to Mr. Bush, to exercise stock options, in its financial statements at the time, but did not publicly disclose the change in the terms of Mr. Bush's 1986 loan.
One issue that has come up again is why Mr. Bush was tardy in filing one of the S.E.C. forms disclosing his 1990 stock sale. The White House has said that it was Harken's responsibility to file the form. At a news conference on Monday, President Bush said, "I still haven't figured it out completely," after saying years ago that the S.E.C. had lost the form.
According to company documents, however, Harken's lawyers sent Mr. Bush two memos in the months before the 1990 stock sale setting out in detail new procedures for filing paperwork with the S.E.C. But one of the two required forms regarding Mr. Bush's sale of the 212,000 shares reached the S.E.C. 34 weeks late -- and while Mr. Bush had signed it, he left the date blank.
Mr. Bartlett said the main point of the memos was to urge Mr. Bush to consult the company's lawyers about any sale of the stock. Mr. Bartlett said Mr. Bush did just that. In deciding not to take any action against Mr. Bush, the S.E.C.'s staff later cited Mr. Bush's consultations with the company's lawyers as an indication that he did not intend to profit from inside information.
Mr. Bartlett said he could not explain why the late form -- known as a Form 4 -- was left undated.
In the case of the sale of his Harken stock, Mr. Bush benefited from the action of an investor who remains unknown even today. The transaction began with a cold call from a broker in early June 1990. Mr. Bush, oldest son of the president of the United States, was then managing general partner of the Rangers.
The broker, Ralph D. Smith of Sutro & Company in Los Angeles, said he was offering to take off Mr. Bush's hands the now unencumbered 212,000 shares of Harken Energy, which had experienced a series of financial setbacks in previous months.
On the face of it, Harken did not seem to be a particularly attractive investment in mid-1990. The company's annual report for 1989, issued in April 1990, showed a loss of $3.3 million, mostly from trading losses. The reported loss for the first quarter of 1990 was $2.18 million, and the company was having trouble with its lenders. In the beginning of May, the stock was near $5. But in the weeks after May 22, when the first-quarter results were announced, the stock traded at $4.12 to $4.62.
Harken's internal analysis of its plight, which company documents show went to Mr. Bush in early June, reported that companies doing business with it were "nervous" about its annual report and cutting back their trade credits. Harken officials tried to soften the bad news by not distributing its disappointing first-quarter report filed with the S.E.C. in May "unless specifically requested," the analysis noted.
But out of the public eye, there was some good news developing. The company was completing an agreement with the wealthy Bass family of Fort Worth to back a venture to drill for oil off the coast of Bahrain, a big opportunity to break into international exploration. Mr. Bush had been briefed on the pending financing agreement, which had not yet been disclosed to investors.
At the time, Mr. Bush wanted to pay off the loan he had taken to finance his stake in the Rangers, and the Harken stock was his biggest asset. But Harken stock was thinly traded; its average daily volume on the New York Stock Exchange was only about 10,000 shares. Until he contacted Mr. Bush on behalf of an anonymous buyer, Mr. Smith said in an interview this week, he could not find anyone willing to sell, either.
So it was in many ways a perfect match of buyer and seller, and two weeks later, after checking with lawyers at Harken, where he was a consultant as well as a director, Mr. Bush completed the deal. 
A dozen years later, it is still not known who bought Mr. Bush's shares, or why the buyer made the offer at that time. Mr. Smith said he would not disclose the buyer's identity except to say that it was an institutional investor. Mr. Smith also said that he was unaware of the pending Bass deal.
The White House said today that Mr. Bush never knew the identity of the buyer. Mr. Bartlett said it was "very far fetched" to assume that the buyer was knowingly helping Mr. Bush at a financially convenient moment for him.
Mr. Bartlett said Mr. Bush's awareness of the progress in securing a deal with the Basses was one reason he sought advice from Harken's lawyers about whether it was permissible for him to sell the stock at that time. Harken stock rose slightly after the announcement of the Bass brothers' investment, and then slid again.
Over the years, Mr. Bush's representatives have cited the likelihood that Harken would soon announce good news about the Bass deal to rebut the implication that Mr. Bush was selling ahead of bad news about the company's earnings. Harken announced the Bass deal on July 23, 1990, a month after Mr. Bush completed the stock sale. The Bahrain exploration venture ultimately ended up drilling nothing but dry holes.
Mr. Bush's involvement in Harken traces back to 1986, when it acquired an oil company he controlled, Spectrum 7 Energy. In return, Mr. Bush got more than 200,000 Harken shares and a seat on the board.
Soon after, Mr. Bush was given a chance to participate in a stock option program that the company's filings describe as being available to its "executive officers," even though Mr. Bush was technically a director and consultant rather than a member of management.
Mr. Bush, like some of the other Harken executives who received shares at the time, chose to pay for them through a promissory note.
According to a letter on April 27, 1987, from Harken's general counsel to Mr. Bush, the note was collateralized by the 80,000 shares he was buying plus the "shares due to you from Harken's acquisition of Spectrum 7 Energy Corporation."
But two years later, the arrangement was changed. No longer was Mr. Bush personally liable for repaying the loan. The only shares he had to pledge as collateral were the 80,000 the loan was allowing him to buy. In effect, Mr. Bush's risk was limited to not profiting on the deal, since he could simply return the shares should they decline in value to less than the loan amount.
In 1993, Harken changed the option plan. In exchange for returning the 105,000 shares he had received under the program, his loans were canceled and he received new options for 42,503 shares. But Mr. Bush left the company at the end of 1993 and never exercised the options.

He finances the purchase through a $96,000 loan from the company at5 percent interest. The loan is collateralized by both the 80,000 shares he is acquiring through the option plus his other Harken shares. 1988 DECEMBER -- Harken awards Mr. Bush 25,000 shares through the option program, which he finances through an $84,000 loan. 1989 Mr. Bush joins a group buying the Texas Rangers baseball team and takes a $500,000 bank loan to help purchase his stake. FALL -- Harken changes the terms of Mr. Bush's 1986 loan. He is no longer personally liable for the loan, and no longer has to pledge as collateral the stock he acquired in selling Spectrum 7 to Harken. This change allows him to sell the 212,000 shares. 1990 JANUARY 19 -- Harken's general counsel sends a memo to Mr. Bush alerting him of stiffer S.E.C. reporting requirements for stock sales by corporate insiders.MAY 23 Harken releases its results for the first quarter and discloses that losses were almost twice those of the same period a year earlier and that it was in trouble with its lenders. EARLY JUNE -- Mr. Bush gets a cold call from a broker offering to buy his 212,000 shares in Harken. Mr. Bush consults with Harken's lawyers about whether it is permissible for him to sell the shares and gets an O.K. JUNE 22 -- Mr. Bush sells the 212,000 shares at $4 each and files one of two required forms with the S.E.C. He uses proceeds to pay off the loan used to purchase the Texas Rangers. AUGUST 20 -- Harken reports worse-than-expected financial results, a $23 million loss for the second quarter. The stock temporarily falls to $2.37 from $3 a share. 1991 FEBRUARY -- Mr. Bush and Harken belatedly file the second of the two required forms with the S.E.C. The commission subsequently begins an insider trading investigation. The commission's staff recommends taking no action. HEADLINE: Bloomberg Signs Budget Bills, Including New Taxes on Phones 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed several bills into law yesterday to help the city balance its budget by raising fees on cellphones and regular telephones, changing the way the city calculates its business tax, and offering early retirement to some city workers. 
 All the measures were part of the $42.3 billion budget agreement that the mayor and the City Council entered into last month. 
 The new laws made having a telephone in New York City more expensive. The city's monthly surcharge (levied to pay for 911 service) on regular telephones will rise to $1 a month from 35 cents a month, generating an additional $35 million a year. 
The city will also add a 911 surcharge of 30 cents a month to cellphone service, which is expected to bring in an additional $8 million a year. The cellphone surcharge comes on top of a state surcharge, recently raised to $1.20 a month from 70 cents a month, to pay for the New York State Police and their 911 system.
Another law will change the way the city calculates its business taxes, so that the federal stimulus bill that President Bush signed into law in March will not end up unintentionally hurting the city's finances. The stimulus law cuts federal business taxes, but since the city's tax has long been calculated based on the federal government's, the law could have ended up cutting the city's business taxes as well.
The law signed yesterday will disconnect the city tax from the federal tax in most of the city, allowing the city to collect an estimated $108 million in additional tax revenues this year. Businesses south of Houston Street, though, will still calculate their taxes the old way, so they will have an additional tax break.
