HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Bush Used Insider Benefits That He Now Wants to Ban
President Bush has called for an end to some of the very insider transactions that he used as a director of Harken Energy in the late 1980's. Mr. Bush received two low-interest loans and then benefited from the company's relaxation of the terms of one loan. On Tuesday, he challenged directors to "put an end to all company loans to corporate officers."
 Dan Bartlett, the White House communications director, discounted suggestions that Mr. Bush was being hypocritical in calling for an end to loans of a kind he once received. Mr. Bartlett said that while such loans had been properly used in the past, they had recently been abused. Page A1. 

The Senate has endorsed broad penalties for corporate officers who cheat investors or harm employee pensions that include prison terms for officers who allow their company to publish misleading financial results. A1.

AT&T Investors Approve Breakup
AT&T shareholders have approved the breakup of what is left of the company. As part of the split, AT&T will spin out its cable operations, which will then be merged into Comcast. The chairman of AT&T, C. Michael Armstrong, left, will become chairman of AT&T Comcast. Floyd Norris: Market Place. C9.

Deutsche Telekom has scheduled a board meeting for next week, a gathering that could determine the fate of its chief executive. C4.

Stocks Continue Their Plunge
The worst bear market in a generation deepened as stocks plunged for the second day. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.4 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged more than 3 percent, and the Nasdaq composite index skidded 2.5 percent. C9.

Qwest Under Federal Investigation
Qwest Communications, the phone service provider, announced that it is under investigation by the Justice Department. C9.

The United States attorney's office in Manhattan will lead the WorldCom investigation, according to government officials and other people involved. C7.

Bottle and Can Bill Aims at Makers
The first Congressional hearings on recycling in at least a decade begin today, with environmental advocates pushing to hold the beverage industry responsible for salvaging the billions of bottles and cans. A16.

Boeing Combines 2 Divisions
The Boeing Company is combining its space and communications business with its military manufacturing unit, a move that will allow the company to better compete for contracts. The division will be roughly equal in size to the company's commercial aviation business and is expected to generate $23 billion in revenue this year. C2.

Wyeth Tries to Reassure Doctors
Wyeth has sent letters to health care providers, seeking to reassure them and their patients about Prempro, used to relieve the symptoms of menopause, after a study of the drug was halted because it found an increase in cancer. A21.

Ad Spending Forecast Is Revised
A widely watched forecaster of ad spending is lowering his estimate for spending growth in 2002. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C8.

Looking for the Regulatory Bite
Something more systemic than a few clever swindlers is staining corporate America. An economists would be inclined to determine whether there are incentives built into the financial system that encourage deception and fraud. A president who wanted to make business trustworthy would focus on those incentives. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "THE AGE OF IMPRESSIONISM: EUROPEAN PAINTING FROM THE ORDRUPGAARD COLLECTION, COPENHAGEN," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 8). Said to be the most important holding of 19th-century French paintings in northern Europe, the Ordrupgaard Collection was assembled in the early 20th century by Wilhelm Hansen (1868-1936), a Danish insurance magnate. With works in depth by Gauguin, Degas, Pissarro, Monet, Renoir and Sisley and treasures by Manet, Matisse, Cezanne and others, the collection, now owned by the state, is ensconced at Hansen's former country home outside of Copenhagen, along with a fine group of paintings by Danish artists of Hansen's day and earlier. At the Met, the Danish and French collections are shown in separate galleries. The larger French section has true delights, among them a lively fauve still life by Matisse from 1909, a rare Polynesian-flavored Gauguin portrait of 1896 and a great Pissarro representation, including a powerful evocation of springtime painted at his home in Eragny, France, in 1894. The most interesting of the Danish artists is Vilhelm Hammershoi, the last of the great 19th-century Danish painters, whose spare, somber interiors and portraits -- untouched by modernism -- have recently returned to critical consciousness. Altogether, the 84 paintings on view make a real banquet. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

"THE ARTIST'S EYE: JANE FREILICHER AS CURATOR," National Academy of Design Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Sept. 22). The academy's sixth artist-selected show has been chosen by Jane Freilicher, whose reserved yet opulently colored landscapes and still lifes might be said to mediate the shrinking gap between the academic and the progressive. To some extent this show explores that gap: its 50 paintings are weighted toward portraits and landscapes and juxtaposed with unusual subtleness and intelligence. They form an engrossing meditation on subject matter, the painter's craft and the history of the academy. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; $4.50 for students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

* "CHANGING HANDS: ART WITHOUT RESERVATION," American Craft Museum, 40 West 53rd Street, (212) 956-3535 (through Sept. 20). In this feast of a show, about 90 American Indian artists -- established and emerging -- from the Southwest exhibit weavings, pottery, jewelry, glass, sculpture, paintings and tableware. Chosen for their venturesome challenges to the traditional and the tribal, the artists advance the show's goal: to help redefine contemporary Indian work as art rather than artifacts. An outstanding contribution is made by the jewelers, like L. Eugene Nelson of Albuquerque, whose intricate, finely engineered brooch uses traditional Indian silver and stones but is modeled on a computer chip. In pottery, another stellar category, two big earthenware vessels by Jacquie Stevens evoke the baskets of her Winnebago ancestry, yet have an elegant modern look that has been influenced by the shapes and colors of contemporary art. This is the first of three shows that will explore the current state of the arts in pre-European American societies; with this one, the series is off to a promising start. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission, $7.50; $4, students and 65+ (Glueck).

* "THOMAS EAKINS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 15). It remains nearly impossible to see America, or at least to look back on the country in the 19th century, without some refraction through Eakins's art. He painted, hands down, the finest 19th-century American painting, "The Gross Clinic," which by itself justifies leaving your home right now and visiting the Met. His sentiments always ran deep below the surface, but they bubbled up in ways even he didn't necessarily seem to realize, or didn't want to acknowledge. The strong current of homoeroticism throughout his work is the obvious example. The show comes with two discoveries: that Eakins occasionally projected photographs with the aid of a magic lantern and traced the projections; and that he often began paintings by putting down bright colors, but then added subtle glazes of brown or black to give the pictures evenness and sobriety, a process overlooked or misunderstood by restorers in the past. Both discoveries help us see afresh this classic figure, who seems as interesting for being uneven and unpredictable as he is for his familiar commitment to unvarnished reality. His most American quality, in the end, may not be his scientific sensibility or pioneering choice of subjects or any other cliche of nationalism, but this combination of dogged, plain-spoken, almost puritanical realism with a simmering, unconventional character. Hours and admission: See above (Michael Kimmelman).

* "GAUGUIN IN NEW YORK COLLECTIONS: THE LURE OF THE EXOTIC," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Oct. 20). The first major New York exhibition devoted to Gauguin in four decades isn't major-major by Met blockbuster standards: more than half of the 120 pieces are drawings and prints. But these are pretty spectacular, and they are joined by some two dozen paintings, including coral-and-mango-colored visions of a mythical South Pacific that are among the most beautiful images created by any modern artist. Only the Met has the resources to put this kind of material together, though if you want to get a real sense of the not-so-nice artist himself, check out the new critical biography by Nancy Mowll Mathews, "Paul Gauguin: An Erotic Life." Hours and admission: See above (Holland Cotter).

* "MEXICO CITY: AN EXHIBITION ABOUT THE EXCHANGE RATES OF BODIES AND VALUES," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through September). Mexico City has an extremely happening art scene. This exhibition of largely conceptual pieces by 17 young artists either born or based there looks sparse and uneven as it has been installed, but it is full of interesting -- in one case deeply disturbing and ethically challenging -- work. Anyone expecting an upbeat, fiesta atmosphere will be disappointed: the predominant subjects here are poverty, decay and human predation, with moments of tenderness and humor glinting through. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2 for students and 62+ (Cotter).

* THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART, QUEENS, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400. People in Queens are now finally free to complain the way obnoxious Manhattanites have always done about the bridge and tunnel crowd bringing their Prada sandals for a walk on weekends and spoiling the neighborhood. The Modern's new temporary home (until 2005) has finally opened in the former Swingline staple factory with part of its permanent collection of paintings and sculpture on view along with a few summer shows, including a contemporary survey called "Tempo." The galleries approximate the classic industrial loft aesthetic, efficient and airless, like the inside of a storage center, which is exactly what this building is, but touching for Cezannes, Seurats and Braques, which suddenly look fresh and by contrast seem to pop off the movable bare white walls. The shows include "Autobodies," five gorgeous automobiles from the museum's collection, and a display of Rudy Burckhardt's little-known photographs of Queens in the late 1930's and early 1940's, a perfect tribute to the museum's new locale. "Tempo," a wide-ranging, global-minded, erratically engaging and fuzzily conceived effort, is supposed to have something to do with movement, change, impermanence, the museum's migration and modernism's condition, I suppose. It's all vague, but approached modestly it's fine, with good art and bad. The trip to the museum couldn't be easier on the No. 7 subway. Now you can tell everyone you're chic. You've been to Queens. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; to 7:45 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+; free for members and children under 12 with an adult (Kimmelman).

"CLAES OLDENBURG DRAWINGS, 1959-77" AND "CLAES OLDENBURG WITH COOSJE VAN BRUGGEN DRAWINGS, 1992-98," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Sept. 15). One of the most original draftsmen around is Claes Oldenburg, whose early sculptures of everyday objects in the 1960's helped to define the Pop art movement. His startling ability to perceive subtle visual relationships among objects and to morph them from one incarnation or state to another is on view in 92 drawings now owned by the Whitney, including 18 done in collaboration with his wife, Coosje van Bruggen. The show is said to be the largest ever mounted of Mr. Oldenberg's works on paper. The drawings, anthropomorphic, often erotic and always full of life, are brilliantly rendered in the cheerfully loose yet energetic Oldenburg style that gives inanimate objects a kind of body language, or attitude, if you will. He is at the top of his form in the proposals for monuments he began in the 1960's, like the gigantic ironing board looming over the Lower East Side of Manhattan (1965) and the cathedral in the form of a colossal faucet for Lake Union, Seattle (1972). But altogether the show is a fine celebration of the Oldenburg wizardry in extracting the extraordinary from the everyday. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Glueck).

* "THE PAINTINGS OF JOAN MITCHELL," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676. Through Sept. 29. The impact of Mitchell's works, especially the later ones (she died of lung cancer 10 years ago, at 66), is so immediately intoxicating that a natural reaction is to distrust the art. Abstract paintings this suave and sure-footed must be glib and manipulative, you may be excused for telling yourself. Distrust your distrust. Lush, opulent fields of colors, seemingly all paradisiacal, contain shades of melancholy that reveal themselves to you after your eyes adjust to their light. Mitchell absorbed the influences of Pollock, Gorky, Kline and de Kooning. There are ferocious paintings of clotted splatters in the 1950's. Then hovering shapes appear in muted green, gray and blue in the 60's. They give way by the early 70's to more vividly colored multipanel paintings in which increasing varieties of shapes and lines jostle. Mitchell, who had moved to France, denied the influence of Monet, which was undeniable. Her last works, from the 80's and early 90's, push Monet into the late 20th century, ecstatically. Hours and admissions: see above. Other Mitchell shows are at Cheim & Read, 547 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-7727, through Aug. 16; Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, Suite 308, SoHo, (212) 941-0012, through Aug. 16; Edward Tyler Nahem Fine Art, at 56 East 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 517-2453, through Aug. 9; and Tibor de Nagy, at 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, 12th floor, (212) 262-5050, through July 26. (Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

* JOHN GRAHAM, Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through July 31). Graham's mystic grandiosity came to fruition in the faux-antique portraits of cock-eyed women in the 40's and 50's, for which he is justly famous today. Four of these strange and loony works -- two on canvas, two on paper -- eclipse all the examples of Graham's earlier, more conventionally Modernist work in this intriguing four-decade survey (Ken Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

"LINGER," Artemis, Greenberg Van Doren, 730 Fifth Avenue, (212) 445-0444 (through July 26). This cheerfully diverse summer show includes a serenely reflective painting by Roy Lichtenstein, a transparent flag on a clear pole by Sze Lin Pang, super-real weeds by Tony Matelli, a bursting postcard by Jim Hodges, an assemblage of Matissean cut-metal shapes by George Sugarman, a tree made of sticks and pebbles by Gedi Sibony, cosmic diamond-shaped paintings by Dorothea Rockburne and more (Johnson).

CARLOS MERIDA, Ramis Barquet, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-9090 (through Aug. 2). Merida, the Modernist painter, was born in Guatemala in 1891, studied in Paris and lived most of his life in Mexico City. This small retrospective follows his evolution across eight decades from a Picasso-influenced 1915 portrait of a woman to playful, mid-century grid compositions to a Cubist quartet devoted to the four seasons made three years before the artist's death at 93 (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* OLAF BREUNING, "Hello Darkness," Swiss Institute, 495 Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 925-2035 (through Aug. 3). Though considerably racier, the tableau that Mr. Breuning has produced here is a lot like what you see in the front yards of creative suburbanites on Halloween. After passing through a ruined library, you come upon the primal scene, illuminated by spinning and strobing colored lights: a skeleton conversing with an extraordinarily realistic sex doll lounging in a deluxe coffin. It's ludicrous but briefly gripping (Johnson).

"WHERE IS ELVIS? THE MAN AND HIS REFLECTIONS," Howard Greenberg Gallery, 120 Wooster Street, (212) 334-0010 (through Aug. 16). This year is the 25th anniversary of Elvis Presley's death in 1977 at 42, a cause for this far-flung and upbeat roundup of nearly 75 photos shot at various times by different photographers. Elvis kissing Mom, Elvis in the Army, Elvis and his Cadillac, Elvis on his Harley, Elvis and his fans, Elvis and his dates, Elvis doing "Blue Suede Shoes" with the Dorsey brothers, Elvis's gold piano, Elvis imitators (including Jerry Seinfeld), Elvis with the blues guitarist B. B. King and a lineup of Elvis dolls all figure in these photographs by such lenspersons as Norma Bergsma, David Byrne, William Eggleston, Marvin Israel and Alfred Wertheimer. Perhaps the most poignant is a 1956 action shot by Roger Marshutz taken in Tupelo, Miss., that shows the powerful communion between the icon and his fans as he straddles the microphone to belt out a song, touching their outstretched hands with his own. Take heart, Elvis seekers. As long as photography lives, old superstars will never fade away (Glueck).

Galleries: Chelsea

"THE ACCELERATED GRIMACE," Daniel Silverstein, 520 West 21st Street, (212) 929-4300 (through July 20). This busy, happily pluralistic exhibition organized by David Hunt generates a gratifying delirium. Bill Walker draws celebrities; Richard Stipl presents 12 wonderful little grimacing wax heads; Adam Henry paints a coolly sardonic vision of a modern museum overflowing with information; Diana Shpungin and Nicole Englemann slap each other silly in a speeded-up video; and the sculptors Andrea Cohen and Elise Ferguson each explore zany possibilities of formal proliferation (Johnson).

"GROUP SHOW," Sandra Gering, 534 West 22nd Street, (646) 336-7183 (through Aug. 30). This well-selected and installed exhibition includes Julian Opie's Neo-Pop landscapes, which look like children's book illustrations; Craig Kauffman's sensuous, baby blue plastic doughnut; Richard Deacon's metal sculptures, resembling flattened pillows; a large Minimalist panel of thin mirror strips by John Armleder; and the image of an inflatable flower converted into a flat, shiny stainless steel cutout by Jeff Koons (Johnson).

"I-BEAM," Cynthia Broan, 423 West 14th Street, (212) 633-6525 (through July 27). The grid as form and metaphor connects the diverse parts of this lively 10-artist show. Highlights include Diana Cooper's intense small doodles; a hallucinatory painting of logs and branches by Dan Kopp; a glossily futuristic abstraction by Jay Davis; playful collages with cut-out windows and rounded borders by Ruth Root; and Graham Parks's sleek, flattened paintings of modernist buildings (Johnson).

"INTERIOR/EXTERIOR," Nicole Klagsbrun, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3335 (through July 31). This understated selection of photographic approaches, mostly to indoor and outdoor architecture, includes a diptych from Dan Graham's essay on popular building styles; blurry pinhole camera shots of ancient Roman remains by Rodney Graham; gleaming corporate spaces by John Pilson; palatial interiors by Candida Hofer; and small, richly atmospheric studio pictures by Saul Fletcher (Johnson).

* KATHLEEN JOHNSON, "The Smallest Wonder," Lucas Schoormans, 508 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3159 (through Aug. 9.) Shimmering, wavy lines of light cascade down blue, underwater swimming pool steps in Ms. Johnson's large-format, panoramic photograhs. The transformation of something so ordinary to something almost mystically radiant is exhilarating (Johnson).

* BRUCE NAUMAN. "Mapping the Studio I (Fat Chance John Cage)," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22nd Street, through July 27: "Mapping the Studio II (Fat Chance John Cage)," Sperone Westwater Gallery, 415 West 13th Street, West Village, through July 27. Even some Bruce Nauman fans I've heard from find these videos stupefyingly dull, but they may turn out to be among his most important works. The original 5-hour, 45-minute version has occupied a vast Dia gallery all year: seven DVD's projected around the walls of the room, showing Mr. Nauman's studio from different angles. The work is shot with a cheap video camera at night, in darkness, by infrared light. What you see are real-time gray-green images edited down from months of shooting. Almost nothing happens. You hear on soundtracks the drone of an air-conditioner, the wind and a distant train whistle. The second version at Sperone has colors added (sickly reds, greens and blues, which slowly phase from one image to the next), with the images also flipping upside down, then right side up every several minutes. The grinding pace gradually sinks into your bones, as is the case with Mr. Nauman's early videos in which he neurotically paced around his studio, but here the desolation is grander because the place is empty. The work overwhelms you with the anxiety, and expectation, that an artist must feel in a studio, alone, desperately waiting for an idea (Kimmelman).

"PHOTO-TRANSCENDENT," Bose Pacia, 508 West 26th Street, (212) 989-7074, (through July 20). Organized by Peter Nagy, this show focuses on artists who use international photographic conventions to explore and to transcend Indian experience. Rajeev Lochan makes big, lush, hand-colored cityscapes that have a painterly richness; Lewis Koch pairs conventional scenic photographs with photographs of pages from literary and academic books to poetic effect; and from the Casa Documentation Center, there's a selection of vernacular, commercial studio portraits that are at once strange and banal (Johnson).

CHUCK RAMIREZ; MEG LANGHORNE, Dee/Glasoe, 545 West 20th Street, (212) 924-7545 (through July 26). Mr. Ramirez makes big photographs of emptied chocolate box interiors, turning plastic gold Godiva and Whitmans containers into Pop icons of quasi-ecclesiastical splendor; Ms. Langhorne has created a wading pool in the rear gallery afloat with wax flowers -- a "retromantic oasis," in the words of the gallery news release (Johnson).

RICHARD SHARPE SHAVER, "Weird and Wonderful Art," Christine Burgin, 243 West 18th Street, (212) 462-2668 (through Aug. 2). Less an artist than a man possessed by nutty ideas, Shaver (1907-1975) believed that images suggested by seemingly natural patterns on ordinary rocks proved the existence of titans who lived on earth before human beings. This exhibition presents a selection of Shaver's quasi-scientific rock photographs, examples of his writings and paintings teeming with blond, red-lipped figures shaded and textured so that they look as though carved from stone (Johnson).

* PHOEBE WASHBURN, LFL, 531 West 26th Street, (212) 631-7705 (through July 26). Ms. Washburn's impressive site-specific construction overwhelms the gallery like a small tidal wave of urban refuse. Made of thousands of lengths of cardboard and drywall screws, it slopes from an upper corner of the room, whirls around a hole in the center and engulfs the gallery desk. Besides the imposing physicality there is an evocative tension between uncontrolled growth and architectural containment (Johnson).

TENESH WEBBER, Yossi Milo, 552 West 24th Street, (212) 414-0370 (through July 26). Ms. Webber's large black-and-white photographs verge on Minimalist abstraction. She shoots simple suspended objects and manipulates negatives in the darkroom to produce photogram-like images of lights spiraling in nocturnal space or layered patterns of stretched string. They are elegant but would benefit from a more adventurous imagination (Johnson).

Galleries: Brooklyn

"FIT," Schroeder Romero, 173A North Third Street, Williamsburg, (718) 486-8992 (through July 28). It is hard to see how the six artists in this exhibition fit together, but it's a good show, anyway. It includes a coolly absurd fabric and metal construction, like a giant vacuum cleaner, by Jack Risley; David Henderson's sensuously smoothed fragments of laminated plywood; Lisa Hein's clever update of Duchamp's last work; Elana Herzog's optically surprising play with staples and fabric; Julia Kunin's little octopi, cast in colored glass; and Bob Seng's 1960's-style wall displacement (Johnson).

"TRACT: SYSTEMATIC SPRAWL," Plus Ultra, 235 South First Street, Williamsburg, (718) 387-3844 (through July 21). This tight little five-artist show is the opposite of sprawling. Each artist pursues the tension between expansion and containment. Rachel Urkowitz paints chromatically subtle shadows; Erick Johnson interweaves sharp bands and arcs of muted color; Tricia Keightley paints a Neo-Pop proliferation of old and new graphics; Guillermo Creus envisions surrealistic viscera; and a half-circle of mirrored tesserae by Louis Cameron bounces sparkly light onto the wall (Johnson).

Other Galleries

YOSHITAKA AMANO, Leo Koenig, 249 Centre Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 334-9255 (through Aug. 3). A superstar of Japanese anime, Mr. Amano is the creator of "Speed Racer," "G-Force" and "Final Fantasy." This show features glossy, cartoon portraits of androgynous young action heroes and a near mural-size painting crammed with every "Final Fantasy" character. Best is a series of brush and ink paintings on paper, each representing a different emotionally excited human eye (Johnson).

"MODEL CITIZENS," Roger Smith, 501 Lexington Avenue, at 47th Street, (212) 832-8831 (through July 27). Four artists explore black femininity. Tony Gray's insouciantly seductive paintings depict giant forest-dwelling "Black Fairies" with butterfly wings. Wangechi Mutu's apocalyptic collages envision knife-wielding, wounded, bikini-clad female warriors. Lennon Jno Baptiste's graphically deft pictures meditate on the semiotics of black beauty, and Nicole Awai imbeds pop heroines in kaleidoscopic spaces (Johnson).

Last Chance

"EMPIRE/STATE: ARTISTS ENGAGING GLOBALIZATION," Whitney Museum of American Art Independent Study Program at the Art Gallery of the Graduate Center, the City University of New York, 365 Fifth Avenue, at 34th Street, (212) 431-1737 (through Sunday). This group show, spread over two galleries in the ground floor gallery of the Graduate Center, uses physically austere means to address the big, tangled-up issue of the unequal global distribution of political and economic power. Some of the artists have been creating trenchant political art for years (Peter Fend, Martha Rosler, Allan Sekula); others are welcome as relatively new faces, among them Francois Bucher, Emily Jacir, Josh On/Futurefarmers and Alex Rivera. (Cotter)

"RALPH FASANELLA'S AMERICA," New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, (212) 873-3400 (through Sunday). A labor activist turned self-taught painter, Fasanella (1914-97) was perhaps the most celebrated American "outsider" artist after Grandma Moses. He packed everything into his paintings of city people, places and events: strikes, storefronts, skyscrapers, tenements, festivals, churches, religious rituals, political rallies and his own past. This large selection of his brightly colored, busy and often repetitive canvases -- persuasive illustration, not heavyweight art -- traces how Fasanella's working-class background and radical political beliefs affected his painting. One of his major efforts, toward the end of his life, was a series of seven paintings documenting the 1912 textile strike in Lawrence, Mass.; known as the Bread and Roses strike, it was the first big textile strike in America. At its best, Fasanella's work is a triumph of perseverance, faith and propaganda: unlike other populist portrayers of the American scene, he can never be accused of coating it with sugar. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for students and 65+ (Glueck).

* "PRICELESS CHILDREN: AMERICAN PHOTOGRAPHS 1890-1925/CHILD LABOR AND THE PICTORIALIST IDEAL," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through tomorrow). Around the turn of the century there was Lewis Hine, who photographed children toiling in mills and factories. And then there were the Pictorialists, led by Alfred Stieglitz, who took charming, romantic pictures of children in the toils of middle-class privilege. Which children were better off? The question is posed but not glibly answered in this insightful show, which juxtaposes for the first time Hine's sociological approach to photography with that of the aesthetically oriented Pictorialists, represented here by Gertrude Kasebier, Fred Holland Day, Clarence White, Edward Weston and Edward Steichen as well as Stieglitz. It makes the point that both Hine and the Pictorialists portrayed children in stereotypical ways. Some editing would help, but the show is absorbing (Glueck).

"STUDIES AND SKETCHES: HENRY DARGER," American Folk Art Museum's Eva and Morris Feld Gallery, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue near 66th Street, (212) 595-9533 (through Sunday). This small, muted show is a supplement to the larger installation of Darger's collage-paintings at the museum's new home on 53rd Street and gives a good sense of how those paintings were created. Darger mainly composed by tracing directly from comic strips, coloring books, newspaper advertisements and magazine illustrations Hours: Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Cotter).

* "TESTIMONY: VERNACULAR ART OF THE AFRICAN-AMERICAN SOUTH," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-4818 (through tomorrow). Another blow to the division between insider and outsider art, this exhibition includes engaging works by artists like Thornton Dial Sr., Ronald Lockett, J. B. Murry, Howard Spelling and Jimmie Lee Sudduth. They slide between painting, collage, automatic drawing and found-object relief with the greatest of ease, paralleling and supplementing some of 20th-century modernism's main moves (Smith).

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
A Restored German Classic of Futuristic Angst

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT

 BODY:
On Jan. 10, 1927, Fritz Lang's "Metropolis," a wildly ambitious, hugely expensive science fiction allegory of filial revolt, romantic love, alienated labor and dehumanizing technology opened at the Ufa Palast theater in Berlin. Lang's film, of course, went on to become one of the touchstones of 20th-century cinema, exhaustively studied and endlessly imitated, but apart from its brief theatrical run in Berlin and Nuremberg 75 years ago, the movie as Lang made it has never really been seen.
 What happened to "Metropolis" is, in some ways, a familiar movie-industry story of a studio's interference with an artist's work. (Or, if you prefer to side with the studios, of a filmmaker's profligate indifference to economic necessity and audience response.) A few weeks after the premiere, Ufa, the studio that had produced the film, pulled it from theaters and cut out 7 of the original 12 reels. 
 Paramount, the American distributor, went even further, engaging a playwright, Channing Pollock, to compose English title cards and to reshape the story to fit his own tastes. "I have given it my meaning," Pollock boasted. Lang was so appalled that he swore he would never go to the United States, a vow he broke a few years later, when Hitler proved to be a much graver threat to his art (to say nothing of his life) than Hollywood could ever be. 
Much of the grandeur and strangeness of "Metropolis" survived Paramount's butchery and the further desecration perpetrated in 1984 by Giorgio Moroder, who added color tints to Karl Freund's eerie Expressionist black-and-white cinematography and replaced Gottfried Huppertz's lush, Wagnerian score with the music of pop stars like Freddy Mercury and Bonnie Tyler.
Had Lang lived to see the age of the "director's cut" DVD, he might have responded to those transgressions and reconstructed a definitive "Metropolis." But now we have something nearly as good. Thanks to four years of painstaking work by Martin Koerber, a German film preservationist, and Alpha-Omega, a Munich company specializing in digital restoration, there is now, at long last, a "Metropolis" with a legitimate claim to being definitive.
Film Forum on Houston Street may lack the decadent Weimar glamour of the Ufa Palast, but it does serve the best movie house popcorn in Manhattan and, for the next two weeks, will be showing the latest version of "Metropolis" in a spotless 35-millimeter print with a new recording of Huppertz's score.
Much has been retrieved -- more than 1,300 feet of film have been added since the last rerelease, in 1987 -- and the English titles have been translated anew. There is also a second set of title cards, printed in a plainer font, without multiple exclamation points, to indicate scenes that are still missing. A subplot involving a character called the Thin Man, a mysterious monk and visions inspired by the Book of Revelation remains tantalizingly sketchy, but Lang's visual audacity and thematic ambition are breathtakingly apparent, as is his astonishing sense of scale, which enabled him to swoop from terrifying sublimity to piercing, quiet intimacy with a single cut.
Pollock complained that, in Lang's version, "symbolism ran such riot that people who saw it couldn't tell what the picture was all about." He was not altogether wrong: Christianity, German romanticism, modernism and Marxism stampede through the movie like the crowds of angry workers and bourgeois revelers in the apocalyptic climax, but the confusion that results ultimately resolves into hallucinatory, visionary clarity. Only by pushing himself to the very edge of coherence was Lang able to transcend the schematic moralizing that keeps so much science fiction tethered, ultimately, to the mundane.
This is not to slight either the emotional impact or the political resonance of Lang's fever-dream of the future. Quite the contrary: "Metropolis" retains its power to overwhelm, trouble and move because it is connected to the deep anxieties of modern life as if by a high-voltage cable. The story of the scientist Rotwang (Rudolf Klein-Rogge), a modern Pygmalion designing a female robot to replace his lost love, stands between "Frankenstein" and "A.I." as an expression of the defining modern preoccupation with machines that blur the boundary between the human and the mechanical.
The early scene of workers trudging into the dark maw of their underground factory has been copied to death (most recently in "Road to Perdition"), but it remains unsurpassed as an image of how mechanized work for another's profit can strip people of their individuality. Later, as the mob of workers smashes the factory and unleashes a flood of anarchy on the city, we see an equally chilling image of the senseless destruction that revolt against exploitation can produce.
In 1927, "Metropolis" was attacked by the German left as implicitly fascistic, and by the right for its Communist tendencies. But one of the curiosities of the film is that its aesthetic extremity serves a mild and moderate ideology. The city, run by the suave industrialist Joh Fredersen, is a drastically polarized place, with lush gardens and soaring skyscrapers above ground and infernal slums below.
In the depths, a young woman, Maria (Brigitte Helm, the Kirsten Dunst of the Weimar Republic), prophesies the coming of a messianic figure called the Mediator, whose name sums up the temperate, reformist message buried in the movie's sweep and bombast. The Mediator turns out to be Freder Fredersen (Gustav Frohlich), the boss's sensitive son, whose infatuation with Maria leads him to a moral awakening.
His ultimate triumph is delayed by obstacles and digressions too numerous and wonderful for mere prose, and the audience is distracted from the film's moral by its elements of horror, mystery, burlesque and romance. Far from a historical curio, "Metropolis" arrives, three-quarters of a century late, like an artifact from the future. At last we have the movie every would-be cinematic visionary has been trying to make since 1927.
"Metropolis" opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village. Tickets: $9.75; $5 for members and 65+ weekdays before 5 p.m. Box office: (212) 727-8110.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Brigitte Helm in Fritz Lang's "Metropolis," with most of many cuts restored, the English title cards retranslated and the score rerecorded. (Kino International)

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Edged Higher Last Month 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11 

 BODY:
Wholesale prices nudged up 0.1 percent in June, the Labor Department reported today, the first increase in three months, lifted by higher costs for gasoline, cars and trucks. Jobless claims climbed to a six-week high. 
 The advance in the Producer Price Index, which matched expectations, came after wholesale prices dropped 0.2 percent in April and 0.4 percent in May, the department reported. 
 Even with June's small increase, the report suggested that inflation remained under control.
But after being flat in May, the "core" rate of wholesale inflation, which excludes energy and food prices, rose 0.2 percent in June. That was double the forecast.
In June, energy prices were flat, after dropping 2.3 percent in May, the report said. Gasoline prices rose 1 percent, residential electricity prices increased 0.7 percent and natural gas prices rose 0.5 percent. Those higher costs were tempered by a 0.6 percent decline in the price of heating oil. 
Car prices increased 0.4 percent in June and prices for light trucks, like sport utility vehicles, rose 0.5 percent, the biggest increase since February. Food prices edged up 0.1 percent, after falling 0.2 percent in May. 
In another report, new claims for unemployment insurance increased last week by a bigger-than-expected 16,000, to a seasonally adjusted 403,000, the highest level since May 25, the Labor Department said. It was the first increase in three weeks.
Economists predicted claims would move higher in part because car plants temporarily shut down around this time each year to retool for new models. Some textile plants often temporarily close in July.
The more stable four-week moving average, which smooths out weekly fluctuations, edged up to 395,000 last week, suggesting that the job market continues to be sluggish.

HEADLINE: Bill Seeks Openness at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac 

BYLINE:  By ALISON LEIGH COWAN 

 BODY:
Some members of Congress are seeking to force two government-sponsored entities, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, to adhere to the same disclosure rules that bind most public companies. Though their proposal has obvious intellectual appeal, it may not accomplish all they are seeking, given the example of a similar entity that already complies with most of those rules, Farmer Mac.
 Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, charged by Congress with building the secondary market for home loans, are the sole focus of the proposed legislation. Their exemption from all Securities and Exchange Commission requirements strikes GE Capital and other competitors as unfair. A bill sponsored in March by Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut, and Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, would revoke the exemption. 
 Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac contend that they already divulge much of what the S.E.C. expects, if not more, albeit on a voluntary basis.
A look at Farmer Mac's disclosure in recent years suggests that forcing these companies to file with the S.E.C. may not improve what investors are told. Of all the government-sponsored enterprises, only Farmer Mac, whose official name is the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation, is now obliged to submit annual reports, quarterly filings and proxy statements to the S.E.C. -- all but registration statements.
Even so, Farmer Mac disclosed less in 2001 than it did in 2000 in at least three instances. In discussions with investors and a reporter in recent weeks, the company has argued that its public filings comply with all applicable securities regulations.
The most important area where less information is now available concerns disclosure of Farmer Mac's use of interest rate swaps, a type of derivative in which one party swaps fixed-rate payments and gets floating-rate payments in return. Farmer Mac relies heavily on them in its efforts to build a secondary market for farm loans. Yet, in 2001 Farmer Mac ceased publication of a table in its annual report about these instruments. What remains are two paragraphs that are long on definitions but short on numbers. As a result, the company no longer discloses the notional amount of its derivative position, which was $1.1 billion in 2000. That figure is only the starting point that analysts and regulators use to understand how much systemic risk is posed by a company or its financing or trading partners, known as counterparties.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, in contrast, publish the notional amount of their derivative positions and disclose more information about their various counterparties. 
Asked in late April whether it would follow the example being set by the larger government-sponsored enterprises on derivatives, specifically Fannie Mae, Farmer Mac issued a statement saying: "Fannie Mae is not subject to S.E.C. disclosure requirements, whereas Farmer Mac is. Farmer Mac completely and accurately discloses all information required of it by the securities laws and regulations. As long as that distinction exists, we expect there will be differences between Fannie Mae's disclosures and our own." 
Asked last week why the company had dropped a table about interest rate swaps, a spokesman for Farmer Mac, Robert Siegfried of the public relations firm Kekst & Company, said accounting rules for derivatives changed in 2001 and that the current presentation complied with all accounting and S.E.C. requirements. 
A spokesman for the S.E.C., John Heine, said he could not "discuss specific filings." But he referred to Congressional testimony in which a commission official explained how the agency used a screening process to determine which filings to review.
The majority are not reviewed at all, said Peter Romeo, a securities lawyer with Hogan & Hartson who was a longtime S.E.C. official. He is pushing to have Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac file to the S.E.C., but acknowledged that there was no guarantee that the agency would make inspection of government-sponsored companies a priority amid so many cases of corporate corruption. "They are truly under siege right now and have been ever since Enron," he said of the S.E.C. "So it wouldn't surprise me that something with respect to Farmer Mac would get a lower priority."
Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the S.E.C., also has professional ties to Farmer Mac. While that relationship is not likely to affect the agency's decision on whether to review a specific filing, it could ultimately affect the commission's ability to pursue an enforcement action if needed.
Mr. Pitt was one of Farmer Mac's outside lawyers when he was in private practice at Fried Frank Harris Shriver & Jacobson. The relationship goes back at least to 1994, around the time Farmer Mac brought him in to explain to its overseers at the Farm Credit Administration why it was restating some earnings figures.
Asked whether that history might affect S.E.C. decisions on Farmer Mac, Mr. Heine referred to a letter from Mr. Pitt pledging to recuse himself from any decisions concerning former clients until Aug. 4, the first anniversary of his appointment to the commission.
Farmer Mac has pared its disclosure in areas other than derivatives as well. For instance, the company ceased disclosing in 2001 how much of its guarantee fees came from securities retained in its portfolio. In 2000, 26 percent of the company's $11.7 million in guarantee income was money Farmer Mac paid itself.
A change in accounting rules as of April 1, 2001, forced companies to begin classifying all future income of this sort as interest income. But no information was given on how much of last year's $15.8 million of guarantee fees included in-house payments. "We are not currently disclosing that number as a separate line item," the company said in a statement some weeks ago. Last week, Mr. Siegfried of Kekst added that soon-to-be released second-quarter earnings would contain some information.
Farmer Mac has also skimped on some of the detail it once furnished about the kinds of farm loans it guarantees and their geographic concentration. In 1996, the breakdowns included 10 types of crops or livestock and 10 regions. These days, the company lumps the information into three commodity groups and six regions. Mr. Siegfried explained that because farmers sometimes switch crops, "it was better not to hang things on specific crops."
But he did not explain why geographic detail was consolidated -- after all, few farmers completely relocate. Andrea Calise, a colleague of Mr. Siegfried at Kekst, said Farmer Mac considered the new format easier for investors to analyze.
Lastly, in defending what it paid insiders last year, the company's April 2002 proxy statement cited the advice of a "nationally recognized independent" compensation consultant no fewer than seven times, without naming the firm. In past years, the company had identified the firm. The company said it had complied with securities laws, but when pressed said the consulting company was Hewitt Associates.
Robert McCarson, director of corporate communications for Fannie Mae, is not surprised that some S.E.C. registrants manage to be stingy with information. "This rush to force Fannie and Freddie to register with the S.E.C. is a flawed argument because it's not a panacea," he said. "Enron was an S.E.C. registrant, and so was Worldcom."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
New Pessimism On '02 Revival Is Pervading Silicon Valley

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 

 BODY:
Hopes that the second half of 2002 would see the end of technology's business decline seem to be retreating.
 Not so long ago, a range of Silicon Valley chief executives were holding out the prospect of a recovery led by purchases of personal computers and other electronic devices. As recently as the beginning of June, the semiconductor giant Intel was telling investors that it expected a "seasonally strong" second half of the year. 
 But recent days have instead seen new caution among some executives and analysts. Dell Computer said today that its second-quarter revenue and profit would be higher than expected, not because the market was growing but because it was "continuing to gain market share in the midst of weak overall demand." 
And last week, Advanced Micro Devices, Intel's chip competitor, cut its revenue projections for the second time in two weeks, citing weakness in its microprocessor line, which is heavily dependent on consumer purchases of personal computers. Its newest revenue expectations were $600 million, down from an original $900 million.
"The challenge for us is unlike our competitor, which has an enterprise business," an A.M.D. spokesman, Morris Denton, said. "It's early to make predictions, but we haven't started to see the early signs from back-to-school, which would indicate that we're coming out of the decline."
Some analysts are seeing weakness beyond the chip market. Merrill Lynch's personal computer analyst, Steven M. Fortuna, last week lowered his revenue expectations for Dell for the second half of 2002 by $800 million. He also changed his forecast to project a revenue decline in the personal computer industry of 6.7 percent for the year, with average unit prices down 9 percent compared with 2001.
National Semiconductor, another of the Valley's large chip companies, was downgraded last week by Jonathan Joseph of Salomon Smith Barney, who expressed worry in a note to investors that the cellphone market might be softening.
Eroding consumer confidence could be a particular blow to the semiconductor industry, which had been projecting a second-half turnaround as recently as last month. The Semiconductor Industry Association reported continued strength in non-PC chip markets like flash memory and digital signal processors, that are dependent on the consumer market.
To be sure, many longtime experts in the Valley said they still expected a turnaround by the end of the year, but they are becoming increasingly cautious.
"I think by the end of the year we're going to see rising employment," said Steven Levy, an economist at the Center for the Continuing Study of the California Economy in Palo Alto, Calif., "but there is all of this wild card stuff." And Michael Murphy, who publishes The California Technology Stock Letter, argued last week that spending on PC's and cellphones would grow this year and more quickly next year as companies seek technology solutions to reduce expenses.
But the prolonged stagnation of the PC market -- which for more than two decades has provided almost assured double-digit growth -- suggests that Silicon Valley may be approaching a shift that goes beyond the collapse of dot-com stocks.
Increasingly, personal computers have become a replacement rather than a growth market, and Silicon Valley collectively is still waiting for the Next Big Thing.
"This has been the perfect storm," said David Readerman, a partner and director of growth equity strategy at Thomas Weisel Partners, the San Francisco-based investment firm. "We had Y2K, the Internet build-out and the biggest of all" -- overbuilding in telecommunications.
Growth, he said, is now seen from sectors of the economy that for more than a decade Silicon Valley has thought of as passe. Military contracting and domestic security are areas that might emerge as economic factors. 
To grasp the depth of the Valley's decline from its peak, it is only necessary to review the fortunes of the Fast 50, an annual list of the region's fastest-growing companies maintained by Joint Venture: Silicon Valley, a coalition of government, corporate and civic groups.
Of the top 10 companies on the list in 2001, only one, eBay, was profitable in the last quarter. Two companies, Excite@Home and Exodus Communications, filed for bankruptcy protection and have since been acquired. Seven others on the list had losses in each of the last four quarters, including Commerce One, which reported a staggering $220 million loss in the first quarter of this year. Finally, the stocks of four of the eight survivors in this group are now trading for less than $1.
At the same time, unemployment levels in Santa Clara County, the heart of Silicon Valley, declined in May, the most recent month for which there is data. The rate was 7.1 percent, down from 7.6 percent in April but more than double the 3.4 percent a year earlier. From May 2001 to May 2002, the county lost 27,400 jobs, with the largest losses occurring in communications equipment and electronic components, according to the California Economic Development Department.
This somewhat positive job news may have been largely offset by the continued gloom nationwide in the telecommunications industry, which had been driving growth among the suppliers of data and voice infrastructure equipment in Silicon Valley.
"I am not as optimistic as I was a month ago," said Andrew Seybold, publisher of Outlook 4Mobility, an industry newsletter in Los Gatos, Calif., covering wireless data. The wireless industry has been edging toward its next generation of data and voice handsets, and a set of new products are planned beginning in August.
The world of wireless data is poised to create a proliferation of hand-held gadgets that could be a powerful driver for Silicon Valley. But the disarray in the telecommunications market has cast a pall over the idea that the rollout will happen quickly. 
This kind of pushing back of new markets that might have spurred a rebound seems to be quickly becoming the norm around the Valley.
"We've been saying that it's really not until the fourth quarter of '03 that you return to earlier levels, and maybe even that's suspect," Mr. Readerman said.

HEADLINE: Craft Project at Columbus Circle; 
Museum Plans $30 Million Makeover and Expansion

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Out of the crumbling marble cocoon of 2 Columbus Circle, Holly Hotchner sees a new American Craft Museum emerging.
 Ms. Hotchner, the director of the museum, sees artwork once again filling the gently curving, oddly angled, walnut-paneled, porthole-punctuated galleries designed 40 years ago for Huntington Hartford's personal collection. She sees diners in the penthouse restaurant once again diverted by the astonishing view of Central Park, whose treetops spread out like a lawn of emerald broccoli. She sees performances in the handsomely appointed auditorium and artists' studios in what is now an office warren. She even sees visitors checking their coats! 
 "We don't have a coat room now," Ms. Hotchner said on Wednesday, pausing at the cloakroom counter during an inspection tour of 2 Columbus Circle, which was awarded to the museum last month by the Bloomberg administration. "This is so exciting." 
By buying 2 Columbus Circle from the city and substantially renovating it, at a cost of at least $30 million, the museum would gain more than four times the gallery space it has at 40 West 53rd Street, which it plans to sell. It would have an auditorium for the first time in its 46 years and room enough for educational programs, a large store and its permanent collection of 1,700 objects -- jewelry, ceramics, glass, wood, textiles, basketry and design prototypes -- which now sit unseen in a Chelsea warehouse.
Much about the project remains uncertain. An architect has not yet been chosen. The museum may propose adding up to three floors atop the nine-story structure, Ms. Hotchner said.
The New York City Economic Development Corporation will submit the sale to public land-use review, though it could have averted the process through a technicality. That will put off groundbreaking for at least a year. Two years of construction will follow.
But Ms. Hotchner, who has been director of the museum since 1997, already envisions a cultural hub open seven days a week. "It's a quantum leap for us," she said.
It will be a quantum leap for the building, too, and not one that will please preservationists.
While Ms. Hotchner says she thinks some interiors can be reused -- especially the Mark Goodson Theater -- there is little question in her mind that the largely windowless marble facade designed by Edward Durell Stone will have to go. Some of it is going already: a few panels of Vermont marble are held in place by steel braces.
"If you were to try to save it, all the marble would have to be removed and reattached, which would be a tremendous undertaking," Ms. Hotchner said.
The concave north wall need not be straightened out, since the museum shows objects, not paintings hanging against flat surfaces. And Ms. Hotchner said it might be possible to keep some walnut paneling. "The wood is very beautiful," she said, "and obviously we're a museum about materials."
But she contends that the blank walls need openings. "There's a tremendous missed opportunity to refer to Central Park and where we're situated in New York," Ms. Hotchner said. "The whole building is hermetically sealed except in those corners where you're allowed to interact with the outside world."
That sense of hermetic isolation is not limited to portholes.
The building's original name is still incised over the entrance -- "Gallery of Modern Art Including the Huntington Hartford Collection" -- even though Mr. Hartford, heir to the A.& P. supermarket fortune, relinquished control in 1969, five years after the gallery opened.
The lobby is still paved with marble disks that resulted from cutting out the portholes. The 30-foot-high Gallery 3D, which once housed an Aeolian-Skinner organ, still has scarlet carpeting and a burnished bronze mezzanine balustrade, repeating the circular motif. Heavy bronze doors, incised with more circles, greet visitors to the theater.
In the basement, there is even an original wall-sized Honeywell building control console, looking like something out of "Goldfinger" with its buttons, plugs and dials. One panel regulates the "radiation hot water system." The central temperature gauge reads 200. ("Do you expect me to talk?" "No, Mr. Bond, I expect you to die.")
Life went on at 2 Columbus Circle after Mr. Hartford pulled out. The gallery, renamed the New York Cultural Center, was operated by Fairleigh Dickinson University from 1969 to 1975. A year later, Gulf & Western Industries, with headquarters across Columbus Circle, bought the building as a gift to the city, intending that it serve for 30 years as a visitors center and headquarters for the Cultural Affairs Department.
The agency moved out in 1998 and the space has since been empty, though used from time to time by film crews, who painted over some of the walnut paneling.
In 2000, the Giuliani administration issued a request for proposals to redevelop the site. The American Craft Museum, which had determined that it would not be able to expand on 53rd Street, replied after the deadline. It is not the policy of the Economic Development Corporation, however, to disqualify an otherwise viable proposal for lateness, a spokeswoman said.
The craft museum was in competition with two other plans.
The Dahesh Museum of Art, now at 601 Fifth Avenue, near 48th Street, proposed to restore the building as its home, working with Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates and Ann Beha Architects.
Now negotiating for new space in Midtown, Dahesh is "very disappointed" about not being awarded 2 Columbus Circle, said Steven Simkin, a museum trustee and chairman of the real estate department at the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. "It's ironic," he said, "because they were probably the single most dogged advocate of preserving the building and using it for a cultural purpose."
Donald J. Trump wanted to build a new hotel, originally working with the architect Alan Lapidus. "The craft museum is a terrible waste of a great site," Mr. Trump said. "A hotel will pay far more in taxes and would have generated a lot more business for the city. Museums have failed there many times. I predict this one will also."
Mr. Trump contends that he was told by Giuliani administration officials that he would be awarded the site. But Andrew M. Alper, the president of the Economic Development Corporation, said no designation had been made.
"We believe that a museum would do more to enhance the neighborhood than another hotel," Mr. Alper said. "And from an economic impact, this proposal was quite favorable." He declined to rank the proposals in order of financial return or specify the purchase price, though he said the museum would get a break for completing the renovation within two years of groundbreaking.
As for replacing the facade, which the Landmarks Preservation Commission has declined to consider, Mr. Alper said, "We liked the idea of making the building more transparent from the park and the park more transparent from the building."
Braced for a fight -- or at least a lively debate -- over the renovation, Ms. Hotchner finds a hopeful augury in the view from the restaurant toward the Columbus Monument.
"I like the fact that Columbus is facing our building," she said. "That's very critical to our sense of well-being."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Pharmaceutical makers and ad agencies fight to preserve campaigns for prescription drugs.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
MADISON AVENUE, facing growing legislative threats to one of the advertising industry's most lucrative categories, is stepping up the fight to protect its freedom to pitch prescription drugs directly to consumers.
 Drug companies, agencies and their media allies who have benefited handsomely from the flood of ads beat back one recent measure in the House of Representatives. But advocacy organizations on the other side of the issue vow to continue battling to limit or even eliminate such campaigns, and one senator has introduced legislation that would limit the pharmaceutical industry's tax deduction for such advertising. 
 The category of direct-to-consumer ads did not even exist until five years ago. Before 1997, broad curbs prevented pharmaceutical makers from mounting any significant efforts, and they aimed most of their spending directly at health care professionals. 
But since the Food and Drug Administration loosened its strictures against those ads, primarily by making it much easier to promote drugs with commercials, the category has boomed. It has become an estimated $2.5-billion-a-year business for the media. That exceeds the amount spent annually to advertise many drugs sold over the counter like analgesics and vitamins, according to CMR, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending.
The spending for the direct-to-consumer drug campaigns, which come complete with the traditional trappings of brand advertising like celebrity endorsers, jingles, free samples and slogans, also exceeds the yearly outlays in mainstay marketing categories like insurance and real estate, apparel and alcoholic beverages.
Agencies are anxious to keep that revenue flowing as they struggle to recover from the worst advertising recession in decades. They and their clients, the drug companies, are also eager to keep open a channel that has significantly stimulated demand and sales. 
Indeed, in a survey last month by the Ipsos-NPD division of Ipsos, a marketing research company, 25 percent of respondents said they had been prompted by direct-to-consumer ads to call or visit a doctor to discuss the product being advertised. Moreover, 15 percent of respondents reported requesting the very drug that was the subject of the ad.
That is one reason opponents castigate direct-to-consumer ads, decrying them as unfairly influencing important health care decisions about powerful medicines that ought not to be sold with the same sophisticated marketing ploys used to peddle movies, soft drinks or fast food.
"The stuff done to promote drugs works, and because it works, it's doing a disservice to the patient," said Sidney Wolfe, director for the health research group of Public Citizen, an advocacy organization in Washington. "The doctors are frequently as misled as the patients are," he added.
One doctor, J. Edward Hill -- the new chairman of the American Medical Association in Chicago -- offered another complaint. "We have no policy that opposes direct-to-consumer advertising, mainly because of freedom-of-speech issues," Dr. Hill said. "However, we do have some big concerns about advertising getting in the middle of the patient-physician relationship.
"It's sometimes even creating an adversarial relationship," he added, "when the patient insists on an advertised medicine but the doctor believes it's not the best or most effective medicine."
Dr. Hill called on the Food and Drug Administration and the pharmaceutical industry to finance "research that would definitely tell us whether this improves the quality of care enough to make it worth the increased costs of the medicines being advertised."
A bill before the House of Representatives, to provide a Medicare prescription-drug benefit to the elderly, had included a provision directing the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, to conduct such a study. But by the time the House passed the bill on June 28 and sent it to the Senate, the provision had been deleted.
"The bill is absolutely devoid of anything to do with advertising," said Dick O'Brien, executive vice president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies and director for the Washington office, who has led the Madison Avenue effort.
"It was serious, really serious," Mr. O'Brien said of the attempt by the critics to urge limits on direct-to-consumer campaigns. "We had to go into overdrive to explain that the role advertising plays is really a very beneficial one," centered on "empowering consumers to talk with their doctors as equals and opening discussions that otherwise would not have taken place."
The agencies are being joined by lobbyists for media that would lose ad revenue if Congress tightened rules for direct-to-consumer ads. At one time, some magazine and newspaper publishers perceived television and radio as rivals for ad revenue from makers of prescription drugs, but the media are now working together.
"This is certainly the one issue we're looking at right now," said Rita Cohen, senior vice president for legislative and regulatory policy of the Magazine Publishers of America.
"We have to be diligent about all potential Congressional action that might be negative," she added. "So we've been visiting the key people on Capitol Hill and showing them ads from magazines, letting the ads talk for themselves, so they can understand the benefits of advertising."
Another charge raised by opponents is that most of the prescription drugs promoted directly to consumers in magazines, on television and elsewhere are the newest, most expensive products and thus offer their makers the most profits.
"American taxpayers should not have to subsidize excessive advertising that only leads to higher prices at the pharmacy counter," said Senator Debbie Stabenow, Democrat of Michigan. She recently proposed that the tax deductions taken by drug makers for advertising -- which is currently a fully deductible business expense -- cannot exceed the tax deductions they take for research and development. Senator Stabenow is seeking to have her Fair Advertising and Increased Research Act become part of the Senate version of the bill the House passed last month.
"She is very well meaning, but this raises very serious issues," said Dan Jaffe, the executive vice president of the Association of National Advertisers who runs the Washington office of the organization, which represents the nation's marketers. "It would create an enormous precedent way beyond prescription drugs, affecting research on energy conservation by oil companies, fuel efficiency by automakers, health benefits by food companies.
"The advertising community and the media community worked very hard on the House side" to assure there would be no advertising limits in the bill passed there, he said.
"We need to work very hard on the Senate side," he said. "This is an issue that will not go away."

HEADLINE: Car Rentals Are Unexpectedly Strong 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

 BODY:
Even as airlines struggle to make fare increases stick, and to attract customers skittish about security measures, rental car companies are doing just fine. Traffic is strong, rates are steady or even rising, and cars are even running short in some places, including the New York area. 
 Industry officials and analysts estimate that consumers are paying as much as 10 percent more on daily rental contracts than last summer, when rental companies competed feverishly in a tepid travel market. 
 Discounts remain routinely available on the Internet, but walk-in specials and discounts offered by reservations agents, where most rental car bookings are made, have dwindled; the companies simply do not need to offer them. 
"Rates are definitely higher," said Rich Broome, vice president for corporate affairs at the Hertz Corporation, a division of the Ford Motor Company. 
He defended the increases as necessary for an industry whose business has been suffering for several years. Indeed, the ANC Rental Corporation, the parent of National and Alamo, filed for bankruptcy last fall, and was in financial trouble even before Sept. 11. Lately, there has been speculation that Budget Rent a Car may soon follow suit if it does not find a buyer. The Cendant Corporation, which owns Avis Rent A Car, is the leading candidate to buy Budget.
"We're still playing catch up" after last year, Mr. Broome said.
Even so, the industry, whose fate has long been tied to that of the airlines, appears to have reduced that dependence this summer. Analysts are encouraged. 
"The rental car companies are being as rational and as intelligent as they can about pricing," said Henry H. Harteveldt, a senior analyst with Forrester Research Inc. of San Francisco. "They are sticking to their knitting, and they are avoiding the suicidal pricing strategies that their brethren elsewhere in the travel industry have embraced."
"Prices are not only holding up, they are improving, and that's something the airlines have not been able to do," added Betsy Snyder, transportation industry analyst with Standard & Poor's in New York.
Summer is the rental car industry's peak season, as millions of Americans head out for vacations. Normally, companies would prepare for this influx by vastly expanding inventories of cars and trucks, a reason spring is generally the strongest season for automobile sales.
But this year, the rental companies have been extremely careful not to let inventories swell. After September's terrorist attacks and the drop in air travel, the companies sliced inventories by an estimated 25 percent. At the time, nine-tenths of industry business resulted from air travelers.
Through the fall and winter, rental companies kept a tight rein on inventories, choosing to keep them lean even as air travel rebounded. Only in late spring did inventories begin to rise, to the relief of Detroit, whose sales of vehicles to rental companies had plunged. "We had half a year when it was very barren," said George C. Pipas, an industry sales analyst with Ford.
Even with the rebound, vehicle inventories remain down about 10 to 15 percent industrywide, compared with last year, according to estimates from the companies, analysts and auto makers. The situation points up the difference between airlines and the rental companies in reacting to shifts in travel patterns.
Though they can eliminate routes and lay off workers, airlines, in the end, can only park their aircraft in desert storage lots. Rental car companies, by contrast, "have a lot of flexibility to reduce the size of their fleet," Ms. Snyder said.
Along with keeping supplies in check, rental companies and analysts say they have noticed an increase in business from both leisure and business travelers, who are choosing to drive short distances, rather than fly. As yet, there are no accurate measurements of how much new business this trend has generated.
But contributing factors are clearly the extra time needed to clear security and lingering fears over the constant flow of terrorism alerts. "You can market cars to people who want to get away" from such inconveniences, Mr. Harteveldt said. And a number of travelers prefer not to use their own vehicles.
"They won't drive their own BMW, they'll go down to the airport, pick up a car from Hertz, and drive that to Charlotte," said Michael Schlott, owner of International Tours of Atlanta, whose travel agency has experienced a rise in rental car bookings.
Companies are willing to pay for employees' rentals, because it is cheaper than flying, particularly when corporate discounts are applied. Some companies are even requiring that employees not fly on short trips, like Detroit to Chicago or New York to Washington, and in many parts of the country that means they must drive.
Many of these customers do not go to airports to pick up vehicles. Officials at Avis and Enterprise Rent-a-Car said they had noticed an increase in rentals at offices and counters in city and suburban locations, what the industry calls off-airport rentals. "To us, that means people are going to their local rental car office, renting a car, and driving to the nearest city as opposed to flying," said Susan McGowan, a spokeswoman for Avis, based in Parsippany, N.J.
Ms. McGowan said Avis had noted that such rentals are lasting longer, suggesting that customers are arranging more meetings during their business trips, as opposed to the short rentals of a fly-in, fly-out schedule. "The more days, the better for us," she said. 
At Enterprise, which does 95 percent of its rentals from nonairport locations, business is up by double digits this summer, as it has been for several summers, said Sarah Bustamante, a spokeswoman for the St. Louis-based company. She declined to offer specifics, but added, "We really have been uniquely positioned to serve that market." Enterprise's fleet remains the same size as last year, and its rates are also the same, Ms. Bustamante said.
Enterprise has experienced no shortages, which have been the norm for other rental companies, particularly in places like Manhattan, Southern California, some Florida cities and Hawaii.

HEADLINE: Top Peruvian Ministers Forced Out in Cabinet Shakeup 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, July 11 

 BODY:
Two of Peru's most highly visible ministers, strong proponents of privatizations and fiscal austerity policies that many Peruvians reject, said today that they planned to resign as part of an impending cabinet reorganization intended to shore up the tottering, year-old government of President Alejandro Toledo.
 Mr. Toledo had sought the resignations of the economy minister, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, and the prime minister, Roberto Danino, whose policies have angered Peruvians. 
 Mr. Toledo's government has been battered by protests and low popularity ratings as it has struggled to control poverty and create jobs in this nation of 26 million people. 
News that the two ministers, both favorites of Wall Street, were on their way out caused the sol to close at a yearly low of 3.55 to the dollar. 
"Kuczynski especially was seen by the markets as the biggest guarantor of fiscal stability," said Rafael de la Fuente, chief Latin economist for BNP Paribas in New York. "His departure is negative in that respect, though not unexpected."
Mr. Toledo was expected to name replacements as early as Friday. Analysts here said that Mr. Kuczynski was likely to be replaced by Javier Silva Ruete, who was economy minister in the interim government that briefly ruled Peru after President Alberto K. Fujimori's administration collapsed in a corruption scandal in 2000. 
Luis Solari, a doctor and socially conservative former health minister, is expected to take Mr. Danino's place. 
Because Dr. Solari is a congressman and a top official in Mr. Toledo's Peru Possible Party, his appointment is seen as giving the party the political influence it craves in the cabinet. 
Mr. Silva Ruete is not a member of the party, but he is a pragmatist whose flexibility in managing the economy is an important consideration for a president deeply concerned about public opinion.
Mr. Toledo's popularity rating has dropped to 16 percent, and his party is likely to be swamped in regional elections in November.
"What President Toledo wants is a political cabinet," Mr. Kuczynski said in an interview on Wednesday night. 
Today, the minister of women and social promotion, Cecilia Blondet, said she, too, was leaving. Resignations were expected from Fernando Olivera, the justice minister; Nicolas Lynch, the education minister; and Luis Chang, the minister of transportation. 
On Monday, Diego Garcia-Sayan, the foreign minister, resigned, after the departure last month of Interior Minister Fernando Rospigliosi, who quit in the wake of antiprivatization protests in southern Peru.
In Lima, there was speculation that Alan Garcia, the former president and rival of Mr. Toledo, had pushed for the removal of ministers like Mr. Olivera, who has investigated Mr. Garcia for corruption. In return, Mr. Garcia's party, the American Popular Revolutionary Party, known by the Spanish acronym APRA, would probably tone down its attacks against the government.
"Toledo probably decided to cast his lot with the APRA," Mr. Kuczynski remarked.
