HEADLINE: Confidence In Economy Off Sharply This Month 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence has fallen the most since terrorists attacked New York and Washington, a report released today showed, as flagging trust in American companies hammered stocks and threatened the economic recovery.
 The University of Michigan said its preliminary index of consumer sentiment for July sank to 86.5, an eight-month low, from 92.4 in June. The index dropped almost 10 points in September. 
 Stocks continued their recent decline yesterday. "There is a heightened risk that the troubles in the stock market will bleed over into the real economy," said Stephen Stanley, an economist at Greenwich Capital Markets in Greenwich, Conn.
Consumer spending supports two-thirds of the economy, a reason for investors to be on the watch for any spillover from the stock decline. That has not happened so far. A separate report released today from the Commerce Department showed that retail sales rose 1.1 percent in June. Shoppers increased purchases of cars, clothing and appliances. Sales were down 1.1 percent in May.
Economists had expected a reading of 93 in the preliminary consumer confidence index, which is based on a phone survey that will ultimately include about 500 households. The University of Michigan will issue a final reading in two weeks.
The current-conditions index, which reflects Americans' perception of their financial situation and their willingness to spend on furniture and home appliances, fell to 99 from 99.4. The expectations index, based on optimism about the next one to five years, dropped to 78.5 from 87.9.
Before Sept. 11, the largest declines in consumer confidence occurred in 1990 after Iraq invaded Kuwait, and in 1991, when the unemployment rate climbed in the aftermath of a recession. The Labor Department reported earlier this month that unemployment rose in June and companies added fewer jobs than expected.
The risks to the economy increase the likelihood that Federal Reserve policy makers may put off any increase in interest rates until next year. Economists at Lehman Brothers said central bankers might even cut rates.
"While the Fed isn't in the business of managing the stock market, they do worry about the collateral damage that the decline in stocks could impose on the economy," said Ethan Harris, one of the two chief economists at the firm.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, delivers a semiannual report on monetary policy and the economy to the House Financial Services Committee next week.
Sales of automobiles and parts surged 3.4 percent last month, the biggest rise since October, when dealer incentives led to record purchases, the Commerce Department said. Excluding cars, sales rose 0.4 percent in June after falling 0.4 percent in May.
Sales at general merchandise stores, which include department stores, rose 1.1 percent after falling 0.8 percent. Sales at clothing and accessory stores increased 2 percent, the biggest gain this year, after a 2.1 percent decrease.

HEADLINE: South Ozone Park Journal; 
At Airport Hotel, Guests Are Now the Homeless

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
Along airport hotel row in Queens, hundreds of new guests are checking into the Best Western Carlton House, their clothes scrunched into plastic garbage bags and tattered suitcases, their mental travel logs filled with tales of eviction, domestic violence, debt.
 The homeless are sleeping in the suites and double rooms that were, until the hotel went bankrupt last spring, occupied by business-class travelers, conferencegoers and tourists. The building, which became a homeless shelter 10 days ago, is now simply called Carlton House. But it still looks exactly like a hotel, with shrubbery around the gates outside, and polished mahogany inside. 
 And the Best Western Carlton House Web site, not yet defunct, still touts three-star details, like plush seating, and mentions sightseeing, fine dining and theater tickets. But the only jaunts most guests take now are to a bus stop, a coin laundry eight blocks away or a pay phone down the street. 
So it is that the surging problem of homelessness in New York City and the travel industry's post-Sept. 11 economic troubles have collided at a 337-room hotel that is now a 337-bed homeless shelter in South Ozone Park, in the shadow of Kennedy International Airport. 
There is plenty of room for the homeless on hotel row, where a string of six major hotels line 135th Avenue, near the Belt Parkway, and where business has plummeted since the attack on the World Trade Center crippled the airline industry. Occupancy for most of the hotels has hovered around 60 percent since September, officials say, but things got so bad for the Best Western that it left South Ozone Park. 
City officials were thrilled to find such a large, idle space. They said that about 80 families had moved in so far, and that they expected Carlton House to be full by the end of this month. 
In terms of supply and demand, the setup in South Ozone Park makes perfect sense. But sheltering the homeless is never that simple. 
At a delicate time for the Queens economy, which is recovering from Sept. 11 at barely a snail's pace, the metamorphosis of a hotel into a shelter has touched off a nasty battle between City Hall and elected officials from Queens.
Some critics, among them politicians who are quick to sympathize with the homeless, are staking the very future of southeast Queens on the situation along hotel row. They see a serious threat to what until recently was the brisk economic development of the area, which is heavily dependent on airport-related business. 
"The city seems intent on dooming us," said City Councilman James Sanders Jr., who represents the district that includes hotel row, where the Radisson, the Holiday Inn, the Hampton Inn and the Courtyard Marriott are a quick taxi ride from Kennedy. "Why would you spend top dollar to go to the Radisson if you're going to stay right next to a homeless shelter? I think that we're in dire straits and I don't think the city has recognized it."
But with homelessness at record levels in New York, city officials might also use the term "dire straits" -- although they chose "unprecedented" -- to describe the situation. The homeless-shelter system, which houses 8,000 families per night, is being inundated with families in need as more apply for beds than leave them, officials said. 
Carlton House, operated by the Salvation Army under contract with the city, is the larger of two big temporary family shelters opening this summer. The Bloomberg administration unveiled a policy recently that envisioned more permanent low-income housing for the homeless, and the facilities -- few as luxurious as the Carlton House -- are intended to house the homeless temporarily. The average stay in such temporary shelters is about nine months, officials said. 
The other new temporary shelter, a 157-bed facility in an unused residential building on New Lots Avenue in Brooklyn, is to open later this month, officials said. 
Linda I. Gibbs, the city's commissioner of homeless services, said she had met with half a dozen Queens officials to discuss their concerns about the shelter, including their frustration that 12 of the borough's 14 homeless shelters are in southeast Queens. (City officials said Queens actually had far fewer shelters than the other boroughs -- 8 percent of the total.) 
"We have to respond to this immediate demand for shelter," Ms. Gibbs said, adding that she did not think the existence of a shelter on the row would make or break the hotel business. "It is really the airport traffic that is going to speak to the occupancy of these hotels."
The outcry over the shelter, which Mr. Sanders said he feared would spawn more hotel closings and a "homeless shelter row" on 135th Avenue, was not lost on some of Carlton House's new residents. 
On July 3, a day before the shelter opened, a group of 100 politicians and community advocates protested in front, shouting, "Hey, hey, ho, ho, this homeless shelter has got to go!" And one of the shelter's many opponents, State Senator Ada L. Smith, got into a spat with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his security detail at a recent town hall meeting after she slammed down a packet of information about homelessness in front of the mayor and startled him.
Several homeless people staying at Carlton House said they had overheard residents of South Ozone Park, who live on the tidy residential streets just north of hotel row, complaining loudly that their property values would tumble.
Susan Taylor, 30, arrived at Carlton House on Tuesday with her three young children after leaving her apartment and her job running a day care program in Brooklyn to escape a man who was abusing her, she said. 
On Wednesday, she tried to use a pay telephone at the Radisson next door because, she said, the shelter's phones were not working yet. She said a Radisson employee told her that the homeless could not use the phone, the fitness room or the spa. 
"In a way, they are right about certain things," she said of the shelter's critics. "Nobody should have to lose business. But people also need to take the time to understand what it's like to be homeless. They don't know, they live in homes."

HEADLINE: In Ecuador's Banana Fields, Child Labor Is Key to Profits 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: PUERTO INCA, Ecuador 

 BODY:
At Los Alamos plantation, it would appear that no expense was spared to produce the Bonita brand Cavendish bananas sold in the United States. 
 The modern 3,000-acre hacienda in this steamy corner of Ecuador, one of the most efficient in Latin America, employs some 1,300 workers to tend banana plants fed by a state-of-the-art irrigation system. 
 The owner is Alvaro Noboa, Ecuador's richest man and a worldly bon vivant. He has become the leading candidate for president with the help of a slick marketing campaign that has cast him as a populist friend of the poor. "I love the workers at Los Alamos," Mr. Noboa told local reporters in May, when he announced his candidacy. 
But in interviews, a dozen children and many adults spoke of child laborers at Los Alamos, among them a spindly-armed 10-year-old, Esteban Menendez. "I come here after school and I work here all day," Esteban said. "I have to work to help my father, to help him make money."
The presence of children on the plantation of a man who may win Ecuador's presidential election in October is one of the more glaring examples of how enduring the use of child labor remains in Latin America, where some 42 million children from ages 5 to 14 have been estimated to be working in recent years.
The problem has been made more durable still by the competition that comes with a consolidated global market. Pressures on businesses to be efficient and profitable are often passed on to the world's most vulnerable population, its poorest children.
Growers and exporters here, who supply 25 percent of the bananas eaten in the United States, say the product earns them about 30 percent less today than a decade ago, often prompting them to turn a blind eye to labor codes. Child labor is common on plantations, large and small. 
Meanwhile, grim economic realities leave families more than ready to send their boys, and sometimes girls, out to work, even if it means pulling them out of school and placing them in fields or factories where they are exposed to hazardous conditions for little or no pay.
For two years, Esteban and his family say, the boy has bounded up 15-foot banana plants, tying insecticide-laced cords between them to stabilize trunks that might otherwise collapse under the weight of the produce that is behind Mr. Noboa's fortune of over $1 billion. 
He works for nothing to help his father, who tends 98 acres, avoid having his pay docked.
"That is the life of my sons, working in the bananas at such a young age," said Esteban's mother, Benita Menendez, 36, who has had three sons working at Mr. Noboa's plantation, only one of them an adult. "I did not want them to work when they were little, but this is the reality."
Ecuador's problem is less severe than that of other countries in the region. Even so, the International Labor Organization estimated that 69,000 children ages 10 to 14, and an additional 325,000 young people ages 15 to 19, were working here in 1999.
Only a significant increase in wages, at best a distant prospect in a country where the average worker earns $5.74 a day, will keep families from sending their children out into the fields, labor advocates here and in the United States say.
But while rights activists regard such labor as unacceptable, many parents like Mr. and Mrs. Menendez see it as a necessity. 
When several plantations, fearing unwanted attention, dismissed their child workers after a damning 114-page report in April by Human Rights Watch, the action was taken as a disaster by families across the lush banana belt of southern Ecuador -- the world's largest banana exporter and an increasingly important source for American corporations like Dole and Del Monte, according to the report.
"They fired all the children, but the work they did helped us," complained Maria Narvaez, 31, whose two sons, Nestor and Luis Boa, 12 and 13, were dismissed from a big hacienda where they earned $3 a day. "The situation is such that we all have to pitch in."
At Los Alamos, which supplies the world's fourth-largest banana company, labor conditions have become increasingly contentious. Employees' efforts to organize for better wages and working conditions led to a violent standoff this year -- a dispute that simmers today in the form of an intermittent strike by some families, including Esteban's own.
The workers unionized in March. The company responded by dismissing more than 120 of them.
When the workers occupied part of the hacienda, guards armed with shotguns, some wearing hoods, arrived at 2 a.m. on May 16, according to workers, and fired on some who had refused to move from the entrance gate, wounding two. 
The guards, workers said, then entered the grounds and burst into barracks where other workers were sleeping and forced them out.
The next afternoon, workers again gathered at the gate, where they parked a bus across the road to block delivery trucks. The guards confronted them again, this time wounding seven more -- including Esteban's father, Bernabe Menendez -- and a policeman.
"It was an attack on innocent people," said Jan Nimmo, a Scottish labor advocate who was with the workers that day and videotaped the afternoon confrontation at the gate.
Mr. Noboa's lawyer, Rafael Pino, attributed the violence to the workers, saying the guards had been sent in to protect property that was being vandalized. "At no moment were there shots from our side," he said.
But the violence prompted the United States Embassy to ask the government to ensure the safety of the striking workers. An American delegation that included two members of Congressional staffs visited Los Alamos workers in June.
"This is sort of the underbelly of globalization," said Representative George Miller, a California Democrat who sent an aide to Ecuador.
"We ask for labor protections and we ask for environmental protections," Mr. Miller said, "and we're told we can't have them, and when the citizens of that country try to get those protections, they're met with force from the company to keep that from happening."
After the confrontation at Los Alamos, a Chicago-based labor rights group, the U.S./Labor Education in the Americas Project, began pressing Costco, a distributor of Bonita bananas, to lean on Mr. Noboa to improve labor conditions.
Under pressure, his banana company has promised to improve medical services, provide masks, gloves and other equipment and settle complaints about unpaid overtime wages. But it has refused to recognize the workers' unions, Labor Ministry officials said.
Mr. Noboa, who divides much of his time between Guayaquil and New York, declined to be interviewed, and campaign aides did not return phone calls and e-mail messages seeking comment. But his lawyer, Mr. Pino, said children under 14, who are tightly restricted from working under Ecuador's labor laws, did not work at Los Alamos. "Impossible," he said in an interview. "To violate the law cannot be done, and it is not the company policy either."
Though no one knows exactly how many children work on the large plantations across Ecuador, Sergio Seminario, an analyst and former president of the Association of Banana Exporters, estimated 6,000, with thousands more working on small family farms.
The Labor Ministry has long been aware of the problem in the industry, which accounts for 20 percent of Ecuador's exports. But Alberto Montalvo, the highest-ranking ministry official in this region, said it was difficult to root out. "We all believe in human rights and labor rights," he said. "It is all very beautiful, but we also have to recognize that all the members of families have to work to pay for basic needs."
The existence of child labor on plantations is a product of simple arithmetic. Workers receive so little in part because the wholesalers and retailers abroad reap most of the profits, particularly with the recent consolidation of huge retail outlets like Wal-Mart, Costco and Carrefour.
Each 43-pound box of bananas purchased here by exporters for $2 or $3 goes for $25 in the United States or Europe. The Ecuadorean grower makes 12 cents on the dollar, according to the National Association of Banana Growers. "These big chains say, 'We will buy your bananas off the boat, but at our price,' " Mr. Seminario said.
If the growers are squeezed, the banana workers feel the pain. Their work force is almost entirely nonunion, and workers are often deliberately shifted from one payroll to another by growers who set up multiple companies on paper to avoid paying benefits and higher wages.
The workers and their children here said difficult conditions had long been the norm at Los Alamos. The families who live here in Puerto Inca cram themselves into crude cinder-block houses with tin roofs. Indoor plumbing is rare.
The main earners among several families said they received $6 to $7 a day -- within Ecuador's minimum wage of $128 a month -- but were often expected to work six or seven days a week, failing to earn the overtime pay set by law. 
The monthly minimum they earn falls far short of the $220 the government says a poor family of four needs to meet basic needs, so children go to work.
"With my husband's salary, we did not have enough for school, not enough for food," said Patricia Cespedes, explaining why she had pulled her nephew out of school at age 11 and sent him to work at Mr. Noboa's hacienda. The boy, Maximo Gomez, whom Ms. Cespedes has raised since his mother's death, is now 14 and a veteran field hand.
Esteban goes to school in addition to working. But many families say they earn so little that they must choose which of their children to educate and which to send into the factories and fields. Such economic necessity keeps 55 percent of Ecuadorean children from attending secondary school, the World Bank says.
Mr. Noboa remains a frequent visitor to New York, where, according to his spokesman, Pablo Martinez, he mingles with the Rockefellers and other luminaries. When his son was christened at St. Patrick's Cathedral last year, an event shown on Ecuadorean television, Robert Kennedy Jr. served as the godfather.
But Mr. Noboa's great hope is to reach the presidency, which he failed to win in 1998. Mr. Noboa, who runs a conglomerate that his late father founded, decades ago, has portrayed himself as an outsider whose policies will improve life for most Ecuadoreans.
He has made no extensive public remarks about the dispute with the workers at Los Alamos. In fact, the poor labor conditions and the existence of child workers have made barely a political ripple here. An investigation of the shootings at Los Alamos has not led to any arrests, nor has it shed light on what happened.
Mr. Noboa's aides say the troubles on his hacienda are politically motivated efforts to embarrass him in the midst of a presidential campaign.
"If he wasn't running for president and wasn't the richest man in Ecuador, this wouldn't be happening," Mr. Martinez said.

HEADLINE: Pennsylvania Struggles to Repair Model Prescription Aid Program 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: HARRISBURG, Pa. 

 BODY:
Pennsylvania's program to help low-income elderly people buy prescription drugs, the largest in the nation, provides invaluable assistance to tens of thousands of people and is immensely popular, but it also shows the problems that could become endemic if Congress adds drug benefits to Medicare.
 The program here costs patients only $6 a prescription and rarely denies coverage. It is financed with proceeds from the state lottery. Despite significant use of generic drugs, however, costs have soared and outstripped revenues. 
 State legislators know they need to adopt stricter cost-control measures, but, like some members of Congress, they have been virtually immobilized by lobbying on all sides. Neither beneficiaries nor pharmacists nor drug companies are willing to make significant sacrifices. 
So the state is desperately seeking new sources of revenue as it considers expanding the program to help more people in need.
Jo Ann H. McCleaf, 67, of Dover, Pa., near York, is just the sort of person whom many state officials want to help. She has no insurance to cover drug costs. With $11,316 in Social Security benefits and $3,000 of earnings last year, she had income just over the $14,000 limit for Pennsylvania's main pharmaceutical assistance program.
A two-time cancer survivor whose right foot was amputated several years ago, Ms. McCleaf said: "I use Lipitor for cholesterol. My legs ache constantly, and I should be taking pain medication every day, according to my doctors. I should also be taking an expensive drug for circulatory problems, but can't afford it."
For Mildred A. Irons, 83, of Linesville, near Erie, the state program has been a godsend. 
"If I didn't have it," Ms. Irons said, "I probably wouldn't have any income to live on." 
For arthritis, high blood pressure and bladder problems, Ms. Irons takes six drugs that cost a total of more than $300 a month. 
Pennsylvania's experience offers lessons for federal officials struggling to provide prescription drug benefits under Medicare.
On Monday, the United States Senate plans to begin a wide-ranging two-week debate on prescription drugs, their benefits and costs, for people of all ages, especially the elderly and disabled on Medicare.
Pennsylvania is deeply committed to its elderly, who make up 15.6 percent of its population, and the drug assistance program, established in 1984, has strong bipartisan support. The program is widely viewed as a model for other states.
"Everybody likes our program because it's a Lamborghini, a Maserati," said Thomas M. Snedden, the director since 1985.
But it has come to acquire a price tag as hefty as the ones on those elite sports cars. 
Since 1997, the cost of the Pennsylvania program has shot up an average of 13 percent a year, to $392.6 million in 2001, while revenues from the state lottery have been flat. Though enrollment has declined, the number of claims for each beneficiary and the amount paid on each claim have steadily increased.
The average number of prescriptions filled for each person in the program now exceeds 3.5 a month, up from 2.5 in 1997 and just 2 in 1987. The state pays an average of $42 for each prescription, up from $27 in 1997 and $14 in 1987.
"The big problem we have, which causes escalating costs, is utilization," Mr. Snedden said. "People are using more and more prescription drug products. If we could get utilization under control, drug prices would not be such a big problem."
Ray Landis, a lobbyist for AARP here, said the situation in Pennsylvania should teach federal officials to be cautious in making assumptions and projections. "In our program," Mr. Landis said, "both utilization and price increases have been much greater than anticipated."
Pennsylvania is second only to Florida in the proportion of its population that is 65 or older. More than 1.9 million of its 12.3 million residents are elderly. About 225,000 people, or nearly 12 percent of the elderly, are in the state's pharmaceutical assistance program.
While trying to hold down drug costs, Pennsylvania does not want to alienate drug companies, many of which have operations here. State officials say they appreciate the fact that Merck, Wyeth, GlaxoSmithKline and other drug makers provide many high-wage jobs in the state.
In its pharmaceutical assistance program, Pennsylvania requires use of low-cost generic drugs that have been approved as fully equivalent to brand-name products. Of the 10 million claims paid last year, 45 percent were for generic drugs.
But state officials have concluded that they must take more aggressive steps to control costs. Many of these steps would be required under a bill introduced by Senator Timothy F. Murphy, a Pittsburgh Republican.
Under his bill, which is supported by the Pennsylvania chapter of AARP, the state would establish a list of preferred drugs, charge higher co-payments for drugs not on the list and encourage patients to use mail-order pharmacies to obtain drugs for chronic conditions.
The bill would also set new limits on payments for generic drugs, and it tries to extract large discounts from makers of brand-name drugs by stipulating that Pennsylvania will not pay more than the "best price" charged to any other customer in the United States. Moreover, drug companies would have to pay rebates to the state to offset price increases that exceed the rate of inflation.
Many of the bills pending in Congress would allow private companies, known as pharmacy benefit managers, to use similar techniques in administering drug benefits under Medicare, the federal insurance program for 40 million people who are elderly or disabled. Such companies say they achieve the greatest savings when they are free to negotiate deep discounts with drug makers and require patients to use selected retail pharmacies.
But in Pennsylvania, the Legislature has specified the amount of drug discounts by law, has allowed virtually every pharmacy to participate and has been reluctant to deny coverage for any prescription drug.
"Politically," Mr. Snedden said, "state legislators just don't want to give up control of the program."
Congress is already facing similar pressures. Drugstores and pharmacists lobbied against the Medicare bill passed by the House of Representatives on June 28. They said it would cut their reimbursement, exclude some drugstores from the Medicare market or drive them out of business by forcing the elderly to use mail-order services. They hope the Senate will protect their interests, just as pharmacists have often persuaded state legislators to do in Pennsylvania.
People 65 and older can receive assistance under the Pennsylvania program if they have annual incomes less than $14,000 for an individual or $17,200 for a couple. Beyond the $6 co-payment for each prescription, there is no other cost to the beneficiary and no cap on annual reimbursements under this program, the Pharmaceutical Assistance Contract for the Elderly, or PACE.
A smaller program, known as Pacenet, offers assistance to individuals with incomes up to $17,000 and couples with incomes up to $20,200. But before getting help under this program, a person must pay a $500 deductible, and that has discouraged enrollment.
In Pennsylvania, the governor, Mark Schweiker, is a Republican, and Republicans control both houses of the Legislature. State officials once hoped that Congress would bail them out by establishing drug benefits under Medicare, but that hope is fading. Officials have concluded that they cannot wait for Congress, but must shore up their state program.
An advisory committee created by the General Assembly said recently that the Pennsylvania program was "the largest, most generous and most widely admired state-administered senior pharmacy benefit program in the United States." It is "the standard to which other states aspire," the panel said.
The committee said, "There is great interest among older people and legislators in expanding eligibility" for the drug assistance program here. But, it said, the state must first control costs. "Any other strategy," it said, "runs a very high probability of bankrupting the program."

HEADLINE: FleetBoston Decides to Close Its Robertson Stephens Unit 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
Add another victim of the plummeting economy to the list. FleetBoston Financial decided yesterday to shut its once-highflying investment bank, Robertson Stephens.
 FleetBoston had put the San Francisco-based investment bank up for sale in April but found no takers except for a proposal for an employee buyout. Top management of Robertson Stephens had been holding a series of marathon negotiations with Fleet executives up until the last moment yesterday in an effort to save the company, but the plan -- which would have effectively given the bank to its bankers free plus about $200 million in assumed liabilities -- was rejected. 
 "In recent weeks, Fleet and the Robertson Stephens management group were unable to structure an agreement for an employee buyout of the firm," said Eugene McQuade, Fleet's vice chairman and chief financial officer. "As a result, we have decided a wind-down is in the best interests of our shareholders."
Robertson Stephens was one of Silicon Valley's biggest players in the late 1990's. In many ways, Robertson Stephens helped build and finance the dot-com bubble, taking dozens of Internet companies public -- from eBay to eToys.com, which has since closed.
"It's another loss for San Francisco; they were an institution," said Amanda Duckworth, director for marketing at Thomas Weisel Partners, a rival investment bank that focuses on the technology sector. "As much as we might be the beneficiaries, it's another sad day."
For the last two years, FleetBoston, the product of the 1999 merger of Fleet and BankBoston, had aggressively cut jobs at Robertson Stephens as the technology markets and then the broader markets collapsed. Just this week, the bank cut 100 jobs and closed Robertson Stephens offices in London, Munich and Tel Aviv to try to cut costs ahead of an employee buyout. Indeed, even under the employee buyout plan, John Conlin, Robertson Stephens' chief executive, had told the firm's managing directors that half the staff, or 450 people, would have to be cut.
Now, the bankers, many of whom had remained optimistic that they would soon own the company, will have little to show for their patience. Indeed, many bankers had deferred their bonuses from 2001, expecting to be paid once the firm's fate was resolved. Some bankers indicated yesterday that they would consider starting their own firm.
Robertson Stephens, which was bought for $800 million in 1998 by BankBoston, lost $61 million in 2001 on revenue of $543 million. That compares with $1.56 billion in revenue in 2000, a drop of 71 percent.
When FleetBoston put the bank up for sale and hired Goldman, Sachs to help drum up business three months ago, it said that it hoped to raise $600 million for the sale of Robertson Stephens. Some Wall Street analysts laughed at FleetBoston's expectations. At the time, Judah S. Kraushaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch said, "It will be hard to find somebody to pay a respectable price."
Last week, the Boston-based FleetBoston, the parent company of Fleet Bank, said losses associated with good will stemming from Robertson Stephens would lower its earnings by $282 million for the quarter ended June 30. FleetBoston may now have to take a charge of up to $500 million, analysts estimate. 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 15, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A heading in the Business Digest column on Saturday about FleetBoston Financial misstated the company's intentions for its investment bank, Robertson Stephens. FleetBoston plans to shut the unit, not sell it.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Bearson Prowl As Market Ends A Dreary Week

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Wall Street's seemingly relentless slide continued yesterday with stocks posting their worst weekly performance since September.
 The plunge appeared to result more from investors' frustration and fear after months of accounting scandals than from any single economic report or corporate announcement during the week. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 7.4 percent for the week, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 6.8 percent. 
 Many institutional investors and Wall Street strategists contend that the most recent sell-off has gone too far. With earnings beginning to improve, inflation low and the economy recovering, stocks are due for a strong rally, they say. 
"The market is flushing itself out," said Byron Wien, director of investment strategy at Morgan Stanley. "I think we're in a bottoming process."
But the process has not been quick. As accounting scandals spread, engulfing companies like Enron and WorldCom, investors are wondering how much of the earnings growth that propelled stocks in the 1990's was real.
Yesterday, stocks opened strongly after an upbeat profit report from General Electric, which said that it expected its earnings to rise by 25 percent in the current quarter, but they quickly gave back their gains. A report on consumer confidence that was weaker than expected and an estimate that the federal budget deficit could reach $165 billion this year added to Wall Street's gloom.
The Dow industrials ended the day down 117 points, or 1.3 percent, to 8,684.53, while the S.& P. 500 lost 5.98 points, or 0.6 percent, to 921.39, and the Nasdaq edged 0.93 point lower, to 1,373.50.
In headier times, G.E.'s announcement might have spurred a market-wide rally. But today, investors are looking for reasons to sell as hungrily as they sought excuses to buy two years ago, when prices were much higher.
Some are choosing to sell stocks and buy corporate and government bonds, which continue to rise. A preliminary survey of investor attitudes for July had its sharpest drop since September. 
Individual investors have also begun to pull money out of stock mutual funds, said Thomas McManus, chief investment strategist at Banc of America Securities. In the last six weeks, they have sold $18 billion in stock funds.
Of course, Mr. McManus and many other professional investors view bearishness by small investors as a contrary indicator. Individual investor optimism reached a record high in January 2000, two months before the market peaked, according to a monthly survey, the UBS/Gallup poll of investor attitudes.
Individual investors are "hopelessly out of step," Mr. McManus said. "They tend to be late."
A longtime bear, Mr. McManus said he was now telling his clients to move more of their portfolios into stocks, and he expects to continue offering that advice.
Many traders had strong hopes when this week began after a powerful rally last Friday that seemed to have brought a decisive end to the market's recent swoon.
But stocks began giving back those gains almost as soon as trading opened on Monday, and the losses accelerated on Tuesday after President Bush's speech about corporate conduct, which many investors thought was short on concrete steps to discourage accounting gimmicks. In addition, a study that suggested that taking estrogen might increase the risk of cancer in women caused Wyeth, a major drug company, to lose about one-quarter of its value and pushed other big drug makers lower.
By week's end, stocks had fallen four days out of five. For the week, the S.& P. 500 lost 67.64 points. The Dow fell 694.97 points, and the Nasdaq composite gave up 74.86 points, or 5.2 percent.
It was the seventh down week out of eight, and the 14th out of 17.
In that four-month stretch, the S.& P. 500, the most important gauge of the market's performance, has dropped about 21 percent, leaving investors $2 trillion poorer. The longer-term picture is far bleaker. From its peak in March 2000, the S.& P. 500 has fallen 40 percent, the worst drop since the bear market of 1973-74.
But the S.& P. 500's losses pale in comparison with the technology-heavy Nasdaq. The Nasdaq has now plunged 73 percent since March 2000, the worst drop in a major United States index since the Depression, as the technology and Internet bubble has decisively burst.
Charles Hill, research director for Thomson First Call, which compiles Wall Street analysts' forecasts of corporate profits, said he did not think stocks had reached bottom. Analysts are still too optimistic about profits for the second half of the year, and more accounting scandals are likely, he said.
For the third quarter, analysts are expecting S.& P. 500 profits to jump 16 percent compared with the period a year earlier. Companies will probably not meet that estimate because the economic recovery has slowed, Mr. Hill said.
"Earnings growth is going to be more gradual than anticipated going forward," Mr. Hill said. "The other thing is that the realization is setting in that this scandal stuff is bigger than had been anticipated."
In addition, although investors have become more pessimistic, they have not yet panicked. Stocks have fallen, but they have not plummeted 5 percent or more in a day on heavy volume, a sign that investors are overly nervous and that a new rally can begin, Mr. Hill said.
In a bear market, "the last phase is that capitulation, that panic, that throwing in the towel," Mr. Hill said. Until that plunge happens, it will be too early to buy, he said. --------------------

Treasury Prices Climb
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices surged yesterday, pushing most yields to lows for the year, as a late-day equity sell-off lighted a fire under government securities already in demand after a plunge in consumer sentiment.
Benchmark 10-year note yields, which move inversely to the price, had their biggest weekly fall since October 1998, a time when the Federal Reserve had to deliver emergency rate cuts after the near-collapse of a prominent hedge fund.
By late in the day, the price of a 10-year note rose 15/32 , to 102 10/32 . The note's yield fell to 4.57 percent from 4.63 percent on Thursday. The 30-year bond also climbed, up 22/32 , to 100 25/32 . Its yield dropped to 5.32 percent from 5.37 percent.

HEADLINE: How to Fail in Business: 'Please Hold' 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Press '1' if You're Steamed" (editorial, July 7):
The remedy for the frustrating phone-menu syndrome is not likely to come from measurement of consumer anger, as "mood analyzer" software described in a recent patent attempts to do, but from the current business recession. 
Our abhorrence of the circuitous automated menus is hardly a mystery in need of calibration. 
 But sales slumps are very real and measurable, and it is easy to predict that they will bring back the realization that customer care is what makes the cash register ring. 
 All it will take is for one provider in any given industry to realize that no matter what it is selling, the real product is the relationship. If that provider drops the automated menu, its competitors will follow like sheep. They'll all realize that the money saved by cutting receptionist salaries is more than offset by loss of customer good will.

SEYMOUR H. FINE
Providence, R.I., July 7, 2002

The writer is a business consultant.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Both Sides Say Talk About Baseball's Problems Is One

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
So much negative talk has engulfed Major League Baseball over the past week that it would seem Commissioner Bud Selig would be reeling from it and swimming desperately against the tide, trying to keep his head above the rising murky waters. But Selig himself has contributed to the talk, and he acknowledged yesterday the mixed feelings he has about that contribution.
 "You walk a very thin line," Selig said when he was asked if his comments and disclosures about clubs' problems had hurt baseball. "I worry about that a lot. One could make the case. On the other hand, there are many who feel that we haven't told our story, that we haven't been aggressive enough in telling our story." 
 Among those, many are club owners, Selig said. Asked if owners tell him not to talk about the game's problems so much, he said in a telephone interview: "No. In fact, I would tell you there's a significant number of owners who say we should talk about it more, that we should tell our story more."
The owners' story is primarily about their economic plight, the disparity in revenue between the wealthier teams and the poorer teams and the absence of competitive balance, where the Yankees and other high-payroll teams dominate the playoffs each year and if a low-payroll team advances, it is shown the door quickly. Those concerns are being raised in the negotiations with the players union for a new collective bargaining agreement.
This was supposed to be a showcase week, with the All-Star Game in Milwaukee and its attendant festivities enabling baseball to show off its best players and the attraction it has for eager fans.
But events in Milwaukee on Monday, the day before the game, were overshadowed by the union's executive board discussing a possible strike date at a meeting in Chicago. On the day of the game, Selig conducted an Internet town hall, and the first six questions and nine of the 17 he answered dealt with baseball's economic problems.
Then Wednesday, meeting with reporters in his office, Selig triggered two days of newspaper articles about teams in trouble, either encountering difficulty meeting payroll or wallowing in so much debt that the rest of the season could not be guaranteed. The Tampa Bay Devil Rays and the Detroit Tigers recently experienced payroll problems and needed bank loans to pay their players, people in baseball familiar with the problems said.
"There is only one way to solve this," Selig said. "Get a system that works. Do I like this? No, not one bit. I hate it.
"But when you get into stadium debates and other things, this comes out. You can't stop it. Do people know the system isn't working? You bet they do."
Even trades prompt talk of economics, he noted. 
"Everything is tied into this," he said. "When a trade is made, for example, we talk more about the financial aspects of it than anything else. That's regrettable. The first question I was asked yesterday was what about the money in the deal. Years ago we'd talk about the players and who got the better of the deal. That seems to be secondary now."
He was referring to the trade that sent Cliff Floyd and his $6.5 million contract from the Florida Marlins to Montreal. Because the Expos, owned by Major League Baseball, cannot increase their payroll, the Marlins had to give the Expos about $1.5 million to balance the salaries of the players in the deal.
People in and close to the union have expressed skepticism about some of Selig's comments about baseball, especially his talk on Wednesday about troubled teams.
"It's amazing," one person close to the union said, speaking on condition of anonymity, "that when you're trying to sell the best product in the world, essentially you do it by doom and gloom. Normally that's not a good technique."
Some people on the labor side believe that the doom-and-gloom talk is deliberate, aimed at gaining leverage in the negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement.
Selig said there was no ulterior motive involved, only the belief among the owners that they had to impress on everyone -- players, fans, and members of the news media -- the serious nature of their problems.
"I am extremely sensitive about it," Selig said about the constant talk of problems. "I do have concerns. Anything that takes focus away from the field can't be good. That's unfortunate. But there are such strong feelings in so many places. It has so many manifestations it's hard not to talk about it. 
"There are times when it comes up when nobody has said a word. People just bring it up. But I do regard it as a negative. I hate talking about it."
Selig expressed hope that the talk would not have to last much longer.
"Hopefully," he said, "we can have a successful conclusion to the labor thing and we can quit talking about it."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
VISX, A MAKER OF LASERS, EXPECTS PROFITS TO FALL SHORT

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Visx Inc. shares fell 18 percent after the company, the biggest maker of lasers used to correct vision, said profit for the rest of the year would not meet forecasts. The shares fell $1.70, to $7.60 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange, where Visx led the list of percentage losers. 
A slow economy has hurt demand for vision-correction surgery, and sales and profit are expected to decline the rest of this year, Visx said. The company forecast earnings of 15 cents to 18 cents a share in the second half, lower than the 27 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Visx, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it earned $5.92 million, or 11 cents a share, in the second quarter, reversing a year-earlier loss of $10.7 million, or 19 cents a share. Sales fell 24 percent, to $36.6 million from $48.3 million.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Federal Government to Post $165 Billion Deficit in 2002
The Bush administration said the federal government would run a deficit of $165 billion this year, a sharp turn for the worse after four years of surpluses and further evidence of how the stock market's long slide is rippling through the economy.
 Administration officials said the main reason for the swing from a $127 billion surplus in the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30 to the projected red ink for the current fiscal year was a steep falloff in tax revenue from capital gains and other receipts associated with the stock market. Page A1. 

Another Brutal Week for Stocks
Wall Street's seemingly relentless slide continued with stocks posting their worst weekly performance since September. The Dow industrials dropped 7.4 percent and the S.& P. 500 6.8 percent. The plunge appeared to result more from investors' frustration and fear after months of accounting scandals than from a single economic report or corporate announcement in the week. A1.

Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored buyers of home mortgages, said they would begin making the same kind of quarterly and annual reports as other publicly traded companies. C3.

Burberry shares fell 2.2 percent in their first day of trading. C2.

FleetBoston to Sell Investment Arm
FleetBoston Financial decided to shut down its once highflying investment bank, Robertson Stephens. FleetBoston had put the bank up for sale in April but found no takers except for a proposal for an employee buyout. But top management rejected that plan. C4.

G.E. Posts 14% Increase in Profits
Despite steep losses on WorldCom bonds and in its insurance businesses, General Electric reported a 14 percent increase in earnings in the second quarter, in line with analysts' expectations. The company also promised a robust third quarter. C2.

Conseco's Prospects Dealt a Blow
The key insurance rating of Conseco, the insurance and finance company, was downgraded by A. M. Best, a decision that will make it harder for Conseco to compete and worsens the prospects for a turnaround. C4.

Plea Bargain Possible for Waksal
Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone Systems charged with insider trading, is discussing a plea bargain, federal prosecutors acknowledged. C3.

Deutsche Telekom's Chief Resists
The chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, Ron Sommer, left, stepped up his resistance to efforts to oust him, even as speculation grew about potential successors. His future is expected to be decided on Tuesday at a meeting of the company's 20-member supervisory board. The Ver.di services union said it would back an internal candidate to replace Mr. Sommer if he quit or was fired. C3.

Confidence Slumps as Sales Climb
The University of Michigan said its preliminary index of consumer sentiment for July sank to 86.5, an eight-month low, from 92.4 in June. The government reported that retail sales rose 1.1 percent in June. C5.

Subpoenas for 2 Energy Traders
Duke Energy and El Paso said that they had received subpoenas for trading records from authorities looking into sham transactions in natural gas and electricity. C15.

Key Vivendi Official Expected to Quit
The chief financial officer of Vivendi Universal, Guillaume Hannezo, is expected to resign as soon as a replacement can be found, people close to the company said. He would be the second executive in a month to lose his job. C3.

HEADLINE: A Rosy Forecast From G.E. As Its Profits Increase 14% 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Despite steep losses on WorldCom bonds and in its insurance businesses, the General Electric Company reported a 14 percent increase in earnings for the second quarter yesterday, in line with analysts' expectations. The company also promised a robust third quarter.
 "We see a very strong pipeline of new products and services across G.E.," Jeffrey R. Immelt, G.E.'s chairman, said yesterday. 
 G.E. earned $4.4 billion, or 44 cents a diluted share, in the latest quarter, compared with earnings of $3.9 billion, or 39 cents a diluted share, in the quarter a year earlier. Mr. Immelt predicted that revenue would rise as much as 10 percent and profits at least 20 percent this quarter. He also said G.E. was on track to meet analysts' expectations of full-year per-share earnings of $1.65 to $1.67. 
But the numbers were not all so reassuring. Second-quarter revenue inched up only 4 percent, to $33.2 billion from $32 billion. Much of that came from GE Power Systems, which some analysts say has peaked in sales. Revenue at GE Capital, normally a growth engine, fell 4 percent, because of a write-down of $110 million on its WorldCom bonds and losses of $236 million at its insurance unit, the Employers Re Corporation.
Elsewhere, G.E. said that GE Medical was going strong and that its NBC television network, plastics, appliances and other "short cycle" businesses -- most sensitive to the economy -- were growing rapidly.
"If people accept that G.E. is on a path to credible operating numbers, the stock could really move," said Nicholas P. Heymann of Prudential Securities, who rates G.E. a buy.
G.E. shares closed at $28.60 yesterday, up $1.25. But that is closer to Thursday's 52-week low of $26.40 than to last year's high of $47.75.
Investors, analysts say, have had to pick through a tangled morass of numbers to assess G.E. earnings, one reason the stock price is low. 
Robert Friedman, an analyst with S.& P. Equity Research, who rates G.E. shares a hold, said he routinely stripped away gains from overfinanced pension plans and other items that did not reflect what he called core activities. "When we only look at core earnings, the numbers are a lot lower," he said. 
Other analysts worry that a rub-off effect of scandals at Enron and elsewhere will continue to depress G.E.'s stock, even if its accounting is faultless. And still others say the shares trade at too high a premium.
Timothy M. Ghriskey, who runs his own investment management firm in Greenwich, Conn., sold all his G.E. shares in May, when he heard rumors of problems with the company's accounting.
"I did not believe it for a second, but in this market you have to quickly get out of harm's way," he said.
Such reactions frustrate Mr. Immelt. In a letter to employees last week he decried the widespread belief that "companies making their commitments must be cheaters." And he staunchly defended G.E.'s integrity when an analyst raised the question yesterday.
But more than secondhand tarnish is holding down G.E. stock. G.E. relies heavily on GE Capital for growth, yet its stock sells at a premium to other financial services companies. "I'm not sure that will continue," Mr. Ghriskey said. 
Older businesses, like lighting and appliances, meanwhile, drag down growth. "They should get rid of them," Mr. Heymann said bluntly. 
Moreover, many analysts have grown cynical about G.E.'s timing on one-time gains and losses. This quarter, for example, a $358 million tax benefit will offset a $300 million loss from WorldCom and Employer Re. G.E. will probably use a $500 million gain from selling its electronic commerce business last week to offset coming revamping charges.
"They're offsetting genuine costs with gains that have nothing to do with underlying business operations," Mr. Friedman said. 
G.E. used to brush aside such criticisms. Now it is tackling them.
For only the second time, G.E. followed its earnings release with a conference call with analysts, and it was the first time that its chairman participated. G.E. issued its results at 6 a.m, giving analysts three hours to digest the numbers before the call commenced at 9 a.m. And, it offered a finer breakdown of numbers than it did last year. For example, it no longer lumps transportation systems and lighting under "industrial products and systems."
"Immelt has gone much further than Welch in making the numbers transparent," said Noel M. Tichy, a professor at the University of Michigan Business School who has written extensively about John F. Welch Jr., Mr. Immelt's predecessor.
Maybe so, but analysts remain skeptical. "It's still hard to find salient numbers," Mr. Friedman said, "so they still have a ways to go."

HEADLINE: Trouble With Trash 

 BODY:
New York City's ubiquitous trash -- 11,000 tons of it daily from residences alone -- has traveled to Pennsylvania and Virginia, and there's even talk of sending it to a Caribbean island. It is seeing more of the world than some New Yorkers do, and it could threaten to overtake culture as the city's most notable export.
 Recognizing the scale of the problem, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has made the garbage crisis the focus of his second 100 days in office, promising to deliver something in the way of a solution by next Friday. It is an ambitious target, given the political, economic and environmental hazards surrounding the issue. And it has City Hall scrambling, entertaining some novel approaches, including using a semi-submersible garbage freighter that sounds like something out of Jules Verne or "Waterworld." 
 This spring the mayor toyed with the idea of building incinerators; but New Yorkers, fearing added air pollution and other problems, cried foul. Experts say the waste management industry is on the brink of a cleaner, safer incinerator that will produce energy without creating tons of toxic residue. That technology always seems to be right around the corner, but until it actually arrives, incinerators are best left on a back burner.
It was irresponsible of Mr. Bloomberg's predecessor, Rudolph Giuliani, to close the Fresh Kills landfill before finding an alternate trash disposal solution. Mr. Bloomberg should reopen it on a temporary basis, while continuing to send the rest of the trash to landfills elsewhere. Nevertheless, that's a horrifically expensive option -- becoming more so as private trash haulers and landfill owners realize they are in a sellers' market. Further, the trucks that currently haul the trash to Pennsylvania and Virginia are wearing down roads and fouling air quality along the route.
It would be better to use existing marine transfer stations in the city, where barges would be loaded and sent to Port Ivory or Howland Hook on Staten Island. From there, rail links can take the trash to landfills. The city should consider retrofitting the transfer stations so the garbage would travel in sealed containers. If it becomes available, a waterfront facility in Linden, N.J., could handle about half the city's residential trash. An investigation involving ownership of the proposed site has all but taken it off the table, although a resolution there could contribute to a diversified, practical and sustainable solution.
But finding trash depositories cannot be the only focus if the city is going to seriously address the mountains of garbage it produces. New York has been living large for too long, and like overly indulgent parents, its officials have done little or nothing to rein in the excess. The city needs to go on a trash diet. Here are a few ways to start:
Expand the recycling program. Mayor Bloomberg's suspension of glass and plastic recycling cannot be the end of the discussion. We need new strategies for separating glass and finding markets for plastics. The program may never actually break even, but reducing the size of our trash burden will be worth a lot. The State Legislature can help by widening the bottle bill to include redeemable deposits on noncarbonated beverages. Albany should also correct an outrageous injustice in which unclaimed refunds on drink containers -- tens of millions of dollars in New York City alone -- go back to the bottlers. That money should be directed to recycling and environmental projects.
Compost. The whole idea of composting in a city this large and crowded sounds ridiculous, but there are places where it can work. In neighborhoods with lawns, cuttings should be mulched and returned to the ground, an uncomplicated task that could save the city as much as $9 million a year. Composting table waste is being done successfully on Rikers Island, and it worked in a Park Slope experiment a decade ago. It should be explored for larger applications.
Cut down on packaging. Manufacturers who wrap their products in layer upon layer of packaging could be persuaded to pare down if the city used the muscle of its more than seven million consumers to demand more restraint.
The problem is big enough to require a trash czar -- a high-level mayoral appointee who can help usher in a new era of waste reduction. This project will require new and creative thinking that goes beyond just how to get rid of what the city's residents throw out. The time is right and the garbage crisis demands this kind of attention.

HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE SAYS IT EXPECTS DEFICIT TO HIT $165 BILLION 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12 

 BODY:
The Bush administration said today that the federal government would run a deficit of $165 billion this year, a sharp turn for the worse after four years of surpluses and further evidence of how the stock market's long slide is rippling through the economy.
 Administration officials said the main reason for the swing from a $127 billion surplus in the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30 to the projected red ink for the current fiscal year was a steep falloff in tax revenues from capital gains and other receipts associated with the stock market. 
 Wall Street closed out another dismal week with another down session. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 117 points today, closing at 8,684.53. Its loss for the week was 694.97 points, or 7.4 percent. The Nasdaq composite index edged down by less than a point to close at 1,373.50, bringing its loss for the week to 74.84 points, or 5.2 percent. 
Consumer confidence fell to its lowest level since right after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, according to the University of Michigan's preliminary index for July that was released today. The index fell to 86.5, an eight-month low, from 92.4 in June. 
The cascade of bad news about corporate behavior is weighing increasingly heavily on both Wall Street and Washington, where Democrats sought today to use the tumble in stock prices to argue against President Bush's plan to allow workers to invest part of their Social Security taxes in stocks and bonds. Page A9. 
By further undermining investors' confidence, the corporate scandals are also increasing the fiscal pressure on the government. Its finances have deteriorated for a year because of the combined effects of the weak economy, increased spending on national security and the initial costs of the tax cut pushed through Congress last year by President Bush.
The fiscal squeeze has intensified during the last several months, in large part because tax revenues have dried up more than anticipated, private economists and government officials said.
The recent dropoff in tax receipts and the ensuing surge in the federal deficit is due "almost entirely to what I will call stock market related income -- capital gains, and to a lesser extent income from mutual fund distributions, options, perhaps bonuses tied to stock performance," said Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., director of the White House's Office of Management and Budget. "This is a new and I think important phenomenon we are all going to have to understand much better."
Mr. Daniels said that the deficit for the next fiscal year, starting Oct. 1, should decline to $109 billion, and that the government could return to running surpluses two years later.
Democrats called the administration's projections overly optimistic. They said the long-term fiscal outlook remains bleak, and they renewed their argument that the root of the problem was Mr. Bush's insistence last year in pushing through a $1.35 trillion, 10-year tax cut on the basis of long-term surplus projections that were wildly optimistic.
"They have now wandered off to fantasyland and are seriously understating the deficits and the buildup of debt we are facing," said Senator Kent Conrad, the North Dakota Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. 
Mr. Conrad said next year's deficit was likely to be more than $200 billion, nearly twice the administration's estimate. Senate Republicans are also projecting a deficit for next year of more than $190 billion.
Traditional economic theory holds that governments should run deficits during times of economic weakness because doing so effectively puts more money in the hands of businesses and individuals. Neither party advocates trying to close the budget gap this year or next, in part because of the economic implications.
But Democrats hope to make a case that the Bush administration has put the government on a path leading to deficits for years, perhaps decades, eventually limiting its ability to pay Social Security and Medicare benefits to the growing ranks of retirees and hurting the economy by driving up interest rates.
Running deficits also means that the government's debt will rise, further burdening future generations. Congress already raised the legal ceiling on the national debt this year, and this week a developer restarted the "debt clock" in midtown Manhattan that tracks the government's liabilities, setting it at $6.1 trillion, after turning it off for two years.
Mr. Conrad said the $5.6 trillion, 10-year surplus projection the White House relied on last year in pressing for the tax cut proved to be a mirage. While last year's recession and the costs of the war on terrorism played a role, he said, the bulk of the deteriorating fiscal outlook over the long run was attributable to the administration's emphasis on tax cuts.
"The markets are voting every day on the credibility of this economic team, and they're giving a thumbs-down to this economic plan," Mr. Conrad said.
But Democrats have not offered deficit-reductions plans of their own, and most have shied from advocating a repeal of Mr. Bush's tax cut or delaying the provisions that phase in over the rest of the decade.
The administration's presentation of the new budget numbers did not dwell on the long-term outlook, but focused instead on the short term. It pointed to the stock market as the immediate problem, and asserted that the key to maintaining fiscal responsibility was for Congress to hold down government spending.
Mr. Daniels said that the administration's projection of a return to surplus in 2005 makes room for increased spending on national security as well as for other issues like health care. "But it also contemplates real restraint in spending in the rest of the budget, and that's the biggest if," he said.
In the budget analysis it released today, the administration said it expected total revenue for the current fiscal year to decline by $124 billion, or 6 percent, from last year's level. 
Nearly all of the decline -- $121 billion, it said -- would come from individual income tax receipts. And, it said, most of that decline was within the "non-withheld payments" category, which is largely made up of capital gains taxes.
Through May, the administration said, non-withheld payments were down by $80 billion, or 28 percent, from the same period a year earlier.
Mr. Daniels said that the administration was not making any specific assumptions in its projections for next year about a recovery in the stock market. But he said its projections assume an overall increase in tax revenues of 5 to 6 percent.
Democrats said the assumption that the budget could be rebalanced by 2005 was built on unrealistic economic projections. Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the House Budget Committee, noted that the administration assumed, without any explanation, very large jumps in corporate profits in 2004 and 2005.
"It's a critical detail," he said, "and it shows you why we're skeptical, to say the least, about the numbers they've presented."

HEADLINE: Records of Two Utilities Are Subpoenaed 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 12 

 BODY:
The Duke Energy Corporation and the El Paso Corporation said today that they had received subpoenas for trading records from authorities looking into sham transactions in natural gas and electricity. 
 Duke said the requests for its documents came from the United States attorney's office in Houston, as part of a grand jury investigation, and from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. El Paso, the operator of the largest natural gas pipeline network in the United States, received its subpoena from the United States attorney in Houston. 
 Prosecutors have previously sought trading records from Dynegy Inc., Reliant Energy Inc. and the CMS Energy Corporation. Energy producers and traders are under increased scrutiny since the collapse of Enron and disclosures of fake trades and accounting mistakes.
El Paso denied that it had used so-called round-trip trades, which have no economic benefit, to inflate volume or revenue and said that it had not used them to manipulate prices. The company said it would cooperate with the investigation.
Duke, like some rivals, has acknowledged engaging in round-trip trades. It included about $1.1 billion of such trades in financial statements over three years. 
The company has said that the trades were done at the request of a third party and accounted for less than 1 percent of its $107.4 billion of energy trading and marketing revenue from 1999 to 2001. The transactions were used to "validate real-time prices," not to increase revenue, it said.
Duke found three such gas transactions out of more than 30,000 in the West, the company said as part of its response to an inquiry of 150 companies by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.
"We don't know" the scope of the grand jury inquiry or whom the investigation is focusing on, said Terry Francisco, a Duke spokesman. "We were just told to provide information on trading, and specifically the round-trip trades." The company is cooperating with the request, he said.
Shares of Duke declined $3.20, to close at $24.75, after falling as low as $24.05, their biggest drop in almost 15 years. El Paso disclosed its subpoena after stock markets had closed.
"Any day you receive a subpoena from a federal prosecutor is not going to be a good day for your stock," said Timothy O'Brien, who has been selling Duke shares since April from the $245 million he manages in the Evergreen Utility and Telecommunications Fund. "Duke is one of the largest and most successful energy traders in the country, and they've caught the gangrene of the trading scandal."

HEADLINE: Oh, Brother 

BYLINE:  By Karen Karbo; Karen Karbo's most recent books are a novel, "Motherhood Made a Man Out of Me," and a cultural memoir about divorce, "Generation Ex."

 BODY:
 THE MONK DOWNSTAIRS
By Tim Farrington.
276 pp. San Francisco:
HarperSanFrancisco. $22.95.
 WE modern folk are spiritually exhausted. We have lost faith in so many things -- love, work, raising our children in a manner that will keep them out of the federal penitentiary -- that our low-grade distress is an almost constant theme in the modern novel. But rarely in contemporary fiction do we come across a man or woman of God -- forget about devotees of the healing power of crystals; we're talking about old-fashioned nuns or monks, straight out of central casting -- who is also exhausted, who has lost faith not so much in God but in the point of devoting a life to him to the exclusion of everything else.
In Tim Farrington's tender, witty new novel, "The Monk Downstairs," Michael Christopher, formerly Brother Jerome of Our Lady of Bethany Monastery in Mendocino, Calif., has left his order after 20 years and landed in San Francisco, where he rents an in-law apartment in the Sunset district from Rebecca Martin, a lonely graphic designer and single mother of a 6-year-old daughter, Mary Martha. Rebecca is crawling out from under the wreckage of her marriage to Rory, a professional (read: fundamentally unemployable) surfer who "didn't quite have rock-star good looks, though he acted like he did and usually pulled it off." To say that she is disillusioned with life is only to say that she's entering early middle age in America.
When the story opens, Rebecca is being relentlessly pursued by a 40-ish suitor named Bob Schofield, one of those fulsome guys (with a shelf in his library devoted to "Relationships") who can lay claim to having a love life merely because it's against their religion to take a hint. Rebecca and Bob are a couple only because Rebecca hasn't the energy to be really cruel to him -- cruel enough to make him go away for good. But when Bob proposes on bended knee at a trendy North Beach restaurant, violinist at the ready, she finally decides it's simply too much.
In her refusal, Rebecca defines her life for him and for us: "I'm 38 years old, and I've got a daughter learning to read and a job I don't quite like. I've got a mortgage. I'm making my middle-aged peace with network television. Tomorrow is another day I've got to get through. If you could just behave yourself, we could have the occasional movie or meal together and I would feel that much less like a troll and a drudge.+But I don't need the violin music, Bob. I don't want it. I find it sort of pathetic, really."
Of course, she does want the violin music -- at least metaphorically -- which is the reason she can't settle for Bob.
Rebecca's romance with Michael Christopher begins haltingly. It turns out that they both smoke (Rebecca allows herself five Marlboro Lights a day, which she thinks of as "little suicides"), and she runs into him from time to time on the back steps, having a cigarette. She's surprised that he smokes. As an ex-monk, he's an oddity, but an oddity who intrigues her. She finds herself vaguely charmed by his disinclination to fill conversational gaps with small talk and his determination to plant a garden in her backyard, a weed-choked square of dirt that screams neglect. Still, she convinces herself that it's ridiculous to pursue her attraction. Wouldn't having an affair with a former monk be like getting involved with someone on the rebound from a relationship with God? Serious as the question is, it's a delectable conceit.
Perhaps unwisely, Rebecca tells her mother about her new tenant. And, sure enough, Phoebe (a vivacious widow who lives up the coast in a small artsy community, where she works in an art gallery and attracts the requisite eccentric pals) immediately decides that he'd be the perfect person to preside over the baptism of a baby born to a single mother she's taken under her wing: "Just a few words in the proper spirit is all we're looking for. A soupcon of ritual."+Rebecca won't ask him, but Phoebe will, and soon Mike and Rebecca and Mary Martha are headed up the coast for a beach party that doubles as a baptism. The reason he accepts? "I was told there would be hot dogs."
One of the many satisfactions of "The Monk Downstairs" is the way it captures Rebecca's slow acceptance of the risk she is taking with Mike. All too often these days, we're bombarded by stories about the love affairs of gorgeous young people who have nothing to lose but their self-imposed alienation. When you're a middle-aged single mother living on a shoestring, spending a week's grocery money on some fancy boxers for your new boyfriend, as Rebecca does once she spies Mike's dingy, old-man underwear, is risky indeed. And not just on a practical level.
Once, when Rebecca and Mike are arguing about their fears, he acknowledges that he's afraid he can't love her properly because "he's spoiled for real life." "We're all spoiled," she retorts. "Life does that. It's what you do with yourself after you realize you've been spoiled that matters. It's the life you make in the ruins."
Farrington has created a great cast of supporting characters: high-spirited Phoebe; Rebecca's best friend, Bonnie, a jovial cynic who lives with her German shepherd and has made peace, more or less, with being single; Rebecca's hapless ex-husband, Rory; willful Mary Martha; even the annoyingly earnest love machine, Bob.
The book's only peculiarity is its tone. It's as if Farrington himself had been in a monastery for the last 20 years. His is a San Francisco without one gay man or woman. AIDS, the real-estate boom and the rise and fall of dot-com mania never happened here. At Utopian Images, the graphic design firm where Rebecca works, the main concern of the staff seems to be selling out their hippie good intentions to The Man. Even surfing isn't as flaky as it once was. Since the rise of ESPN and extreme sports, a talented, telegenic surfer like Rory might actually be able to make decent white-collar money.
But this is a mere quibble. "The Monk Downstairs" manages to be both a wry page-turner and a thoughtful investigation of what Christ may have meant when he said, "Love one another."+Come to think of it, pulling off a story like this -- where the principals are embarked upon a love that genuinely appears to have a chance of lasting -- is something of a modern-day miracle all in itself.
