LENGTH: 2595 words

HEADLINE: Boot Camp for the Real Estate Wars 

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
TERRY EDLEFSEN, a ballet dancer, went back to school this week, intent on mastering a different kind of choreography: the give and take of selling residential real estate. 
 Mr. Edlefsen, a former soloist with the Pennsylvania and Stuttgart Ballets, was one of 100 new sales agents at Weichert Realty enrolled in "Fast Tracks," a one of several training courses at the company's 20-acre campus in Morris Plains, N.J. 
 A television commercial actor who also teaches at the New Jersey School of Ballet, Mr. Edlefsen contemplated his professional detour during a class break on Monday and said: "After 9/11 the commercial work slowed so much that I decided I needed to do something else. But I didn't want to do what actors do: temp work or wait on tables. I have a five-month-old baby boy now." 
He has plenty of company in the ranks of new recruits to residential real estate sales, both in the city and suburbs. Though the field has always attracted people seeking a new career, the pool of novices is becoming noticeably more diverse than it was, say, 10 years ago. 
At the moment, there is a particularly noticeable influx of refugees from Wall Street, dot-com companies and other corporations who have been downsized out of jobs or have seen their employers disappear altogether. But participants in a training course conducted by Insignia Douglas Elliman at its Park Avenue headquarters last month also included an early-childhood-education professor, a Malibu real estate broker, an opera singer, a restaurateur, a nutritionist, a songwriter, a recent Columbia graduate and an accountant from Arthur Andersen.
Whatever their backgrounds and whether dealing in co-ops in the city or houses in the suburbs, the newcomers need to be trained in the nuts and bolts of a complex, sophisticated industry, where top performers can earn $1 million or more a year.
Although they may impart the same basic principles, firms do so in markedly different ways as they seek to cloak their associates in the agency's brand image.
"Buying or selling a home is the single most important financial transaction most people will ever make in their life, so it is critical that an agent have proper training," said Kathy M. Braddock, executive managing director and general sales manager at Insignia Douglas Elliman. "You owe it to the consumer, be they purchaser or seller, to provide them with agents trained in the company's image, and we owe it to existing agents and shareholders as well as consumers to be sure that everyone whose license in held by our firm is trained in the same way."
By the time they join a given firm, most people have already taken the 45-hour course required for a New York State sales license. (An agent must work in the field for at least a year to qualify for a broker's license and must take 22 1/2 hours of classes every two years to renew the license.) In New Jersey, the licensing course is 75 hours, but no recertification is required. Connecticut requires a 30-hour course for the sales license and two years of an active practice plus two additional 30-hour courses for a broker's license. In addition, licenses must be renewed annually and every two years agents must take four three-hour courses. 
Licensing preparation focuses primarily on state, city and federal laws dealing with such matters as contracts, construction, environmental considerations and title closings. 
"The state course gives you an education in the law, but it doesn't teach you to market and sell real estate," said Angela Anderson, a vice president of the Daniel Gale agency, which has 12 offices on the North shore of Nassau and Suffolk Counties. "We do that ourselves." 
Among numerous topics covered in the companies' courses, which vary widely in format and duration, are strategies for attracting clients and obtaining listings, conducting open houses, reading financial statements, preparing board packages for co-ops and condos, negotiating prices and closing dates and assessing investment potential of properties. Agents also learn how to tread the fine line between persuasiveness and aggression and how to accommodate the panoply of personalities they will encounter.
As Paul F. Purcell, president of Insignia Douglas Elliman, told a class during a recent three-week program: "We have to become chameleons. We have to get along with a lot of different people."
Whatever their approach, brokerage executives are adamant that their new agents be thoroughly grounded in the particular methodology and culture of the agency, even if that sometimes means untraining people who have worked with other firms. 
Demonstrating the tenacity that firms expect of their associates, Mr. Purcell told his class: "There is no way I won't get a listing I go after. I just don't leave without an understanding."
Ms. Braddock concurred. "They are being prepared not just to be a broker or an agent, but an Insignia Douglas Elliman agent," she said. "We want everyone to talk the talk and walk the walk." 
At Weichert, Ali Lanfrank, an assistant trainer, put it this way: "We Weichertize them." 
At some companies, the training entails a few days of classes and a great deal of direct observation of a seasoned broker. At others, the approach is more academic, providing newcomers with lectures, seminars, workbooks and homework assignments before sending them into action.
At Bellmarc Realty, for example, "our class takes about two months, during which time the agents can take no phone calls and participate in no professional activities," said Neil J. Binder, a principal of the firm. 
By the time they have completed the Bellmarc course, students will have listened to 16 audiotapes, mastered a 600-page sales manual, memorized every clause in a standard contract and passed two four-hour exams. "Only when they finish all that are they ready to sell," he said. 
On the first day of the Corcoran Group's program, Mitchell Lawrence, the managing director of education, leads a workshop he calls "Meet a Rookie on the Move." 
"I introduce them to someone who joined us in the last year, was just like they are on the first day and who has really taken off," he said.
The Corcoran program lasts two weeks and consists mainly of classes taught by company managers, brokers and outside speakers like mortgage brokers. "I always get the top brokers to volunteer to do role playing of different scenarios, and I give homework asking the class members to pretend that I am their customer," Mr. Lawrence said. 
WEICHERT, which has a separate building devoted solely to education, has a particularly elaborate facility and comprehensive curriculum. All told, it has six training hubs on the East Coast, including the center at its 20-acre corporate headquarters in Morris Plains. New programs begin every month for about 300 agents, who will work out of 200 offices and whose training extends over six months.
Right from the start, they are encouraged to ply their trade. "Tonight the 100 people being trained here will begin by calling 50 friends each, and by this weekend they will be conducting open houses with a mentor," said Chris Giugliano, vice president for training and development.
In one room, there are 25 cubicles with telephones on which students can practice their communications skills. At the back of the room is a mirrored wall where, Mr. Giugliano explained, "people who don't smile are sent." He added, "We teach them to smile on the phone." 
Small agencies like McClellan Real Estate, which has 28 agents in two offices in Pelham and New Rochelle, N.Y., tend to offer less formal programs. 
"We don't add on more than one new agent a year because if we did, everyone would trip over everyone else," said Carol Brown, one of the firm's three owners. "We spend about a month having them learn the paperwork and computers, answer the phone, the nitty-gritty of real estate. We find they pick up so much just from being around and listening to a seasoned agent. 
"During this time they also go to open houses and see what new properties are coming on the market. Then we put them in a car and pretend they are the customer, giving them a tour of the town the way we would with a customer." 
Elizabeth Stribling, president of Stribling Associates in Manhattan, is a firm believer in the one-on-one method. "We take the tutorial approach," she said. "I read English literature at Cambridge, and there you work with a tutor. What we do here is take the new salesperson and have that person sit between Betsy Dean, the supervisor of brokerage at our uptown office, or her equivalent and me for about five or six weeks. They work literally in a brokerage bullpen and get the blitz of everything that comes across our desks."
That format seems to be working well for Joanne R. Wenig, who joined Stribling last month as an associate broker. (Because she is a lawyer, she was able to bypass the agent rank.) A former partner at the investment firm of E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company and founder of her own venture capital fund, she was already schooled in negotiation.
"The way that Stribling trains new brokers is, in fact, one of the reasons I decided to join the firm," Ms. Wenig said. "My sense was that one-on-one training would better suit someone like me who has so much business experience in that it would allow me and the firm to customize my training, emphasizing the things I don't know from prior experience and spending less time on the things I already know." 
Then there are lessons that cannot be conveyed in the classroom. 
Mara Kurtz, for example, who joined Coldwell Banker/Hunt Kennedy in January when her freelance graphics design business began to feel repercussions of the faltering economy, gave herself an assignment. "Since there was no business the first month, I decided to see an apartment in every building on Central Park West from 60th to 97th Street," she said. 
Though Ms. Kurtz is specializing in the West Side area on or abutting Central Park, her first sale was a co-op on East End Avenue, in the building where she was raised. "I just knew the client would be happier there," she said.
As soon as training begins, new agents are expected to start gathering clients and listings by mining what is known as their "sphere of influence." That means getting in touch with everyone with whom they have any contact whatsoever, from relatives and neighbors to names on Christmas card lists and in Rolodex files, to friends of friends.
In a class titled "How to Market Yourself as a Business" that she led on Monday in Morris Plains, Virginia Carpenter, manager of Weichert's West Milford office, advised her students to establish an income goal for the year. If they hoped to earn $100,000 a year working in an area where the average sales price is $400,000, she said, it is necessary to complete 20 transactions with an average commission of $5,000. 
To do that, she recommended that agents come in contact with 3,000 people a year. 
"Three thousand people sounds like a lot, but it's not really," she reassured her audience. "It comes out to 250 people a month. You meet them through open houses, answering the telephone in the office, self-promotion and farming, which is introducing yourself to everyone in the neighborhood and then continually sending them mail."
Although new agents are offered considerable counseling through mentoring arrangements and friendly advice from more experienced colleagues, in the end they are more or less told to swim or sink. 
"What we give brokers is 50 percent of what they need, a business card, 91 years of our history and our marketing and advertising departments," Ms. Braddock of Insignia Douglas Elliman said. "We truly believe this is an entrepreneurial career within a structured organization. We supply the desk, the phone, the support and the name -- but it is up to you to run with the ball."
Not everyone does, of course. Some people realize that they have neither the tenacity to be in what is essentially their own business under the umbrella of an agency nor the nerve to rely solely on commissions. 
Others are weeded out by their firms because their performances do not justify the so-called "cost of a desk." "Last year, we probably took in about 70 new people and asked about 8 to leave," Ms. Braddock said.
The attrition rate is even greater at the Corcoran Group. "Of the people joining us from 2000 to 2001, about 50 percent didn't make it," said Pamela Liebman, the president and chief executive. "Now we are finding that 25 percent don't make it. We have certain expectations and if they don't meet them, we let them go. If you think this is a good way to play golf and enjoy weekends in the Hamptons, you are in for a rude awakening."
Though it still tends to be a second career rather than the first, real estate brokerage is drawing more people in their late 20's and 30's than it once did. In addition, it is also attracting men. "Fifteen years ago, it was stigmatized as a career for men, but now we are seeing a lot more of them," said Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Associates in Manhattan.
To what did he attribute the shift? "What gets anything to change in New York?" he said. "It's always money. Once people learned that it was possible to make $1 million or more, it became an attractive alternative." 
NOVICES, of course, cannot expect to reach those levels for some time. Because they draw no salary and work strictly on commission, they are advised to begin with a nest egg sufficient to ride out six months without any income.
"Even if you sell something on your first day, it won't close for three months," Mr. Lawrence of Corcoran said. Commissions are not fixed, but 6 percent is considered standard, though the rate can be negotiated up or down depending on the individual property, market conditions and unusual services required of the agent. "It's not like hanging a bracelet at Tiffany's," Ms. Braddock said. 
If the buyer has been brought in by an agent working with a brokerage other than the listing agency, the commission is split equally between the two firms. The agencies and the agents then divide their commissions. New salespeople generally receive 45 or 50 percent of the firm's commission, while star brokers command as much as 70 percent.
Most executives were reluctant to discuss actual income, but one after another emphasized that there is no ceiling and that top sales agents and brokers earn well into seven figures.
"If a new broker is successful in their first year, they should think in terms of $50,000 to $75,000 net," said Ms. Stribling. Later, "a good one will earn $200,000 to $300,000, and a lot take home $600,000. Top brokers net $1 million or more." 
A. J. Tesler means to be the exception to the six-month rule of thumb for nest eggs for those starting out. A theater major who graduated from Northwestern University two years ago, he is what is known in the industry as "a real estate brat." His mother is a former agent in Stamford, Conn. 
Mr. Tesler, who is 23, came to New York from Chicago in September and enrolled in a licensing course. On Oct. 1, he joined the downtown office of Coldwell Banker/Hunt Kennedy, where, he said, "one of the more experienced agents decided he wanted me to succeed, so he took me under his wing."
"I was told I wouldn't see any money for six months," he continued, "but I had a closing today, and it is No. 6." His smallest sale so far was a $100,000 studio; his largest, a $650,000 two-bedroom co-op.
"I used to sell yellow page ads door to door," Mr. Tesler said, recalling his first job. "Now I'm selling doors."

HEADLINE: Painting by the Numbers: What and Where Is Home? 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER 

DATELINE: SHILOH 

 BODY:
AT the heart of this Salem County farm town, six country roads converge at the weathered Richardson's General Store, where a half-dozen locals meet every morning at 6 for coffee and to discuss the world's woes. A sign over the counter reads "God, Guns and Guts Made America, Let's Keep All Three."
 According to no less an authority than the federal Bureau of the Census, Shiloh is the most American town in New Jersey, with 15.3 percent of the residents reporting their ancestry as American or United States. In neighboring Lower Alloways Creek, 15.2 percent said they were of American blood. 
 "New Jersey, especially North Jersey, is a melting pot of the world," said Clarence Woolbert, who worked as a part-time census worker in Salem County and lives in Lower Alloways Creek. "But in Salem County not much has changed a great deal in the 76 years that I've been around." 
"Many of these people have been in this area for five generations or more," he said. "So in my opinion, you should be calling us American."
Every 10 years the census reveals a big picture of the country, pointing to changing patterns of wealth, racial makeup, education and family structure.
Along with all that comes little slivers of insight into obscure corners of New Jersey and the way people live their daily lives. At the census bureau these data are known as "social characteristics."
How many rooms are in the house? How long have you lived there? How many cars in the driveway? How is the house heated? How many bathrooms do you have?
"The census is important because we need to know the social and economic characteristics of our nation," said Sen Yuan Wu, senior research economist in the state's Department of Labor. "For the civil aspects of government we need to know our social characteristics in order to plan or improve."
Mr. Wu said decisions about new schools, roads and hospitals were all rooted in census data.
But must we know about coal-burning furnaces and plumbing?
Mr. Wu said the questionnaire was approved by Congress and is standard across the country. "Just because a question doesn't seem important in New Jersey doesn't mean it's not important in West Virginia," he said.
When searching among New Jersey's 566 municipalities for census distinction, small size carries statistical stature. In many categories tiny Teterboro, population 16, in Bergen County and Tavistock, population 23, in Camden County topped the rankings. Walpack Township in Somerset County, population 37, ranked tops in the percentage of Irish, German and Hungarian ancestry.
"It's because the base is so small, it's very easy to get a high concentration in a particular area," said Mr. Wu. "It's not very meaningful in my opinion."
Shiloh and Lower Alloways Creek remain much the way they have for decades. Small family farms stretch out along the country roads, men still trap and skin muskrats for coats and locals still crab the Delaware Bay.
When pressed, Mr. Woolbert acknowledges he is of German, Irish and Welsh stock, but he can trace his great-great-grandfather to America, where there are now two generations beyond himself.
Kevin Deardorff, chief of ethnic and Hispanic statistics at the census bureau in Washington, said there had been an increase in people reporting American ancestry.
"One suggestion is that the number of people who haven't had recent migration experiences don't have the close affiliation with a specific country," he said. "Several generations of family are in the United States, and they feel that's where their heritage lies.
"On the other hand," Mr. Deardorff continued, "there is another possibility, that people who are recent immigrants -- first generation -- feel a particular affinity with the United States. They moved to the United States. They are naturalized citizens. Therefore, that's how they feel they want to be identified."

Americans or . . .?
Only the 19 million households receiving the long form of the census were asked about ancestry. Respondents could list more than one nationality. In the United States, 7 percent listed American ancestry. In New Jersey, 3.14 percent reported American ancestry, up from 2.2 percent in 1990.
Perhaps the oddest fact about ancestry in New Jersey is that its most Arab municipality attained that title because of its large Jewish population. According to the census, Deal Borough, in Monmouth County, is 22.6 percent Arab. But that is primarily because of its population of Sephardic Jews from Syria and elsewhere in the Arab world.
Mr. Deardorff explained that when people filled in the name of a country of ancestry, such as Syria, where the official language is Arabic, they were counted as Arab.
If they filled in Jewish, the answer was discounted, he said: "That's a religion."
Other results were almost surprising in their predictability. After Walpack and Tavistock, Spring Lake, New Jersey's so-called Irish Riviera, is indeed New Jersey's most Irish municipality. Just over half of Spring Lake's population, 50.7 percent, said it had roots in the auld sod.
English blood has diluted to the point where the highest concentration is 26.5 percent, in Cape May Point.
Agricultural Hammonton was New Jersey's most Italian town with 54.3 percent. After Teterboro, Millburn Township and Fair Lawn tied for most Russians with 11.7 percent. Milford Borough was the most German with 35 percent, disregarding Walpack.
Wallington is the top Polish town with 51.5 percent.
Mayor Walter Wargacki said that originally Poles migrated to the Wallington area in the early 20th century to work in textile mills and the local rubber plant. But a new wave occurred after the fall of Communism.
At first, he said, it was mostly blue-collar workers with family or friends in the area who helped sponsor their moves. Lately, he said, the immigrants have been professionals.
"We have constant turnover of new immigrants coming in, and it's not the same ones," Mr. Wargacki said. "Now we're getting doctors, architects, engineers and computer people that have come."
He said that immediately after the fall of Communism, professionals felt an obligation to stay in Poland to see what would happen to the economy. Eventually, many decided to strike out for the United States.
"The new immigrants believe in owning land because under Communism they couldn't," Mr. Wargacki said. "Here they have the opportunity to take an old house that's run-down and fix it up. The neighborhoods have been regenerated by the immigrant population that believes in property."
Property was also a major area of census inquiry.
In a state known for its bedroom communities and transient sprawl, Millstone in Somerset County is the most established, with 35.3 percent of the residents of its 167 housing units living there since 1969.
Ray McAdam, 83, arrived in 1962 when he bought a home dating to the early 1700's. He worked as a purser for T.W.A., commuting to New York for international flights several times a month.
Many of the residents work in New York, but many more are retired, Mr. McAdam said.
The town has many historic homes along the Millstone River and a new section of ranch homes known as "the Village," which was developed in the late 1960's.
Mr. McAdam said that there was a park in town but that people mostly socialize at small dinner parties where the discussion can be volatile.
"We have a lot of dissension," said Mr. McAdam. "When you get a lot of old people, they give their opinion. Nobody's here to impress anybody. It's impressive that they all still live here."

Something Old, Something New
The state's heaviest concentrations of newcomers, after Teterboro and Tavistock, are in Plainsboro Township in Middlesex County and New Hanover Township with only 0.9 percent of their populations in residence before 1969.
"Plainsboro was really a sleepy little town until there was a massive development of condos in the late 1980's," said Bruce Busch, a local real estate salesman.
Soon after the condos were built, Mr. Busch said, their prices plummeted. When their owners wanted to move, they rented the properties with one-year leases. Now prices are up again and people are selling, he said, creating another wave of transience.
The leader in owner-occupied units valued at $1 million or more is Alpine with 57.8 percent of its 612 homes in that price range. Next are two other Bergen County municipalities, Saddle River and Rockleigh.
The state's oldest homes are in Loch Arbour Village, Monmouth County, where 83.5 percent of its 158 housing units were built before 1939. 
Jim Foley, a local historian, said the town's Victorian homes were built as summer residences for wealthy New Yorkers: "I don't think there's been a new home built in Loch Arbour in many a year."
Other towns with well-worn homes include Glen Ridge and Montclair in Essex County; Riverton and Bordentown in Burlington County; Lambertville, Bloomsbury and Frenchtown in Hunterdon County, and Princeton borough in Mercer County.
Surprisingly, when it comes to the number of units in a structure, Shrewsbury Township, Monmouth County, has the smallest percentage of single-family homes, topping Hoboken, West New York, Union City Weehawken and other urban municipalities.
There is but one single-family home in Shrewsbury Township, which has a total of 546 housing units, mostly in attached rows, all built to house military men and their families during World War II.
Jack Moran, a recently retired Amtrak employee who invests in properties in the area, bought the two-bedroom home two years ago and rents it to a father and son.
"It was unique," he said. "It was the only unattached one, so I bought it as an investment. I'm thinking of gutting the place eventually, maybe for my retirement."
But $1 million homes and single-family residences are not all the census found.
Englishtown reported that 9.6 percent of its 643 housing units had no kitchen, but town officials attribute that largely to the communal kitchen at Liberty Manor, an assisted-living center with 71 units.
In seven towns, more than 2 percent of the housing units did not have complete plumbing facilities, defined as hot and cold piped-in water, a flush toilet and a bathtub or a shower. In Camden, 14 percent of the city's 24,1778 housing units have no phone.
Arnold Cohen, policy coordinator for the Housing and Community Development Network of New Jersey in Trenton, said the municipal figures often masked pockets of poor housing in affluent towns.
"New Jersey is one of the most expensive housing markets," he said. "Whether it's elderly who can no longer afford to live in a community because of the high property taxes or the inability of children to live in a community where they grew up, or even people who work in professions, teachers, firefighters and police, we have segregated off the poor and not put the resources into revitalizing communities."
While the latest batch of census results was released in the heat of summer, it delves deep into how New Jersey residents heat their homes.
White Township in Warren County, near the anthracite coal country in Pennsylvania, has the highest percent of homes heated with coal in New Jersey, with 1.9 percent of the 1,668 housing units.
"There is a good chunk of people who have moved to this part of New Jersey who are from the coal areas around Scranton or Wilkes-Barre and were presold on that type of heating," said Nicholas Ritter, vice president of L. E. Ritter Lumber Company, which sells building materials and coal.
Mr. Ritter, who converted his own home to coal heat, said coal was efficient and sold for half the price of heating oil, although installation of a new coal-burning system cost about double that of a new gas system.
Mr. Ritter said his company delivered coal to about 200 customers in the area, which supports four or five coal dealers.
"We believe in coal," he said. "I've had coal heat all of my life, and the few times I've moved into places heated otherwise I was never happy."
If coal heat seems antiquated, consider Kathy Schoonfield who lives in Estell Manor, Atlantic County, the municipality with the highest percentage of homes heated by wood. Of the town's 529 homes, 9.6 percent are heated that way.
In Estell Manor, zoning requires homes be set on 5 to 25 acres, so most homeowners, like Mrs. Schoonfield, have woods on their property.
"It's free," said Mrs. Schoonfield of her primary heat source.
In the summer, Mrs. Schoonfield walks through the woods and marks the leafless dead trees and limbs with pink surveyor's tape so her husband, Drew, can identify them in the winter when all of the trees have lost their leaves.
She hacks the bigger logs with a small handsaw and stokes the wood-burning stove that keeps her three children warm all winter.
"It's just a little hard work," she said. "You've got to bring the wood in and you've got to watch it in the stove. But once it gets cold enough, you get into a rhythm."
Finally there are those who said they didn't live in a house at all.
Long Beach Township in Ocean County had the highest percent of people -- 1.18 percent -- who said they lived on a boat, or in a recreational vehicle or van.
Town residents pointed to the High Bar Harbor Yacht Club, a private club at the edge of town, for an explanation.
Oops! It is illegal to live on a boat in Long Beach Township.
Joe Egles, manager of the yacht club, said none of the boat owners, who pay about $40,000 to $60,000 for a slip, actually lived on their boats, no matter what they may have told the census.
"They might have written that down," he said, "but either they're just boasting or they only wish they lived on a boat."

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
A Path Paved in Dreams, Not in Gold

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
EVER wonder what prompts a rising executive to jump off the corporate fast track and into the not-for-profit world? If so, read on, and decide whether Robert L. Waldron represents an anomaly, or a societal change.
 At 36, Rob Waldron had his career all mapped out. He had a degree from the Harvard Business School and experience as a Morgan Stanley analyst, and he ran the San Francisco region for Kaplan Educational Centers. In 1996, Kaplan bought Score, a $2 million tutoring company, and let Mr. Waldron run it. By May 2001, when Mr. Waldron took off to Boston to help a college friend start a software company, Score's yearly sales had ballooned to $50 million. 
 Mr. Waldron looked in the mirror and saw a budding corporate chief. So when Kristine Stotz Langdon, a director at the executive search firm of Spencer Stuart, tried to recruit him to Jumpstart, a program to help disadvantaged youngsters succeed in school, he brushed her away.
"I just wanted to run a big company and make a ton of money doing it," he said. "I felt it was the only way you proved you were smart, accomplished, a success."
Note the past tense, "felt." Try as he would, Mr. Waldron could not shut out the larger world. He would read about the drug problem, about the Arab-Israeli conflict, about poverty, and he would feel a mounting sense of helplessness. "It seemed like the problems in the world were increasing all the time," he said.
Then came Sept. 11.
For two horrible hours, he mistakenly thought that his wife's sister, who lived in Battery Park City, near the World Trade Center, had died. Then came anthrax scares and a mad dash to stock up on Cipro. Then came the rumors of poisoned reservoirs and the equally mad dash to stock up on bottled water.
Suddenly, money seemed a pathetic life's goal. "I had this terrible need to feel like I was fixing something," he said.
When the persistent Ms. Langdon called again, Mr. Waldron acquiesced. In March, at the age of 37, he became Jumpstart's chief executive.
He is earning a third what he made at Kaplan and a fraction of what he thinks he might have reaped from the start-up. He sometimes feels pangs about making his wife, Jennifer, and the child they are expecting in September live on a budget -- albeit, he acknowledges, not a terribly stringent one. When those feelings come up, his wife talks him down.
"I still want to win, and my whole life has been about solving problems," he said. "She reminds me that helping children read, that's solving a problem and winning, too."
So, that question again: Is chaos in the world -- and, lately, scandal in corporate America -- yielding more Rob Waldrons? Talks with recruiters turn up adamant yeses -- and equally adamant nos and maybes.
"A growing number of high-ranking executives are not even waiting to be called but are seeking us out to ask about moving to the nonprofit world," said Malcolm MacKay, the not-for-profit specialist at the search firm of Russell Reynolds Associates.
If so, they are not calling Michael Kirkman, who runs the not-for-profit practice at Korn/Ferry International. "There's no avalanche of people wanting to change the world," he said, "only a slightly greater inclination toward the public sector." 
Ms. Langdon, meanwhile, sees even that as an overstatement. "I'm not finding people to be more receptive at all," she said, noting how long it took her to woo Mr. Waldron.
THE difficulty of the searches -- and the low fees they often yield -- is still not discouraging recruiters from taking them on. With the economy sluggish and many companies doing more firing than hiring, they certainly have the time.
In the first quarter, not-for-profit clients were 22 percent of Korn/Ferry's search load, versus 7 percent in the corresponding period of 2001.
"Of course it's going to be a larger percentage of our circle of searches, since the total of searches is down," Mr. Kirkman acknowledged.
Of course, some people moved from the corporate world to the charitable one long before Sept. 11. Some of the switching dates back at least six years, when the baby boomers started turning 50. Many had become rich on stock options and Internet stocks during the 1990's bull market. Their children had finished college, and mortgages had been paid. They were too energetic to retire and young enough to embark on second careers.
At the same time, government, universities and philanthropies recognized that they needed people who were knowledgeable about business. A result was a steady trickle of managerial talent from the private to the public sector.
Most recruiters agree that the flow increased a bit over the last year. They say the terrorist attacks, coupled with the nonprofit world's growing respect for business expertise, probably did a lot to polish the image of the nonprofit world, just as corporate scandals were tarnishing the title of chief executive.
"The trend has less to do with Sept. 11 than with a real unhappiness and embarrassment over what's happening in the commercial world," said Mr. MacKay of Russell Reynolds.
But even that explanation is not so cut and dried. Just ask Charles F. Kalmbach Jr. Mr. Kalmbach, 55, was a global managing partner at Accenture when Mr. MacKay recruited him to become Princeton University's senior vice president for administration in February. He had plenty of money, Princeton was his alma mater, he liked its new president, and he felt that academia was going through exciting changes. He happily said yes.
He does not regret his choice, he said. But for the first time it seems to carry a hefty opportunity cost.
"There's all this turmoil in the corporate world," he said, just a wisp of longing in his voice. "It sure would have been great fun to be a consultant right now."

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for MONA DOYLE; 
How Long Will the Shopping Spree Last?

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER BAYOT 

 BODY:
 MAYBE it was just the warm weather, but consumers went on a shopping spree last month at America's malls and stores, giving major retailers a healthy sales gain after a soft spring. The big discount chains like Wal-Mart, Kohl's and Target all exceeded Wall Street estimates of June sales. Whether shoppers will continue to spend at a relatively robust rate is unclear. Many economic forecasters have said the plummeting stock market and the loss of investor confidence from the barrage of corporate scandals will inevitably catch up to the consumer, who will feel more insecure, less wealthy and less inclined to shop. 
 Mona Doyle, president of Consumer Network Inc., a market research firm in Philadelphia that surveys shoppers, says cynicism about the integrity of American business is seeping into how shoppers think, although it hasn't deterred them from shopping. Ms. Doyle spoke last Thursday after major retailers reported their sales gains for June. JENNIFER BAYOT

Q. How has the news of accounting and other corporate scandals affected the mood of shoppers? What's the connection?

A. All the talk about the marketplace -- how much corruption is there, corporate greed, the C.E.O. problems -- all of that has been presented by the media in terms of investors. But consumers are connecting what they're hearing in the news to the low levels of service they're seeing at clothing stores and the supermarket. We've heard consumers say things like: "Management is too busy doing their own thing and covering their own tracks and lining their own pockets to pay attention to consumers. The fact is we're not being taken care of, it's not the employees fault, it's managers' fault."

Q. Are retailers carrying a lot of inventory now? Are stores selling at a loss to reduce high levels of inventory? Are they stockpiling for a boom later?

A. I can't speak about retailers. The consumer perception is that there is a real glut in the stores, that shopping is really made much more difficult by the amount of excess merchandise. It's just too crowded. They can't navigate. The perception is there hasn't been any softening of inventory. Are stores slashing prices? If they are, they haven't gotten that message to consumers -- not right now. The consumers don't think there are huge bargains out there. For them, the low levels of service -- of store associates and employee information -- are concerns; that shopping is harder than it has to be, harder than it should be.

Q. Economists have repeatedly expressed concern about the high level of consumer credit card debt. Are shoppers spending more than they can afford?

A. I think a lot of people have really worked very hard to pull back on credit card spending, but for every 1,000 people who are getting in line, another 10,000 get trapped because they need things and they max out.

Q. The June sales results show shoppers spent at a greater rate than they had this spring, especially at the discount retailers like Wal-Mart, Target and Kohl's. What should we conclude? And how has Kmart's bankruptcy filing changed the landscape?

A. Besides getting things cheaper, people are getting nice treatment at Wal-Mart. In one of our surveys, 45 percent agreed that Wal-Mart has most of what they need. We also had 45 percent saying that Wal-Mart greeters are great. At Kohl's, people really like the shopping experience and the values. The perception is Kohl's is for stylish merchandise, cheaper.
The perception that you can get everything you need at Kmart has eroded. Kmart may have the stores looking full, but the variety is not there. I think a fair number of people tried to shop at Kmart to be helpful, and many of these people have felt burned. What I expect to happen is really going to depend on whether suppliers continue to support them. If Kmart goes under, Wal-Mart and Target are really going to have more control over the suppliers. Will Martha Stewart go to Sears, and will that make a difference? It's hard to say how that will play out.

Q. Do you see any trends in what shoppers are buying this summer?

A. I think the action is in products that are mobile. The "to go" market is increasingly huge. I saw that Black & Decker is now selling a coffee dripper where the coffee flows into a great big 20-ounce mug that you just take with you. Just this morning I saw the new baby strollers that have something like a car's dashboard: there's room for the mother's and father's and baby's water bottles. It's a new turtle society -- we carry everything with us, we expect it to be convenient. We're going to be more and more mobile, and we're going to have more and more with us.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
New Reasons To Wonder If the Worst Is Over

BYLINE:  By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
HOW much worse could the worst bear market in a generation get? A lot.
 For some insight into just how bad things could still turn out on Wall Street, it is worth paying attention to Robert D. Arnott, managing partner at First Quadrant, a money management firm in Pasadena, Calif., and co-author of a provocative recent article in the Financial Analysts Journal. It has the seemingly innocuous title, "What Risk Premium is 'Normal'?" 
 "The market has come down quite a bit from the unprecedented levels it reached a couple of years ago," Mr. Arnott says. "It has now reached the same valuation level as at the market top in 1929." 
That's right, the market top: before the crash that heralded the start of the Depression, not afterward.
Mr. Arnott, whose view of market history extends a bit further than that of most people on Wall Street (his research examines the performance of stocks back to 1802) doesn't really expect the kind of stock market collapse that occurred from 1929 to 1933. And he certainly doesn't expect the economy to fall apart; indeed, he is counting on economic growth to average the same rate of the last three decades.
But his study is a powerful reminder of just how over the top the stock market became in the 1990's and how much more downward adjustment may still be needed before prices reflect a fair valuation of the earnings and dividends that support them.
To reach that point, Mr. Arnott predicts, Wall Street may have to endure a long spell -- a decade or longer -- in which the stock market, while providing plenty of ups and downs, repeatedly disappoints investors. "I would be very surprised," Mr. Arnott said, "if bonds don't outperform stocks over the next decade or so." Meanwhile, he added, "The economy is probably going to be fine; it will just take a decade or two to catch up with what the market had anticipated."
Even as everybody from President Bush on down struggles to restore confidence among investors who no longer trust corporate earnings reports, the bitter truth is that stocks may go up on a sustained basis only after they have fallen far enough that investors are persuaded that they can go no lower.
As James Grant, the editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, wrote recently: "If U.S. stocks were absolutely and unequivocally cheap, today's alleged crisis would be self-correcting. Having fled an overvalued market, people would be creeping back into an undervalued one."
The problem, to vastly simplify Mr. Arnott's complex analysis, stems from the fact that investors in recent years failed to resolve a fundamental contradiction.
On one hand, they seemingly forgot that stocks are inherently riskier than bonds and began bidding up prices in the market accordingly. That drove down the so-called risk premium for holding stocks until it essentially vanished. Yet at the same time, investors came to believe that stocks -- because they are supposed to reward investors for taking extra risk -- would continue to outperform bonds and inflation.
YOU can't have it both ways indefinitely. When stocks were priced at, say, 12 times earnings and offered dividend yields of 4 to 5 percent, it was very easy to beat the return from government bonds and inflation by 5 to 8 percentage points a year. But when the market, at its top in 2000, was selling at about 35 times earnings and dividends were yielding barely more than 1 percent, investors could no longer expect to maintain such premium returns.
David Bowers, Merrill Lynch's chief global investment strategist, said in a recent report that "this sell-off has not just been about the overvaluation of U.S. stocks." 
"Rather, it has turned into a full-scale reassessment of the attractiveness of stocks versus bonds," he added. "And stocks have so far been the losers."
For the bull market to return, Mr. Arnott reasons, either the stock market must fall even more or earnings and dividends must soar. But his research found, contrary to the conventional wisdom on Wall Street, that the growth in earnings and dividends over the longer run cannot even keep up with real economic growth per person, largely because new enterprises rather than established companies account for a significant share of the gains.
"Earnings growth will not keep pace with G.D.P. growth -- that's a really important insight," said David Levine, a former chief economist at Sanford C. Bernstein.
Like everyone who tries to understand the market, Mr. Arnott could turn out to be wrong about the future. But even though, as he wryly acknowledges, "it is hard to get rewarded for telling people what they don't want to hear," it pays these days to listen.

HEADLINE: ESSAY; 
An Affair to Remember

BYLINE:  By ANNIE COHEN-SOLAL; Annie Cohen-Solal is the author of "Sartre: A Life" and writes frequently about French intellectuals and cultural policy. She was recently named professor in American studies at the University of Caen in Normandy. She lives in Paris and the West Village.

 BODY:
IN April 1977, Janine, a Palestinian friend who worked for a travel agency in Paris, asked me whether I wanted a free charter-jet ticket to spend Easter weekend in New York. 
 At the time, nothing seemed farther away. I was spending whole days at the Bibliotheque Nationale on Rue de Richelieu, arriving at 8:45 a.m., before all the others, to get a peaceful corner seat, a row behind the philosopher Michel Foucault, working painstakingly on my Ph.D. "Well, are you interested in this free ticket?" Janine asked again on one of her many phone calls. "It would give you a break. And, anyway, the library is closed over Easter weekend." 
 That persuaded me. I already knew two people in New York: Eleonore Ament, a pianist trained at Juilliard, who had been my roommate on Kibbutz Beit Alfa, in Upper Galilee, and Laurent Jenny, a friend from the good old activist days of May 1968, who taught literary theory at Columbia. Both lived on the Upper West Side. 
Once I arrived in New York, I could not rest, could not sleep, could not even sit. For three days and three nights, I walked with Eleonore, walked with Laurent, bewitched, obsessed by the city. I recall the thrill of freedom at crossing Broadway in the middle of the night, the feeling of infinite possibilities when stepping into a grocery store at 4 a.m. to buy a toasted bagel. 
Then there was the desperate charm of those gloomy apartments on West 99th Street, decorated with East European Jewish furniture and infested with impossibly gymnastic cockroaches. I scrutinized the 20-floor buildings, trying to adapt to brand-new proportions. I remember my reckless decision to immerse myself in the city's chaotic layers of beauty. Was it the smells, the smoke, the noise, the sirens of the police cars, the juxtaposition of so many cultures that moved me? 
New York ferried me back to childhood memories of Algiers -- the bags of spices on the other side of my grandparents' apartment near the Casbah, the sirens of the harbor boats, the smell of burned coffee, the churning traffic of cultures near the open sea, the lingering sense of a nearby sprawling danger -- and I instantly became a New York addict.
I know that I am not alone in this addiction, especially among Parisians. And the attraction runs both ways. New York and Paris are two of the world's great cultural capitals. Just as Parisians ache for New York, so New Yorkers long for Paris. I've been lucky enough to be on both sides of that trans-Atlantic yearning.
I came to New York again in October 1989 as cultural counselor for the the French Embassy. The offices of the cultural services were located in the Fifth Avenue mansion, near 78th Street, designed by Stanford White for the Payne Whitney family. For the next four years, I experienced the city through the history of this house. Every morning, when the guard opened the wrought-iron gate, I stepped into turn-of-the-century New York: white marble floors, the Cupid balanced on the back of three turtle shells that I presented to guests as "attributed to Michelangelo," a grand staircase decorated with John LaFarge's stained-glass windows "The Seasons," and the magnificent arched bow windows in the sitting room overlooking Central Park.
With its 40 rooms and five stories, this Italian Renaissance-style palace that Oliver H. Payne commissioned as a wedding gift for his nephew was the most expensive mansion that Stanford White ever built in the city. I tried to learn as much as I could about the Whitneys, buried myself in books about them, and devoured biographies of Stanford White.
After reading E. L. Doctorow's "Ragtime," I dreamed of throwing a fancy ball where, as in Milos Forman's movie, Norman Mailer would arrive dressed as Stanford White. I had trouble, though, finding anyone who would agree to be Evelyn Nesbit, once one of White's lovers, let alone Harry Thaw, Nesbit's husband, who killed White. "No guns allowed," I planned to add on the invitation.
But, as much as I savored my New York life, I still missed Paris. After an exhausting week of work, on Saturday mornings an irrepressible nostalgia for Paris washed over me. I would have given anything to walk downstairs to a nearby market. For a long time, I thought that what I really missed was French food -- the strong coffee, the fresh baguette, the salted butter, the sophisticated brebis cheeses. 
It took months before I realized that what I could not live without was not so much the food, but the daily human contact of a Parisian public market or local street. These contacts, quilted of negotiations, of gossip, of jokes, of bets on soccer matches, almost build a village life. Monsieur Crouzat, my butcher on the Rue de Verneuil, once told me: "The local Parisian store owners do indeed practice a social link; they make the street life. When a customer has not showed up for a few days, my wife calls him up to know what's going on."
I was torn between my love affair for New York and the homely lure of Paris. But my New York life finally felt less forlorn once I moved downtown. "Welcome to the West Village," Bud and Alice Trillin said to me. "It's a little bit like going to Europe." 
I adored living in the Printing House on Hudson Street and St. Luke's Place. I shopped on Bleecker, the epitome of the New York Italian street -- with its Sicilian baker, its Neapolitan butcher and its Calabrian pastry shop. On Saturday mornings, I would go to the farmers' market at Union Square, where the quince jam, fresh bread and broken pretzels somehow became a pale version of the Parisian markets. 
Downtown, where I slowly started to find my bearings again, I still resented the absence of so many Parisian commodities like street furniture -- the shelter where you can sit and avoid the rain while waiting for the bus, or the sophisticated fleuristes who might spend 15 minutes assembling a bouquet for you, or the daily voitures-balai that clean each Parisian street with water and brush.
Paris is a city that carries its own wounds and marks of violence, and the catastrophe of Sept. 11 in New York was considered here at first with silent dismay, mute empathy and speechless panic. "New York, September 11, 2001" was the stark headline that the daily paper Liberation presented on two full pages, under the pictures of the emasculated city skyline. Indeed, those horrible events have led some Parisians to believe that, with the experience of a "mutilated city," they and New Yorkers now share not just a mutual attraction, but a common fate.
STILL, for all the two cities share, the differences are crucial. When I left New York, after seven and a half years, it took me five years to get used to Paris again. With many friends who have felt the same pain, we play with the idea of starting a support group. Some of them indeed started seeing a shrink, some tried drugs, some fell into depression, some gathered on Sunday night to watch "Sex and the City" on the Teva channel.
"I suffocate in Paris," my friend Frank, a young French lawyer trained at N.Y.U., tells me over and over. "I resent the mentality of this society. The fear of taking risks, the lack of trust for young professionals, the rigidities, the archaisms and, above all, the 35-hour-week law, which might well diminish the unemployment rate, but kills all personal initiatives." 
For Jerome Godefroy, a journalist who moved back to Paris last fall after 12 years in New York, the return was like "coming back to a peaceful, quiet and provincial town."
"Beautiful indeed, but so unbelievably drowsy!" he added. "I found people and things intact, exactly as they were 12 years ago; nothing had changed or evolved, and more and more I am struck by a feeling of absolute stagnation."
But what do we really miss? We miss the New York weather and its intensity. We miss the city's arterial beat, its constant nudgings to wake up again and go on. Sometimes we agree that we suffer from an obsession with the city that never sleeps. "The main problem of Paris is its last metro," the writer Jerome Charyn, a regular shuttler between the West Village and Montparnasse, once told me. "The last metro is like a mark-off point where the ordinary Parisian can travel. In New York, there is no last metro."
Recently, while weathering the pains of moving out of my beloved New York apartment, I bought the most sophisticated tri-band cellphone and an e-mail-equipped digital organizer that allows me to read The New York Times online.
And after surfing the Web for trans-Atlantic flights and learning frequent-flyer tricks, I have decided that the only way to live peacefully is to accept my fate -- and shuttle between the two cities.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF; 
This Cable Story Offers a Lesson (And a Happy Ending)

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
HINDSIGHT, of course, brings great clarity. We look back at the technological advances of the late 18th and 19th centuries -- from the steam engine and the railroad to the telephone and the automobile -- and speak of the Industrial Revolution without hesitation. The economic and social legacy of the innovations of the industrial era is apparent, while the doubts, boom-bust cycles and investment schemes are mostly forgotten. History has long since sorted out the winners from the losers, the visionaries from the charlatans.
 Whether we will ever speak of a "digital revolution" in quite the same way is not clear. At the moment, it looks doubtful, given the depressed state of most technology companies, their battered stock prices, and attendant bankruptcies and scandals. But the issue has little to do with the fate of some dot-com start-ups, the trend of personal computer sales or the current travails of telecommunications companies. 
 No, the long-term question is whether the combination of exponential growth in computing power, global networks and clever software can transform one field after another -- medicine, communications, media, manufacturing and so on. Yes, computing is, in a sense, merely a tool. But unlike hammers or screwdrivers, computers are general purpose tools, which can be used, when properly programmed, for most everything from unraveling the mysteries of the human genome to outwitting the world's chess champion. This is what helps make the digital question interesting.
If the digital revolution is to rival the Industrial Revolution in significance, it will require a lot more than technology. It will require investment, patience and entrepreneurs who care more about building something of value than trying to make a quick buck.
Anyone in search of a historical antidote to the current gloom and an inspiring narrative of entrepreneurial triumph would do well to read "A Thread Across the Ocean" (Walker & Company, $26), John Steele Gordon's account of Cyrus Field and the first trans-Atlantic telegraph cable. Field persevered for 12 years and through four failed attempts to lay a working telegraph cable across the Atlantic before succeeding in 1866.
Over the years, Field was alternately an object of public adulation and scorn. His personal reputation and wealth were entirely committed to the submarine cable venture. 
He was prone to seasickness, but he made 50 trans-Atlantic crossings by ship to raise money, meet with engineers and oversee operations in Britain. About to set out on one cable-laying attempt, he recalled, "When I thought of all we had passed through, of the hopes thus far disappointed, of the friends saddened by our reverses, of the few that remained to sustain us, I felt a load at my heart almost too heavy to bear, though my confidence was firm and my determination fixed." 
That mission, like others, ended in failure, and it would be eight more years before he prevailed. Talk about the entrepreneurial right stuff.
For his book, Mr. Gordon relied heavily on previous biographies of Field and accounts of the trans-Atlantic cable. Based on his footnotes, four books in particular were sources. Two were published in the 19th century: "The Story of the Atlantic Cable," by Henry M. Field, the younger brother of Cyrus, and "Cyrus W. Field, His Life and Work," edited by Isabella Field Judson, a daughter of Cyrus Field. The others are Arthur C. Clarke's "Voice Across the Sea" (1958) and "Cyrus Field: Man of Two Worlds," by Samuel Carter III (1968).
Yet Mr. Gordon's book is a masterly retelling of the cable adventure, filled with illuminating detail about the times and the people who made it happen. Field was the son of a renowned New England preacher, and his more studious brothers became distinguished lawyers and ministers. But Cyrus Field was attracted to business -- its pace, pulse and risk-taking. He went to New York and made his early fortune turning around a failing wholesaler of paper and printing supplies.
Once he had revived the business, he had little interest in running it. After he and his friend Frederic Church, the landscape painter, took a long trip to South America -- Field collecting biological specimens, Church painting -- Field became intrigued by the possibility of a trans-Atlantic telegraph cable. By connecting the old and new worlds, he recognized, the cable would have enormous business potential, reducing the speed of trans-Atlantic transmission of information from weeks by ship to just minutes or seconds and thus greatly accelerating the 19th-century wave of globalization.
IN the 1850's, Mr. Gordon writes, science and capitalism combined to engender great optimism, almost of a sense of technological manifest destiny. The journalism and oratory of the day were filled with references to the "genius of man" and "the subjugation of nature." So in 1854, Field raised $1.5 million -- a huge amount at the time, but a fraction of the eventual cost -- from a small group of similarly enthusiastic investors. Field would later recall: "God knows that none of us were aware of what we had undertaken to accomplish."
Field was no technologist, but he did his homework and had a genuine intellectual interest in the technical aspects of the cable project. It was also a time when scientists and engineers tended to be generalists -- educated and informed in other disciplines. Over the years, Field engaged all kinds of inventors, oceanographers, physicists and engineers from Samuel Morse to Isambard Kingdom Brunel. 
And he would need them all, because the trans-Atlantic cable, like the Internet, was made possible by advances in a collection of technologies, all coming together.
Field's technical education came gradually and at some cost. He and the other original investors were so lacking in knowledge in the nascent field of electrical engineering, Mr. Gordon writes, that they vastly underestimated the challenge of their trans-Atlantic project. One management lesson from "the Victorian equivalent of the Apollo project" seems to be that business timetables can be mercilessly compressed to save money and meet deadlines, but that a promising technology often takes time to percolate, through trial, error and refinement, before it comes to fruition.
Field had to wait 12 years. When the cable was finally in place and working in 1866, and a cable that had been lost at sea 13 months earlier had been recovered, Field received a six-letter message: "Both O.K."
"I left the room," he later recalled, "I went to my cabin, I locked the door; I could no longer restrain my tears -- crying like a child."

(Marcell Vandehaar)

HEADLINE: Business; 
Paper or Plastic? Currency Making Is in Flux

BYLINE:  By CAROLYN MARSHALL 

 BODY:
PAPER money first appeared in China more than 13 centuries ago, and the counterfeiting industry was born soon after. But now a growing number of countries, worried about inexpensive technology that enables a counterfeiter armed with little more than a computer inkjet printer to create real-looking fakes to the untrained eye, are switching to plastic.
 Australia, which converted entirely to plastic bank notes in 1996 because of chronic counterfeiting, has turned them into an entrepreneurial export business. It licenses plastic bank-note technology used by 15 governments including those of Taiwan, Brazil and Mexico. Some of the 12 European Union members that have adopted the single currency, the euro, have been researching polymer materials for possible future use. Canada may issue a plastic $50 or $100 bill next year. The United States Treasury has tested at least four polymer compounds, seeking a plastic that might someday replace the paper greenback. 
 While the change to plastic is hardly universal, it has enormous implications for how hundreds of billions of dollars' worth of everyday cash moves through the global financial system. 
"Any time there is a redesign of banknotes, we have to redesign the hardware and software in our machines," said Richard Baggot, vice president for electronic security and currency systems at Diebold Inc., based in North Canton, Ohio, and a leading maker of currency-counting machines for big banks.
A changeover to plastic is not necessarily smooth, even though plastic notes appear to be nearly counterfeit-proof, more durable than paper and even recyclable. Replacements or adjustments are needed not only for currency counting machines but also for A.T.M.'s and vending machines. Some machines have had difficulty recognizing plastic notes, which have the look, thinness and flexibility of paper but feel smoother.
Mr. Baggot said plastic presents a new kind of challenge because its physical properties are different than those of paper. "We have to keep all of the properties intact -- the machine has to count and sort the old and new at the same time," he said.
There have been problems. Kevin Newton, a vice president for global design at Diebold, said dog-eared or nicked plastic bills have jammed some A.T.M.'s, and plastic notes with even tiny rips have been torn in half. But Mr. Newton, whose company dominates the global market for currency machinery, said the glitches so far have been minor. 
Rob Evans, director for industry marketing at NCR, a big maker of A.T.M.'s that is based in Dayton, Ohio, said the plastic bill has benefits over paper. "It stays clean and lasts a long time," he said. "It really is a nice document to dispense."
IN fact, it is now widely acknowledged in the world of paper currency that plastic means more than just credit cards. The United States, which has more paper bills in circulation than any country, at $608 billion, began to incorporate a small plastic thread into new bills in 1996, to distinguish them from counterfeits. And Treasury officials are openly complimentary of Australia's plastic notes.
"It's a very interesting product, a good product," said Thomas A. Ferguson, director of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing at the Treasury Department. "Some countries have decided the economic benefits merit making the switch."
For now, the United States will keep using paper as the basic material, Mr. Ferguson said. But, he added, "that does not mean polymer won't be a factor in the future."
The shift to plastic has its roots in the advances in computers, digital scanners and inkjet printers that have made the counterfeiting of paper money easier. Governments that use paper find themselves redesigning their currencies much more often to stay a step ahead of forgeries.
"You will never eliminate counterfeiting completely; the technology is moving too fast," said James Mackin, a spokesman for the Secret Service's Counterfeit Division. 
Counterfeiting of United States bills has jumped in the last few years, Secret Service data shows: in 2001, $47.5 million of fake bank notes passed into circulation domestically, up from $39.7 million in 2000. Mr. Mackin attributed much of the increase to what he called casual counterfeiters who previously might not have had the skills or printing presses to create fake money. In 2001, Mr. Mackin said, 39 percent of all counterfeits circulating domestically were created on computers, up from half a percent in 1995.
Les Coventry, who is in charge of note issue at the Reserve Bank of Australia, talks more like a salesman than a government banker when it comes to plastic bank notes. 
Mr. Coventry said Australia's plastic, a nonporous, thin polymer sheath, resists tearing, water, sweat, oil and bacteria. But the main selling point, he said, is a transparent window embedded in the bank note that makes it impossible to copy on an inkjet printer. The bank notes are produced by Securency Ltd., a joint venture of the Reserve Bank of Australia and UCB, a Belgian chemical firm. 
"The next generation of security features will raise the technology bar," Mr. Coventry said. "And we have not started to explore the possibilities yet."
The two dozen companies that make the specialty paper for currencies around the world have clearly taken notice of the trend toward plastic. Domtar Inc., a large paper producer based in Montreal, has developed its own plastic for bank notes.
DuPont, Exxon Mobil and Agfa-Gavaert are among companies that have patented technology for the manufacture of plastic bank notes.
Others are more skeptical of plastic, particularly Crane & Company of Dalton, Mass., the sole supplier of bank-note paper to the United States Treasury. Lansing E. Crane, the chief executive of the company, which is privately held, said it was premature to conclude that plastic is superior.
"The plastic people say the main benefit is the counterfeiting deterrence. It's nonsense," he said, contending that advances in anticounterfeit technology had made paper notes just as good. The selling point of plastic, Mr. Crane said, "is its durability, and the marketplace will determine whether plastic notes stand the test of time." 
Just how long plastic notes last is unclear, partly because they have been around for only a few years. Australia says its plastic $5 note has an average circulation life of 40 months, versus six months for Australia's previous, paper version. But in many cases, the life span of paper notes in other leading industrialized countries is not much different from Australia's plastic; the United State Treasury says its typical $5 bill lasts 24 months, and the $20 bill lasts 48 months.
The Bank of Canada has not yet decided whether to use a plastic note next year, said Joseph Basile, a consultant at the bank. But the possibility arises primarily from concerns about counterfeiting.
Canada has been plagued by an epidemic of fake $100 Canadian dollar bills. Last July the police said they shut down a counterfeiting ring that had used a computer scanner and inkjet printer to produce more than 40,000 of the bills. But a new crop of fake bills, from a different source, was discovered in Newfoundland last February. And many Canadian merchants have posted signs warning that they do not accept $100 bills, fearing that they are fakes.
Canada's prototype plastic note was invented by scientists at Domtar. Raman Nayar, vice president of Domtar's product development and marketing division, described it as a layer of plastic sandwiched between two outer layers of paper. The design gives consumers the familiar feel of paper money, coupled with the durability and strength of plastic, he said. 
Domtar has sold the mill that produces the plastic to Spexel Inc. of Beauharnois, Quebec, the central bank's paper supplier. But Domtar retains the patent. "We were so high on the technology that we kept it in-house," Mr. Nayor said. "We think it will take hold worldwide in the next few years." 
Mr. Crane, whose company has supplied the United States Treasury with bank-note paper since 1879 and clearly regards the United States as its most important client, hinted that advances in plastic could eventually force him to enter that business. Asked what he would do if the United States switched to plastic, Mr. Crane said: "We're in the bank-note business. We're here to serve our customers."

 CORRECTION:
A chart last Sunday with an article listing countries that have switched to plastic bank notes from paper included an incomplete reference to Romania. While the country indeed introduced a 2,000-lei plastic note in 1999, it switched completely to plastic last year, adding denominations of 10,000, 50,000, 100,000 and 500,000 lei.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Patent IssuesHurting Big Drug Companies

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE 

 BODY:
MANY investors who fled the collapse of technology stocks have sought refuge in shares of global drug makers, traditionally known for consistent earnings growth in all kinds of economic conditions.
 Since last fall, however, the stocks of big pharmaceutical companies have tumbled amid concerns about competition from generic drugs and a slowdown in the number of products in the approval pipeline. The sell-off has left the sector trading roughly in line with the broad market. 
 The market concerns are genuine, fund managers and analysts say. Although they see some possible bargains, mainly among European companies, they advise investors to tread carefully and to resist the temptation to buy just because prices have fallen sharply. 
"There are a few companies that have come down quite a long way and don't look very well," said Emil Doerig, a manager of global pharmaceutical and health care funds for Credit Suisse Asset Management in Zurich. "Investors are of the opinion that drug companies have insufficient new products in the pipeline to compensate for old ones" whose patents are expiring. "Many products have lost patents," he added, "and generic manufacturers are challenging existing patents."
The patent assault, based on an argument that the new drugs are substantially the same as the old ones with expiring patents, has been initiated by makers of less expensive generic drugs. The patent challenges came at a particularly bad time for the industry, said Paul Kavanagh, a partner at Killik & Company, a London broker.
"Until October, big pharmaceutical companies had displayed very good outperformance and had traded up to quite high valuations," Mr. Kavanagh said. "Then, suddenly, investors wanted to buy cyclical stocks. At the same time, something more worrying started to creep into the industry. You started to see court cases by smaller companies trying to get around patents."
In a notable defeat for the big companies, a federal judge in Norfolk, Va., ruled in May that the United States patents on Augmentin, an antibiotic marketed by the large British drug maker GlaxoSmithKline, were invalid because they did not contain new inventions. But there is a good chance that Glaxo will win on appeal, Mr. Kavanagh said.
The industry has also been criticized for the types of new products it has developed. A report by Salomon Smith Barney said that a number of these drugs are "me too" products that treat the same ills in much the same way as existing drugs.
The report also noted that the Food and Drug Administration, which regulates the industry in the United States, had been critical of the manufacturing standards of several large American companies, including Schering-Plough, Abbott Laboratories and Eli Lilly. Salomon recommends holding fewer shares of American drug companies than the group's stock-market weight implies and relatively more shares of their European counterparts.
As a result of the regulatory scrutiny and the challenge from generics, industry profitability has been depressed. Mr. Doerig expects this year's earnings to be within 5 percent of last year's results. "Hopefully they will recover" in 2003, he said.
Drug makers are forever searching for the next blockbuster, typically defined as a product that generates at least $1 billion in annual sales. Mr. Doerig said the delay in finding a new F.D.A. director, to replace Dr. Jane E. Henney, who resigned in early 2001, had created a bottleneck in the approval process.
"The F.D.A. has been an organization without a C.E.O.," he said. "It's not really encouraging. There is an impression that nobody is ready to take responsibility for approving new drugs. That is probably the most critical issue" facing the industry.
Mr. Doerig recommends avoiding companies that "have less attractive product profiles" -- that is, more drug patents about to expire than others -- and investing in companies "with recognized patent protections."
As in other industries, the best companies have strong managements, he said. "Some companies are more successful than others because they have vision," he said, "a focused strategy in which they concentrate on core competence, getting rid of all nonstrategic business." 
One of his favorite companies, a success based on both of those criteria, is Novartis of Switzerland. It sold off its agrochemical subsidiary in late 2000 to focus on its pharmaceutical business, and has some strong products up for approval, including treatments for arthritis and irritable-bowel syndrome.
ANALYSTS at Lehman Brothers also like Novartis, citing the success of its existing products over those of rivals. In a report on the company, they said its Lotrel drug for hypertension had been gaining market share over a drug made by Pfizer. 
Glaxo, by contrast, is struggling to bring significant new products to market, while the other big British drug maker, AstraZeneca, is straining to defend patents on old ones, Mr. Kavanagh said.
AstraZeneca expected strong revenue from Crestor, its new anticholesterol drug, but has fallen victim to the F.D.A.'s approval logjam. The company is counting on Crestor to help compensate for reduced sales of its ulcer treatment, Losec.
Mr. Kavanagh finds AstraZeneca's stock prohibitively expensive, at roughly 25 times estimated 2003 earnings. Glaxo, at about 16 times earnings, in line with Britain's stock market, offers better value, he said, but he prefers to wait until the price, down about one-fourth from its high of the last year, falls an additional 10 percent or so. 
"You're buying a market rating and market yield for a company in what is still a growth industry," he said, "but you have to see very compelling value before you would consider buying these things."
