HEADLINE: Mortgage Bargains May Not Provide Big Lift to Economy 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
With mortgage rates matching their lowest levels in more than 30 years, thousands of Americans are rushing to refinance the loans on their homes. But the lift to the economy that usually comes when homeowners negotiate a better mortgage deal is unlikely to be as great this time as in the past.
 The falling rates -- dropping to 6.54 percent on average last week for a 30-year mortgage -- are indeed a prop for the wavering economy. With loans so cheap, home sales and home construction are booming. Those who refinance to raise cash also strengthen an economy dependent on consumer spending, and in the new rush to refinance, the majority of households are doing just that. 
 But many homeowners who might have refinanced their mortgages now did so last fall when rates also fell just as low for a few weeks. The pool of people who missed that window is relatively small, mortgage lenders say. In addition, a growing number of households are using the lower rates to shrink 30-year mortgages to 15 or 20 years for about the same monthly payments. The economy gets no stimulus when a homeowner does this instead of using lower rates to decrease monthly payments and increase consumer spending.
The economy, as a result, is not likely to get the same kick from this round of refinancing as it did last fall, when interest rates fell in the aftermath of Sept. 11. Then, people with 7 percent mortgages rushed to refinance at 6.5 percent, and the tendency to shorten a mortgage's maturity, rather than to refinance, was not as common. 
"The people most sensitive to interest rate changes refinanced last fall," said Sterling Edmunds Jr., the president of SunTrust Mortgage, a nationwide lender headquartered in Richmond, Va., "and for them to do it again, the 30-year rate would have to fall another half-a-percentage point."
Not since the 1960's have rates on 30-year mortgages fallen that extra half-point, to 6 percent or less.
The increasing popularity of shorter mortgages is apparent in the 11 offices of MortgageAmerica, which operates in Florida, Alabama and Georgia. John B. Johnson, the chief executive, attributes the trend to a growing desire among cautious Americans to be debt-free by their late 50's. There is an absence today of more profitable investments than homeownership itself, he said, and people realize this.
"The strongest reason for refinancing is still to get lower monthly payments," Mr. Johnson said, "but we are seeing significant numbers of people refinancing to shorter maturities while leaving their payments unchanged. More than last fall."
For Mr. Edmunds's SunTrust, the flow of refinancing activity, while up sharply from early spring, is still running 25 percent below last fall's peak of $4 billion in new mortgages in October. Or as Dorothy Lubbes, the mortgage officer at Southern Commercial Bank in St. Louis, said: "I have lots of appointments and I am extremely busy through the day. But I am not putting in the extra hours that I put in last fall; it has not gotten to that point yet."
The window of opportunity last fall stayed open only a few weeks. Rates reached their low point in the second week of November, then bounced back to roughly 7 percent by year-end and stayed there until May, when the current fall began, accelerating last week. Through each episode, stock prices also plunged, displaying a grim relationship.
Falling stock prices, it turns out, have become a principal reason why, in this business cycle, long-term interest rates, including mortgage rates, are also falling. In this respect, the two have become wrapped in a strange embrace that has made the flight from stocks an unexpected source of strength for consumer spending, mainly through mortgage refinancing.
In a recovery, stock prices and interest rates usually rise together, but this time they are falling together. 
"It suggests that if you get a rally in stocks, you will get a setback in mortgage rates," said Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist and consultant. "We are caught in a recovery that helps people and hurts them at the same time."
Fear seems to make this unusual mechanism work. Displaying more fear of stocks than at any time since the 1980's, investors are shifting their money to what they consider safe investments, mainly 10-year Treasury notes and mortgage-backed bonds. Treasuries are guaranteed by the federal government and mortgage-backed bonds have homes as collateral. As the demand rises for both these types of bonds, their rates fall, and so do the associated rates for household mortgages.
The stock market is not alone, of course, in pulling down long-term rates. A weak economy has convinced many investors that the recovery from last year's recession will take longer than originally anticipated and the Federal Reserve will not even consider raising rates until late this year, at the earliest. As recently as May, forecasters had expected the Fed to have raised rates by now to control inflation, but in the weak economy, inflation has been dormant.
"A bit of gloom and doom has developed about where the economy is going and that weighs on rates," said Lyle E. Gramley, a senior economic adviser to Schwab Capital Markets. 
Clearly it weighs on the 30-year mortgage rate, which edged down to 6.54 percent last week from 6.57 percent the week before, according to Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage agency. The 6.54 percent matched last November's low of 6.45 percent after including the additional points charged in the fall as a refinancing fee.
Freddie Mac bases its average rate on a weekly survey of mortgage lenders. Its average rate last week also matched another post-1960's low, in early October of 1998, when a surge in refinancing helped to lift the economy during a growing global financial crisis. Stock prices fell then, too, as investors shifted their money to what they considered safer investments.
Now, in the latest round of mortgage refinancing, many homeowners are reducing their payments by significant amounts. Some customers at Southern Commercial, for example, have cut up to $80 from each monthly installment on an $80,000 mortgage. The second most popular option has been to keep the monthly payments unchanged but borrow more, thus tapping the rising value of homes when prices are rising so quickly that some experts say a bubble has developed.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, rejects that concern. In Congressional testimony, he has argued that the housing market does not lend itself easily to bubbles because home prices vary by region and homeowners do not buy and sell quickly, as stockholders do. Fed policy makers argue that even before the latest refinancing boom, homeowners who sold diverted some of their windfall profits to consumer spending, and that dynamic continues to provide crucial support for the recovery. 
"The Fed is supporting every dimension of the housing market," said Albert M. Wojnilower, a Wall Street economist. "In principle, if stock prices keep dropping, there is no reason why the rate on 30-year mortgages should not go below 6 percent."

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
In New Jersey, Everybody's Badmouthing the Ex

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
NOT everyone knows that New Jersey's state bird is the goldfinch, but it suddenly seems that everyone has decided that the state goat is Christie Whitman.
 Pick a problem that needs a villain -- the state's budget crisis, an E-ZPass system mired in debt, festering toxic dumps -- and she's the go-to girl. 
 On Tuesday, a lineup of New Jersey politicians accused the Republican former governor and current administrator of the federal Environmental Protection Agency of forsaking her state by carrying out policies that would further foul the Garden State. Representative Frank Pallone, a Democrat, said Mrs. Whitman "should be ashamed of herself." 
On Wednesday, a legislative committee in Trenton disgorged a mammoth report showing how E-ZPass tumbled into debt, calling for a criminal investigation and accusing the Whitman administration of "misleading the public."
The next day, Gov. James E. McGreevey jumped in. He has criticized Mrs. Whitman for her fiscal policy and accused her of dumbing down the state Supreme Court, but talking tolls in New Jersey is as serious as it gets.
Calling E-ZPass "a classic example of how the previous administration operated government," he said, "It was a poorly designed fiscal premise, entirely based upon false projections, that was incompetently administered to the public who was told of rosy and fantastical promises that at the end of the day generated a $400 million deficit." Then he imposed a $1 a month surcharge on E-ZPassers.
Through it all, hardly a word of defense of Mrs. Whitman has been heard, and no one has noticed that more than Mrs. Whitman herself. "What surprises me is how quiet the Republicans have been," she said. 
Perhaps none of it should be surprising.
Christie Whitman is a political Martha Stewart. Her can-do style won fans, but State House veterans found her aloof, even smug. Governing well enough was her best revenge. She appeared to have it all: tax cuts, a robust economy, few scandals, even a flirtation with national prominence.
She squeaked through two elections and landed a big job in Washington, but New Jersey political insiders could almost taste the moment she became vulnerable.
Now with the economy in a slide, her tax cuts and expanded state debt have come under attack by the new governor. Parts of the Bush environmental agenda are unfriendly even to causes she embraced as governor. And her well of support back home is now just a trickle.
"Christie was horrible at forging long-term relationships with people," laments one prominent state Republican.
In the current atmosphere, Mrs. Whitman needs one of those protective moon suits to shield her from the political particulate matter. "So much of it has gotten personal," she said in an interview. "My name is mentioned with malfeasance, with lying, with so many things. It's Whitman. It's Whitman. It's all Whitman."
SHE asks: what about the years of prosperity? The open-space initiative? The budget surpluses? Her Jersey Girl defense sounds like mock Springsteen lyrics. "The state is in my heart," she said. "It's part of me."
She dismisses the criticism as politics-as-usual, and some of it seems to be. In April, Mr. McGreevey called Mrs. Whitman's Supreme Court appointments "an avenue for patronage for those within the executive branch." Last week, Mr. McGreevey paved his own avenue, nominating to the court Barry T. Albin, an old friend and member of a law firm that generously backed him.
Some criticism, however, seems the result of Whitman-as-usual. She loyally plays her roles for the national Republicans -- darling of the deep tax cutters, appropriately measured advocate of abortion rights. She is doing the same at the environmental agency.
But New Jersey, which has labored to shed labels like "Landfill of Opportunity," also demands loyalty. News of possible federal cuts in the Superfund program alarm New Jersey, where toxic waste sites outnumber even minor league ball teams. And the Bush administration's clean-air proposals give leeway to utilities that were the subject of lawsuits by New Jersey and other states when Mrs. Whitman was governor. 
"She was on the right side of the issues before she went to Washington and was co-opted by the administration," said Jon Corzine, the Democratic United States senator.
Mrs. Whitman says she is true to both her president and her state. She wonders whether the criticism reflects concern she may run for office again. Have no fear, she says. Her current job is no way to build support. "All you do is make enemies," she said.
And on that point, no one disputes her.

HEADLINE: Air of Uncertainty Hangs Over Turkey as Government Erodes 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, July 13 

 BODY:
The government of Turkey is not so much careering out of control as it is stumbling, step by jolting step, down a path toward potentially dramatic upheaval in its political and economic landscape.
 Seven cabinet ministers and 39 members of Parliament have resigned from the governing Democratic Left Party in the past week, leaving its ailing leader, Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, struggling to hold on to power and creating doubts about Turkey's ability to cope with economic and political problems. 
 While change seems inevitable and the prime minister's days in office appear numbered, the degree of transformation and direction of the next government remain irritatingly obscure.
"Anyone who claims to know where this is headed is fooling himself," said Ilter Turan, a political scientist at Bilgi University in Istanbul. 
The stakes are high for 65 million Turks, who are eager to shed bitter months of economic hardship, and for the United States, which needs a compliant and stable ally as a base for any military operation against Iraq.
At least as important in the long term, the outcome will determine whether Turkey presses forward on reforms necessary for membership in the European Union or retreats to the role of a disgruntled nationalist on the margins of the West.
"There are enormous uncertainties because so many players have so many different interests," said Zeyno Baran, an analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, in Washington. 
Divisions over how far to bend in exchange for joining the European Union, and particularly whether to abandon the death penalty, provided the catalyst for this week of government resignations and political gamesmanship. The results decimated Mr. Ecevit's party and threaten to cast him out of office.
Mr. Ecevit, 77, is a veteran of four decades in and out of power in Ankara, but his health has deteriorated markedly in the last two months. He was hospitalized numerous times and often slurred his speech in rare public appearances.
Propelled by Mr. Ecevit's weakness and bickering within the three-party governing coalition, elections before the scheduled date, April 2004, appear to be one certainty on an uncertain horizon.
Devlet Bahceli, the leader of the coalition's nationalist party, hastened the date when he called for elections in November in what many see as an attempt to bring down the coalition and stop a deal to get rid of the death penalty as a price for joining Europe.
Fearing Mr. Ecevit was too weak to lead the party into early elections, members of his left-leaning party began to abandon ship. By the end of the week, 44 members of Parliament, including the 7 cabinet ministers, had resigned, robbing the party of its slim majority.
The most prominent resignation was that of Ismail Cem, the popular foreign minister who was considered an Ecevit protege. On Friday, the day after he quit, Mr. Cem announced that he was forming a new party intended to usher Turkey into the European Union, a goal supported by a majority of the country in opinion polls.
"Turkey must not miss this chance," Mr. Cem said at a news conference. "We are determined to take the necessary measures."
Forming the leadership of the yet unnamed party with him will be Kemal Dervis, the economy minister, and Husamettin Ozkan, another longtime Ecevit ally who resigned as deputy prime minister.
Mr. Dervis tried to resign on Thursday, but he reconsidered after the country's president asked him to stay on for the sake of the economy. Mr. Dervis was brought into government from the World Bank 16 months ago to deal with the economic crisis, and he has generally been given good marks for engineering the beginnings of a turnaround.
Mr. Cem is a popular and untainted figure in Turkish politics, and Mr. Dervis is respected by the international financial community. Both will be embraced by Turkey's influential businesspeople, who favor joining the European Union.
But the party's success is far from assured in a country where new political groups come and go as regularly as prayers from the mosque, and only a few stalwarts endure.
Mr. Dervis also carries political baggage. He left Turkey in the 1970's and returned only last year, so many Turks see him as an outsider. The nationalists have played to that issue and tried to brand him as a proxy for the United States and international lenders.
In addition, the financial reforms he pushed through to keep international loans flowing caused considerable pain among working Turks, who have watched helplessly as living standards have dropped sharply. The country's large agriculture sector was hit particularly hard when the subsidies were slashed and sweetheart loans from state banks ended.
Any future political equation will have to contend with the popularity of the Justice and Development Party, which was created a year ago out of the ashes of the banned Islamic party. Opinion polls show that the party, led by Istanbul's former mayor, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, far outstrips the other existing parties with voters.
The political permutations being debated are as plentiful as minarets on the Istanbul skyline. 
One potential situation has Mr. Ecevit trying to hold on to power by forming an alliance with Mr. Bahceli's nationalist party and agreeing to keep the death penalty and block granting more rights to the minority Kurdish population.

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
Trying to Figure Who Benefits From the Rules

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J. 

 BODY:
For a moment last week, I wondered if Monique Harwell and her son, Reginald Harwell II, could be the people I've been searching for, the corrupters of big-time college sports. 
 Why else would those smooth, educated people from the National Collegiate Athletic Association have lectured the mother so sternly about accepting unauthorized phone calls from college coaches or warned the son against taking home the uniforms and shoes he had been lent for the Adidas ABCD basketball camp? The Harwells had already been warned not to talk to the coaches who had shown up here to watch Reginald and 230 other high school players audition for them over four days at Fairleigh Dickinson University. 
 "I can understand the coaches' not being allowed to speak with the children," Monique Harwell told me over Adidas hamburgers we were allowed to swallow. "But it would be very good for the coaches to be able to speak with the parents. Many of us can't pay to go on official visits with our children or to make phone calls to the schools. And it would be good to put faces on all those letters we get." 
She sounded reasonable, but her ambition for her child, 17, is naked. They had come from Richmond Heights, outside Cleveland, to be discovered. Reginald is 6 feet 5 inches, and if his game "picks up" during his coming senior year at Villa Angela-St. Joseph's High School, his mom said, she would allow him to go directly into the National Basketball Association.
No wonder the N.C.A.A. has to keep a rein on people like Monique Harwell, a 35-year-old single mother of three who lives in her ailing grandmother's house and who receives public assistance while she attends school to become a drug counselor. After she told me that she doesn't think all these N.C.A.A. rules are in her best interests, I began to doubt she was slick enough to be the corrupter I was searching for. Where did she ever get the idea that these rules were created with her needs in mind, much less Reginald's?
So who is the bad guy here? Sonny Vaccaro, who runs this camp, is always volunteering for the title, but that's how he keeps his name in the news. Vaccaro, 62, wants us to think he pioneered the corruption of higher education while he was at Nike, supplementing coaches' salaries with sneaker deals that have since become critical to university economics, along with the soft drinks they "pour."
Nike ran a rival camp in Las Vegas last week which was also "certified" by the N.C.A.A., which meant that convoluted rules had to be followed so that N.C.A.A. coaches could attend. It was part of the N.C.A.A. plan to "bring more accountability" to summer ball.
Accountable to whom? Its own whimsical and determinedly understaffed enforcement branch?
But Monique Harwell got the message. She says she has made unofficial college visits to Dayton and Toledo, and when she saw the Dayton coach here she just waved back, didn't even mouth a hello. She can stick to a game plan. She started Reginald in a Montessori school, moved him to a special science junior high, then on to Catholic high school. They are not Catholics.
The Dayton coach was sitting in the grandstand with several hundred other college coaches, most of whom were ostentatiously preening so the players and their parents saw them, or at least the university logos on their golf shirts. Coach Gary Williams of Maryland, wearing his N.C.A.A. championship ring, said that even he needed to show up.
"There's a lot of negative recruiting going on," he said. "If you're not here, other coaches will tell players that you weren't interested, that you were after someone else."
So maybe the Amateur Athletic Union coaches Sonny hired to run the camp are the bad guys? A once-powerful organization, the A.A.U. withered in the mid-20th century as the N.C.A.A. and the Olympic federations ate youth sports. Now, with sneaker money, the A.A.U. is coming back strong, especially in basketball and soccer, creating a national network of traveling teams that challenges the N.C.A.A.'s control over high school players. A.A.U. coaches here, who spoke freely but anonymously, hint of a future when American sports will be dominated by clubs rather than educational institutions. One reason there are so many foreign players in camps, colleges and now the N.B.A., they said, was that Europeans in particular were free to sign with agents at 14 and develop their games away from crippling regulations.
Monique Harwell said she related to that, especially after an edgy hour in a ballroom at a nearby hotel. N.C.A.A. staffers, with visual aids, tried not to sound like immigration officials at a crowded border crossing as they read the latest rules while the players, parents and club coaches clamored for explanation.
They asked questions like these: Wouldn't more phone calls mean a better chance to develop a relationship? Why are athletic scholarships given for only a year at a time, and subject to summary cancellation? Why are athletes bound to the college they sign up for, but the coach who recruits them can move on? Don't you think all these rules are racially motivated, since they seem to single out African-American basketball players? How come you N.C.A.A. people are so worried about our previously worn sneakers and not about your colleges' zero graduation rates?
The N.C.A.A. representatives, who were mostly young, attractive and black, admitted that the rules were complex but said that they were really in the players' best interests. Who wants to get all those phone calls from coaches all the time?
We do, roared the players, and Reginald's mom agreed. "You're going to give your child over to this man," she said. "Who is he? What does he think about academics? What kind of environment is my child going to live in? Maybe I'll get up a petition."

The Series So Far
Articles in this series about the role of college sports in American culture have explored race and athletics, paying the players, gambling on campus, football and Title IX, and a whistle-blower's defiance. Robert Lipsyte's e-mail address is thelipsite@aol.com.

HEADLINE: Bangladeshis Sipping Arsenic As Plan for Safe Water Stalls 

BYLINE:  By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: CHOTOBINAR CHAP, Bangladesh 

 BODY:
The arsenic, a slow, sadistic killer, has just about finished its work on Fazila Khatun. She teeters now. The fatigue is constant. Pain pulses through her limbs. Warts and sores cover the palms of her hands and the soles of her feet, telltale of the long years of creeping poison.
 Mrs. Khatun is hardly alone in this suffering. Bangladesh is in the midst of what the World Health Organization calls the "largest mass poisoning of a population in history." Tens of thousands of Bangladeshis show the outward signs of the same decline. Some 35 million are drinking arsenic-contaminated water, the poison accumulating within them day by day, sip by sip. 
 This calamity is accompanied by paradox. For two decades, the government, along with Unicef and various aid groups, desperately worked to wean the nation from pond water, often an incubator for lethal disease. People were instead urged to install tube wells, tapping into the plentiful supply of underground aquifers. Regrettably, no one had tested these subterranean sources for arsenic. 
By the mid-1990's, Bangladeshi officials -- once reluctant to provoke alarm -- finally admitted that yet another tragedy was unfolding in their impoverished, disaster-plagued nation. In 1998, the World Bank sped the normal paperwork and lent the government $32.4 million to act on the emergency. Every tube well was to be tested. Safe sources of water were to be provided.
But the race against time has gone badly. In the four years since The New York Times first looked into the situation, the nation's "arsenic mitigation project" has been hobbled by the unforeseen problems of so unprecedented a crisis. It is yet another example of how the world's poor continue to die from unsafe water, a threat long ago surmounted by the wealthy.
Suspicious of each other, the World Bank and the government became stubbornly bound up in their mutual bureaucracies, many critics say. Most of the country's estimated 11 million wells have yet to be tested. Most stricken villages are absent solutions. Most people -- the trusting converts to the "safety" of tube wells -- are baffled when now told that within the water lie the malign beginnings of arsenic-induced cancer.
"It seems like nonsense to people, telling them the water is killing them when it looks so clean and nice," said Dr. Allan H. Smith, an epidemiologist at the University of California at Berkeley and an expert on arsenic.
Dr. Smith has called the situation in Bangladesh "the highest environmental cancer risk ever found," worse than Bhopal or Chernobyl.
"People need to stop drinking the contaminated water," he said. "But they don't seem to pay attention unless there are people around them showing signs of the disease, which is of course what we're trying to prevent."
Here in the village of Chotobinar Chap, with the cancer pulling her under, Mrs. Khatun seems to have surrendered. She has no strength for work. She has no appetite for meals. She lies in a spare room beneath a thatched roof.
"I feel myself fading away, and sometimes I ask God to take me," she muttered. "My husband has abandoned me. He doesn't even look at me anymore."
For nearly two decades, Mrs. Khatun, 39, pumped the iron handle of a tube well sunk in her front yard beside a palm tree. Her father-in-law, Abdul Hakim, his six sons and all their families used the same convenient apparatus.
Two years ago, the water was tested. The arsenic concentration measured .760 milligrams per liter, 15 times the amount considered safe by Bangladesh standards and 76 times the limit set by the World Health Organization.
Arsenic, a speedy killer in high doses, is a sluggish and fickle assailant in low ones. The poison requires 2 to 10 years or more to work its damage and it affects different people in different ways -- and some, seemingly, not at all.
While Mrs. Khatun is the most woefully stricken in her family, others have the same nodules on their palms and heels and dark spots on much of their skin. Still others, their thirst slaked from the same well, show no signs at all.
Informed of the danger, the family beseeched, "Where can we get safe water?" Here again the arsenic displayed its erratic hand, for some of the wells here are terribly tainted and others, just yards away, are harmless.
The nearest safe water for the family was beside a neighbor's home a quarter mile away. To get there required a walk on a narrow mud path, past several houses with shiny tin roofs, past ponds where animals bathed and algae bloomed.
"It was hard to fetch water from so far away," said Mr. Hakim, a weaver. Dark spots pocked his bare chest. "One of my daughters-in-law would go and carry back a full pitcher for drinking. But sometimes the path was too muddy. It was knee deep. She couldn't wade through it and she stopped going."
It is difficult to predict how many Bangladeshis will eventually die from causes related to the arsenic. Most researchers, including Dr. Smith, are shy with estimates. Richard Wilson, a Harvard physicist who is an expert in risk analysis, puts the number at one million. Dr. Sk. Ahktar Ahmad, a public health specialist with the government, predicts a total of three million to five million.
Any such arithmetic is highly speculative. The morbid work of the arsenic -- a persistent nudging toward cancers of the liver, lung, bladder or kidney -- can be halted in most cases by simply switching to safe water, doctors say.
So the question is: How many Bangladeshis will be persuaded to switch? And, if persuaded, how many can find water both safe and accessible?
Alternatives do exist. There are even ways to filter arsenic from water. But each solution requires effort, to educate villagers and to pay for the required equipment.
With 130 million people, Bangladesh is the world's eighth most populous nation, its citizens packed into a territory slightly smaller than Wisconsin. The average per capita income is $370.
Arsenic has competition on the nation's mortality tables. Each year, pneumonia kills 91,000 children under age 5. Diarrhea claims 61,000 more. Tobacco surely rivals arsenic as a progenitor of fatal cancer.
Mother Nature, prone to furious mood swings, is often a mass murderer. In the wet summers, melting snow from the Himalayas joins with monsoon rains to overwhelm the rivers, flooding as much as two-thirds of the landscape. In dry months, the fierce sun can parch the soil enough to trigger a famine.
A few miles from here is Khandkar Kalagachia. As in most hamlets, there is water, water everywhere: wells, ponds, irrigated fields.
Though many of the villagers display signs of the poisoning, it is hard to know the extent of the contamination. Khandkar Kalagachia lies on the wrong side of the road, among the 77 percent of the nation's "hot spot" areas still untested.
Muhammad Ahsanullah, a rickshaw puller, endures an overwhelming itchiness, another of the symptoms. His hands are always in motion, scratching their way from his palms to his wrists to his biceps to his shoulders. In one dexterous maneuver, he crosses his arms to get at his sides, looking like a man confined to a straitjacket.
"I should drink from another well," Mr. Ahsanullah, 45, said.
His fingers have lesions the size of chickpeas. His soles are similarly affected, a hazardous problem for a rickshaw puller who goes barefoot. Infected wounds often lead to gangrene.
As Mr. Ahsanullah spoke, a small crowd gathered. Some of the men pulled up shirts to show their own dark speckling or lumpy palms.
Standing at the front door of a shack was a young woman, Khorsheda Begum, the rickshaw puller's wife. The couple wed three years ago. Their families had arranged the marriage. She had never seen him until the wedding day.
Now, sheepishly, she admitted she wished she could undo their union. A village quack has told her -- incorrectly -- that her husband's skin condition is contagious. Actually, the grave danger comes from the tube well in the yard.
"Yes, I drink from it," she said. "We all do."
Their well is the standard device, a small cylinder sunk into the earth with a hand pump above ground. Its location was familiar to Mostafa Kamal, an engineer who works for an aid agency called Proshika. He had once tested the well and found it contaminated. But for one reason or another, he had never gotten back to Khandkar Kalagachia to assay any other samples.
"Please test our wells now," one man pleaded.
But the engineer could not comply. He was apologetic. His agency had a contract to examine wells. "But I only have supplies to test 200 a month and I have run out," he said. "I can request more but I don't think I will get it."
From the start, the effort to correct the problem has run into problems. The primary mission was the testing of every well. If the water was safe, the top of the well was to be painted green. If not, it would be colored red.
This task required test kits that could accurately measure minuscule levels of arsenic, but nothing that precise was immediately available. While it was presumed that every family had a right to know if their well was tainted, little had been decided about how to help the unlucky.
"We started taking the measurements, but as we tested, painting the wells red or green, there was a great hue and cry from people with contaminated water," said a government official. "These people asked us, What do you expect us to do now?"
"It took us a while to come up with new technologies, such as pond sand filters or rainwater harvesting or, in some areas, deeper tube wells," the official said. "Different areas have different solutions. But once the best one is decided, to whom do you provide the money for installation? How do you prevent corruption?"
Programs were required, and each scheme seemed to call for round after round of design. The World Bank, after lending so much money, wanted the protection of exacting oversight. Some government officials, practiced in steering contracts to cronies, had supervisory interests of their own.
"It has been terrible frustration to watch," said Han A. Heijnen, the environmental health adviser for the World Health Organization in Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh. "So much remains to be done. Even now, the lack of knowledge among villagers about arsenic is a shame."
The arsenic itself may well have been in the area's alluvial sediments for 20,000 years or more. Exactly how it came to dissolve in the groundwater is a matter of debate, but the prevailing theory is that it was a natural process.
Whatever the cause, the arsenic's belated discovery is at the root of the calamity. Water-quality experts are divided about how much, if any, negligence was involved. Some victims are suing the British Geological Survey, which did not include a test for arsenic when it surveyed the groundwater in 1992.
But even after the poison was found, responses were tardy. Unicef is now a dedicated participant in the testing of wells, but it and the government were slow to admit that their "safe water program," the laudable effort to stop people from drinking from disease-laden ponds, had dire unintended consequences.
Now, with the disaster continuing, Bangladesh is of great interest to global experts, their laboratory for the study of arsenic.
Researchers have questions, among them: Has the poison breached the food chain? Why are some people more affected than others? Is the level of arsenic in each tube well stable? Will fatalistic villagers change their habits?
Mr. Ahsanullah, the rickshaw puller, incessantly scratching, had himself given thought to an alternate source of water. Recently, he began using a neighbor's well.
"But now I am told that, too, is bad," he said as he stood amid lush greenery and sprawling ponds. Within 20 feet, villagers were sloshing through the shallows that nourished a rice paddy. Still, the confused man, displaying his fear, asked gravely, "Where can I find water?"

HEADLINE: Defining Limit Of Generosity For 9/11 Fund 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Within the next two weeks, the man responsible for distributing billions of taxpayer dollars to thousands of families who lost relatives in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks will decide two dozen test cases that will at last establish the rough boundaries for the sizes of the awards.
 For the last few months, Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master in charge of the federal Victim Compensation Fund, has been conferring with family lawyers to identify the cases that will, each in their own way, answer many of the open questions concerning the generosity and scope of the fund. At least three cases, for example, will test Mr. Feinberg's willingness to make awards in excess of $4 million, something he said months ago he was loath to do. Others will help settle the question of just how far he will go in compensating families for mental anguish. 
 After months of speculation about the mechanics and fairness of the compensation process, these test cases represent the most critical moment to date for the fund. Where Mr. Feinberg draws the lines, and what his explanations are for doing so, will go a long way toward deciding if he prevails in his greatest ambition: convincing the roughly 3,000 families of victims that the fund is not just their only true option for relief, but an unassailably fair one. 
"We're going to test the waters, and we're going to get some decisions that will define how the fund works," said William L. Mauk, who, as the former director of litigation support for Trial Lawyers Care, a consortium of more than 1,100 lawyers offering free legal advice to Sept. 11 families, chose the bulk of the test cases.
"It will define Ken Feinberg's sense of fairness and justice," Mr. Mauk said. "It will send a message to those who are uncertain about the fund. And one way or another, it will launch the process."
When Congress created the fund in September as part of an airline bailout package, officials praised the idea as a novel one that offered a fast and straightforward alternative to litigation. To be eligible for the fund's average payment of about $1.5 million, however, families have to waive their right to sue, a condition that strikes some lawyers as unfair, and others as reasonable, given the prospect of protracted and risky lawsuits.
To outsiders, it may appear that the fund has produced precious little so far, other than perhaps an atmosphere of waiting and wariness. After all, perhaps only 605 families have filed even the partial applications since the government opened its checkbook in December, a pace that even Mr. Feinberg has said is much slower than anticipated. No awards have been made, either.
The reality, though, is that many determinative matters have been unfolding behind the scenes for months, as lawyers scramble to establish some unofficial case law for a fund without precedent.
Mr. Feinberg has already unveiled his rough calculations of a person's worth and lost income. So the relatives of a victim who was 45 and married with two children making $125,000 a year would be eligible for a payment of $2.04 million (minus any life insurance or pension payments), while the relatives of a victim who was 25 with no dependents and an annual salary of $90,000 would be eligible for a gross payment of $2.11 million.
But many family lawyers, as well as companies that lost a large number of employees, have taken issue with Mr. Feinberg's economic assumptions or want clarification on numerous knotty issues.
As a result, the test cases, selected because of their economic diversity and wider potential implications, will probe the value of civilian heroes and intangible, hard-to-replace services provided by loved ones, like handiwork, cooking or day care. They touch on the predicament of devastated families afflicted by lingering psychological consequences. They deal with controversial topics like long-term respiratory ailments and future earnings potential.
So far, the families' lawyers say that they have been encouraged by what they describe as an informal, give-and-take process. They have been heartened, too, by Mr. Feinberg's empathetic attitude, even as they inundate him with reams of supporting documents as thick as telephone books, not to mention an occasional CD-ROM or photo album.
Indeed, at his offices in Midtown Manhattan last Monday, Mr. Feinberg convened an all-day session of 30-minute meetings with more than a dozen families and their lawyers in which there was no shortage of evidence, experts or emotions. And afterward, many families said that Mr. Feinberg and his staff seemed genuinely moved by the anguish of people like Erma Bourdier, who, sobbing, recounted how her husband, Francisco Bourdier, a security guard, was a hero on Sept. 11, saving everyone but himself from the Bankers Trust building.
He has listened, too, to the heartbreaking tale of Florence Kneff; because of the deaths of her son, Matthew Diaz, a carpenter, on Sept. 11, and daughter-in-law, Karen, of cancer in January, she has to raise two orphaned grandsons alone.
And he has tried to absorb and calculate somehow the plight of Edwin Zambrana, who tearfully stated that his shy son, Edwin Jr., truly had two jobs, even if one was nonpaying: one at the World Trade Center as a maintenance worker and the other at home caring for a mother battling lupus.
"It was a very emotional day," Mr. Feinberg said. "Emotionally draining and tough. But it's very important and worthwhile."
In general, Mr. Feinberg said that he was inclined to be far more flexible in accounting for economic losses rather than emotional ones, and in relying on corroborated patterns of income rather than projected earnings. But one of the wild cards, as written in the rules, is that Mr. Feinberg also has an enormous amount of discretion.
In several cases discussed on Monday, Mr. Feinberg also gave the family lawyers a tentative range for possible awards, a range that some said seemed a bit low, but not exceedingly so. He also promised to furnish a firmer number within the next two weeks, then give families the option to accept that figure, or to press for a more formal hearing in the future to make their case one last time.
Spearheading these cases has been Trial Lawyers Care, a nonprofit organization created by the Association of Trial Lawyers of America. In all, Trial Lawyers Care has identified 16 cases that would result in combined payments of approximately $20 million according to Mr. Feinberg's original tables. But the figures that have been discussed by Mr. Feinberg have been significantly higher, in a range of $30 million to $40 million, according to lawyers.
For Mr. Zambrana and his lawyer, Daniel Kramer, the key themes being tested include the psychological trauma that the family has endured since Sept. 11 and the death of his 24-year-old son. But he is also trying to make a case that the care his son provided to his ill mother had a real value, and that, somehow, that should figure in Mr. Feinberg's determination of compensation.
The claim is also noteworthy because the elder Mr. Zambrana, who was a maintenance worker at the trade center, was badly injured during the towers' collapse, but did not seek medical treatment within the time limit of 72 hours set by the fund because he was too busy searching, in vain, for his son. How elastic Mr. Feinberg will be in honoring such injury claims could affect hundreds of claims.
"To this day, he's on inhalers, his vocal cords aren't right, and the doctors have said, 'This will never go away,' " Mr. Kramer said of Mr. Zambrana's injury.
For Richard King, life has not been the same since his wife, Lucille, a secretary at Aon, died on Sept. 11. They had been married for three decades, had no children, and lived in the same modest apartment in Queens for years. He is struggling with his new solitary existence in a complex for the elderly in the middle of New Jersey, close to relatives, and trying to learn how to drive.
According to E. Drew Britcher, a lawyer in Glen Rock, N.J., who is representing Mr. King, Mrs. King was not just the only breadwinner in the household. She also ran the household, did the finances, did everything. So what is being tested here is not her loss of future income -- which would be relatively modest, since she was 59 -- but the value of personal services at home, as well as the emotional impact of losing a soulmate.
"You're talking about someone whose entire life was this one person," said Mr. Britcher of Mr. King, who was too distraught to attend the meeting with Mr. Feinberg on Monday.
And in a case that has been handled not by Trial Lawyers Care, but by the aviation disaster specialists Kreindler & Kreindler, Jenna Jacobs, widow of Ariel Jacobs, anxiously waits for Mr. Feinberg's judgment, too.
Mr. Jacobs, 29, had climbed from a clerk at Radio Shack to chief of United States operations for Caplin Systems, a multinational company, in a decade. He was making an annual salary above the unofficial $231,000 cap that Mr. Feinberg has said he will use when calculating economic losses. He also had no insurance. So his case could be representative of the young, promising financial wizards who might eventually have earned a lot more money, said Justin T. Green, Mrs. Jacobs's lawyer.
"The question is, is Feinberg going to pay this person what he said this person should be paid according to his methodology?" Mr. Green said. "Or is he going to apply an arbitrary cap? Because if he does apply a cap, we'll be disappointed and lose confidence in the program."
For Mrs. Jacobs, the test case is important because she needs assistance sooner than most other families. She and her husband had recently moved into a comfortable suburban house in Westchester County. But she has had to abandon the fledgling human resources consulting business that she had just started to provide full-time care for her son, Gabriel, who was born on Sept. 17.
"I know Feinberg wants to do well by the families, but it's a little disconcerting to think that there's this one guy who has so much power," Mrs. Jacobs said. "I just want Feinberg to know that I'm putting my faith in him, my trust in him, my future in him. He seems like a sincere guy; I hope he follows through."

HEADLINE: Stocks' Slide Is Playing Havoc With Older Americans' Dreams 

BYLINE:  By KATE ZERNIKE 

 BODY:
As the owners of an Atlanta advertising agency that billed $40 million a year, Jim and Jan Pringle were featured in a cover article in Inc. magazine asking, "What's the best time to retire?"
 In January 2000, with the Dow well above 10,000, they were confident they had picked the right time. They took more than $2 million they had made from selling their company and bought stocks. Their broker encouraged them to take a month in Europe; instead they moved to South Carolina, where they began building a dream house on the beach. 
 The Pringles have since lost about 75 percent of their investment. Far from taking any trips to Europe, they have done what they vowed never to do: mortgaged their house and gone back to work. 
"I thought I would at least be able to take a break and think about what to do with the second half of my life," Mr. Pringle, 63, said. "But I didn't have a lot of options when the market went south."
To many Americans, the sustained slide in the stock market -- particularly last week's nose dive -- has been something to fret about, a darkening cloud. But to many people at or near retirement age, it has been a colossal jolt.
People in this age group -- 55 to 64 -- have had almost twice as much money invested in stocks over the last few years as the average American. But if that money took them higher during the boom years, raising their expectations for living easy and dying rich, they have since fallen farther.
Unlike younger investors, older ones do not have room to ride out their losses, particularly those who, while swimming in capital gains, ignored the basic principle of shifting from stocks to less volatile investments as retirement drew near. Perhaps as a result, federal statistics show, the same age group has been entering the work force at a higher rate than any other in the last two years -- or simply not leaving.
In interviews last week from Hawaii to New England, older investors told stories of losing the entire value of their portfolios, of canceling travel plans and scaling back expectations. They used to stand mesmerized outside storefront stock tickers, or glued to CNBC at home. 
Now, they are looking the other way.
For these investors, what they thought would be comfortable retirement years are now shrouded in anxiety, disappointment and, in some cases, shame.
One 68-year-old man pleaded for anonymity as he told how he and his wife had sold their home in Manhattan and their beach house in the mid-1990's, planning to retire on the income of about $1 million he invested in the market.
As tech stocks rose, so did his portfolio. He hung on despite losing $4.5 million over two years. But last year, with some of his stocks reduced to pennies, and fearing that he would be "sitting in the street," he and his wife took jobs at the Mohegan Sun casino in Connecticut.
"The market was going up so rapidly, it was easy to live off the appreciated value of your assets," he said. "It was to some extent delusional, thinking this thing would turn around and come back, but it takes a while to come to grips with it. It hadn't happened in my lifetime, that kind of demise. I was born during the Depression, but I wasn't old enough to understand it."
Jacobo Black, 67, a retired real estate agent in Miami, said that he and his wife, Sophie, had canceled plans for a trans-Atlantic cruise this year. He could have used the distraction from thinking about the market.
"I feel so vulnerable," Mr. Black said. "Here I was with thousands of dollars in savings and here I am losing it like water running through my fingers."
Gena Lovett, walking along Laguna Beach in California with a group of friends who, like her, are in their late 50's, said that she and her husband, John, 57, would not be able to contribute as much to their grandchildren's education. 
"Our retirement is one-half of what it was a year ago," she said. "And because John works for G.E., we have mostly G.E. stock. I suppose we should have diversified, but G.E. stock was supposed to be wonderful. John's simply not looking at retirement. We simply told our kids that we're spending their inheritance."
The oldest retirees, those over 70, tend to have pensions and so rely less on the stock market, economists say. Those approaching retirement are far more likely to have 401(k) plans, which became the primary retirement option offered by companies over the last two decades. As the stock market swelled in the 1990's, so did those plans, and many people looked at the big gains and thought they could retire early.
"Many retirees became complacent," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, a consulting firm in Pennsylvania. "There was so much money being made, they didn't do the normal shifting most people do. Many of them were putting more in the market, thinking this was a quick way to fund their retirement. They got caught."
According to Labor Department numbers quoted by AARP, the nation's largest lobbying group for retirees, the number of people over the age of 55 in the work force rose by 8.4 percent, or 1.6 million people, between June 2001 and June 2002, compared with far smaller gains in previous years. Every other age group declined in that period.
"What do you do if you find yourself at retirement age without enough to retire on?" asked John Rother, AARP's policy director. "You keep working."
John H. Saxman, the chairman of the biobehavioral sciences department at Columbia University's Teachers College, said he had begun his career believing that if he set aside money each year, he could retire by 65.
"All I knew was that I didn't want to become one of those doddering old professors who can never afford to leave," Professor Saxman said. "Now I'm 63 and every time I try to think about a specific retirement date, I look at my quarterly reports and realize I can't pick a date yet."
He said he had grown accustomed to seeing his Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund grow 8 percent to 10 percent a year, until it began posting losses a year ago. His latest quarterly statement arrived a few days ago, but he left it unopened, not wanting to see how much money was gone.
"I get the feeling now it won't be next year," Professor Saxman said. "It may be another five years."
Many people said they felt cheated at having to postpone their retirement, particularly as every day seems to bring questions about fraud, executive compensation or accounting irregularities at yet another company.
"Obviously the stock market goes up and down, and the crap shoot is whether you're going to retire at the moment that it's up or down," said Gail Hovey, 62, who works for nonprofit groups in Hawaii. "But to have all the accounting irregularities and all the fraud on top of it, it makes you wonder who you can trust."
"I've worked hard all my life and been a responsible citizen." Ms. Hovey added. "And it's not supposed to be threatened at this point." 
But if the fraud has made people angry, the losses have made some more philosophical.
"I really enjoy controlling my own destiny, rather than depending on the stock market or corporate America," said Mr. Pringle, who started an advertising agency with his wife, as they had done 29 years earlier, at their retirement home in South Carolina.
Misfortune has also revealed pockets of pluck. Mrs. Pringle let off an exasperated laugh as she told how she "retired, supposedly" but then spoke enthusiastically about the new kind of pretzel, shaped like a golf tee, that she is marketing at professional tournaments. She and her husband have far fewer accounts than they did in Atlanta, she said, but now they work overlooking the beach.
"When we got here, I said: 'Lord, I am just going to come down here, do good by you and do your work. What would you have me do?' " she said. "I suppose this was what he had in mind."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: INSIDE BASEBALL; 
Bankruptcy Fallout Would Prove Thorny

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
While the Yankees and the Atlanta Braves are headed for the playoffs again, fans of some less economically blessed teams have to wonder if they are headed for bankruptcy.
 Such a financial fate has long been unthinkable, but Commissioner Bud Selig has raised the specter of one or more teams going out of business, saying Major League Baseball is no longer in a position to bail teams out of economic distress. 
 Some people on the players' side believe the talk from Selig and club owners about teams in danger is part of management's negotiating strategy. Selig firmly rejects that suggestion. He points to trouble two teams have had recently coming up with money to pay their players. He talks about $3.6 million in major league debt. 
It seems only reasonable, then, to ask if Chapter 11 is in anyone's future, and that's not a section of the Official Baseball Rules. The possibility hasn't escaped the attention of Major League Baseball.
"They have been diligently getting analysis from bankruptcy experts of the consequences of bankrupting individual teams," a baseball lawyer said.
A baseball official said that Bob DuPuy, the chief operating officer, has a 300-page notebook covering all of the issues that could arise in a club bankruptcy.
"Bankruptcy would be available as an option for a baseball team, and a Chapter 11 filing would not require a team to cease operating," said Kenneth Eckstein, head of the bankruptcy group at the New York law firm of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel. "They would be permitted to continue to operate, and if they wanted, they could try to reorganize and restructure their long-term obligations in a way that could make them more viable."
But Eckstein added, "Bankruptcy for a Major League Baseball team would certainly raise a wide variety of complicated and difficult problems that would have to be carefully worked through."
Player contracts, for example. If a team filed for Chapter 11 and couldn't pay its players, would they become free agents? Their contracts stipulate that if the club defaults in its payments to the player, it has 10 days in which to remedy the default. If it is not fixed in that time, the player has the right to become a free agent. That's how Jim (Catfish) Hunter became a free agent in 1974. But the bankruptcy laws supersede individual contracts and even collective bargaining agreements. There is, for example, an automatic stay that comes with bankruptcy and would prevent anyone from taking adverse action against the team. No one could sue the team to get any money he is owed.
How that concept would apply to the contract clause calling for free agency might have to be determined by the bankruptcy judge. Lawyers who were asked their view of the matter differed, a labor lawyer saying he believed the contract clause would stand up, a management lawyer saying he thought the players would have to petition the court for relief from the automatic stay before they could become free.
A few years ago the Pittsburgh Penguins of the National Hockey League went into bankruptcy, and their players were paid to prevent them from leaving as free agents.
One lawyer suggested that a team could pick and choose with its contracts, letting players leave if they had big contracts and weren't producing but retaining their other players. A player in that situation could file a damage claim against the club, but the claim could be limited under bankruptcy law.
The Tampa Bay Devil Rays, one of the troubled teams, could pursue that course with Greg Vaughn, for example. Vaughn is in the third year of a four-year, $34 million contract, and he's hitting .163. The unproductive designated hitter could face another problem. About 40 percent of the contract, $14 million, is deferred. If the Devil Rays filed for bankruptcy, he would have to get in line with the rest of the team's unsecured creditors to try to collect any of that deferred money. "If I were a player owed deferred money, I'd be concerned," a bankruptcy lawyer said.
Some people think baseball wouldn't allow a team to go bankrupt because it wouldn't want a judge to control the destiny of the team. But when the Baltimore Orioles were sold at an auction in bankruptcy court in 1993 after their owner, Eli Jacobs, filed for personal bankruptcy, the judge gave baseball great leeway. He recognized that the transfer of the team to a new owner would be subject to baseball's rules and approval by the other owners. Before the auction was held, baseball screened the prospective bidders, Peter Angelos (whose winning bid was $173 million), Bill DeWitt and Jeffrey Loria. 
One lawyer said he didn't think an owner would file for bankruptcy because if he did, he would forfeit his equity in the team. 
DuPuy, baseball's No. 2 official, said if a team faced bankruptcy, baseball would not step in and rescue it. "It's not a would not, it's a cannot," he said. "We have no resources to prevent it. We'll do everything we can to help teams survive. It's why we're engaged in the collective bargaining process. We have no desire to see teams fold. But we do not have the ability to take extraordinary steps to help individual clubs. There's no capacity for it."
If a team like the Devil Rays were to go into bankruptcy, a labor lawyer suggested, it could pose potentially perilous problems for baseball. He said he believed that a bankruptcy trustee would file an antitrust lawsuit against baseball, alleging that the expansion fee was exorbitant and constituted an unlawful exercise of a monopoly. 
"The argument," the lawyer said, "would be that if Tampa Bay hadn't had to pay all that money, they wouldn't be in this situation. But because they had to pay it, they didn't have enough operating capital. I'm not saying it's a winning lawsuit, but it's not a frivolous suit."

Contraction Ruling Delayed
Given the owners' desire to eliminate two teams through contraction, would they rather eliminate them that way or through bankruptcy's Chapter 7, under which a company liquidates its assets and goes out of business?
The owners and the players had hoped to learn tomorrow what the arbitrator, Shyam Das, thought of the contraction plan, but he has delayed until Aug. 1 his ruling on the union's challenge to the plan. Das could rule in one of three ways.
He could find that contraction is a step that the owners have to bargain with the union, he could decide that the clubs can eliminate teams without the union's approval, negotiating only the effects of contraction, or, and this possibility is the most intriguing, he could conclude the case without a win/lose result. He could declare the case moot.
Das could opt for the third ruling based on the absence of a second volunteer for contraction. When Commissioner Bud Selig was prepared to act last winter, the Montreal Expos and the Minnesota Twins were willing victims. But legal challenges blocked Selig's path.
Now that Major League Baseball has settled the Minnesota lawsuit by agreeing not to eliminate the Twins for the 2003 season, it has no team volunteering to join the Expos in extinction. Since Selig has made it clear that he will not eliminate a team without its consent, Das could find that without two contraction candidates, no decision is necessary.
When and if the owners find a second volunteer and are prepared to act, circumstances could be different. The arbitrator could feel it would be more appropriate to decide the case then.

Tie Not Selig's Fault
Bud Selig is a natural lightning rod for criticism for just about every negative development in baseball, but he was an undeserving target for his decision to end the All-Star Game when it was tied.
In the immediate aftermath of the fiasco, the managers, Joe Torre and Bob Brenly, let the commissioner take the brunt of the criticism from fans and the news media when they were the ones who put him in position to make that decision.
By using all of their pitchers, Torre and Brenly left Selig with no alternative. He wasn't about to tell them to finish the game with position players pitching. That idea would have made the game a real farce. 
"They mismanaged themselves into a box and ran to Bud," one baseball person said of the managers. "When he made a decision the world didn't like, they didn't stand up and say 'we mismanaged.' "
Torre subsequently did acknowledge that he and Brenly put Selig in that position. "Nobody else did," the Yankees' manager said.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Using Two Lenses for Snapshot on Jobs

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton

 BODY:
WHO would have thought that arcane economic statistics would become a hot issue in the New York State governor's race? But they have, with Democrats and Republicans issuing dueling press releases and accusing each other of cooking the economic books.
 The dispute is over the upstate economy. Supporters of Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, insist that everything is hunky-dory, or at least better than in most other Rust Belt states. The State Democratic Party, which has two candidates vying to replace him, contends that Mr. Pataki "Has presided over massive job loss," as a recent press release put it. 
 Both sides trot out official government statistics to make their cases, but the statistics show opposite trends. In Buffalo, for example, the figures favored by the Republicans show a small job gain since the governor took office; the Democrats' data for the same period shows a hefty job loss. 
 Who's right? The upstate economy is obviously not fine and dandy, unless you are a fan of boarded-up storefronts.
 But the statistics that the Democrats are citing are, to put it kindly, flawed.
 You could almost call them "made up" - not by the Democrats, but by the New York State Department of Labor and federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Nor is it the fault of these agencies. Congress orders them to come up with numbers, but won't give them the money to do it right. So they do the best they can.
 Let's start with the simple stuff. The job numbers that Republicans use and most economists rely on are based on a monthly survey of about 18,000 businesses. Then the State Labor Department fiddles with the numbers to try to make them reflect the economy.
 The cool thing about these numbers, from a data-nerd point of view, is that they are subject to an annual reality check. That's because practically every company in the state files tax returns for the unemployment insurance program, spelling out how many workers they have. So estimates can be revised to reflect reality.
 According to these numbers, New York State has gained 601,200 jobs since the end of 1994, an increase of 7.5 percent. About 288,000 of those jobs were in New York City, where employment increased 7.4 percent. Meanwhile, poor Buffalo's employment rose by just 8,500, or a measly 1.6 percent. 
 But there's another government statistic called employment, and it shows a statewide jobs increase of 5.1 percent, a rise in New York City of 9 percent, and a decline in Buffalo of 3.6 percent, or more than 19,000 jobs. What gives?
 These figures are calculated as part of the effort to determine unemployment rates, which the government uses to dole out its largess. They are based on a small survey of households - at most, 3,300 statewide, said Vincent S. DeSantis, state analyst for the Labor Department.
 People are asked questions about whether they are working or looking for work, and their answers are plugged into two statistical models, one for New York City and one for the rest of the state.
 Problem is, the models are based on the 1990 census, which, aside from being dated, may have undercounted the working-age population. The numbers these models produce have been lagging behind the payroll survey for years.
 Not until next year will the findings of the 2000 census start to be reflected in the models, said Ken LeVasseur, a senior economist for the Bureau of Labor Statistics. At that point, he said, household employment levels should be revised substantially upward.
 Things get even muddier once you get to any areas less populous than New York City (or Los Angeles). The survey sample is too small to be accurate, so all the counties and urban areas get their employment level and unemployment rates by a mysterious method known as the handbook, or cookbook, technique. It uses data including the job numbers from the business survey, unemployment insurance claims, historical patterns and old census data to come up with employment and unemployment estimates.
 Economists tend to be dubious about all this. "You have the impression of cookbooks covered with dust, passed on from generation to generation and stored in a cave under the Brooklyn Bridge," said Mark Sandi, chief economoist for Economy.com, which specializes in regional analyses.
 The payroll survey "has its warts," he said, but "economists prefer it." It will be interesting to see if voters prefer it, too.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "A Conflicting Calculation" shows percent change in number of people employed from December 1994 through May 2002. (Source: New York State Department of Labor)
