HEADLINE: 4 IN PEARL MURDER ARE FOUND GUILTY IN PAKISTAN COURT 

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Monday, July 15 

 BODY:
A British-born Islamic militant was convicted and sentenced to death today for the kidnaping and murder of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter.
 Ahmed Omar Sheikh was convicted with three other men, Salman Saqib, Fahad Naseem and Shaikh Adil, who were sentenced to life in prison, said Abdul Waheed Katpar, Mr. Sheikh's lawyer. The verdict was handed down this morning by Judge Ali Ashraf Shah. 
 Mr. Pearl, 38, disappeared Jan. 23 in Karachi while researching Pakistani's Islamic extremist movement. A videotape sent to American diplomats in February confirmed Mr. Pearl's murder, and the police later found remains of a body in Karachi believed to be those of Mr. Pearl. 
Mr. Katpar said he would file an appeal. Even if the appeal was unsuccessful, Mr. Katpar said, it would likely be months before Mr. Sheikh's death sentence would be carried out. In Pakistan, murder convicts are typically hanged. 
Mr. Katpar expressed frurstration with the prosecution's case, which he characterized as a weak. But he said his client was resigned to the conviction, convinced that American pressure on the court would never allow him to receive a fair trial. 
Security was extraordinary in Hyderabad, the southern Pakistani city where the case was tried. Snipers ringed the rooftops and the police sealed off the street leading to the courthouse. Truckloads of armed policemen, army soldiers and black-uniformed paramilitary commandos patrolled outside the walled jail compound.
The trial has fanned the anger of Islamic militants against Pakistan's government, which many militants feel betrayed them by abandoning the Afghan Taliban and supporting the United States after Sept. 11.
"The government will impose the decision at the behest of the United States," said Sheikh Aslam, Adil's brother, told reporters as he arrived to hear the verdict. "All executive decisions in Pakistan are being imposed by the United States."
Soon after the kidnapping, e-mails received by Pakistani and Western news organizations from the previously unknown National Movement for the Restoration of Pakistani Sovereignty showed Mr. Pearl in captivity and demanded better treatment for Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners at the United States naval base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
Pakistani officials believed that the group was likely a front for militants previously associated with other groups, including Jaish-e-Mohammed and possibly Al Qaeda.
The first e-mail called Mr. Pearl a C.I.A. agent; a second claimed he was working for the Israeli intelligence service, the Mossad. Mr. Pearl's family denied both allegations.
Mr. Sheikh and his co-defendants denied involvement in the kidnapping and accused the government of fabricating the case to appease American anger. 
Mr. Sheikh admitted a role the kidnapping during his initial court appearance Feb. 14, but later recanted.
The trial began April 22 in Karachi but was moved to Hyderabad, about 110 miles away, after prosecutors said they had received death threats.
Prosecutors said Mr. Sheikh, a former student at the London School of Economics, lured Mr. Pearl into a trap with a promise of a meeting with an Islamic cleric, who has been cleared of any involvement in the kidnapping.
The prosecution relied heavily on technical evidence provided by the F.B.I., which traced the e-mails to the co-defendant Fahad Naseem, who identified Mr. Sheikh and the others. 
Mr. Naseem said Mr. Sheikh had told him that he intended to grab someone who was "anti-Islam and a Jew," the police reported.
The key prosecution witness, a taxi driver named Nasir Abbas, testified that he saw Mr. Pearl get into a car with Mr. Saeed in front of a Karachi restaurant on the night the reporter disappeared. The defense claimed Mr. Abbas was pressured into making his statement.
The United States has asked for Mr. Sheikh's extradition to face charges in the Pearl case and in the 1994 kidnapping in India of an American who was freed unharmed.
On the highway between Karachi and Hyderabad, graffiti painted in black lettering on concrete barriers proclaimed: "America, your death is coming," and "The war will continue until America is finished."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ahmed Omar Sheikh, convicted in the murder of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl. (Associated Press)(pg. A7)

HEADLINE: Notes From Yaak; 
The Thirty Years' War

BYLINE:  By Rick Bass; Rick Bass is the author, most recently, of "The Hermit's Story."

DATELINE: YAAK, Mont. 

 BODY:
Where I live, some people decide whether to wave at each other, or even speak a greeting of the day, based on whether the person across from them supports protection of the last roadless areas here. This despite the fact that the timber in these areas is a nonissue: roadless areas are the farthest, most rugged, least productive areas, which is why roads haven't been built there yet.
 It's estimated that the last remaining roadless areas in our national forests -- a total of about 58.5 million acres across 39 states -- contain less than two-tenths of 1 percent of the nation's timber. Yet the divisiveness over such an insignificant amount of timber casts a poisonous pall over entire communities. Some powerful elements in the timber and mining industries are trying wherever they can to scare local millworkers and businesses into believing we can't afford to protect these lands. Here in western Montana this can mean warnings of mill closings and labeling environmentalists as terrorists. 
 In my own valley, the Yaak -- a gnarly, rank, mosquito-ridden jungle that's been subject to countless clearcuts in the last half-century -- there's still not a single acre of roadless land protected as wilderness. Only 15 small roadless areas remain eligible for protection -- the largest is only about 35,000 acres, and the smallest, 1,000 acres -- little more than gardens, from the perspective of the Western landscape.
To date, it's a 30-year war, ever since the United States Forest Service inventoried these last roadless areas for wilderness designation in 1972. Must it be this way for another 30 years? Rural communities of 50 or 100 people fighting over philosophical scraps of land that really belong to every American?
When I began this fight, I was a young man, and went hiking almost every day in many of these public treasures, though almost always with a dull worry in my heart, knowing that these places were not protected for future generations. I'm middle-aged now, with a middle-aged man's responsibilities. Yet still my heart is heavy with that worry of my younger days: How can we defend the nation's last roadless areas?
We've been arguing for decades that building roads in our national forests, where the Forest Service sells public resources (often at a loss), leaves behind damaged land whose repair the taxpayers are left to finance. At last count, the projected cost for such repairs was $8.4 billion. We've been arguing about the necessity of genetic and ecologic diversity. Grizzlies and other rare and endangered species like bull trout depend on the sanctuary provided by roadless areas. We've been arguing that local economies adjacent to wilderness areas are often thriving.
But political recognition of the merits of these arguments has been long delayed. The Clinton administration began the process of establishing permanent protection for these lands in 1998. The Forest Service held hundreds of public meetings over the course of two years, and received an overwhelming public response in favor of protection. But the Bush administration requested further analysis, complaining that there hadn't been enough local input. Last fall over 80 percent of the residents in Idaho, Wyoming and Montana who responded during a second comment period asked -- again -- for the land to be protected. Recognizing this public will, Representatives Jay Inslee of Washington and Sherwood Boehler of New York have introduced an amendment to an appropriations bill for the Interior Department to protect roadless areas. Votes on this proposal are expected as early as this week.
I admit I've grown a bit tired of arguing for the beauty and the economic benefits of wilderness, of the need to protect the endangered species that rely on these lands. I am sick of the polls, which show again and again that we want these lands protected. But what I am not sick of is beseeching, on behalf of wilderness, and the future. If these last wildlands had been protected yesterday -- or last year, or the year before -- little if anything would have changed. That's the point. We choose to live, vacation and work in these lands, hoping they will remain as much the same and secure as possible. Is that so radical?
The Wilderness Act of 1964 passed the House by 373 to 1. I am still naive enough -- and patriotic enough -- to believe that a vote for protecting our last roadless areas can still pass beyond the brittle barriers of party lines: that conservatives can still know what it means to conserve, and liberals what it means to liberate. That we can have joy and logging, both; that we can survive, and then flourish, with our wilderness.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Silicon Valley, Without All the Trimmings

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF and MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif. 

 BODY:
Within walking distance of Stanford, where the economist who coined the term "conspicuous consumption" once taught, a dark reality is playing out. Having already gone from boom to bust, many dot-commers are coming to something worse. Unable to make payments, they are selling luxury cars, canceling home renovations and returning jewelry by the box.
 This region has grown accustomed to high-technology highs and lows over four decades, but the current dot-com collapse has lasted longer and cut deeper. And the recently affluent technology workers who had come to believe in the "long boom," the idea that prosperity would be permanent, are quietly giving up their flashy signs of success to make ends meet. 
 On a counter at Neiman Marcus here, an anchor of one of the nation's most exclusive shopping centers, sits a necklace of amethyst and labradorite. The opaque lavender piece goes for $470, which seems like a fair price for handcrafted jewelry. It is, however, preowned: bought two and a half years ago, at the peak of the Internet bubble, it was returned to the retailer six months ago. 
"When people have too much new money, the way to demonstrate their success is with a lot of frivolous expenditures," said Randy Komisar, a longtime high-technology executive and the author of "The Monk and the Riddle: The Education of a Silicon Valley Entrepreneur." 
Now he says the downturn has produced a painful return to reality: "There is a sense that people got ahead of themselves. People were trying to be more than they actually were, and they expected that the future would look like the past."
It was the economist Thorstein Veblen who first captured the foibles of the recently rich in devastating fashion more than a century ago in "Theory of the Leisure Class." He argued that there was an innate urge to consume as an end in itself and that an entire social class defined itself by what it could buy.
Now, in Silicon Valley, a part of the dot-com class is being defined by what it needs to return. "This is the reality of downward mobility," said a jewelry saleswoman who works at Neiman Marcus. "There is an underlying need to appear that this isn't happening in their lives."
Jewelry, perhaps the most frivolous of purchases, is returned first, she said, in an effort to keep up appearances of normalcy. 
Occasionally the personal financial crises descend into pathos. Not long ago, the saleswoman said, a woman came to her and tried to return the small ornament the store puts on gift-wrapped packages. "It's bizarre and funny," she said. "There are people who are not as wealthy as they once were, and then there are the people who are desperate." 
Indeed, a growing number of those who rode up with the boom are now doing what they can to hang on quietly during Silicon Valley's downturn.
"My fantasies have gone from Gulfstreams to Airstreams," said Matthew Naythons, who was once worth millions on paper as the editorial director of PlanetRX and who is now starting over with a new company, Epicom.
This downsizing of lifestyles is consistent with the rising unemployment, soaring commercial real estate vacancy rates and softened market for hotels and restaurants.
The one area where the economy remains hot -- although no longer so sizzling -- is the market for homes, which are still in short supply. Moreover, brokers say, homes here are increasingly viewed as a haven from the much riskier investments in the staggering stock market.
For others, housing is a mainstay, not one of the luxuries they are purging from their lives. Indeed, unable to make payments, some former dot-commers, and others whose income swelled with the bubble and shrank when it burst, are selling Porsches and BMW's on consignment. They are unloading second homes and canceling renovations.
"People are going through old jewelry boxes and pawning old jewelry," said one high-end jewelry designer, who insisted on anonymity. She said the return rate at Nordstrom was as high as 50 percent, double the traditional rate. 
Jewelry is coming back "worn, torn, filled with hair spray and broken," she said. "Some people are breaking it and then coming back saying, 'This is broken.' "
While the economy is by no means moribund here, there are signs of suffering at both the low end -- where people are unemployed -- and the high end, where the reserves have run thin.
"These dot-com guys can't handle the payments anymore," said Eddie Manio, a sales associate at Bay Area Lease in Redwood City, which sells cars on consignment, taking roughly a 5 percent cut. A picture behind Mr. Manio's desk shows Abraham Lincoln, George Washington and Mr. Manio, with the legend: "Three people you can trust." 
A growing number of people are trusting Mr. Manio to help them sell cars like Porsche, BMW and Mercedes. In the showroom is a 1997 Red Lotus whose owner, who works in commercial real estate, put 15,000 miles on it and is asking $57,500.
Next to the Lotus sits a Porsche Boxster and a '99 Mercedes SL500 for $59,500. The company recently took in a BMW 740i, a luxury sedan, from someone in the software industry.
Mr. Manio said the seller was typical of the kind of client he was seeing more of -- "Silicon Valley and Internet people." But he said that while the numbers of people bringing in cars for sale was rising, he was having trouble finding any buyers.
Carmen Michaelian did not work for a dot-com, but she is feeling the pain, too. She works at the jewelry counter at Nordstrom, selling mostly costume pieces from $30 to several hundred dollars. She said that Nordstrom was liberal about letting people return things, even if they had not recently bought them and even if they were unable to prove that they had bought them at the store.
While this is perceived as good customer service, it is tough on the salespeople, who lose their commissions when there are returns. Ms. Michaelian, who during a very good two-week period will sell $15,000 of jewlery, is also regularly seeing the effect of returns of $3,000 to $4,000 on each two-week paycheck -- a figure she said was typical.
Late last year, she processed a return for a woman who brought in eight necklaces and some bracelets she had bought two years ago. "She didn't say why," Ms. Michaelian said. "Maybe she lost her job." 
According to Jan English-Lueck, a professor of anthroplogy at San Jose State University and author of "Cultures at Silicon Valley," the downturn appears to have eased for some people, but that is hardly universal. She said many people remained overextended -- stuck with big mortgages, for example -- and may be returning items not just to downsize their lifestyles, but to lift their bank accounts. "People are turning merchandise into money," she said.
More generally, the idea that people are returning big-ticket items is consistent with how they view acquiring those items in the first place. "People use disposable income as a cushion," she said, spending money on more extravagant items they know they can return if necessary.
"People buy things with the understanding that, 'if it doesn't work out, we'll sell it,' " she said. "It's like a buffer of wealth." More specifically, she said, Silicon Valley consumers are "sophisticated consumers who know how to return merchandise." 
Lately, Ms. English-Lueck has been researching the attitudes of teenagers and their families in Silicon Valley. She said that she was seeing a renewed emphasis on simplification. Young people are thinking more about the long-term future, even retirement, she said.
"There is a sense that money could go and jobs are not that stable," she said. "Those things are beginning to loom in people's consciousness."

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Fuel-cell work is helping build research prowess for Detroit.

BYLINE:  By Steve Lohr 

DATELINE: WARREN, Mich. 

 BODY:
IN 1956, when General Motors opened its sprawling research center here, President Dwight D. Eisenhower praised it as a symbol of democratic capitalism's natural impulse to explore the frontiers of technology. G.M. executives declared their commitment to making the Warren research center "one of the nation's great resources." 
 Yet the research centers of Detroit -- Ford Motor opened one in 1953 -- never really rose to rival the labs of the information technology industry. A handful of computer and telecommunications companies, led by I.B.M.'s Watson Labs and AT&T's Bell Labs, were the places where the best and brightest minds gravitated to do pioneering work on everything from solid-state physics to software algorithms. 
 Detroit, however, seems to be making a comeback as an industry in which people are working on breakthrough technology. There is perhaps no better place to get a sense of that technological excitement than here in Warren. Today, it is a place of work spaces separated by shoulder-high partitions and informally dressed researchers carrying laptop computers. Except for the prototype automobiles, the place could be mistaken for an office in Silicon Valley. 
One of the more intriguing projects is led by Christopher Borroni-Bird, a young research director who holds a Ph.D. in physics from Cambridge University and did post-doctorate work at Tokyo University before joining the auto industry. He worked for DaimlerChrysler and then moved to G.M. two years ago to help it completely rethink the conventional automobile -- its design, technology and propulsion.
Mr. Borroni-Bird is the program director for a concept car called the Automony, a sculptured, aerodynamic vehicle that is intended to be powered by hydrogen-based fuel cells and controlled electronically using so-called drive-by-wire technology. About the only thing left of the traditional automobile would be the wheels and the driver.
Gone would be the internal combustion engine and, oh yes, the petroleum-based energy economy. The electronic controls would mean there would be no need for foot pedals or even a steering wheel. The car could be driven with a joystick or a device resembling a video-game controller. With no hump for a drive shaft down the middle of the interior, design would be liberated. And the driver could sit anywhere in the car, since the portable electronic controls could be taken to any seat.
A working prototype of the Autonomy is scheduled to be shown later this year. Most other car companies, including Toyota and BMW, also plan to have demonstration fuel-cell vehicles ready soon.
The sincerity of the auto industry in developing fuel-cell cars is difficult to determine. Detroit has an enormous stake in the internal combustion engine and the status quo. But there are incentives to pursue a long-term transition: oil reserves will not last forever, and fuel-cell technology does provide a way to sell cars to the 88 percent of the world's households who still do not own automobiles, without choking the globe in pollution.
The G.M. concept has some particularly interesting elements that Mr. Borroni-Bird, a small, slight native of Liverpool, explained with animated enthusiasm. The Autonomy idea is to separate the chassis from the body. All the fuel-cell propulsion equipment is in the chassis, a series of modular components, beneath a solid platform. Mr. Borroni-Bird refers to the chassis as the skateboard, fittingly, since it resembles a giant skateboard riding on four automobile wheels.
All kinds of car bodies could, in theory, rest on a single platform, secured by mechanical locks. There could be a sports-car style body for a drive in the country or a van-like body for a family vacation. The skateboard platform would use sensors and software to automatically adapt to whichever body happens to plopped on top -- plug and play, as they say in the computer industry.
Such an approach to car-making has the potential to overhaul the structure of the industry. For example, some companies might specialize in making skateboard platforms, while other companies might make bodies. There could be a proliferation of companies and innovation. Yet if one company became the leading producer of skateboards, it could own the crucial technology platform in the industry -- just as, for example, Microsoft's Windows operating system is the dominant technology platform in the personal computer business.
The hurdles to bringing a car like the Autonomy into the mainstream market are daunting as well. Mr. Borroni-Bird is a veteran of fuel-cell research, and he is well aware of the progress that still needs to be made in cost, size and storage if fuel-cell technology is going to become commercially practical. But the trends are going in the right direction. A decade ago, a fuel cell to power an automobile was the size of a van, while today a vehicle like the Autonomy is possible. But can there be enough on-board storage to give a fuel-cell car the 300-mile range before refueling of a conventional car? And what about the fuel-distribution infrastructure? After all, there are roughly 175,000 gas stations in the United States.
Mr. Borroni-Bird and other experts see an evolutionary path toward fuel cells in which first gasoline and ethanol are used in a reforming process to produce hydrogen, which is then used by the cell to produce electricity that powers the car. Still, Mr. Borroni-Bird says, even the gasoline-to-hydrogen conversion would mean 50 percent greater energy efficiency and 50 percent less pollution than internal combustion cars.
Many experts predict that fuel cells will first be used on portable electronic devices like cellphones and laptop computers. Start-ups, like Neah Power Systems of Bothell, Wash., are developing such systems; plug a fuel-cell device the size of a lighter onto the side of a laptop, and it could run for days or a week.
Mr. Borroni-Bird said he was hopeful that by 2010 there would be substantial numbers of fuel-cell vehicles on the road. 
Whatever the outcome, others have noticed the altered mood among the technologists of Detroit. "They are pursuing a radical change in the design and power plant of vehicles," observed Peter Schwartz, chairman of the Global Business Network, a consulting firm in Emeryville, Calif. "It has some of the feel of the early days of the Internet and biotechnology, a sense of vision, enthusiasm and desire to help the world. Microchips and PC's felt that way 20 years ago."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Toyota turns to smaller agencies to set the stage for its new Scion line.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
TOYOTA MOTOR SALES USA is snubbing its main agency, Saatchi & Saatchi, by awarding a group of smaller, creatively focused agencies an estimated $50 million assignment for its new Scion line of less-expensive vehicles. 
 In a departure from the centralized way Toyota typically handles its marketing campaigns, the assignment will be divided among outside agencies including Attik in London and Oasis in New York. Attik is to create a brand identity for Scion as well as concepts for television and print advertising that will present the brand to the intended audience, primarily consumers ages 18 to 24. Oasis is to concentrate on creating content for the Scion Web site, www.scion.com. 
 The initial two Scion models are to be priced under $18,000 and combine elements of cars, trucks and sport utility vehicles. They are expected to start appearing in Toyota showrooms in California in June 2003, then be expanded gradually across the country with a goal of national distribution a year after that.
The introduction of Scion is indicative of efforts by the giant auto makers like Toyota Motor Sales USA, part of the Toyota Motor Corporation, to develop products that will appeal not to the estimated 76 million baby boomers born from 1946 to 1964, but rather to their children and grandchildren. That market consists of the estimated 70 million potential drivers expected by 2010 among Americans born from 1977 to 1994.
From the start of the review for the Scion assignment in February, there had been widespread speculation that executives at Toyota Motor Sales wanted to spread the work. The goal is to help distinguish the Scion brand as much as possible from its older siblings, Toyota and Lexus.
"Everything needs to be perceived as distinct," said Brian Bolain, the national manager for Scion at Toyota Motor Sales in Torrance, Calif. "These buyers demand something especially for them, and it's important every aspect of this project meet that requirement."
The creative assignments for Toyota and Lexus are consolidated at Saatchi & Saatchi, much as the American Honda Motor Company division of the Honda Motor Company consolidated its Honda and Acura brands at Rubin Postaer & Associates in Santa Monica, Calif., and the Chrysler Group division of DaimlerChrysler consolidated its Chrysler, Dodge and Jeep brands at BBDO Detroit, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group.
Such consolidation would not be the right strategy for Scion, Mr. Bolain said. "A very traditional approach is not necessarily going to get us the results we need," he said. "We plan a mixture of traditional and nontraditional, with an emphasis on a grass-roots, under-the-radar approach."
The Los Angeles office of Saatchi & Saatchi produces campaigns for the flagship Toyota brand, which spent $568 million last year for ads in major consumer media like television and magazines, according to the CMR division of Taylor Nelson Sofres. A Saatchi & Saatchi division, Team One Advertising in El Segundo, Calif., creates campaign for the Lexus luxury brand; CMR estimates Lexus spent $187 million last year for ads in major consumer media.
Saatchi & Saatchi took part in the first round of the review, Mr. Bolain said, "but that was where it stopped." He declined to identify the finalists in addition to Attik and Oasis.
Bypassing Saatchi & Saatchi on Scion "has absolutely no implication whatever" for the relationship of the agency and Toyota Motor Sales, Mr. Bolain said, adding that Saatchi & Saatchi would continue to create ads for the Toyota-brand models aimed at younger drivers, like the Celica.
Liv Eisaman, a spokeswoman for Saatchi & Saatchi, which is owned by the Publicis Groupe, referred questions to Toyota Motor Sales.
Attik and Oasis will join two companies already working on Scion. One is Rebel in Los Angeles, a division of Urb magazine that "has helped us with events and promotions related to the music industry," Mr. Bolain said. 
Those include compact discs given away in March and April at the Scion exhibit at the 2002 New York International Auto Show, where the vehicles displayed included the bbX, a tall, boxy four-door reminiscent of a Chrysler PT Cruiser crossed with a Mini Cooper.
The other company now working on Scion is Enterprise Communications in Torrance, a design and graphics agency.
Oasis, owned by the Japanese agency company Dentsu, also works for Toyota Motor Sales, creating corporate image campaigns, ads with environmental themes and ads that promote the Toyota Prius, a hybrid vehicle that runs on gasoline and electricity.
Although Attik has not worked with Toyota Motor Sales before, Mr. Bolain said, the company was attracted to its history of working with a number of youth-oriented clients, which include Adidas, Nike, Sony and Virgin. Attik also handled a project for the Ford Motor Company, involving a concept car aimed at younger consumers.
"Though we've had a taste of the automotive world, our real strength is our understanding of the target audience," said James Sommerville, the chief executive at Attik, which also has offices in New York, San Francisco and Sydney, Australia.
"With people in this age group, you need an alternative spin, an alternative way of thinking," he added. 
"It's less about product and more about feeling, less about 'You've got to buy this car because' and more about fitting into their world with something they love like music, entertainment, friends and family."

HEADLINE: Chief Executive Of Phone Giant In Germany May Be Ousted 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER with ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 14 

 BODY:
The troubled chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, Ron Sommer, is likely to lose his job this week, when the board is expected to replace him with one of his deputies, Gerd Tenzer, people close to the situation said today. 
 Mr. Sommer has fought an increasingly uphill battle to hold onto power since the government of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder began maneuvering last week to oust him before elections this September. The government holds a 43 percent stake in the company, which first issued stock six years ago. 
 On Friday, a four-person steering committee of Deutsche Telekom's supervisory board agreed to propose Mr. Tenzer, 59, as a replacement for Mr. Sommer, 53, whose plan to transform a stodgy state monopoly into a global communications empire foundered on an unforgiving stock market. 
Deutsche Telekom's 20-member board will meet on Tuesday to resolve the issue, executives at the company said.
The power struggle of the chancellor and the chief executive has riveted Germany, pitting a vote-hungry politician against an ambitious businessman. When Mr. Sommer, an ex-Sony executive who was born in Israel, became the chief salesman for the initial public offering of Deutsche Telekom shares in 1996, he persuaded millions of Germans to buy stock for the first time.
But Telekom has lost 90 percent of its value from its peak in March 2000.
In order to remove Mr. Sommer, two-thirds of the board members must vote against him. Given that half the members are drawn from unions and other employee groups, the government must win the support of the rank and file to make a change.
Union leaders have said they could support a new chief executive, as long as he came from within the company. Mr. Tenzer, a longtime Telekom official who oversees production technology and purchasing, would be a conservative choice who would very likely mollify the unions.
Executives at the company, however, said Mr. Sommer planned to appear at the meeting to defend himself.
He has mounted a spirited, well-orchestrated campaign to keep his job. Last week, 20,000 employees of Deutsche Telekom signed an open letter in support of the chief executive, while the company's union leaders unions urged the government not to interfere in its management.
Deutsche Telekom's American investment bankers are also stepping up behind Mr. Sommer. The chief executive of Goldman, Sachs, Henry Paulson, urged the supervisory board not to oust Mr. Sommer, in a letter sent last Friday to the board's chairman, Hans-Dietrich Winkhaus.
Mr. Paulson said the company was in the process of solving its problems, which stem largely from its $67 billion in debt after acquisitions like Voicestream, an American wireless provider. 
"The essential element of the successful execution of this plan is the continuity of Deutsche Telekom's management," Mr. Paulson said in the letter, excerpts of which were read to The New York Times by an executive close to the situation. 
As if to underscore that point, Telekom released first-half financial results last Friday, days earlier than usual. 
Telekom said its traditional phone business had stabilized, though it reported only cash-flow results. On a net basis, the company has said it expects to post a record loss this year of 6.7 billion euros, or $6.57 billion, stemming mostly from its more than $15 billion in annual interest payments. 
The company also said in Friday's report that Voicestream, the No. 6 cellular provider in the United States, had increased its number of subscribers by 525,000, to more than 8 million. Mr. Sommer has been harshly criticized for acquiring Voicestream last year for $24 billion in cash and stock. Telekom has said it would be open to a merger of Voicestream with another provider.
Goldman, Sachs played a central role in Mr. Sommer's acquisitive strategy -- advising him on several deals -- and executives close to the bank said it had taken a major risk in defending him so publicly. "There's a chance we might get fired if Sommer goes down," one executive said. 
That would be a blow for Goldman, which used its close relationship with Mr. Sommer and Telekom as a calling card to become a dominant player in European telecommunications mergers. 
Still, the executives said that Mr. Paulson felt so strongly about Mr. Sommer's keeping his job, that he was compelled to write the letter, after much internal debate at the bank. Mr. Sommer did not put Mr. Paulson up to writing the letter, the executives said, nor did Mr. Paulson mention Mr. Sommer by name. 
Analysts say Mr. Tenzer is a low-key contrast to Mr. Sommer, a charismatic, combative boss who carried on a tempestuous relationship with journalists and even shareholders who questioned his strategy. 
Mr. Tenzer's biggest recent project, people at the company said, was trying to sell Telekom's cable-television properties to Liberty Media, the company controlled by John C. Malone. 
German regulators blocked the $5 billion deal because Liberty refused to commit to upgrading the cable systems to provide high-speed Internet connections and telephone service in competition with Telekom. 
Some analysts said the regulators' decision was misguided -- depriving German customers of a vigorous new competitor in cable television while depriving Telekom of an easy way to whittle its debt. 
If the supervisory board removes Mr. Sommer on Tuesday, it will amount to a far more direct intervention in the company by the government. Analysts say Mr. Schroder was responding to pressure from his political rival, Edmund Stoiber, who has challenged the chancellor's economic stewardship. 
Though Mr. Schroder is personally popular, his Social Democratic coalition trails the Christian Democratic Union coalition, led by Mr. Stoiber, in polls. Elections are scheduled for Sept. 22. 
Last week, Mr. Stoiber, the conservative premier of Bavaria, said "politics should intervene" to revive confidence in Deutsche Telekom.
The political maneuvering has been exceedingly messy. Mr. Schroder apparently decided to cast Mr. Sommer overboard before he had lined up a replacement. That set off an embarrassing spectacle, as German officials offered the job, without success, to a long list of leading German industrialists. 
Critics say the government is also jeopardizing its reputation for market-oriented economic modernization. 
"Schroder set out to create the impression that Germany Inc. was changing," said Thomas Mayer, an economist at Goldman, Sachs. "But this just plays to the old cliche that there is a lot of political meddling in business." 
"It is certainly not something that is going to enhance Germany's reputation for overseas investors," Mr. Mayer said.

HEADLINE: White House Letter; 
Distant From Wall Street, Bush Pays Necessary Visit

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
George W. Bush spent a good 20 minutes, a presidential eternity, slapping backs and signing autographs on Wall Street last week after his speech denouncing corporate sleaze. He looked at home, just as the nation's first M.B.A. president should. 
 But underneath all the public snuggling was a more interesting reality: Mr. Bush, for complex reasons both political and familial, has never been chummy with Wall Street. People on Wall Street now argue that his distance in part explains why the Dow fell nearly 700 points after the president's speech last week, and why many responded so badly to words meant to soothe them. 
 "With Wall Street, he never had close relationships historically," said John M. Hennessy, the former chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston, a friend of both President Bushes. "He is quite different from his father."
So the story of Mr. Bush and Wall Street begins, like so much else in the Bush II White House, with the complicated bonds of the 41st and 43rd presidents -- two men who personify the longtime divide in the Republican Party between the blue-blooded internationalists of Wall Street and the small-business isolationists of Main Street.
The first President Bush, whose ancestors made their fortune in railroads and steel in Ohio, was famously at ease in the Wall Street clubrooms of his father, Prescott S. Bush, the United States senator who ran Brown Brothers Harriman, the bluest of the blue-blood investment firms, which in its heyday was the nation's largest private bank. He named another Ivy League blue-blood, Nicholas F. Brady, as his treasury secretary.
The second President Bush, while he mightily enjoyed his family's Wall Street wealth and connections, needed his own identity. He sought to make his fortune in oil, and although he was not particularly successful, friends and advisers say that he has retained the pride and romanticism of the American businessman who tries to create something with his own hands.
"Those are the people who are the salt of the earth," said Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans, who forged a bond with President Bush when both worked in the oil and gas business in Texas in the 1970's. "It's a community of independent thinkers." Back in Texas, "We were trying to find oil and gas," Mr. Evans said. "We were trying to build companies. We were trying to provide jobs to the local community." 
Talking to Wall Street financiers was little more than an unpleasant necessity. "The action was in the field," Mr. Evans said. "We found more enjoyment going out in talking to the workers in the oil fields than we had in going to New York and talking to the investment bankers." 
A Republican businessman who advises the White House said Mr. Bush came of age in Texas with a disdain for Wall Street bankers, who in the president's view were people who simply moved money around at the expense of those doing the real heavy lifting, America's businesses. "Wall Streeters were basically people who charged big fees to produce dubious results on deals," the adviser said.
These days, however, it is far less Wall Streeters than C.E.O.'s who are engaged in dubious deals.
But when it came time for Mr. Bush to name a treasury secretary, he gravitated toward the C.E.O.'s. Wall Street was scoured, but none of the frequently mentioned big shots -- Mr. Hennessy, or Donald B. Marron, chairman of UBS America -- even made it to the finals, the adviser to the White House said. 
"The president-elect never wanted a Wall Street investment banker as treasury secretary," the adviser said. "He wanted a corporate C.E.O. who had been involved in a company that was more oriented towards the buying and selling of actual products, one that had been involved in the tangible economy, not the intangible economy." 
Vice President Dick Cheney finally offered the job to Paul H. O'Neill, the chairman of Alcoa, who is seen on Wall Street as a bottom line-obsessed truth-teller whose habit for popping off -- Mr. O'Neill said a month ago that there should be public hangings of corrupt corporate executives -- has not been reassuring to the markets.
As a result, some financiers say that Mr. Bush's distance from Wall Street made him months late in forcefully responding to the corporate scandals, and that his administration has not fully understood that Wall Street wants more far-reaching reform than the tough talk of his speech.
"I think if he were closer to Wall Street, he would have a more nuanced view of this business," said Felix Rohatyn, the longtime Wall Street financier and former ambassador to France. Mr. Rohatyn has advocated putting institutional investors on corporate boards and reporting stock options granted to top executives on income statements, neither of which were mentioned in Mr. Bush's speech.
"There are a lot of people in cities other than New York, Los Angeles and Washington who think Wall Street is kind of a casino, that it's full of sharpees and people who did some of the things that happened," Mr. Rohatyn added. "Wall Street has become such a part of Main Street through the mutual funds that you can't say, 'I despise Wall Street,' because Wall Street and Main Street have come together."
Mr. Bush would be unlikely to disagree with that, but that hasn't stopped people like Mr. Evans from remembering how different things were back in their oil days in Texas. "The way you dealt with somebody," he said, "is that you shook their hand -- and you took their word."

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Chief Rejects Calls for His Resignation 

BYLINE:  By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14 

 BODY:
Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that he would not resign despite calls for him to do so by lawmakers who say he has been lax in enforcing commission rules and shares responsibility for the nation's corporate accounting scandals.
 Mr. Pitt has become a focal point in a broadening barrage of criticism of Bush administration appointees over corporate responsibility, most of it by Democratic lawmakers. But he asserted today that he was especially well suited to help bring order to the situation because of his long experience as a lawyer for corporations and the accounting industry. 
 Speaking on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Mr. Pitt formulated a new argument against critics who have said his background in representing the corporate and accounting world should disqualify him from leading the commission.
"I am the right person for the job," he said. "This guilt by occupation is really a needless diversion."
Mr. Pitt's assertion could be used by many other top administration officials, including President Bush.
Mr. Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney and other officials have faced questions about their own corporate involvement in the period that is coming under intense scrutiny. More recently, Deputy Attorney General Larry D. Thompson, who is a member of the administration's new task force on corporate accountability, has faced questions about his role as a director of a credit card company that paid more than $300 million to settle complaints of consumer and securities fraud.
Mr. Thompson, whom Mr. Bush appointed to lead a new multiagency unit to combat corporate crime, was a member of the board of the company, Providian Financial Corporation, and chairman of its audit and compliance committee from June 1997 until May 2001, when he was confirmed as deputy attorney general.
Providian, based in San Francisco, settled complaints by state and federal regulators that it engaged in improper practices, including charging excessive fees to poor people struggling to maintain their credit accounts. The company later settled complaints by shareholders who said its officers did not properly disclose its financial weaknesses in 2001.
Barbara Comstock, the Justice Department spokeswoman, said today that the questions about Mr. Thompson's role in the Providian case were unfair and that he had been the leading force in getting the company to change its ways.
"His experience, his integrity and his professionalism is beyond reproach," Ms. Comstock said. "As an outside director of Providian, he only became aware of the problems when regulators began to make inquiries. As soon as he was aware of the issues, he personally took the lead to make sure the company did the right thing."
She said Mr. Thompson was the driving force in the company's decision to settle the complaints and in changing Providian's practices.
On "Meet the Press" today, Mr. Pitt said that the questions about President Bush's sale of stock in the Harken Energy Corporation in 1990 came from dredging up old material that had been investigated.
But Senators Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, both Democrats, called for Mr. Bush to disclose all records of those investigations.
Mr. Pitt said that the Bush administration had moved swiftly enough to increase the enforcement budget of his agency by $100 million, and that adding more money should wait until his staff completed a comprehensive study of how much it needed. He said that the Securities and Exchange Commission was more effective than ever in investigating and punishing companies, executives and accountants and that the agency was not "being light on anybody."
"We are setting records every day," he said, "and I'm proud of my staff."
Nonetheless, people like Mr. Lieberman, who was Vice President Al Gore's running mate in 2000, and Senator John McCain of Arizona, who ran against Mr. Bush for the Republican nomination, repeated their calls for Mr. Pitt's resignation today.
Mr. Lieberman said on "This Week," the ABC News program, "His background is so infused with a law practice, and a practice that was involved with the very accounting firms that have been accused of the wrongdoing that has so hurt our economy and millions of average investors, that I think it would be better for everyone if Mr. Pitt stepped down as chairman of the S.E.C. and President Bush had the opportunity to appoint somebody totally independent."
Mr. Lieberman also called on President Bush to disclose the details of his sale of Harken stock.
"Because of the president's involvement in the Harken Energy case," he said, "there is a large cloud hanging over his head, which I'm afraid, if he doesn't eliminate it soon by giving full disclosure, will diminish his moral authority, his presidential authority to lead the critical effort to restore confidence in the market."

HEADLINE: Coke to Report Stock Options As an Expense 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS and SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company, breaking ranks with the vast majority of American companies, said yesterday that it would change its accounting so that its earnings reflect the value of the stock options it grants to executives and other employees.
 That move, which will lower Coke's reported profits, is permitted but not required by accounting rules, largely because of intense lobbying by corporations when the rules were adopted in 1994. 
 Companies have feared that reduced profits would hurt their stock prices. But with corporate abuses now a major political issue and some executives having made hundreds of millions of dollars from options before their companies collapsed, the debate seems to have shifted ground.
"I think you will see other companies doing this," said Warren E. Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway and a Coca-Cola director, speaking from Sun Valley, Idaho, where he was attending a meeting with many other corporate leaders. "There has been a lot of discussion out here about this." 
The Coke decision was announced by Douglas N. Daft, the chairman and chief executive, who said it was clear that "stock options are a form of employee compensation expense" and that the change in accounting "ensures that our earnings will more clearly reflect economic reality when all compensation costs are recorded in the financial statements."
Coke officials said Mr. Daft had been considering the move for several weeks, but decided to act after President Bush's speech about corporate abuses on Tuesday.
"Doug Daft took that very seriously," said Gary P. Fayard, the company's chief financial officer. "We know we're in a new environment and we need to take the lead on this issue and perhaps in a small way, try to help restore confidence in corporate America."
The Coke decision drew immediate praise from people who have been pushing to change the accounting. "God bless Coke," said Arthur Levitt, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. "This will become a litmus test," he said, both for corporations, who will have to decide whether to follow Coke's lead, and for politicians who have opposed requiring companies to report this expense.
At stake are billions in reported profits. At Coke alone last year, had the company treated its options as an expense, its profits would have been reduced by $202 million.
All other forms of compensation are reported as an expense. Mr. Buffett said he thought that as more companies report the value of options as an expense, some may turn to different forms of compensation that do a better job of rewarding successful management, such as options that pay off only if the stock outperforms its rivals'. Such options already must be reported as expenses, and as a result, few companies issue them.
Mr. Fayard said the change would permit the company to design better compensation plans, but said the damage to profits would not cause the company to reduce the number of options it grants. "I've always said that accounting should never drive a business decision," he said.
In 1994, the Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets accounting standards in America, retreated from its proposed rule to require options to be expenses. It reacted to heavy political pressure directed by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, who had pushed through the Senate a resolution opposing the plan on a vote of 88-9. He then proposed legislation to all but put the board out of business, but dropped that proposal after the board backed down.
The board surrendered on the private advice of Mr. Levitt, then the S.E.C. chairman. Yesterday, he said that was the worst mistake he made at the commission.
Denis Beresford, the accounting board's chairman in 1994 and now an accounting professor at the University of Georgia, praised the Coke move. "It's about time," he said. "My hope is others will follow."
Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, who led the opposition to Mr. Lieberman's resolution in 1994, will seek today to attach an amendment to the pending accounting bill that would call on the standards board to reconsider the decision to permit companies to avoid treating options as an expense. It is a measure of how corporate scandals changed the political landscape that Mr. Levin thinks he can win a vote today if one is held. But Senate rules permit any senator to block a vote.
President Bush has announced he opposes requiring the reporting of options as expenses, but Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has said they should be expenses.
Under the 1994 rule, the accounting board stated that reporting the value of options as an expense was preferable, but that companies could choose to disclose their value only in footnotes to their annual report. Virtually all companies chose that course, although Boeing and Winn-Dixie Stores chose to report them as expenses.
Last week, a real estate investment trust, the AMB Property Corporation, based in San Francisco, announced that it would begin reporting options as expenses.
Two factors have reopened the option debate in the past year. First, the International Accounting Standards Board, which is seeking to develop global rules, is expected to support reporting options as expenses.
But more important was the reaction to growing corporate scandals. If the old public image of options was of secretaries becoming millionaires through them, the new one is of Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, Enron's two top officers, making hundreds of millions by cashing in options when the company was filing false profit reports.
"When the Enron scandal first hit, I thought it was going to be an isolated incident," Mr. Fayard said, "and then every time you pick up the paper and you turn on the television news there's another restatement or another accounting scandal."
During the bull market, most investors and analysts were happy to ignore the cost of options. But this year, Standard & Poor's announced that in computing the profits of companies in its indexes, it would treat the value of options as an expense.
Analysts praised Coke's move yesterday. "Mr. Daft is taking a leadership position as a corporation that's well known and is attempting to be out in front and be as accurate as he can in the issue of corporate compensation," said Andrew Conway of Credit Suisse First Boston.
Stock options normally allow a recipient to buy stock at a fixed price, usually the market price when the option is granted, for up to 10 years. 
Advocates have long argued that options align the interests of recipients with those of the shareholders. But that is not completely true, since option holders do not lose money if the stock falls. In fact, a temporary fall in the stock price can be to their advantage, since some companies then reprice options, permitting them to be exercised at a lower price. That increases the profits for option holders if the stock recovers.
To many accountants, options are obviously part of employee compensation, just like salaries and bonuses, and therefore should be treated as a compensation expense. But there has not been as much agreement on when the expense should be recognized, or how it should be measured. Coke appears to have broken new ground on the valuation question.
Measuring the expense when options are granted makes sense because that is when employees performed the work for which they are being compensated. But that is also when the eventual value of the option is least clear. Some options will end up being very valuable, while others will expire worthless.
Opponents of treating options as expenses say that no cash changes hands when options are granted, and that the value of the options cannot be calculated with precision. But proponents say that the options are clearly valuable, and note that when a company grants stock to an executive, everyone agrees on the value of the stock, even though the executive may realize more or less money when the stock is eventually sold.
Coca-Cola said yesterday that it would set the value of the options by asking investment banks to submit firm bids to buy or sell options under the identical terms of the options being granted. It will then average those prices.
Mr. Buffett, who was given credit by Mr. Fayard for suggesting seeking those bids, said he was confident those values would be fair because any investment bank that submitted prices too high or too low would run the risk of Coke forcing the bank to buy or sell options at those unreasonable prices.
That method of valuation differs from the one used by Boeing and Winn-Dixie. They estimate the value using an options pricing model known as Black-Scholes. Critics of options as expenses have long said that model is not reliable. Mr. Buffett said he thought that by seeking bids, Coke would assure that its valuation was fair.
Mr. Beresford, the former chief of the accounting board, also praised this approach. "This is really going for a market-based price," he said.
The immediate earnings impact on Coke will be small, perhaps a penny a share this year, because it will not be reporting as expenses the options issued in previous years, and because it issues options late in the year. Options granted this year will be charged to expenses over the next several years, as the options become vested, meaning that employees may exercise them.
Mr. Fayard said that by 2006, when the new accounting is fully phased in, the impact should be about 9 cents to 10 cents per share. 
Previously, Coke estimated the value of options, for its footnote disclosure, based on the Black-Scholes model. In 2001, it said, its annual profit of $3.97 billion, or $1.60 a share, would have been cut to $3.77 billion, or $1.51 per share, had it reported the options as expenses.

HEADLINE: Michigan Senator Who Ran on Drug Issue Will Lead Democrats in Debate 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14 

 BODY:
When the Senate begins a two-week debate on prescription drugs on Monday, Senator Debbie Stabenow will be at the center of the action, leading Democratic efforts to provide Medicare drug benefits and rein in pharmaceutical costs.
 Ms. Stabenow, a lifelong resident of Michigan, personifies the political power of the issue. She rode it to victory in 2000, and many other Democrats hope to do so this fall. 
 More significant for consumers, and more ominous for the brand-name drug industry, is the fact that Ms. Stabenow also symbolizes a change in Congressional attitudes. Growing numbers of lawmakers say they are willing to use the power of the government to make drugs available at more affordable prices. 
Ms. Stabenow was named several months ago by the majority leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, to head the Democrats' prescription drug task force, a "message team" that would harp on the issue, giving voice to voters' frustration over drug prices, while assembling data to rebut arguments by drug manufacturers. 
"We have an industry that is the most profitable in the world," Ms. Stabenow said. "And I don't begrudge that in any way. But when an industry is allowed to make 18 to 20 percent a year, at the same time it's raising prices three times the rate of inflation, and people who need life-saving medicine cannot afford it, I think it's time to ask where the corporate responsibility is." 
The pharmaceutical industry topped the Fortune 500 list of the most profitable industries, providing investors with an 18.5 percent return on revenues last year. But many drug companies report sagging profits this year. 
The bill before the Senate would expand access to low-cost generic medicines, deemed by the government to be just as safe and effective as brand-name drugs. Senators plan to offer amendments to add drug benefits to Medicare, the federal health insurance program for 40 million people who are elderly or disabled. The Senate will also vote on proposals to allow commercial imports of prescription drugs from Canada, where government regulation often keeps prices lower than in the United States. 
Ms. Stabenow's populist crusade disturbs drug industry executives, who dispute her assertion that they spend more on marketing and advertising than on research. 
"We admire Senator Stabenow's energy, but believe she puts politics ahead of good public policy," said Alan F. Holmer, president of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America. "The proposals she promotes are shortsighted, misguided and potentially dangerous for American patients." 
Brand-name drug makers oppose the bill to speed the marketing of generic drugs. They say it would undermine patent protections, reducing incentives for the discovery of new treatments beneficial to patients. Generic competition often causes precipitous drops in sales of brand-name products. 
Drug companies also oppose efforts to import cheaper prescription drugs from Canada. Inevitably, they say, such imports will include products that are counterfeit, contaminated, adulterated or misbranded. 
The first bill introduced in the Senate by Ms. Stabenow, in January 2001, was a bill to permit imports of prescription drugs. "Keeping the Canadian border closed is an obstacle to competition and is serving to maintain artificially high prices for drugs in the United States," she said. 
Although Ms. Stabenow has spoken to Mr. Holmer and other drug company representatives, she said: "I've gotten more and more frustrated because they fight everything. I would love to find a way to work together on something meaningful. But they have the financial capacity, and a financial incentive, to fight everything, because so much money is at stake." 
Mr. Holmer said that the drug industry favored Medicare coverage of prescription drugs, "offered through competing private insurance plans that rely on marketplace competition to control costs." 
Ms. Stabenow said such coverage would be unreliable and unstable, like the coverage provided by health maintenance organizations. Many H.M.O.'s have found federal payments inadequate and pulled out of Medicare, dropping 2.2 million beneficiaries since 1998. 
Senator Stabenow (pronounced STAB-uh-now), 52, speaks with a quiet intensity.
"When you talk to her about something that is causing you pain, it almost seems to affect her breathing," said Richard T. Cole, senior vice president at Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Michigan, who has known Ms. Stabenow for more than 25 years. 
In 1974, at the age of 24, Ms. Stabenow ran against a local official who was trying to close a county nursing home with many low-income residents near Lansing, Mich. "I ran against my county commissioner, who referred to me as 'that young broad,' and I beat him," Ms. Stabenow said. "That's really what got me into politics. I've been involved in health care and mental health care ever since." 
In 2000, she narrowly defeated the incumbent Republican senator, Spencer Abraham, even though he spent nearly 60 percent more than she did. 
"The drug companies did everything humanly possible to stop me from winning my election," Ms. Stabenow said. "They spent millions of dollars in my race. In the last three weeks, they gave money to the Chamber of Commerce to run ads against me. They threw everything at me, including the kitchen sink, but the public stood with me."

HEADLINE: White House Memo; 
Minus One, Bush Inner Circle Is Now Open for Sharp Angling

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14 

 BODY:
President Bush lost one of his closest and most important advisers last Tuesday evening when Karen P. Hughes put her golden retriever and her most precious presidential mementos into her Mazda and headed back to the life she had missed in Texas.
 But by the time she made it to Tuscaloosa, Ala., early on Thursday, she had spoken twice on her cellphone from her car to the boss she was leaving behind, a president who was having one of his rockier weeks. 
 First they discussed the mixed reaction to his speech slamming corrupt corporate executives, which she reassured him had been well received in the Econo Lodges along America's highways. Then they moved on to longer-range planning.
"We talked about the fall, and a couple of issues he wanted me to think about," Ms. Hughes reported that evening, just after crossing the Texas state line. 
Yet for all her cheery insistence that she remains an important influence at the White House, she has chosen a bad moment to leave Mr. Bush's inner circle. He watched the markets tumble after giving a speech meant to soothe investors, then was bombarded by questions about his own stock dealings and company loans. The departure of Ms. Hughes, 45, who announced in the spring that she would move back to Austin with her homesick husband and teenage son, meant that a president who relies heavily on a powerful and close-knit staff instead had one in major transition at a tense time.
Republicans express concern about how effectively that circle of confidants will now serve Mr. Bush, even as Ms. Hughes continues to advise from a distance. Already there is talk that Karl Rove, the feared and canny political adviser who tends to the president's conservative base, will fill the void left by the more moderate Ms. Hughes and make the White House harder-edged and more politically aggressive.
Few of the advisers who remained behind are as trusted by the president as Ms. Hughes, who had a conversation with him barely 12 hours after she left Washington. Mr. Rove is the master of the political universe, Andrew H. Card Jr. is the organized and disciplined chief of staff, Ari Fleischer is the daily voice at press briefings, and Dan Bartlett is a fresh face in Ms. Hughes's old office whose advice is already influencing significant decisions. But not one is a stand-in for a woman who can hold the president's hand or tell him he is completely wrong. 
Even Mr. Card, in an interview in Esquire, called Mr. Rove a "formidable adversary" and fretted that with Ms. Hughes gone the delicate balance on the staff would be lost and there would be no one to stand up to Mr. Rove. Mr. Rove dismissed such talk last week and asserted that his influence had not grown. "I think my role has remained pretty much what it has been from the start," he said. He also denied any political differences with Ms. Hughes. "Karen and I are ideologically about two degrees apart, and it would be hard to tell who is left of the other," he said.
Republicans now say that Mr. Card himself toyed with leaving the White House this spring but that Vice President Dick Cheney was one of those who persuaded him to stay. As it is, many Republicans do not see Mr. Card as tough enough for Mr. Rove. Neither do they have faith that Ms. Hughes's successor, Mr. Bartlett, a savvy 31-year-old former president of the Future Farmers of America, will have the gravitas to balance out Mr. Rove, even though Mr. Bartlett is close to the president. Mr. Bartlett, the White House communications director, is a Texan who got his job in Mr. Bush's 1994 Texas governor's campaign from Mr. Rove. He remains a Rove loyalist.
But it may have been a sign of things to come that it was Mr. Bartlett who took a call early last Monday from Mr. Bush, who was at that point undecided about whether to have a news conference later that day to face reporters clamoring for answers about his stock dealings.
"What's the thinking down there?" Mr. Bartlett said Mr. Bush asked from his parents' summer home in Kennebunkport, Me., where the president had just come in from a dawn golf game with his father. 
"I think we ought to go ahead with it," Mr. Bartlett had replied. A week earlier, before accounts of Mr. Bush's 1990 sale of Harken Energy stock had resurfaced, Ms. Hughes and Mr. Fleischer had decided that Mr. Bush should have a news conference to urge Congress to move on his domestic agenda. By Monday, even though they knew that the press would focus on Harken, they decided that it was better for Mr. Bush to absorb one day of heat rather than a week of news reports about his refusal to answer questions.
"It gave us an opportunity for the press to take its best whack at it," Mr. Bartlett said. Although Mr. Bush's performance -- including his statement that accounting is not "black and white" -- may have ignited more questions than it extinguished, Mr. Bartlett asserted that he was pleased, as was the president.
"That was actually fun," Mr. Bartlett quoted the president as saying after the news conference. Mr. Bartlett asked Mr. Bush if he was being sarcastic, but Mr. Bush insisted not.
Mr. Bartlett could not say there was a lot of fun in the rest of his week, when he ran damage control for the stock sale and Mr. Bush's low-interest loans in the late 1980's from Harken, when Mr. Bush was on the Harken board of directors. 
While Ms. Hughes was making her way across the country with her dog, Breeze, in the passenger seat and her husband, Jerry, driving along in the couple's other car, Mr. Bartlett was telling reporters that Mr. Bush was not hypocritical when in his speech he called for an end to the type of insider loans he had received. Mr. Bartlett said that such loans had been properly used by many companies to encourage long-term share ownership but that in some recent cases they had been abused.
It was a job, Mr. Bartlett said, for which he was uniquely qualified, since he had so often defended the president when the same charges surfaced in previous campaigns. "Look, these issues come up ad nauseam," Mr. Bartlett said, adding that he and the president knew the lingo. "It's almost in code, the two of us have talked about it so much."
On Monday, he is to move from his cramped West Wing quarters into Ms. Hughes's large corner office, with its view of the Truman balcony. (He will not get her title, counselor to the president; that is being retired.)
Last week, as Mr. Bartlett talked to a reporter in Ms. Hughes's abandoned space, he said it had not sunk in that she was gone. "But every time I see the empty office, it does hit me," he said. On Monday, he will take her place on the Oval Office sofa that is closest to the president's chair for the 9:45 a.m. communications meeting. Mr. Bartlett, like 10 or so others on the senior staff, also has Oval Office walk-in rights. 
For now, the White House is putting the best face on the departure of Ms. Hughes, the president's alter ego. (In 1998, when he told Ms. Hughes of his ambitions for the White House, he said, "If you have any doubts about this, we need to talk about it right now, because I'm not doing this unless you're coming with me.") Staff members say that they will just have to dial 512, the Austin area code, more often, and that Ms. Hughes, who has a contract with the Republican National Committee, will remain a crucial Bush adviser. 
Mr. Rove, who spoke to Ms. Hughes by phone up to 20 times a day, said that the new era would be more like the presidential campaign, when he and Ms. Hughes communicated between the Bush campaign plane and headquarters. Others on the staff say that Mr. Bush will demand Ms. Hughes's input. "He will say in every case, 'What does Karen think?' " said Mary J. Matalin, a senior adviser to Mr. Cheney. "And someone will have to talk to Karen." 
Ms. Hughes said she would be at the president's side next month for his break at his ranch, and she was already planning his speech to mark the year anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. She will have a major hand in all his big speeches, she said, and will travel regularly to Washington.
So when she last saw the president, on Monday night at the White House, there was no tearful parting. "I guess this is your last day," Ms. Hughes said the president told her. "But remember, you're not leaving."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 18, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The White House Memo column on Monday, about the workings of President Bush's inner circle after the resignation of his adviser Karen P. Hughes, reported that Andrew H. Card Jr., the president's chief of staff, had considered leaving the White House but that Vice President Dick Cheney helped persuade him to stay. The article should have carried a response from the White House. 
Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Card and Mr. Cheney dispute the report. "Andy did not toy with leaving the White House," Mr. Fleischer said, "and he had no discussions with the vice president about it. So he was not persuaded to stay."

HEADLINE: They've Seen the Future and Intend to Live It 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE SCHECHTER 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif. 

 BODY:
Dr. Ralph C. Merkle is celebrated as an inventor of the encryption technology that allows secure transactions over the Internet. But that was a long time ago. These days, he is better known as a leading theorist of molecular nanotechnology, the still unperfected art of building machines that are little bigger than atoms.
 On a recent morning in a hotel auditorium in Palo Alto, Calif., in the heart of Silicon Valley, Dr. Merkle addressed a singular mixture of scientists and engineers, venture capitalists, economists, students of policy and even a poet or two. 
 All were members of the Foresight Institute, an organization founded on the belief that nanotechnology will transform almost every facet of human existence by giving people mastery over matter.
Nanofactories will churn out everything from rocking chairs to rocket ships, superior to any ever made, at "the cost of potatoes and wood," in Dr. Merkle's words. Nanocomputers will interface directly with the brain, vastly increasing human intelligence. And nanobots will cruise through bloodstreams, banishing disease and debility.
Many in the audience said they believed all that -- and believed that it would happen in their lifetimes. As a consequence, their lives would never end -- at least, not until the universe itself winds down or recollapses in a big crunch. So when Dr. Merkle asked, "How many of you take a personal interest in cosmology and the heat death of the universe?" many hands shot up.
Nanotechnology is a very active field, pursued by researchers around the world in government, corporate and academic laboratories.
The National Science Foundation's National Nanotechnology Initiative has spent more than $600 million in the last year, though most of that is not for research on the technologies envisioned by the Foresight group but for studying the basic science of matter at the atomic level and discovering how to trick simple molecules into assembling themselves into useful structures.
The first fruits of these efforts are emerging in products like pants woven from nanofibers that resist stains, tennis balls that keep their bounce and more efficient light-emitting diodes.
On the horizon are faster, smaller computers built from atomic-scaled carbon tubes, ultrastrong cables that could be used to build an elevator into space, better drug-delivery systems and much more.
The Foresighters applaud such work. But they have a far more expansive vision of the future, based on atomic-scaled machines called assemblers. The assemblers would have tiny arms that could pick up individual atoms and stick them together like Tinkertoys. In this way an assembler could build virtually anything, atom by atom, including a copy of itself. One microbe-sized assembler could become two, then four, then eight, and before long a vast colony. A signal would then turn them from cloning themselves to making, say, dining-room furniture or supercomputers.
If this sounds far-fetched, the proponents say, consider the lilies of the field. They toil not, nor do they spin, yet molecular machinery in their cells transforms air, water and soil into all their glorious garments.
The term nanotechnology was introduced in the early 1980's by K. Eric Drexler, then a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
In his 1986 book, "Engines of Creation," Dr. Drexler popularized his ideas by presenting a vision of the future of material plenty and physical well-being made possible by armies of invisible machines. He also laid out the dangers inherent in this technology, envisioning a nightmare of self-reproducing nanobots run amok, a "gray goo" that would consume everything.
Dr. Drexler and many scientists and engineers who have read his work say they believe such technology is not only possible but more or less inevitable. And once it occurs, they say, it will spread with incredible rapidity. In 1989 Dr. Drexler founded the Foresight Institute to "help prepare society for anticipated advanced technologies."
Every year the institute's senior associates (as members call themselves) gather for a weekend of prognostication, planning and hand-wringing over the future. It is a diverse group of smart and articulate people, many of whom have made their fortunes in the computer industry and have the leisure to think about the future.
Transcending the human body -- fallible, feeble and finite -- seems to be most on their minds. Around the wrists of many of the hands that shot up when Dr. Merkle asked his cosmological question were silver bracelets with instructions on what to do if the wearer is found dead.
After they die (if they do), many senior associates plan to have their bodies or heads frozen in liquid nitrogen until the day they can be resurrected, either into flesh or silicon, by a herd of nanobots. (Dr. Merkle is a member of the board of the Alcor Life Extension Foundation of Scottsdale, Ariz., the organization that is freezing the body of the baseball slugger Ted Williams at the request of his son.)
For those who manage to avoid death for long enough, there is the hope of having nanobots circulate in their bloodstreams to fight disease.
Chris Phoenix, a software developer and would-be nanotechnologist, has drawn up intricate plans for a system of nanobots that would make blood circulation obsolete. Tiny robot tankers containing oxygen, nutrients and wastes would replace all the functions of the circulatory system. The heart, that great, clunky pump, would no longer beat. Mr. Phoenix would not miss it. "Personally, I'd rather not have a heartbeat," he said. "The noise in my ears keeps me up when I try to go to sleep."
Ray Kurzweil, the enormously successful inventor of reading machines for the blind, electronic pianos and many other useful gadgets, does not expect to die. A member of Foresight's board, Mr. Kurzweil presented the conference with graph after graph that he said demonstrated that the rate of technological progress was exploding.
"The 21st century will see 20,000 years of progress at today's rate," he said, adding that computers and humans will merge, producing a being of almost unlimited intelligence.
Dr. Gregory Stock, director of the Program on Medicine, Technology and Society at the University of California at Los Angeles, presented a very different vision of the future of humanity. Dr. Stock does not believe that the merging of humans and machines will be easy, and he doubts that most people will go for it.
"I'm the conservative, because I think we're going to remain largely biological," he said. "I'm not going to go through a brain operation to install the moral equivalent of a programmable toaster."
The world view of the Foresight Institute, Dr. Stock says, reflects an unexpected spiritual longing -- a "strange urge in us to transcend our biology."
"If you can't buy Christianity," he said, "there is a strong desire to create those same visions of heaven and transcendence through our technologies."
