HEADLINE: Canadian Auto Workers Open Talks With the Big 3 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON

DATELINE: TORONTO, July 16 

 BODY:
The union representing 46,000 Canadian auto workers began talks today with the big three North American automakers on a new labor contract that might set precedents for similar talks next year in the United States. There were signs that the local unit of General Motors would be the union's primary, and most accommodating, target.
 G.M., Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler all have closely integrated their American and Canadian operations, with assembly lines in each country producing vehicles for the entire North American market. But for the first time in many years, bargaining on labor contracts is not taking place simultaneously in the two countries. 
 Buzz Hargrove, president of the Canadian Auto Workers union, told reporters at a downtown hotel here today that "we have the full attention of corporate executives on both sides of the Detroit River." Mr. Hargrove's union signed three-year contracts with the companies in 1999, while the agreements concluded by the United Auto Workers at the same time run for four years. The Canadian contracts expire Sept. 17.
Scott R. Hill, an analyst at Bernstein Investment Research and Management in New York, said that the talks in Canada would probably be dominated by demands for greater job security, while bargaining in the United States next year was likely to center on pensions and health benefits.
Canadian union officials presented their contract proposals to G.M. today. They are to meet with Ford on Wednesday and DaimlerChrysler on Thursday.
Al Green, vice president for personnel at General Motors of Canada, said that whatever deal was reached in Canada would not necessarily influence the parent company's talks next year with the U.A.W.
The union in each country usually selects as a target the company that it thinks will yield the most favorable deal. It negotiates, and if necessary takes job actions, against that company first. Whatever contract is reached with the target then becomes the basis for negotiations with the other two.
The union expects to announce its choice shortly after Labor Day. Echoing other industry watchers, Mr. Hill said that General Motors was "the likely initial target."
G.M. "could agree to a lot of things on plant closures that Ford and DaimlerChrysler would have difficulty agreeing to," Mr. Hill said. G.M. has been posting overall sales and profit gains in recent quarters, including a strong second-quarter report released today, while both Ford and DaimlerChrysler results are off from a year ago. The sales pattern in Canada is much the same.
Mr. Hargrove would not say directly which company the union intended to choose as its target, but he hinted that it would be G.M., saying, "If they're making money, as you head down to the deadline, they're much easier to deal with."
Mr. Green said his company would welcome being the initial target. "It gives us an opportunity to fashion an agreement that's most appropriate to us," he said. The Canadian union last chose G.M. as its bargaining target in 1984.
Flanked by a chart showing rising motor vehicle sales and falling jobs in Canada, Mr. Hargrove said that the union would be seeking to lower the present 10-year seniority threshold for workers to qualify for guarantees of work or income under the contract. The union was also asking for "substantial" wage increases and compensation for the reduction of benefits under Canada's public health system, Mr. Hargrove said.
All three automakers have recently announced plant closings in Canada. A G.M. plant at Ste. Therese, Quebec, that produces Camaro and Firebird sports cars is scheduled to close next month, eliminating 1,400 jobs. Ford plans to close a pickup truck assembly line at Oakville, west of Toronto, next year.
But G.M. recently added a shift at its large plant in Oshawa, east of Toronto, to step up output of Chevrolet Impala sedans. It also said last month that it would invest $195 million there to produce a new midsize Pontiac. "They have already provided the security that the union is asking for," Mr. Hill said.
Mr. Green said the main issue for his company was "intense competitive pressure," especially from foreign manufacturers, whose share of the North American market has risen markedly in recent years. He said G.M. would seek to lighten its expenses for retirees' pension and health care costs with "cost offsets," but declined to elaborate.

HEADLINE: G.M. Profit Doubles, but Worries on Pensions Hurt Stock 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 16 

 BODY:
Profit at General Motors more than doubled in the second quarter, the company said today, but its pension liabilities and its investment in Fiat continued to pull down its stock price.
 Foremost among Wall Street's concerns is how much money G.M. will have to inject into its huge pension fund to offset the falling value of its stock investments and maintain payments to its more than 400,000 American retirees. 
 G.M. said today that the value of its fund declined 3 percent in the first half of the year. Though that was far better than the 14 percent decrease in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in the period, the company had projected a 10 percent gain this year. Such swings can require the injection of billions of dollars to make up the difference. 
Another worry is the $2.4 billion investment for a 20 percent stake in Fiat, the struggling Italian automaker. John M. Devine, the chief financial officer, said G.M. would take a substantial write-down of the value of that stake in the third quarter. 
The news overshadowed G.M.'s more positive news. The company earned $1.29 billion, or $2.43 a share, in the quarter, compared with $477 million, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $48.27 billion from $46.22 billion.
Excluding losses from its Hughes Electronics division, which it is selling, and nonrecurring charges, the company earned $2.63 a share, beating analysts' expectations of profit of $2.42 a share on that basis, according to Thomson First Call.
G.M.'s share of the United States auto market also increased, to 28.1 percent in the quarter from 27.3 percent in the quarter a year earlier. 
Shares of G.M. fell $2.08, or 4.3 percent, to $45.84. The stock closed as high as $68.02 in May. 
Despite momentum on sales and earnings, G.M. has not been able to shake concerns about how painful it will be to meet its pension obligations with the stock market sliding. G.M. said today that if its returns were flat for the year, its pension fund would be underfinanced by $12.7 billion, compared with $9.1 billion at the end of last year. But Mr. Devine said the situation was not nearly as dire as some analysts saw.
"Our cash requirements are significantly below what a lot of people have been guessing," he said.
Last week, Saul Rubin, an analyst at UBS Warburg who had been bullish on G.M., downgraded the stock to a hold from a buy solely because of the pension liability and said if investment returns stagnated the fund could have a $31 billion deficit by 2005 and jeopardize the company's plan to earn $10 a share annually by the middle of the decade. 
"If one ignores the pension fund, the G.M. story is a good one," Mr. Rubin wrote in a report. He added that it was "unfortunately impossible to ignore the pension issues."
There are also concerns from Wall Street that G.M.'s sales are driven by the company's big rebate and interest-free financing offers. Such incentives are good for car buyers but hugely expensive for G.M., as well as Ford and Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler.
Because of quality and reputation issues, the Big Three have to use far more incentives than foreign competitors to sell cars. Big Three incentives were more than $2,500 for each vehicle in June, while the average Asian car sold in the United States had incentives of $857, according to the Autodata Corporation, an industry research firm. 
Some analysts, though, think that G.M.'s steep stock decline since May makes it an attractive bargain. Scott Hill, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, said if the economy recovered in the second half, as he expects, G.M. would gain twice as much. Not only will its business be strengthened, but a recovering market will change its pension outlook.
"The risk to the pension plan hasn't changed in the last two years," he said. "What's changed is that each time the market swoons, it exacerbates the negative issues." 
Mike Holton, an analyst at the investment firm T. Rowe Price, had a similar view.
"If you are worried about the economy and the market, then clearly G.M. has issues," he said. "However, if you think we're heading to a better economy in the second half and gaining traction in 2003, that's clearly positive for G.M. and the automakers. And along with that, you figure the capital markets will act better."

HEADLINE: As Recession Drags On and Coalition Crumbles, Turkey's Premier Calls Early Elections 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL SIMPSON 

 BODY:
Turkey's ailing prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, succumbed to the inevitable yesterday and agreed to early elections, in November, after more defections from his wobbly coalition brought it below a majority in Parliament.
 The three-party coalition has been crippled by bickering over reforms that are a condition for talks on joining the European Union. 
 Mr. Ecevit's hand was forced by an exodus from his own Democratic Left Party this month of almost half of its members in Parliament, making it the smallest party in the coalition instead of the biggest. 
Mr. Ecevit, who is 77 and has been sidelined for weeks with illnesses that include a spinal disorder and Parkinson's disease, plans to soldier on until the elections, which will be 18 months earlier than required.
Although six more members resigned from the party yesterday, Mr. Ecevit persuaded a bloc of nine to stay, apparently removing the threat of a vote of no confidence as the political focus shifts to the election campaign.
Deputy Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz said Devlet Bahceli's Nationalist Action Party, now the biggest party in the coalition, had promised not to block reforms needed for European Union membership, in return for setting an election date.
"We will start working toward recalling the Parliament as soon as possible," Mr. Yilmaz said, "at the latest by the end of this month, to make the necessary legal amendments for E.U. membership."
All three parties in the governing coalition are fighting for their survival. None can be sure of clearing the threshold of 10 percent of votes that they would need to be returned to Parliament.
Opinion polls indicate that the new Justice and Development Party, forged a year ago from the ashes of a banned Islamic party, is by far the most popular with voters.
Many of the defectors from Mr. Ecevit's party are expected to join a new centrist party being formed by his most prominent former allies. They jumped ship fearing that the political deadlock could jeopardize the ambition of Turkey, NATO's only mostly Muslim country, to join the European Union and to receive a $16 billion International Monetary Fund loan.
The stakes are high for this country of 65 million, which is suffering from high unemployment and its worst recession since 1945. They are also high for the United States, which needs a compliant and stable ally as a base if it decides to proceed with military action against neighboring Iraq.
Financial markets appeared to be relieved that the election had been called after weeks of bluster and uncertainty that have pushed the currency, the lira, to all-time lows and increased Turkey's already huge debt service. But the outcome is uncertain.
The new centrist group, announced last week by former Foreign Minister Ismail Cem, is expected to attract support in the big cities. But it needs time to develop effective party machinery, and Mr. Ecevit appears to be banking on elections as the best way to thwart its challenge.
"At the last minute, coalition leaders agreed on an early election in an effort to preserve their strength," said Dr. Ahmet K. Han, a political scientist at Bilgi University in Istanbul. "Their aim is surely to dissolve the new formation, given its organizational uncertainties."
Mr. Bahceli plans to make Turkey's European Union candidacy an election issue. He opposes membership because of requirements to abolish the death penalty and to ease curbs on the use of the Kurdish language by the country's ethnic Kurds.
His party, which is seeking voters in more nationalistic rural areas, insists that concessions to the Kurds would encourage them to renew a separatist revolt. The captured Kurdish guerrilla leader Abdullah Ocalan, who was sentenced to death for treason, has been granted a stay of execution pending a ruling from the European Court of Human Rights.

PERSON: John J. Gilbert 

HEADLINE: John J. Gilbert Is Dead at 88; Gadfly at Corporate Meetings 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
John J. Gilbert, one of the earliest and most persistent gadflies to speak out at annual meetings on behalf of small shareholders -- dramatizing his demands with such attention-getting props as a red clown's nose -- died on Monday at his daughter's home in Denver. He was 88.
 Margot Gilbert Frank, his daughter, said he became ill last September while attending a reception to honor his establishment of a chair in accounting at the University of Denver. He never returned to his home in Manhattan. 
 Mr. Gilbert and his older brother, Lewis, each attended more than 80 annual meetings a year to press what they called corporate democracy. By persistently questioning chief executives -- not a few of whom considered it badgering -- they succeeded in prodding more companies to hold annual meetings in accessible locations, to issue post-meeting reports, to limit stock options for executives and to require the independent auditors of companies to attend meetings.
Some companies were persuaded to adopt one of the Gilberts' pet ideas, cumulative voting for directors, which improves the chance of minority shareholders to name board representatives. Under this method, shareholders are permitted to cast all their votes for one candidate.
As a result of cumulative voting, "we can get honest directors on the board," Mr. Gilbert argued. "We want to keep these companies honest."
Mr. Gilbert brought more flair to the campaign than his more cerebral brother. At a PepsiCo meeting, he donned his clown nose and asked why none of the directors were wearing PepsiCo ties.
After being kicked out of a Chock Full o' Nuts meeting, he returned the next year with two pairs of boxing gloves hanging from his neck.
The result approached outright theatricality in settings where a few shareholders had formerly gathered in small numbers to quickly and quietly pass the management agenda. Wilma Porter Soss, who once dressed as a cleaning woman to protest the quiz show scandals at CBS, and Evelyn Y. Davis, who waved an American flag at a General Motors meeting, were others who brought showmanship to the fight for shareholder rights. Sometimes, all appeared at the same meeting.
But the Gilberts were leaders. In 1983, they proposed 198, or 20 percent, of the 972 resolutions proposed at annual meetings, according to the American Society of Corporate Secretaries. The next closest, with 100, was Andrew W. Duncan, a champion of conservative causes.
John Jacob Gilbert was born in Manhattan on May 8, 1914. His father had owned part of a paper mill, but sold it and lived from investments.
"I was born with a silver spoon and polished it," Mr. Gilbert said. He attended private schools and graduated from Patrick Business School, since closed, in Manhattan.
He and his brother started attending annual meetings in the 1930's, at first just to watch over their investments. But Mrs. Frank -- who along with three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren survives Mr. Gilbert -- said they were "appalled" at what they saw.
"It was like going to a private club," she said. "It was the good old boys."
So they amassed relatively small blocks of stock in 1,500 companies, initially as an investment. Because of this, their early complaints often concerned companies that paid no dividends, but greatly increased executives' compensation.
Mr. Gilbert considered his 1946 stand against the insurance company Transamerica a defining moment for outside shareholders. He proposed moving its annual meeting from Delaware, the state of incorporation, to California, where operations were. He further proposed that shareholders approve management's choice of auditors, and that those who could not attend be provided minutes.
A result was that the Securities and Exchange Commission began to require that relevant shareholder resolutions be included in proxy statements. Mr. Gilbert called this ruling "the Magna Carta" for small shareholders. Not only did this propel his push for shareholders' economic rights, but such diverse shareholders as unions and churches started using proposals in proxies to advocate social and political causes.
For 40 years, ending in 1979, the Gilberts published an annual compendium of activities at corporate meetings. They, of course, were often at the center of the action.
At a Macy's annual meeting in 1963, for instance, John Gilbert railed against "management stooges."
Jack I. Strauss, the company's chairman, replied, "Mr. Gilbert, we love you." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: John J. Gilbert, 1972 (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: VISIONS OF GROUND ZERO: AN APPRAISAL; 
An Agency's Ideology Is Unsuited to Its Task

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
Six plans for redeveloping the World Trade Center site are now on view at Federal Hall, the landmark Greek Revival building on Wall Street half a block north of the New York Stock Exchange. Except as a starting point for public discussion, the plans have little to recommend them. 
 And the discussion should extend far beyond the narrow, not to say provincial, scope of the task that the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the state agency created after Sept. 11, has defined for itself. Thus far, it has demonstrated little besides a breathtaking determination to think small. 
 Don't come looking for ideas that reflect the historic magnitude of last year's catastrophe. Nor will you find any sign of recognition that ground zero has become a tragic symbol of the troubled relationship between the United States and the rest of the world. What you see, instead, are proposals for real estate development: six ways to slice the pie. 
The plans, which will also be presented this Saturday at a town hall meeting at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, are more notable for similarities than differences. All of them meet the same quotas for mixed-use development: 11 million square feet of office space, and 600,000 square feet each for retail space and a hotel. These figures represent the amount of space lost.
To a greater or lesser extent, all of the plans reintroduce the Manhattan street grid to divide the 16-acre site into smaller parcels. In each, Greenwich Street would cut through from north to south, while Fulton Street would cut from east to west. All but one of the plans envision a memorial park or green space.
The differences lie mainly with the number and shape of the individual parcels, and with the inclusion or not of superblocks containing multiple high-rise buildings. There are also implied ideological differences. Two plans reflect the New Urbanist retro theme park approach favored by Alexander Garvin, vice president for architecture and planning for the development agency. The superblock proposals evoke presently disfavored planning strategies employed by modern architects in the mid-20th century.
Three of the six plans should not even be considered in their present form. Gov. George E. Pataki is correct to insist that the footprints of the twin towers should not be built upon. Half the plans fail to respect the symbolic sanctity of this ground. 
Otherwise, the distinctions are superficial. All six plans emanate from the underlying ideology of privatization, which is what public debate should be focused upon. These plans represent a crisis for the increasing privatization of the city planning process through its vehicle of choice, the public-private real estate development process. As the most ambitious model of this vehicle yet realized, the development corporation itself deserves far closer scrutiny than the plans it has set out.
(Disclosure: The New York Times Magazine is sponsoring an architectural study project on the future of the financial district. I have advised the editors on the composition of the design team. An overview is scheduled for publication in September.)
As a planning agency, the development corporation is multiply redundant. Since the Koch administration, New York's woefully understaffed Department of City Planning has steadily deteriorated into an engine for economic development. A second city agency, the Economic Development Corporation, performs the same function, on a more explicit basis. The Empire State Development Corporation, a state agency created to build subsidized housing, also funnels resources into profit-making ventures.
Meanwhile, business improvement districts, like the Alliance for Downtown New York, have also subsumed planning functions within commercial considerations. Another agency, geared to the same market-driven agenda, was scarcely needed.
However, the Law of the Instrument states: The instrument must be used. It is not in the nature of bureaucracies, once created, simply to wither away. Although the development corporation merely adds a new layer of officialdom to an already overcrowded field, it must justify its existence by undertaking what appear to be tasks it is uniquely qualified to perform. Leaving aside, for now, the experience or competence of the corporation's officials in city-making, the authority by which the agency operates is open to question.
Clearly, that authority does not derive from cultural values. Though we have been told to expect an international architectural competition to design a memorial, and despite vague allusions to something called "cultural programming" (a contradiction in terms), no effort has been made to solicit guidance from thinkers, historians or economists, or from any architects or groups known for depth of historical awareness. This is an astonishing oversight at a time when the architectural field is crackling with ideas for rejuvenating older urban centers for the era of globalization.
What we see, instead, are the usual strategies employed to foster an image of expertise. Chief among these is secrecy. Despite an outward display of transparency, the agency has gone about its business with a remarkable lack of candor. Though a competition to design site plans was heralded with much fanfare, for example, two of the six plans were prepared by Peterson Littenberg, a New York firm retained independently by Mr. Garvin.
Peterson Littenberg's plans are not identified as such in the Federal Hall exhibition. Indeed, the display provides no provenance for any of the plans. But those who have been tracking the story closely will recognize that one of the plans originated with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, a firm retained by Larry Silverstein, the developer who holds the lease on the property. Another plan is based on a concept developed by Cooper, Robertson & Partners, architects for the Brookfield Properties Corporation, owner of most of the World Financial Center.
While Beyer Blinder Belle, the New York firm selected in the competition, has tweaked these plans, the failure to attribute authorship is a public disservice.
Without this information, we might as well be looking at Rorschach tests, or floor plans for luxury condominiums. All that's missing from these decontextualized images are the names. Do you prefer "The Greenwich" duplex, say, or "The Wall Street" suite?
There is a Potemkin quality to the development corporation's planning efforts. We're never quite certain whether the agency is talking about actual proposals, plans that stand a chance of implementation, or pipe dreams that will fade away after the election for governor this November.
Without the power to implement its plans (this power resides with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the owner of the site), the development corporation is "like" a planning agency and the six proposals are "like" plans. In precisely the same fashion, this Saturday's town hall meeting will be "like" democracy. Five thousand people will be invited to weigh in, but who will hold the microphone?
Let's put this undertaking back in context. Here is the news of the day. The financial marketplace is in disarray. Markets for publishing, music, art, fashion and other New York-centric industries have all been affected. Last year's attack on the twin towers was a contributing factor. Along with the Enron scandal, it helped to precipitate widespread challenges to the conduct of business as usual.
And here, in the geographical midst of the disarray, is the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, going about business as usual with what to this observer looks a lot like a vengeance. Our public-private development machines must press on, regardless of the actual need for square footage, with no consideration for the conflicts of interest and the lack of accountability that they typically involve. It is hard for the city lover to stomach the enlistment of architecture in such an unworthy cause.

HEADLINE: In New Jersey, Nuclear Fears Have to Stand in Line 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LEZIN JONES

DATELINE: MANCHESTER TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 16 

 BODY:
The talk was of terrorists and the possibility that they might strike 15 miles from here at Oyster Creek, the nation's oldest operating commercial nuclear plant. But as she stood in line last weekend to collect federally issued potassium iodide tablets -- a precaution in case of radiation exposure -- Marcie Ekelmann said that in the event of an attack, she would most likely opt for something less medicinal, but perhaps more soothing.
 "Chances are it will be too late," she said, "so I'll just grab a six-pack and head out onto my boat." 
 Sunglasses perched atop her head, Ms. Ekelmann, 36, said she was collecting her handful of foil-covered pills mostly to calm the fears of her three children. But for herself, she waved away talk of any barleyfree precautions: "I think there is a lot of worrying over nothing." 
She might well have been speaking for much of the rest of New Jersey. Residents of other communities in the New York region that are near nuclear reactors -- the Indian Point plant in New York and Millstone in Connecticut -- have been moved to anxiety and activism by fears of terrorism. But the response has been noticeably muted in New Jersey, which has four nuclear plants.
Distributions of potassium iodide tablets here have drawn a small fraction of the takers they have attracted elsewhere. The public debate over other steps that might be taken to prevent nuclear terrorism has been more subdued. And people on all sides of the debate say there is a perceptible nonchalance about potential dangers here that may be born of such factors as income levels, the chemical hazards common in New Jersey (insert your own toxic waste joke here) and this state's somewhat cynical view of itself.
"Bad things are part of being in New Jersey," said Frank Kasmer, 43, a maintenance worker in an Atlantic City casino who lives about a mile from the Oyster Creek plant. "It's a part of being everywhere. People in New Jersey have that type of attitude -- you have to take the good with the bad."
New Jerseyans are well acquainted with the painful toll of terrorism: nearly one of every five people killed in the World Trade Center attack was from the state. There is a growing chorus of residents concerned about a possible nuclear disaster, and state emergency officials remain at their highest state of alert.
Still, the vague threat of calamity has left many here unfazed.
"Perception is always worse than reality," said Dr. Barry E. Truchil, a sociologist at Rider University. "If you look at what New Jersey has faced -- we've had anthrax scares, chemical dumping in Toms River, the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island, we have Superfund sites -- New Jersey has a lot of reality that they can use to put this risk into context.
"It may be a false sense of security, but it also qualifies why people may not react in a loud, scary way."
Their silence may also stem from the location of the state's reactors, in small towns in South Jersey, far from densely settled places like Westchester County, N.Y., where Indian Point sits. The Oyster Creek reactor is in Forked River, about 80 miles south of Manhattan on the Jersey Shore. The Hope Creek and the Salem 1 and 2 generators are clustered in Lower Alloways Creek Township, in the southwesternmost corner of the state. 
"This is a small town, and I don't think they've had anything happen here yet," Dolores Aviles, a waitress at the Forked River Diner, said of the threat of terrorism. "You're closer to it in New York, so you're more likely to be sensitive to it."
Consider the turnout for potassium iodide pills on Saturday at Manchester High School, about 15 miles north of Oyster Creek -- one of five giveaways planned statewide during the next few weeks.
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has offered the pills to everyone who lives or works within 10 miles of any of the nation's 74 nuclear power plants, suggesting that the tablets be ingested in the event of radiation exposure. Officials say the pills prevent cancer-causing radioactive iodines from invading the thyroid.
At Manchester High, residents took home only about 4,000 of the 100,000 doses that Ocean County emergency officials had on hand. Three times as many pills were distributed last month during a similar handout in Rockland County, N.Y., across the Hudson River from Indian Point in Buchanan. Rockland has about half the population of Ocean County, but had stocked almost twice as many pills.
Likewise, there are more potassium iodide pills than people in Westport, Conn., where town officials last month bought 50,000 doses -- a figure roughly twice the town's population. And Westport is not even within the 10-mile radius in which the pills are recommended; Indian Point is more than 40 miles away, and the Millstone plant is more than 60 miles away, in Waterford, Conn.
Dr. Truchil wonders if the difference in the public response can also be traced to economics. The median income levels in Rockland and Westchester Counties are at least $15,000 more than those in Ocean and Salem Counties.
"The higher up the social plane you are," he said, "the more likely you are to have the wherewithal to deal with governments, the more likely you are to know how to work the system," he said.
In smaller, more remote communities, a power plant can also be a major economic engine, a provider of jobs and money. That is the case in Salem County, where an antinuclear group, the Unplug Salem Campaign, has been urging since September that all four New Jersey plants be closed because of the terrorist threat and other potential hazards. 
A similar campaign to close Indian Point has drawn hundreds of supporters to rallies. But the response in South Jersey has been disappointing, said Norm Cohen, a coordinator of the campaign.
"Salem County is unfortunately an econmically depressed area," he said. "People are looking at day-to-day realities like putting food on the table."
The group has actually been more successful in marshalling opposition the farther it gets from the Salem plant. But it is still difficult to mobilize New Jerseyans over issues of plant safety, advocates say.
"They don't seem concerned, but I think that people certainly need to be concerned," said Joe Deckelnick, an organizer with the New Jersey Environmental Federation, which has tried to focus public attention on ecological threats from the plants.
He attributes much of the indifference he has seen to a belief that safeguards will prevent accidents like the one in 1986 at the Chernobyl plant in the former Soviet Union. But he said Sept. 11 had shown the dangers of such assumptions. 
"We're not talking about people who think the way we think," he said of terrorists. "Certainly, if they could fly a plane into the trade towers, they can fly a plane into a nuclear plant."
Even if that were to occur, experts in nuclear power say that a large-scale catastrophe is unlikely.
"The chances are just very, very small that you'll get a large leaking of radiation," said Raymond W. Durante, a Washington consultant on nuclear power issues.
Mr. Durante, a former official with Westinghouse Electric, a manufacturer of nuclear plants, said the buildings designed to contain nuclear reactors in the United States were stronger than those in other countries. That, he said, would prevent major radiation exposure.
He conceded that in an extreme case like Sept. 11 -- heavily fueled jets striking power plants at sensitive points and starting hard-to-extinguish fires -- "we'd see a lot of serious damage, a lot of problems related to nonnuclear equipment."
But even then, at least four layers of protective coverings around the radioactive core must be destroyed before there is any serious danger of extreme radiation exposure, Mr. Durante said.
Emergency management officials have ordered extra security measures outside the state's nuclear plants since September. National Guard posts and loaded dump trucks in front of entrances at Oyster Creek are just some of the visible signs of the security changes. "Everything that can be done is being done," said Capt. William A. Nally, deputy coordinator of emergency management for Lacey Township, which includes Forked River.
Many people here seem content to leave the worrying to someone else. Even those who stopped by Manchester High for potassium iodide pills seemed to do so more out of curiosity than concern.
Carole Lake, 55, a software saleswoman from Bayville, a town that was evacuated last month because of a fire in the pinelands that ravaged 1,300 acres, said the blaze was a reminder that some preparations can be pointless. "I have plenty of bottled water and an evacuation route, if necessary," she said, "but it'll be useless if we all get vaporized anyway."

HEADLINE: June Industrial Production Rose; Gain of 0.8% Beat Expectations 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve reported today that production at factories, mines and utilities increased in June for a sixth consecutive month, jumping by 0.8 percent, the largest monthly increase since October 1999. The report on industrial production showed a stronger performance than the 0.5 percent many analysts had been expecting. 
 The output of automobiles and parts, home electronics and computers, and office equipment rose. Declines were reported in appliances, furniture and carpeting. 
 "Manufacturing activity is gaining momentum," said Stan Shipley, senior economist with Merrill Lynch.
Industrial production in May was revised slightly higher, to 0.4 percent compared with the 0.3 percent advance the Fed estimated a month ago.
Factories alone rose 0.7 percent in June. Output at mines expanded 1.1 percent, and production by utilities increased 1.6 percent.
"The growth was widespread across manufacturing industries since 17 of the 20 major industries within the manufacturing sector experienced growth in June," said Daniel J. Meckstroth, chief economist at the Manufacturers Alliance/MAPI.
Also encouraging, Mr. Meckstroth said, was an increase in business capital equipment and a 0.6 percent gain in communications equipment, an industry that had been shrinking.
The Fed said capacity utilization rose sharply, to 76.1 percent from 75.6 percent in May, a sign factories were using more resources to increase production.
The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, testified to the Senate Banking Committee today that the economy was "poised to resume a pattern of sustainable growth," but had been hampered by uncertainty over the revival of profitability, fears of terrorism, and the recent corporate scandals and resulting lack of investor confidence.
Some economists worry that higher unemployment, the wave of scandals and the sour stock market might dampen the willingness of consumers to spend and businesses to invest, which would slow the economic recovery.

HEADLINE: Arafat's Role Is in Dispute During Talks in New York 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

 BODY:
The administration and its major Middle East mediating partners agreed yesterday on the broad goal of creating a Palestinian state within three years, but differed sharply on almost everything else, including the future role of Yasir Arafat and the correct degree of emphasis on security as a condition for resuming peace talks with Israel.
 In a daylong series of meetings in New York, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and top envoys from the United Nations, the European Union and Russia discussed how to create fresh momentum for political talks in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The group, which styles itself the Quartet, said in a statement that it remained committed to "promote a just, comprehensive and lasting settlement." 
 But even in public comments intended to be upbeat, the diplomats could not avoid revealing differences over specifics. 
Speaking just hours after the latest bomb attack in Israel, Secretary Powell made his strongest acknowledgment yet that the administration had abandoned its brief springtime effort to jumpstart political talks while working to provide economic assistance to Palestinians and crack down on terrorism.
"I wish they could all move in parallel," Secretary Powell said at a news conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in midtown Manhattan. "But until we get a better handle on the security aspect of it, and until we get a little more movement on the humanitarian side of it, they will be parallel, but they will not exactly be in synchronization with one another."
But a different view came from the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, who while acknowledging the need for better security said there would have to be swift progress on the other fronts or terrorism would continue. "Even if the security track gains some traction, unless we show some progress on the other tracks, that would not work, that would also fail," Mr. Annan said. 
Except when pressed by reporters, the officials seemed to go out of their way to avoid discussing Mr. Arafat's future role. Parrying the question yesterday, Secretary Powell said, "Most of our time was spent on real, concrete things, and we did not spend a great deal of time on personalities."
But in an interview with the ABC News program "Nightline" on Monday, he said under repeated questioning that he would be "more than willing to consider" an arrangement in which Mr. Arafat remained as a kind of figurehead leader in a Palestinian government with a different prime minister who exerted day-to-day control. 
Mr. Annan -- along with Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov of Russia and Javier Solana, the European Union's national security chief -- said Mr. Arafat was still regarded as the legitimate Palestinian leader.
"It is only for the Palestinians to decide who they want to have as their leaders," Mr. Ivanov said. "It is the sovereign right of the Palestinian people. As for Chairman Arafat, he is the legitimately elected leader of Palestine and while he is in this capacity we will continue to maintain our relations with him."
As for when Israel should begin easing its occupation of the West Bank, none of the officials gave a time frame; but in the group statement, they said it should do so "as security improves through reciprocal steps."
Secretary Powell also said Washington was close to presenting specific new ideas for security cooperation between Israel and a restructured Palestinian security force, and Mr. Solana said he expected that an American-led delegation would go to the region within two weeks to begin work on such an effort, probably with Arab assistance. 
Secretary Powell also met separately yesterday with the foreign ministers of Egypt and Jordan, who then met with the other officials at Mr. Annan's East Side town house last night. Together with the Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, the Arab ministers are to go to Washington on Thursday for further talks with Secretary Powell and with President Bush at the White House.
After his meeting with Secretary Powell yesterday, Foreign Minister Marwan Muasher of Jordan said that although he and his Arab colleagues remained committed to working out specific benchmarks and a "work plan" that would lead to Palestinian statehood within three years, devising the specifics would take more time. "I think it's too optimistic to get it today," he said, "but I think all the parties are committed." 
In fact, senior American officials said, much quiet work is under way among Europeans, Arabs, international institutions like the World Bank and the Palestinians themselves on how to restructure Palestinian security forces and civilian society, and how to provide economic and relief assistance to a Palestinian population facing crisis conditions in the West Bank and Gaza.
"We obviously do have tactical differences" over how to handle Mr. Arafat, which occupied "two or three minutes" of discussion yesterday, one senior administration official said. "But again, what was striking was the degree of strategic agreement" on the need for Palestinian reform, increased security and relief assistance.
Secretary Powell said there had been discussion of how best to provide financial aid. The United States is urging its allies to contribute through international relief organizations, instead of directly to the Palestinian Authority.
Israel has said that European Union money provided directly to the authority has effectively been siphoned off to support terrorism, but Mr. Solana took umbrage at that notion yesterday, saying briskly, "I want to tell you that the donors community's resources that go to the Palestinian Authority, including the European Union, has more controls than any other donors community contributed to any other country in the world."
Mr. Annan said Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel had called him before the meeting yesterday to advocate a "worldwide humanitarian operation to alleviate the plight of the Palestinian people."
"Of course we shall have to find out more details about that," Mr. Annan added, "but meanwhile the Quartet agreed that full humanitarian access would be the fastest way to begin improving the plight of the Palestinians." 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 19, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about talks in New York on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict misstated the title of Javier Solana, a European Union official who took part. He is the high representative for common foreign and security policy, not the national security chief. The article also misidentified the location of a bombing attack on a bus that coincided with the talks. It was near the Immanuel settlement in the West Bank, not inside Israel's pre-1967 borders.

HEADLINE: In Westchester, a New High School Builds on Diversity 

BYLINE:  By MERRI ROSENBERG

DATELINE: PURCHASE, N.Y. 

 BODY:
Under most circumstances, David Distant and David Gallagher probably would never have met each other.
 Last fall, David Distant was a freshman at Woodlands High School in Greenburgh in central Westchester County. David Gallagher was a freshman at Harrison High School in a mostly white and more affluent community on the eastern side of the county. 
 This winter, though, the two Davids became classmates. They are members of the first class of the Westchester Magnet Academy, an experiment started in late January on the Purchase College campus here that brings together some 55 students from three quite different school districts -- Greenburgh, Harrison and Irvington -- for the express purpose of creating a more diverse school. The program's first group has 25 black students, all from Greenburgh, and 19 white students, 4 Hispanic, one Asian and 6 who classify themselves as multiracial. 
Created in collaboration with Purchase College of the State University of New York, the magnet school was set up to address an issue that few people in Westchester speak about but everyone tacitly understands. As a hodgepodge of more than 40 cities, towns and villages, most with a distinct economic profile, Westchester provides relatively few opportunities for racial and economic integration in its schools. School systems are either overwhelmingly white or overwhelmingly black and Hispanic, with only a few schools like New Rochelle and White Plains High Schools providing genuine opportunities for mingling.
"Some of the kids from the other schools hadn't seen so many African-Americans before," said Melva Lloyd, who, like David Distant, came from the Greenburgh Central 7 district. 
The school, which received a $2 million three-year grant from the United States Department of Education, is neither an academically selective school like Stuyvesant, the entrance-exam-driven high school in New York City, nor an alternative school for troubled students. And the mix of schools participating in the program makes for somewhat unlikely bedfellows. Harrison is a place where millionaires live behind gates and working-class residents dwell in modest homes on small lots or in apartment buildings. Irvington, a village nestled on the Hudson River, is predominantly wealthy and white. And Greenburgh has an economically diverse black population, along with a substantial number of whites, who live primarily in the hamlet of Hartsdale.
"There are lots of suburban communities that are in decent shape, and attract large numbers of black and Latino students," said Gary Orfield, a professor of education and social policy at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. "Then whites move out, and they become minority schools, and lose that diversity of community. There's far too little cooperation among suburbs to address the issue of integration." 
Partly because the school has not yet completed a full academic year -- the first semester ended last month -- and partly because the school is so small, the outcome of Westchester's experiment is still uncertain.
While the concept has been embraced enthusiastically in Greenburgh and Harrison, the decidedly lukewarm response in Irvington suggests that the program is less attractive to students and parents in that wealthy community.
Consider the selection process at each school. In Greenburgh, where there were 75 applicants for that district's allocation of 30 slots, the district assigned placement by lottery, a procedure it is using for next year's class as well. A similar process is being used in Harrison, where 37 students have applied for the 15 slots allocated to that district for next year. By contrast, Irvington so far has 11 prospects for its 15 slots in next year's freshman class. This year's 10 students were recommended by the high school guidance counselors or school psychologist.
After only a semester in operation, it is also too soon to tell if the Magnet Academy's ideal of racial amity will take root. 
"There hasn't been complete intermingling, but there hasn't been overt tension," said Bill Gladstone, the social studies teacher. "It's not the same integration model that used to exist. These things shouldn't matter. The point is to give as many kids as possible a different educational opportunity." 
Still, the Magnet Academy's supporters remain optimistic about the program. "People are opting to come back into the public schools because of the magnet," said Miriam Bernabei, director of arts, music and special projects in the Greenburgh Central 7 district. "One of our goals was to give the option within the public schools, to get people back. At Greenburgh, it's a choice, not an 'alternative' for troubled kids." 
That is certainly the appeal for Felicia Walker, a parent in the Greenburgh Central 7 district who hopes that her son, who just completed the eighth grade at a local parochial school, will be able to attend the magnet program in September. 
"I didn't want my son to hang out with the wrong group of kids," said Mrs. Walker, a graduate of Woodlands High School whose older children also attended there. "At the Magnet Academy, it's much smaller, and there's more discipline. When he went for the day to shadow another student, he came home and said: 'Mom, I really love it. The work looks really hard, but there are so many different types of kids, and no one was fighting with anybody.' I'm not letting him go to Woodlands. I think the magnet is part of how the district keeps people." 
What seems to have drawn most of the students was the prospect of smaller classes and a more intimate academic setting. For the Greenburgh students particularly, the Magnet Academy is seen as a surer path to further education than their previous high school. "This is a better school if I want to go to college and get a scholarship," David Distant said. "This will make it a lot easier."
Students spoke about the pleasures of wandering around the sprawling SUNY Purchase campus, being liberated from the restrictions of a single high school building, and having the chance to pursue theater and music classes after school with SUNY professors as well as pursue weekly Outward Bound-type experiences with Magnet Academy instructors. 
And even though the curriculum follows the Regents requirements, the Magnet Academy structures the classes in blocks of an hour and fifteen minutes, giving students more time to work on English, earth science, biology, math and global studies. Each day, students spend a half hour meeting with their advisers and writing compositions, with Fridays dedicated to laboratory work and field experiences like participating in an archaeological dig. In a 14-student English class recently, nearly all students participated in the intense debate and discussion about slavery, the meaning of mixed race, and the Haitian exodus from political repression in Edwige Danticat's story collection, "Krik? Krak!" During a biology class, the students sat around a seminar table and followed on laptop computers as their teacher led them through a detailed explanation of how to analyze DNA strands. 
Getting to know other teenagers, beyond the limited social confines of their home districts, was another lure. Many of the students have attended their districts' relatively small high schools where they have known the same students since preschool days. The current ninth-grade classes number about 235 students in Harrison, 115 in Irvington, and about 110 at Woodlands.
"I wanted to meet new people," said Jennifer Tassler, who came from Woodlands.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Omar Senior, left, seated at table, and Trent Miller, opposite him, are members of the first class at the Westchester Magnet Academy at SUNY Purchase. The school takes students from diverse backgrounds and works with them in small classes. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
There's something to celebrate for the cable TV networks as preseason ad sales beat expectations.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
IN another indication that the advertising economy is turning upward after its long recession, cable television networks are taking in more advertising dollars ahead of the 2002-03 season than had been expected even a month ago.
 Though the preseason negotiations between the cable networks and advertisers -- known as the upfront market -- are still unfinished, industry analysts are now estimating that when the dickering is done in the next week or two the final total of purchased commercial time could reach as much as $4.8 billion. That would represent an increase of 20 percent from the $4 billion sold in the depressed cable upfront market of last year. And it would tie the record set before the start of the 2000-01 season. 
 The more robust demand for commercial time on cable networks, from marketers seeking to peddle wares including cars, movies and mortgage loans, represents a trifecta for the television industry. The broadcast TV networks set a sales record in their upfront market, which concluded last month, at more than $8 billion, compared with about $7 billion for 2001-02. And the demand for commercial time in syndicated series also exceeded recent forecasts, totaling an estimated $2 billion.
Although the cable upfront market proceeded more slowly than had been expected, and the rising tide is not lifting all the boats, the anticipated end result is being welcomed by the industry.
"We're certainly above last year, which wasn't too difficult to achieve, and an increase of 20 percent is a real possibility," said Joseph W. Ostrow, president and chief executive at the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau in New York.
"The ratings story" is a big reason for the increased demand, he added. In June, for the first time, cable networks carrying commercials -- that is, excluding premium-priced movie channels like HBO and Showtime -- were watched by more than 50 percent of American households in prime time.
High ratings for original movies and series like Sunday's William H. Macy film "Door to Door" on TNT helped fuel increased ad sales there and at TBS, said Mark Lazarus, president for Turner Entertainment sales and marketing in Atlanta and New York, part of AOL Time Warner. The gains, he said, came in categories like fast-food restaurants, films and telecommunications.
"It's pleasantly surprising," he added, "but logical."
Rival general entertainment channels like FX also benefited from advertiser ardor.
"Advertisers moved a little more cautiously in cable after the speed and strength of the broadcast upfront and the syndicated upfront, but we are in double-digit volume gains," said Bruce Lefkowitz, executive vice president for entertainment advertising sales at the Fox Cable Networks Group in New York, part of the News Corporation, who handles ad sales for FX as well as the National Geographic Channel.
Marketers are buying commercial time during "The Shield," Mr. Lefkowitz said, a series on FX that some advertisers shunned during the 2001-02 season because of its frank content, as well as during "Lucky," a dark sitcom to be introduced by FX in the second quarter of 2003.
A Fox sibling, Fox News Channel, is also reporting strong gains.
"I keep knocking wood because I've done this for a while, but we're about 80 percent done and our dollar volume has almost doubled," said Paul Rittenberg, senior vice president for advertising sales at Fox News in New York.
Among the ad categories contributing to the gains, Mr. Rittenberg listed automobiles and financial services.
"They're still a little nervous," Mr. Rittenberg said of the brokerage firms and mutual funds, "but they do a lot of spending not because the market is good but to say 'You can trust us.' "
Greg D'Alba, a counterpart to Mr. Rittenberg at CNN, the AOL Time Warner cable news network, said that he was seeing gains in "our blue-chip business" like automobiles and financial services, including banks and mortgage lenders, along with computer hardware and telecommunications.
Some companies have cut back ad spending, said Mr. D'Alba, who is executive vice president for sales at CNN in New York, but those losses are being compensated by increased budgets from other advertisers.
Other cable networks that are selling commercial time beyond projected levels, in addition to the general entertainment and news channels, are niche networks that are aimed at more specialized audiences. Those include MTV and VH1, part of Viacom; Comedy Central, owned by Viacom and AOL Time Warner; and the Food Network and HGTV, owned by E. W. Scripps.
"The targeted networks are enjoying high-single-digit and double-digit volume increases," said Joe Mandese, editor of Media Buyer's Daily in New York, a newsletter published by Primedia.
Some networks did well by lowering their rates and gaining market share, agency executives said. They included Lifetime, owned by the Walt Disney Company and the Hearst Corporation, and USA Network, part of Vivendi Universal. Networks that lagged their peers, the executives said, included A&E, owned by Disney, Hearst and General Electric; and Discovery Channel, part of Discovery Communications.
For all the growth in demand for commercials on cable, questions loom for the coming season. The major one is also being asked of the broadcast networks: How much of the sales increase is attributable to more money coming into the market and how much is just being shifted from the money spent during the season, in what is known as the scatter market?
"It's too soon to tell," said Mr. Lefkowitz of Fox Cable. "Some advertisers moved their scatter dollars into the upfront, but that's not to say they also weren't putting more into the upfront, too."
"And as the season goes on and the economy picks up," he added, "we should get advertisers that didn't commit at all in the upfront."

HEADLINE: Facing New Costs, Some Smokers Say 'Enough' 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 12 

 BODY:
Michael Krygowski curses his shortness of breath while coaching his 10- year-old son's baseball team. He dreads dying before his three children finish college. And the 40-cent tax rise that took effect July 1 brings his two packs of Marlboro Lights to $8.70 a day -- $269.70 this month. 
 "That's a pretty big car payment," Mr. Krygowski, 39, who lives in Hirscher, Ill., lamented during a call to a smokers' "quit line" today. "I am just sick of smoking. I'm tired of the way I feel. 
 "I wanted to quit even before the price went up," he added. "The cost just kind of sealed the deal." 
So it has been for scores of smokers who have flooded the telephone lines here since Illinois raised its tax to 98 cents a pack. Calls to the quit line, which is financed through the state's share of the settlement reached with tobacco manufacturers and run by the American Lung Association, have spiked along with the tax, to an average 155 a day, from 100. On Tuesday, it was 205.
Illinois is among 16 states that have raised tobacco taxes this year, as budget deficits have collided with an election-year aversion to broader tax increases.
The per-pack increases are the largest and most widespread since the states began taxing tobacco in the 1920's, from Tennessee's rise of 7 cents a pack to New Jersey's jump of 70 cents. Smokers in New York City were hit twice: not only did the state raise its per-pack tax by 39 cents, but packs sold within city limits faced an additional city tax increase of $1.42. The federal government, which now charges 39 cents a pack, initiated such levies in 1794.
Economic studies have suggested that a price increase of 10 percent reduces smoking about 4 percent. It is too early to track significant shifts in behavior, but this could be the busiest season yet for the business of quitting.
Sales of nicotine patches and gum on the drugstore.com Web site were up 43 percent the second week in July compared with sales in the second week in June. In New Jersey, where the per-pack tax is now $1.50, QuitNet.com, an online cessation program, has registered 272 residents so far this month, compared to 300 in all of June.
"Everybody's like, 'Yeah, I've got to quit smoking now,' " said Bill Scheer, president of the New York City Pharmacists' Society, who has filled a dozen Medicaid prescriptions for nicotine patches and gum in the past two weeks, up from three in June, at Scheer Drugs in Flushing, Queens. "It's implied -- but not said -- that this is the reason: because cigs have gone up. I think it's the breaking point."
In previous years, a dozen states might introduce tobacco taxes, but only a handful would enact them. Lee Dixon, director of the health policy tracking service at the National Conference of State Legislatures, explained this year's rush in two words: budget shortfalls. All together, the 16 states expect to raise $2.2 billion this year.
Despite their deficits, only a few states raised overall sales taxes this spring; 19 states considered raising alcohol taxes, but only Tennessee did so. Mr. Dixon said that cigarette taxes were more popular among lawmakers, in part, he said, because of "the push from the public health advocates and the antitobacco groups who see it as an issue that will help cut tobacco use."
Indeed, Connecticut's smoking cessation hotline experienced a 50 percent surge in calls since the state's per-pack tax rose 69 cents, to $1.10, in April; New York's quit line has received 12 percent more calls than usual just this month.
Here in Springfield, in a hive of plain-gray cubicles at a building on the west end of town, the tax rise has translated into 30, 40 or 50 voice-mail messages each morning.
"I just keep hitting the button," sighed Carol Ramm, a respiratory therapist, as she hung up on one smoker and greeted another. "They start out and say 'it's because of my health.' But the big reason is the tax."
Counselors here spend 10 to 15 minutes on each call and encourage quitters to check in at least once a week, as with a parole officer. 
Raymond Buckner, a deputy sheriff in Cook County, said he had called the quit line 26 times since Nov. 13, 2000. When he sees the "Killing Me Softly" billboards with the quit line's telephone number, 866-QUIT-YES, it is "almost like I am being watched" by the voices he now knows so well, Mr. Buckner said when he called this afternoon.
Trained at the Mayo Clinic, the counselors, who are former smokers themselves, urge people to try a combination of Zyban or Wellbutrin -- anti-depressants that spur a brain response similar to the one stimulated by nicotine -- and nicotine patches in decreasing strengths, to wean themselves off cigarettes in about 12 weeks.
At the same time, trainers caution the quitting smokers that they must reprogram themselves to drink orange juice when they wake rather than light up, for instance, or take a walk after meals to avoid reaching for the ashtray, chew toothpicks instead of smoking in the car.
"You've got to deal with your stress in a way other than reaching for a cigarette -- that's just like a pacifier, James," Sarah Skeadas, 23, told a caller in his early 50's who suffers from emphysema.
"I quit every day," he responded. "I've quit at least a thousand times, I always go back to it because I say 'well, James, you ain't got that much going for you, you might as well smoke.' "
Ms. Skeadas's voice softened. "It's not that bleak, honey," she said, promising to call him the next morning. "I can tell you're having a hard time breathing just talking to me. It doesn't have to be that way."
In the next cubicle, Priscilla Matli stood and stared out a window, telephone headset in place, as she soothed a woman whose husband had lung cancer yet smoked through chemotherapy. 
Ms. Ramm told Marvin, a pack-a- day smoker, to get out his calendar and mark Saturday and Sunday 19, Monday and Tuesday 18, tapering his daily cigarette intake to 15 before starting the patch so he would not experience withdrawal.
And Michael Mark, the nurse who runs the quit line, spoke with Mr. Krygowski, who was recently laid off from a marketing job in which he stood outside gas stations, dispensing coupons for free cigarettes.
"There will come a point in time where you will say, 'Well, I've done real good, I can have one,' " Mr. Mark warned. "No. If you have one, you're back to 40 again."

HEADLINE: Gray Outlook From Intel; Bluer Skies AtMotorola 

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Intel, the world's largest microchip manufacturer, said yesterday that it had encountered few signs of economic recovery in the second quarter and that it expected weaker than normal seasonal improvement in demand the rest of the year.
 As a result, Intel said, it plans cost-cutting measures, including a cut in capital spending and the elimination of about 4,000 jobs, almost 5 percent of its work force. It has cut about 5,000 jobs in the last year. 
 "We have yet to see momentum from the economic recovery," said Andrew Bryant, Intel's chief financial officer. 
In another sign of weakness for the technology sector in the second half of 2002, Apple Computer said that its sales and revenues slumped in the recent quarter and that earnings in the current quarter could be well below Wall Street's expectations. But another bellwether technology company, Motorola, which makes a broader array of microchips than does Intel and is among the world's largest cellular communications companies, said that it had returned to operating profitability in the quarter, ahead of forecasts, and that its markets were slowly improving.
All three companies announced their results after stock markets had closed. In after-hours trading as reported by Instinet, Apple fell; Intel recovered a small portion of its 3.9 percent decline, to $18.36 during regular trading; and Motorola, which had risen 5 percent, to $14.53 in regular trading, rose as high as $14.75. 
Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said that it earned $446 million, or 7 cents a diluted share, in the quarter, up 133 percent from the 3 cents a share, or $196 million, it reported in the second quarter of 2001. But earnings were down more than 50 percent from the first three months of this year.
In addition, stripped of one-time charges related to how it accounts for acquisitions, Intel's operating income for the quarter actually fell 27 percent from a year ago. More important to many analysts, Intel's revenue for the quarter, of $6.32 billion, was slightly less than the $6.33 billion reported a year ago, as well as 7 percent lower than in the first quarter.
The second quarter is historically a weak one for personal and desktop computers, which account for 80 percent of Intel's business, but the decline this year was among the worst in recent years. Intel said that the current quarter, which normally produces a rebound fueled by back-to-school sales, might be flat and would at best result in an improvement of 9 percent. Intel typically expects 3 percent to 14 percent growth for the quarter.
Intel's performance would have been worse had the company not managed to gain market share in all of its businesses, according to Craig R. Barrett, Intel's chief executive. The company cited emerging markets, sales of flash-memory chips and continued consumer demand as bright spots. But Intel said that businesses remained reluctant to invest in new information technology equipment.
Investors' expectations were reined in on June 6 when Intel told Wall Street that revenues could end up anywhere from $6.2 billion to $6.5 billion, down from its forecast of $6.4 billion to $7 billion in April. At that time, Intel had warned that it was encountering weaker than expected European sales and a decline in gross margins from 53 percent to 49 percent. Its actual margins ended up slightly lower, one reason that earnings per share ended up 2 cents below the consensus estimate of analysts tracked by Thomson First Call.
Intel's net loss included a $106 million charge resulting from the company's decision, announced last month, to end its three-year, money-losing venture as a host of Internet sites. Shedding marginal operations and attrition will permit Intel to cut its work force with few layoffs, if any, in its core businesses, analysts said.
"They are really focusing on the stuff that matters," said Mark Margevicius, an analyst at Gartner.
Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., said that its net loss jumped to $2.32 billion, or $1.02 a diluted share, from $759 million a year ago. But that figure included $2.37 billion to cover one-time costs like cutting 7,000 jobs, writing down factories it closed and potential losses from a loan to a Turkish cellphone company. Excluding such costs, Motorola earned $48 million, or 2 cents a share, beating forecasts by 6 cents.
The news was good only compared with what investors had come to expect from the company the last two years. Revenue declined 10 percent from a year ago, to $6.74 billion, the smallest decline in the last six quarters. Sales in the cellular phone unit, its largest business, climbed 5 percent, to $2.6 billion, and Motorola forecast further growth the next two quarters.
In addition, Motorola continued to clean up a balance sheet that was formerly so debt laden that its investment and strategic options had been severely limited. It increased its cash and cash equivalents $500 million, to $6.5 billion.

HEADLINE: VISIONS OF GROUND ZERO: THE OVERVIEW; 
Six Plans for Ground Zero, All Seen as a Starting Point

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
On the day that six proposals for the redevelopment of the World Trade Center site were unveiled, the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said yesterday that the public could consider a seventh possibility, a new design without some of the requirements for office and retail space that shaped the initial proposals. 
 The chairman, John C. Whitehead, characterized the six designs as simply a starting point, a means for Americans to demonstrate their resilience and determination after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. 
 If the current proposals do not create "the kind of beautiful center that we want this to be, then we will change our plans," Mr. Whitehead said at one of a series of briefings at Federal Hall, the landmark on the Wall Street site where George Washington was first inaugurated as president.
His suggestion that the six plans were not at all the only approaches that could be considered seemed to be prompted by the disappointment of many people who had reviewed them. Those critics said the plans seemed driven more by the desires of developers and businessmen than by concerns about what was best for Lower Manhattan. Some objected that the designs would make the site too dense and crowded, and others felt they did not offer enough variety. 
Mr. Whitehead asked for "the ongoing input, feedback and recommendations of citizens here and throughout the country" about the plans. 
All of them call for a memorial, for office and retail space, and for a new transportation complex to be built on the site, but they varied widely in their details. The proposals for memorials varied in size from 5 to 10 acres, some including the footprints of the twin towers and others favoring an elegant promenade leading away from the building site. 
Each plan contained several office towers, responding to the requirement by the development corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the owner of the 16-acre site, that the designs replace all of the commercial and retail space that was destroyed on Sept. 11. 
Although Mr. Whitehead said he believed the six plans adequately achieved those goals, he added, in response to a question after the presentation, that the plans could be significantly altered if the public strongly favored that.
The suggestion met with hopeful surprise among some of the civic leaders, architects and family members of trade center victims who attended the presentation. 
"I thought it was very heartening," said Fredric Bell, the executive director of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects. "There are more options that need to be drawn, and different options that need to be considered."
Many of those people who had already reacted negatively to the plans said they packed too much office space on too small a site. Several of the civic groups monitoring the process had also objected that the brief time in which the plans were produced did not allow consideration of their affect on the area's economy and traffic patterns, among other factors.
Margaret Helfand, an urban planner who is co-chairwoman of the executive committee of New York New Visions, a civic group that has offered ideas and designs for the redevelopment of downtown, said the designs did not meet the spirit of the design principles outlined by the development corporation in April.
"That called for a vibrant, mixed-use community," Ms. Helfand said. "What we got was what was there before, packaged differently." 
Several people involved in the planning process said that they had not heard until about a month ago that the designs would have to replace all 11 million square feet of office space in the trade center and that the available retail space would be increased to 600,000 square feet from about 450,000. In addition, the planners were directed to include space for a hotel to replace the one that formerly stood on the site with the twin towers.
"These plans are all driven by hard economics," said Beverly Willis, an architect and the co-founder of Rebuild Downtown Our Town, a civic group. "There's no heart in them and no recognition of what we all had been led to believe would occur, that we would wind up with something wonderful on this site."
Kent Barwick, the president of the Municipal Art Society, a planning organization that organized a series of public forums to discuss the future of the site, said the office and retail constraints "diminished the prospects" for the designs.
"There hasn't been time for the analytical work that generally precedes that kind of site planning," Mr. Barwick said. "The next phase needs to be to go back and do the analytical work necessary and determine what this part of town can and should support in terms of office space and retail space."
Steven K. Peterson, whose firm, Peterson Littenberg Architects, worked on the designs, said the planners always considered them to be a first step.
"We knew we couldn't solve every problem at once," he said, "but we first had to prove that there are many ways to do what had to be done under the current restrictions. It's easy to then reduce the program if the economic or political considerations call for it."
Officials from the Port Authority and the development corporation also said that from the first, they had intended to consider everything that might be done on the site, then to scale back those plans. 
"This was the opening offer," one government official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity, "but this was not the time to amend those restrictions." 
City and state officials were also unanimous in characterizing the plans presented yesterday as "a starting point." 
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that what the planners have done so far was simply "to take a concept and give you some variations on it to get you to think, to realize that we shouldn't be tied into any one thing." 
Gov. George E. Pataki, who appointed Mr. Whitehead as chairman of the development corporation to lead the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, said he expected New Yorkers, who "are not inherently shy," to offer their most creative ideas.
Federal Hall was a building under heavy security, a reflection of the continuing concern about possible terrorist acts directed at anything associated with the World Trade Center. Armed federal agents were in evidence, bomb sweeps were conducted with dogs, and bags were searched when people entered. 
Now that the initial designs have been presented for public comment, discussions about amending the restrictions that limited them can be considered, Mr. Whitehead said. 
"We have looked carefully to see whether it is possible to preserve those private-sector rights that those two groups had and still rebuild this as a beautiful place and a place of which we are proud," Mr. Whitehead said, referring to the lease agreements that Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who holds the commercial rights to the trade center site, and Westfield America, which holds the retail right, have with the Port Authority.
"So far, we believe that it is possible to do that," he said. "If we conclude differently, that it is not possible to rebuild and still meet those requirements and have the kind of beautiful center that we want this to be, then we will change our plans."
Nikki Stern, who attended the presentation yesterday and whose husband, James E. Potorti, was killed in the Sept. 11 attack, said Mr. Whitehead's comment "surprised me and gratified me."
"There are a lot of fine things in the plans," Ms. Stern said. "But they were created using givens that may have to be changed. This process is all about the art of compromise, and we want to make sure that all the parties are practicing compromise, including the developers."
